column2: Refusing to yield against the challenge of a presumed stronger rival, Mrs. Adele Rand's Traffic Cop won the $27,150 Roseben Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

TRENTON, N. J.-In an effort to keep ahead of increasing land development and highway construction, New Jersey is stepping up its landmarks-preservation program and in the process outdistancing its northern neighbor, New York State.
Federal guard points outside this occupied village were suddenly pulled back this afternoon, and armored personnel carriers loaded on flatbed trucks rumbled back toward Pine Ridge, 15 miles away.

In a challenge to the leadership of Alex Rose, a dissident faction of the Liberal party held a convention of its own yesterday and approved its own slate of candidates for Mayor, Controller and City Council President.
Miss Linda Jean Zimmer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Basil G. Zimmer of Rumford, and William Christopher Walsh plan to be married here Aug. 18 in St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church.
Lou Andreas-Salome was a woman famous for the men she knew. The formidable roster of her acquaintances included most of the Central European luminaries of her generation (she was born in 1861),

Mr. and Mrs. Ira Katz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Katz, to Stephen Lawrence Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Roth of Forest Hills, Queens, and Pattenburg, N.J. The couple plan to marry in December.
NEWARK -The Newark. customs area was officially credited with less than 10 per cent of the New York region's customs collections in 1972, even though it actually garnered far more.
Brazilians are beginning to realize there is a bottom to their vast natural resources and are trying to curb their own prodigality.

SAN FRANCISCO -- For many years now, foreign countries have eagerly sought capital investments by United States industrial corporations. Countries like Northern Ireland, the Dominican Republic and Nigeria have extolled. their attractions in countless newspaper advertising supplements.

To the Editor. Should even so poor a book as Donald Weeks's "Corvo" fall into the hands or so slovenly and irresponsible a reviewer as Philippe Jullian? Herewith a partial list of his errors and absurdities.
Drinking water was still being boiled in this resort city today but officials said that a water contamination problem should be solved by Monday.

Miss Lucy Stephens Lyden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lyden, was married here this afternoon to Robert Stephen Anderson, son of Mrs. Nils A. C. Anderson of West Hartford and the late Dr. Anderson.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Spalding Coleman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Norton Coleman, to Polk Laffoon 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Polk Laffoon 3d of Cincinnati. An April 14 wedding is planned.

To save the city's oncethriving brewing industry from extinction; City Couincilmen Matthew J. Troy Jr. of Queens and Fred Richmond of Brooklyn have prepared legislation .that: is aimed at discouraging the drinking of out-of-town beers.

Maybe now, with the disclosure of the arrangement between two left-handed pitchers on the New York Yankees and their wives, moralists finally will have learned not to be outraged whenever a professional athlete surrenders to human nature.

During the jagged stock market decline of recent months, many people missed a good bet. They might have profited handsomely by selling stocks short, rather than buying stocks or resting -with their portfolios immobile.

One day last week, Fred Pomerantz, the 72-year-old chairman of Leslie Fay, Inc., and his son John, 39, the company's president, were discussing how they manage one of the most prominent sportswear and dress companies on Seventh Avenue.

To the Financial Editor: In the Feb. 25 article on the new president of Bell Laboratories, Dr. William O. Baker, he is quoted as having said: "For all the gorgeous glory of a Rembrandt, nobody has ever eaten one."

When John Matuszak enters a room, he fills it. If he is not the biggest rookie to be performing in the National Football League next season, he will be so close to it that no one ever will be able to notice the difference.

March rain can be as miserable as any rain that falls, but it is better than March snow, which has to be plowed and shoveled. It seems wetter and colder than any rain should feel; but that probably is because by now our weather nerves are right up at the surface. We want spring fever, not the shivers.
The Vietcong today called off scheduled Vietnamese prisoner exchanges, charging that Government forces had attacked one of the two turnover points and occupied it.
The Soviet Union disclosed this week that West Germany, in a surge of selling fostered by improved political relations, had become Russia's principal trade partner, moving ahead of Japan.
A Harlem man was arrested yesterday and charged with the kidnapping and sexual abuse of a 12-year-old boy. The victim told the police that his screams for help had been ignored by passers-by.

President Pompidou told French voters in a television address yesterday that they would be making a simple choice in today's final Assembly elections between "Marxist Communism and its assured allies, and all the others."
Drinking water was still being boiled in this resort city today but officials said that a water contamination problem should be solved by Monday.

ONE of the most financially successful films of the last two years is a drama called "Billy Jack," a passionately muddle-minded contemporary Western about a half-breed Indian named Billy Jack and the members of the "freedom school" he protects from small-town bigots who hate pacifists, pot smokers and long-haired weirdos.
" PAYDAY" is a briliant, nasty little chrome-plated razor blade of a movie superficially about the last 36 hours in the life of country-western singer.

THEY say we can't go home again. Home to youth, innocence, idealism, romance. Yet all of us try, never acknowledging that the world we have left behind may have changed one way, and we another. Home is Massachusetts' North Shore. It begins for me With the suburban beaches 10 miles north of Boston. Lynn.
Miss Marianna Frances Kelley plans to be married here in May to Kevin E. Sullivan, who is with the investment management division of the Chemical Bank in New York.
Next winter's gas supply in the metropolitan area may be critically short as a direct result of last month's explosion of a liquefied, natural gas tank on Staten Island.
The State Insurance Department will soon ask the Legislature to extend for another four years an experimental "open-rating" system in which insurance companies set their own premium rates.

Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said today that the Government would not how to threats by militant Indians but would "continue to provide a ladder of Federal programs and opportunities on which the Indian can climb out of the bottom of the social barrel."

The United States made another gesture of cooperation today to try to improve the international monetary climate as Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz briefed the French Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, on the Administration's trade bill.

EAST BRUNSWICK-Eight years ago, Rose Sakel began a fight to save a 1,700-acre tract of land for a Middlesex County Park. She fought a tenacious, quiet battle to preserve the land, which lies in East Brunswick, Monroe, Spotswood and Helmetta. Her weapons were gentle persuasion, reason, and sometimes, feminine wiles.
Can a man write a book that explains the goals, visions, history and problems of the women's - liberation movement with sympathy, understanding and insight? Gene Marine,
Horace Silver, one of the jazz powers of the nineteenfifties who went into semi-retirement in the sixties, is back in action again at the Half Note with a quintet patterned on his groups of the past

Auto theft is decreasing across the country. Statistics for 1972 that will be released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation later this month will show what law enforcement officers say is the first one-year decline in car thefts in United States history.
The South Vietnamese Government compromised with foreign newsmen today and agreed to expand press representation at a meeting next week with Communist peace-keeping delegates.

MICHAEL KAHN is on his way to becoming the most enduring artistic director of the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn. No mean achievement, considering the previous mortality rate for artistic directors on the banks of the Housatonic or, for that matter, the life expectancy of artistic directors in general.
Three shots were fired last night at a police radio car on patrol in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, and a 32year-old man was arrested after a struggle.

BELFAST-The balloting in Northern Ireland last week was less spectacular than the bombings in Belfast, less headline-grabbing than the bombings in London. But it was Just as much a part of the Irish war, and about as futile.
William Surtees, the defending champion, and Howard Angus, both of London, reached the final round of the United States amateur racquets championship today at the Boston Racquets and Tennis Club.

The consensus in the Vatican is that the "Pauline line" has been considerably strengthened, this week as Pope Paul VI installed 30 new Cardinals, announced a reform of the papal election system and shuffled top administrators of the Roman Catholic Church.

Tucked behind the blunt end of the Flatiron Building in the continual twilight of Broadway and 20th Street, a shingled mansard roof crowns a five-story structure embellished by every architectural detail known to Western man. There are curving glass bays, windows arched and balconied, endless variations on the columnand-capital theme-every antique motif, and all of-them worked in cast iron.

A Yugoslav student organiZation has accused American diplomats here of prying into sensitive political and social sues during interviews with students seeking to participate in a summer work and travel program in the United States.
Jorge Ruano, coach of the national basketball team of Guatemala, will tour the United States and conclude his visit at the 1973 National Collegiate basketball championship, March 24-26 in St. Louis.
Mexico and Venezuela were tied, 1-1, today after splitting singles matches in the first day of competition of their Davis Cup elimination playoffs.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Platt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Colette Platt, to Scott F. Russotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frances A. Russotto of East Greenwich, R. I.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Bloom have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Bloom, to Dr. Steven Benjamin of Boston. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Benjamin

The city's Board of Education has approved a major reorganization of its headquarters structure-now regarded as "illogical" and "uncoordinated" by some observers-in a move to bring central operations in line with the needs of the decentralized school system.

AUSTRALIA is on the last kilometer toward a metric system of measurements, and has issued this month an ingenious set of four stamps to ease the change from the imperial system of weights and measures to grams, kilos and meters.

THE three-hour television special is upon us. A few weeks ago it took the form of Joseph Papp's Shakespeare Festival production of "Much Ado About Nothing." This past Thursday it was Abby Mann's "The Marcus-Nelson Murders."

The Nassau County medical examiner reported here today that the death of a Hofstra University student a day after a drug raid on the campus last month was attributable to natural causes and did not involve the use of drugs as the police had at first hypothesized.

Jim Quinn's "Word of Mouth" (1973 edition) is the funniest book I have read in donkey's years, funny enough to read aloud to guests. Unlike the vague and lofty reviews of most other restaurant guides,
Lord Howick of Glendale, who as Governor of Kenya helped crush the Mau Mau rebellion of the nineteenfifties, died here today at the age of 69.

CANBERRA, Australia-One of the wisest foreign appointments President Nixon has made since 1968 was naming Marshall Green Ambassador to Australia. This country feels it has been neglected too long by its big American brother.

Miss Patricia Eileen Burke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Burke, was married here this afternoon to Robert Gordon Macionis, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Macionis of Elkin Park, Pa. Msgr. Thomas Moriarty performed the ceremony in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.
Silver Doctor, a candidate for the Triple Crown races, held off the late bid of Big Red L. at Bowie today and captured the $30,000 Prince Georges Stakes by a half-length.
PARK RIDGE-The creative mind that has been producing rock jingles for the last nine years for commercials has also been concerned with the New Testament for the last three of those years.
The New York Urban League has announced that its eighth annual Frederick Douglass Awards dinner will be held on May 3 in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel.

Meter readings indicating the presence of natural gas both inside the Staten Island tank that exploded Feb. 10 and in the sloping earth hill surrounding the tank have been found by Fire Department.and United States Labor Department investigators. Forty persons died in the blast.
ZURICH, SwitzerlandChiristoph Gruebler is a portolio manager under fire, but he thinks the attack is going to let up soon and is making plans accordingly.

Canada vented her mounting frustration over the failure of the international peace-keeping commission to fulfill its mission today by publicly criticizing two members of the commission for obstructing an investigation of alleged Communist violations of the cease-fire.

The specter of a wider school boycott that could affect other sections of Brooklyn, perhaps even other boroughs, loomed last week as white Canarsie parents continued to keep their children out of school in the latest protest against the busing of black children from nearby Brownsville.
FAIR LAWN-The growth of this Bergen County community since the end of World War II appears to have been one of the best managed developments in the state. Houses are neatly

Don McLean, the folk singer who filled Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, is the kind of artist who gives such pleasure to his fans that you hate to knock him too hard. And really there's no need to: Mr. McLean does what he does very well indeed.

The police intensified their hunt yesterday for a youthful assailant who had robbed and killed an elderly widow and brutally beaten another widow in the same apartment house where both lived in the North Bronx.

The engagement of Miss Terry Ann Krulwich, assistant professor. of biochemistry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, to S. Paul Posner has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lester S. Krulwich of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance,.
Moslems bowing in prayer toward the holy city of Mecca. Disturbances in Syria reflect a spilt between Islamic tradition and moderizing immulses in the Arab world.

They call themselves "Jusos," an abbreviation for West Germany's Young Socialists. At their annual congress in suburban Bad Godesberg this weekend they are living up to their name: being both young and socialist.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had received certification for an initial $3million in Federal funds for the development of Riverbank State Park,

BERNARDSVILLE-It has been almost two months since 21-year-old William Wells of Basking Ridge was shot and killed by William Sorgie, a Bernardsville patrolman, and while the official investigation into the shooting has long since concluded, at least two private investigations continue.

Miss Rhoda Sara Schutz, assistant counsel to the State Temporary Commission on the State Court System, plans to be married March 25 at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center in Yonkers to Daniel Riesel, an assistant United States Attorney and chief of the Environmental Protection Unit in the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
David Thompson delivered two free throws with nine seconds to play, clinching unbeaten North Carolina State's 27th victory, 76-74, over the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament tonight.

On his third try, Cougar II won the $170,000 Santa Anita Handicap today, but it took a photofinish and a 10-minute inquiry study by the track stewards to establish the winner by a nose over Kennedy Road.

The Minnesota Orchestra (formerly the Minneapolis Symphony) is celebrating its 70th anniversary this year, and on Friday night it came to Carnegie Hall to play a program of more than ordinary interest under the direction of Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, its music director since 1960.
UNION-The 14th Annual Art Exhibition and Sale at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. will take place here through Wednesday.

The pupil-teacher ratio for public schools in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has remained unchanged despite the fact that there are more than 300 fewer teachers in the. two counties than were were last year.

NINETEENTH - CENTURY American musical life--a mixture of carnival exhibitionism, parlor recitals and tepid academicism - presented an unlikely environment for the conception and development of any kind of important compositional practice.
Jacob Klein, a lawyer who handled real estate for the Shubert Brothers before his retirement 10 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 2 East 86th Street. He would have been 95 years old tomorrow.

ALI MACGRAW takes a valium and un packs her suitcase. She is going to leave today, tomorrow, next week, or never, for one week, two weeks, or a month in a climate that is either hot or cold. Her plane reservations-to Paris, Madrid, Jamaica-have already been canceled 10 times. She is "at the lowest ebb of my life. Everything inside me is run down--my blood, my hormones, my emotions."

The police announced late last night that Sir Richard Sharples, Governor of this British colony, and one other person had been shot to death. The police did not immediately release any information on the shootings or the identity of the other person killed.
A recent Soviet historical novel that seeks to demonstrate a link between Zionists and Nazis in World War II has been favorably reviewed in the officially controlled press.

Eggs, still-despite their price-the biggest bargain on the food list, led seven meat cuts in a new price advance last week and market analysts said they feared that the day was coming soon when eggs would no longer be widely available as a substitute for high-priced meat.
The Chicago Tribune said in its Sunday editions that an American soldier, who allegedly defected to the Vietcong in 1968, has been working in North Vietnamese prison camps and preparing propaganda.

When she left Cuba with the family valuables concealed in a false-bottomed straw handbag, Isis Wilson carried equally precious gems in her head-recipes for this traditional Cuban meal. The pot roast gets its special taste from long marinating.

THE BUSHWACKED PIANO, by Thomas McGuane. (Warner, 95 cents.) A young man at large in a brilliant, hard-edge American landscape: a caustic contemporary picaresque, a virtuoso performance. HOW SHE DIED, by Helen Yglesias. (Warner, $1.25.) A macabre tale of illness, paranoia, marital disintegration and death told movingly and with seldom failing sensibility.

Braulio Baeza packed his tack and returned to New York when Hialeah closed last Saturday, but said he would be back in Florida for selected mounts at Gulfstream. Thus far his selections have been first rate.

Miss Molly Jane Narens and Peter Stephen Ross plan to be married here April 29 at the' home of the bride's parents, Mr. and' Mrs. Leonard L. Narens, who have announced the engagement of the couple. Mr. Ross is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Ross of Washington.
SPRINGFIELD - Thomas Fleming, the historian, made his way among the gravestones at the cemetery here, near the site of a Revolutionary War battle that took place close to 200 years ago.

Willie Mays was missing from camp for a time, Tom Seaver was sidelined with a sore throat, and to make the day complete the New York Mets. got only three singles while losing to the St. Louis Cardinals today,. 4-0.

To THE EDITOR: IF "Bridget Loves Bernie" encourages Jews to "violate the teachings of their religion" as Rabbi Hillel A. Cohen suggests, then I guess "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" encourages career women to remain unmarried.

Bangladesh, a stricken nation in economic disarray now faces a perilous food shortage. Poor rainfall, transportation disruptions, scarce equipment, rising prices and the absence of fertilizers and pesticides have seared the economic fabric of the nation, still convalescing from the war with Pakistan 16 months ago.

Harry Mark Petrakis is so sincere a writer it's hard to tell how honest he is. The subject of "In the Land of Morning" is grim, or at least glum, but its treatment is mechanical; its attitudes are earthy but their expression literary;

To the Editor: I do not understand Frank Shorter's comment (in "The obsessiveness of the longdistance runner," Feb. 25, by Lawrence Shainberg) about the "hobbyist runner[s]... these guys who make a cult out of it. It ruins the whole thing to take it so seriously."
Premier Kakuel Tanaka and Finance Minister Klichl Aichi indicated today that they expected the United States to restore, at least partly, the convertibility of gold.
Many of those who decry business performance and attack business today in the :name of consumerism, and other popular causes, assert that business is not to be trusted and that protection

Lovely private homes and winding, tree-lined streets are the hallmark of uppermiddle-class Jamaica Estates, so when residents learned recently that a synagogue would be built in their neighborhood, a restlessness infiltrated many conversations.

To meet again, after an interval of 14 years, Sydney Taylor's well-known All-of - aKind Family is a bit upsetting-like going back to one's hometown hoping nothing has changed, finding that, indeed, nothing has,

JENSEN BEACH, FLA.--The Family Camping Federation, now three years old, held its first two annual conventions in Chicago's Palmer House but for its third congress it chose to meet at a Florida campground.

BOHEMIA, L.I.-Imagine an eye that sees across six states and one-third of the North Atlantic at one glance, an ear that simultaneously picks up conversations from Cleveland, Boston and Washington, a voice that can be heard - literally within a split second from the Azores to Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON WITH the increasing popularity of home winemaking, some gardeners have begun to grow their own wine grapes. In the Washington area,
Dr. Pamela A. Meyer and Dr. Barry S. Zuckerman, 1972 graduates of the Georgetown University School of Medicine, have announced their engagement and plans for a May wedding in North Andover, Mass.
Twenty-six years after Jackie Robinson broke the color line in the major leagues, baseball people are predicting that the first black manager will be appointed in the next season or two.
Of all poets of this time, Robert Graves is the one who, without solemnity but with total dedication, has kept the idea of poetry sacred and the idea of the poet true.
The University of Colorado retained its National Collegiate Athletic Association skiing crown today by placing three of its jumpers-all Norwegians--among the first four finishers.

Greg Cholish of West Morris High School was named today the outstanding wrestler in the New Jersey high school tournament, capturing the 123-pound division title before a crowd of 8,000 in Jadwin Gymnasium.
Today the "different" show is being held at the Westchester County Center in White Plains. It's the Saw Mill River Kennel Club fixture and, as usual, there are no groups or best-in-show judging.

BOHEMIA, L I.-The rapidity with which a traffic picture can change at MacArthur Airport here was illustrated recently as the quiescent radarscope suddenly came to life with three, five and then six pinpoints of light.

The trustees of Yale University extended today an invitation with reservations to the New York Giants to use the Yale Bowl as the site for the professional football team's home games the next two seasons while the Giants' new stadium

F you associate Lily Tomlin with only her "Laugh-In" characters, such as the prune-faced, middle aged Ernestine or the stringyhaired, elfin 5-year-old Edith Ann, it comes as a surprise that she's conventionally pretty; say, a cross between Loretta Young and Shirley MacLaine (the former's classy mien, the latter's crinkly eyes). Lily is slender and sassy and 33.

Fred Dickson, who spent the last five years seeking the wreck of Columbus's flagship, the Santa Maria, died yesterday during a diving expedition off the coast of Haiti, associates reported here. A spokesman at the Santa Maria Foundation, which Mr. Dickson headed,
Mike Kekich made his first appearance on the mound in an exhibition game today and emerged slightly damaged physically and unruffled emotionally.

Writing in this Book Review on Feb. 18, John Leonard seemed to think the presentation of the idea of the Fifth Estate at the Four Seasons (on the occasion of my 50th birthday) came off better as presentation than as idea. A nice analysis then ensued to show how "the evening would be a success only if Mailer made a fool of himself," for that was what people had paid to see.
When Pletrangelo Masulla and his sons immigrated from Naples to Brooklyn, they found the streets of the New World paved not with gold but with red tape.

When Joe Morrison, the exNew York Giant running back, called his first spring practice session at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga last week, a number of curious townspeople left their jobs early to watch. They wanted a
West Germany's security authorities are in the process of establishing a special antiterrorist department-to counteract foreign and domestic, political militants suspected of plotting violence.

One Penn Plaza, the 57story office building between 33d and 34th Streets and Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has signed six new leases. The building is now more than 60 per cent rented, according to Helmsley-Spear, Inc., its renting agents.

The devalued dollar, still sagging despite two emergency operations in 14 months, was back in surgery this weekend. Top-ranking monetary specialists from the United States and the rest of the non-Communist world huddled in Paris and Brussels to try to infuse new strength into the dollar's increasingly shaky position as pivot of the international exchange system.

BEDMINSTER-Anonymity may be on the way out for residents of five Somerset Hills villages and towns. Homeowners are being asked to come out from behind their long winding driveways, thick privet hedges and private lanes and post their names at driveway entrances for instant identification.

Against a background of mounting public and legal pressure to reform the financing of public schools, a national education group issued a report today portraying the current system in almost all states as chaotic and unjust.

President Nixon called on Congress today to restore the death penalty for certain Federal crimes and to enact a. new program of stringent minimum jail sentences for heroin pushers.

OUT CRY, a play by Tennessee Williams, got two favorable reviews, (Barnes, Times; Watts, Post), two mixed (Watt, News; Harris CBS-TV) and six unfavorable reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gaver, UPI; Bookspan, WPIX-TV).
Miss Maureen Corcoran, a speech pathologist with the Ramsey Board of Education, will be married June 2 to William Thomas Smith, a lawyer with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in New York.

Robert Singer of Dartmouth turned in the best combined time in the giant slalom and the Big Green led the 11 teams in the standing today in the National Intercollegiate Alpine tournament at Wildcat Mountain.

Once again this year, the generosity of more affluent Jerseyans will allow the Garden State Arts Center to invite hundreds of thousands of the young and the elderly, the blind and the orphaned, as well as disabled veterans to widely diversified programs of free entertainment.

The Moroccan Government announced today that it had nationalized foreign-owned agricultural land. Informed sources said that a total of about 965 square miles mostly owned by French citizens, were involved.

SLEEPERS JOINING HANDS, by Robert Bly. (Harper, $5.95.) Poems that seek to discern the whole meaning of the dominion of life and death over America. THE SPUTNIK RAPIST, by Carl Jonas. (Norton, $6.95.) A collection of odd but recognizable campus and urban types caught in the act of seeking their identities toward the close of the Age of Eisenhower; good-humored entertainment.

Olga Korbut, winner of three Olympic gold medals, and Ludmilia Tourischeva, winner of two, charmed an audience of 12,482 at the Astrodmoe tonight as six Soviet Union Olympic gymnasts opened a sevencity United States tour.

The Croton aqueduct system, which has supplied New York City with drinking water since before the Civil War, has become so enriched with nutrients and tiny animal life that, for the first time, the city is seriously considering the need to filter the water that reaches about a million residents of upper Manhattan and the Bronx.
Big business is mounting a national campaign to improve relations with the man in the street and blunt increasing Federal involvement in consumer affairs.

Miss Barbara Knapp, daughter of Maj. Gen. James Barclay Knapp, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Knapp of Bellevue, was married here tonight toRichEdward Bremer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard George Bremer of White Plains.
NORTH BRANCH - A 38-year-old poultry farmer and a 51-year-old man who had labored long in the hotel industry will become next year the first male graduates of Somerset College's nursing program.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.-An upsurge in special housing for older adults is under way in northern Westchester County, to the distress of civil libertarians.
Craig Carrieri began designing three years ago, doing belts and handbags. "And the big companies knocked them off," he-said. So he switched to knitted tops with amusing designs.

Mikhail Tal, who roared through 1972 winning everything in sight, has moved into 1973 without missing a step. He recently mauled the field for still another first prize, this one in the Beverwijk International Tournament.

" It's getting pretty rough out there with the elbows. If they don't stop, I'll have to use a few myself." Bill Lanigan wasn't talking today about football or basketball, but about speed skating at the national championships at Cantiague Park.
Eugene Connor, the Birmingham Police Commissioner who used dogs and fire hoses to break up civil rights demonstrations in the early nineteen-sixties, died here today. He was 75 years old.

THE curtain has fallen on the postwar era of liberal initiatives in trade and capital movements. This does not mean that the next scene is going to be Armageddon. It does mean that the stage has changed, the lights have been lowered and the orchestra is playing a more tentative tune. There's a chill in the air, and we must pay attention to what's happening.

WASHINGTON-"Honesty is always the best policy," said George Washington in his Farewell Address. In announcing wage policy for Phase 3 of the wageprice stabilization campaign, the Nixon Administration may have strayed from the first President's teaching.
Manhattan won the National Collegiate indoor track and field championship today, the first metropolitan New York school to achieve the distinction, outdoors or indoors.

In keeping with the character of the world-renowned scientist for whom the institution was named, the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will observe its 20th anniversary on Thursday.
MIAMI, March 10-An inquiry into alleged corruption in Dade County's courts and local government has been halted, at least temporarily, by a legal action in Tallahassee.

The competitions committee of the National Football League will spend a week in Acapulco, Mexico, before the league's annual meeting deliberating recommendations for changes in rules and other aspects of the game.

Tom Webster, Kevin Ahearn and Larry Pleau scored in the first two periods and a rookie goalie, Bruce Landon, stopped 36 shots tonight as the New England Whalers defeated the Minnesota Fighting Saints, 3-1, to take undisputed first place in the East Division of the World Hockey Association.
Pairings for the 36th National Invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden were announced yesterday by Peter J. Carlesimo, chairman of the selection committee.

A preview of what could be the final match-up in next year's America's Cup will be taking place starting Thursday in Long Beach, Calif., when the Congressional Cup series begins.
MONTCLAIR-More than 250 enthusiastic amateurs will take part next Saturday night in an ambitious musical program at Montclair High School.

The Peronist coalition held a solid lead early today in the national elections, but was falling short of the majority needed to win outright, according to official returns.

Beame if he wins the Democratic may Oral primary.

The Nets turned back the Memphis Tams, 120-113, at Nassau Coliseum today, and with the victory accomplished two things of significance.

A four-alarm blaze in downtown Paterson destroyed three stores and seriously damaged two adjoining ones yesterday. Kane said the fire apparently had started at Uncle Sam's Shoe Store at 76 Main Street.

In the apartment, at 105 West 112th Street, the police said, they found "cut" cocaine in manila envelopes and pure heroin with a total street value of about $30,000.

The avowed aim of the Marcel Couraud Vocal Group is to explore the outer limits of musical and physiological possibilities in the human voice. And it does do that.

The Maine Senate today gave final approval, 26 to 2, to a bill that would repeal the $3 poll tax on adult males, a law that has been on the books since 1845.

President Nixon has called on Congress to defeat crime in America by restoring the death penalty. Even were moral considerations to be put aside, judicial murder happens not to be a particularly effective way to accomplish the desired end.

Unemployment among the highly qualified-what the British call the "Ph.D. dole-queue syndrome"--is becoming a serious social problem in Western Europe, as it has been in the United States for some time, as European industry prepares for the more intense competition of the enlarged Common Market.

Leaders of the Conservative party endorsed Representative Mario Biaggi for Mayor last night, thereby virtually insuring the Bronx Democrat a place on the November ballot even if he loses the Democratic primary.
Danielle De Bernard of France won the women's slalom today in the first World Cup ski races held in Japan. She had an aggregate time of one minute 29.90 seconds.

Frank M. Bitetto, who supervised all printing operations as vice president and director of manufacturing of the Reader's Digest Association, died in a drowning accident Saturday while in Acupulco, Mexico. He was 65 years old and a resident of Stamford, Conn.

In a policy statement on the use of executive privilege, President Nixon said today that members and former members of his personal staff would decline to make any formal appearances before Congressional committees.

A State Supreme Court justice upheld yesterday the law that requires parental consent for the marriage of males from 18 to 21 years of age. Justice Margaret Mary J. Mangan upheld the constitutionality of the 66-year-old statute, part of the state's Domestic Relations Law.

Former Justice Eugene L. Brisach of the State Supreme Court died Saturday at the United Presbyterian Residence in Woodbury, L.I. His age was 89.

The railroads and 14 unions are on the verge of signing a new 18-month nationwide labor contract, union and industry officials reported today. They said it would be the first time in memory that a national rail contract had been reached without strikes or other disruptions.

Fares on most international air routes will increase from 2 to 11.1 per cent next month as a result of the devaluation of the dollar, the International Air Transport Association said yesterday.

A State Supreme Court justice upheld yesterday the law that requires parental consent for the marriage of males from 18 to 21 years of age. Justice Margaret Mary J. Mangan upheld the constitutionality of the 66-year-old statute, part of the state's Domestic Relations Law.

John Thomas Downey, who returned to the United States yesterday after 20 years as a prisoner of the Chinese Communists, was shot down on a day when the Korean war was still raging and the outlook for a truce- was clouded by disputes over the issue of prisoners of war.

Following are excerpts from a statement issued today by President Nixon on his use of executive privilege: The doctrine of executive privilege is well established. It was first invoked by President Washington, and it has been recognized and utilized by our Presidents for almost 200 years since that time.

Edward N. Vetrano, the County Clerk of Westchester, won the Republican designation tonight to run for County Executive. Mr. Vetrano, who built a powerful coalition of leaders in the three largest cities in Westchester, defeated three other candidates at a convention marked by noisy demonstrations.
British troops said they shot a gunman to death early today, and a 16-year-old Protestant youth died of wounds he received in a bomb blast earlier this month.

Four members of a family were found slain today at their Abington Township home in Montgomery County. The police identified the victims as Alex Davenport, 55 years old; his wife, Rowilla, 50, and their two sons, Peter S., 12, and Edwin Drew, 14.

U R S Systems Corporation reported yesterday cancellation of previously announced plans for a registered secondary offering of between 300,000 and 500,000 common shares on behalf of a group of its larger stockholders, citing depressed prices in the current market. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed at 6 1/8, up 1/2. .

The arrest of two Canadian men and two women from California last Friday night on charges of possession of Mexican heroin was announced today by the Nassau County District Attorney and an assistant United States attorney.

Standard Brands has entered the egg market with a cholesterol-free substitute, a frozen product based on egg whites that the company says has a nutritional value similar to whole eggs.

Mrs. Helen Satenstein Brandt, widow of Harry Brandt, theater chain executive, died Sunday at the home of her son, Richard of 911 Park Avenue, while on a visit from Miami Beach, where she had been living. She was 68 years old.

The Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday began a campaign to "sweep unsafe and unclean licensed taxis and livery vehicles off the streets of the city." By 5 P.M. 79 cabs had been found in violation.
The Communist party announced a nationwide drive today to enlist churchgoing Roman Catholics for its rank and file.

Out-boxing his opponent almost all the way and out-slugging him at the end, Francisco Villegas of Camito, Puerto Rico, scored a unanimous 10-round decision over Davey Vasquez before a crowd of 1,563 in the Felt Forum last night.

The flow of new deposits into mutual savings banks dropped sharply in February from the record levels posted in the same month last year, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

Governor Cahill announced this evening that he would nominate his personal counsel, Pierre Garven, and State Superior Court Judge Mark A. Sullivan as associate justices of the New Jersey State Supreme Court.

More than 500 members of the East Orange Education refused to teach again yesterday. A spokesman, Charles R. Cook, said that the teachers had voted to continue the job action to protest the Board of Education's refusal to guarantee that 44 staff positions and programs would not be dropped next year because of a budget cut. cut.

The United Nations command accused North Korea today of killing two South Korean soldiers and wounding another last Wednesday in the first serious shooting incident in the Korean demilitarized zone since September of 1971.
A 59-year-old Israeli was shot to death by a young man in a Nicosia hotel today, the police reported. A warrant has been issued for the arrest of the man, believed to be a Jordanian Arab student.
The Assembly unanimously passed today a tidal wetlands bill designed to protect and preserve about 150,000 acres of wetlands, mostly on Long Island, which still have value for wildlife.
Old musicals are like old wine--they do not always keep. Not that Cole Porter's "You Never Know," which opened at the Eastside Playhouse last night, was remarkably successful the first time around.
Aniello Dellacroce, described as a major figure in organized crime, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and fined $15,000 for income-tax evasion.

New Jersey Democratic leaders reported here today that a liberal drive to stop Senator Ralph C. DeRose from winning the party's nomination for Governor had foundered, and that the Essex County conservative Democrat was now regarded as the leading contender in the June 5 primary.

A Aunman hired to kill Joseph A. Yablonski testified here today that he had backed out of the murder plot when he was told to kill the other members of the Yablonski family who later died in a killing that the State of Pennsylvania has called a labor, "assassination."
A police expert testifying at the trial of H. Rap Brown said yesterday that it was virtually impossible to obtain usable fingerprints from firearms.
The Dial Financial Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

Six persons were killed today when a fire destroyed a tenement building in the city's Indiana Harbor district. Seven persons were missing and feared dead. Fire Chief Edward Simnasich, who called off the search for the night. told newsmen.

President Nixon's radio speech on law and order problems was the most depressing utterance of a man who has given us many. This was not so much because of its concrete proposals, bad as some of them were, but because it continued, and from the highest level, the usual American political response to the fear of crime rather than to the hard fact of crime itself.
Malaysia announced today that she was withdrawing from tile Asian and Pacific Council because it had not done anything.
Miss Elizabeth Shultz, a teacher at the Maili Elementary School in Wainae, was married here yesterday to Capt. Jerald S. Takesono of the Air Force Dental Corps.

Georges Jean Raymond Pompidou, with his Boris Karloff eyebrows, his fleshy nose and his unusual last name, which still makes some Frenchmen giggle, is pictured by acquaintances as a jolly good fellow.
Frank Mulzoff resigned yesterday as St. John's basketball coach two days after his team had lost to Pennsylvania, 62-61, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

James Mosselle, the teacher whose transfer from Vailsburg High School more than a month ago touched off a boycott by white students, returned to the school today, but the boycott continued.
Seven men and three women were charged tonight with conspiracy to cause the explosions that rocked London last Thursday.

The dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity moved forward today as Howard Phillips, the acting director, told all employes that the agency's, 10 regional offices should be prepared to close by April 28.

The three-man judiciary commission interrogating the members of the Black September guerrilla team that killed two American diplomats and a Belgian has decided to seek an indictment on four charges including premeditated murder, a Government-controlled newspaper said today.
Favorites led the way today at the start of a tournament for positions on the United States tennis team for the World Maccabiah Games in Israel this summer.
The military Government tonight declared Dr. Hector J. Campora, the handpicked Presidential candidate of former dictator Juan Domingo Peron, as the victor in Sunday's national elections.

In a policy statement on the use of executive privilege, President Nixon said today that members and former members of his personal staff would decline to make any formal appearances before Congressional committees.
Government troops under intense Communist pressure withdrew from two towns 20 miles south of Phnom Penh today despite heavy American bombing support, according to reports from the field.
Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today, "One ingredient of what we need has been put into place" for solving the international currency crisis.

Unemployment among the highly qualified--what the British call the "Ph.D. dole-queue syndrome"--is becoming a serious social problem in Western Europe, as it has been in the United States for some time, as European industry prepares for the more intense competition of the enlarged Common Market.

Several European governments took further action yesterday in the continuing shakeout of the international monetary crisis. The three Benelux nations, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, decided to maintain parities of their respective currencies.

George A. Locke, holder of 56 patents for inventions, mostly in the teleprinter and teletypewriter fields during his 50 years with the Bell System, died yesterday at his home, 2 Ashley Place. He was 79 years old.

D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, was sentenced today to three years in jail and fined $10,000 for conspiring to extort $120,000 from business concerns between 1965 and 1971.

A show that grandmother loved half a century ago opened last night in Broadway's newest theater. The show, "Irene," the 1919 musical comedy hit in a revived, revised and updated form, starring Debbie Reynolds, opened the spacious Minskoff Theater. It sits in the base of the 55-story tower at One Astor Plaza, on Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets.

Automobile advertising comes in three varieties. There's the advertising from the manufacturer; it tries to sell the product by playing up its features and engineering and that sort of thing. Then there's the advertising from dealer associations; this frequently does the same thing but includes more local flavor. Finally, there's individual dealer's advertising, which lays out his specific deals.

Robert F. Wagner, who from 1954 to 1966 served three terms as Democratic Mayor of New York, would be given the Republican and Liberal lines for the job this year in a delicate deal that politicians were trying to stitch together last night.

Stacy Harris, a character actor who played the part of Leslie Harrington on television's "Return to Peyton Place," died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.
Major changes in the operation of horse racing in New York State are expected to be recommended to Governor Rockefeller tomorrow by the Delafield Commission.

The chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that the supply of electricity this summer "will probably be the best we've had in the last three or four summers."

The United States Court of Appeals here issued an order yesterday blocking Pepsico Inc., from exercising control over the Rheingold Corporation, pending a decision on an application for an injunction by the Federal Trade Commission.

State and Federal officials agreed today on the urgent need for laws to control strip mining as four days of hearings on proposed laws began before the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.

Wilt Chamberlain tied his sea-son high with 25 points and grabbed 23 rebounds as the Los Angeles Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, clinched their third straight Pacific Division title, beating the Buffalo Braves, 121-112, tonight.

Frederick E. Hasler, chairman of the Continental Bank Trust Company from 1941 to its merger with what is now the Chemical Bank in 1948, died Monday at his home in Washington Depot, Conn. He was 91 years old.

An action brought by Motorola, Inc., against the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation in 1968 was dismissed yesterday by Judge William H. Copple, United States judge for the District of Arizona, according to a spokesman for Fairchild Camera.

Tim Buck, retired leader of the Communist party of Canada, died Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, the party's national office announced today. He was 82 years old.

Dr. Ruth Lewis Farkas, wife of the founder of Alexander's deapartment stores in New York and President Nixon's choice to be Ambassador to Luxembourg, said today that she gave the bulk of her $300,000 contribution to the Nixon campaign after the election was over.
The Food and Drug Administration issued today a set of final rules and tentative proposals that are intended to take the mystery out of the contents of food packages.

Zelmo Beaty scored 26 points in 28 minutes to lead the Utah Stars to a 131-118 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight in American Basketball Association action.

Northwest Industries, Inc., and the General Battery Corporation jointly announced yesterday that they have entered into discussions looking toward a cash tender offer by Northwest Industries for all of General Battery common stock.

Manager Leo Durocher of the Houston Astros was fined $250 today by the National League president, Chub Feeney, for interfering with his team's meeting yesterday with Marvin Miller and Durocher responded by threatening to resign and take the matter to court.

The Metropolitan Opera will perform Berlioz's "Les Troyens" for the first time in its history on Oct. 22. That and other plans for next season, which will open on Sept. 17 and include six new productions; were disclosed yesterday at a press conference in the opera house by Schuler Chapin, acting general manager, and Rafael Kubelik, music director.

The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation aligned themselves today with the General Motors Corporation in asking the Environmental Protection Agency to suspend for one year the 1975 Federal limitations on auto exhaust emissions of carbon moxoxide and hydrocarbons.

The dollar strengthened and the gold price fell in European financial centers today, but traders said that while current trends were encouraging, it was still too early to conclude that the latest monetary crisis was over.
Turtles contaminated with salmonella are being sold in New Jersey illegally, the State Health Department said today.

There is probably a market for "Irene," the almost-new musical comedy that opened the completely new Minskoff Theater last night, and I sincerely hope it finds it. One can only admire so much energy and effort.

Rosario P. Romanelli, 431 years old, has been named president of Western Union International, Inc., it was announced yesterday. A lawyer and an engineer, he has been with Western Union International and its predecessor compay for 16 years.

Many influential Republican leaders here believe that Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. has bought himself a political disaster in his confrontation with Governor Cahill over a proposal for a deep-water oil port in coastal waters off New Jersey.

The oldest man ever to win a major national title broke his own record at the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals here last night. Seventy-six-year-old John Simon, a St. Louis financier, successfully defended the men's team championship in a star-studded field.

American farmers intend to plant another record number of acres this year in grains and soybeans--key ingredients of tomorrow's meals. That was the import of usually reliable private forecasts yesterday by a prominent Midwest farm economist.
The constant theme in the political life of Dr. Hector J. Campora, Argentina's President-elect, has been subservience to former President and dictator Juan Domingo Per6n.

Cornell defeated Harvard, 17-15, with two last-minute goals, and Yale vanquished Texas A. and M., 24-5, tonight in the opening round of the national intercollegiate indoor polo tournament. Peter Ambrus, Yale captain, scored 13 goals.
The stock market continued to chug along in low gear yesterday in the absence of any major news breaks from the European monetary front.

With the final scheduled American - withdrawal from Vietnam only two weeks away, there is still little prospect of. a true cease-fire as loth the Communists and the south Vietnamese continue to violate many of the basic provisions of the Paris peace agreement.

The board of directors of the Foreign Policy Association has elected 10 additional members to join 65 scholars, lawyers, businessmen and civic leaders in guiding the national nonpartisan organization.
John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economics professor, defined at the Pentagon papers trial today what in his view would constitute damage to the national defense.
Clark Graebner of New York wore down West Germany's Meiler for a 7-6, 5-7, 6-3 victory in the quarterfinals of a $15,000 tennis Tournament tonight.

Since Harry Belafonte introduced Nana Mouskouri to the United States in the mid-sixties, the striking-looking Greek singer, whose dark-rimmed glasses have become her visual trademark, has built steadily on the strong foundation of her pure - toned, richly colored voice.
John T. Downey reflected today on his long imprisonment in China and said it had cost him a great part of his life, apparently for naught.

A public offering of 1.5 million common shares of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation at $54.50 a share was announced yesterday by Dillon Read Co. The company's stock closed at 54 1/2 up 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange.

The White House today proposed legislation that had been in the works since last year to increase the terms of broadcast licenses from three to five years and to establish as the chief criterion for renewal whether a television or radio station is "substantially attuned" to the needs and interests of its local public.

The city's Board of Standards and Appeals rejected pleas yesterday by the Planning Commission and a local planning board and granted a zoning variance to the developer of an apartment house on Third Avenue.

Senator Raymond H. Bateman, a Somerset Republican, announced yesterday the formation of a committee to urge Governor Cahill to seek re-election. Mr. Bateman, also announced that he had decided to seek re-election to his Somerset County Senate seat.

David Barrett, the premier of British Columbia, suggested today that a United States decision to support a railroad to carry oil and gas from Alaska might improve the likelihood that Ottawa would permit additional exports of Canadian oil and natural gas to this country.

The police said today that an 18-year-old suburban Philadelphia youth had bludgeoned to death his parents and two brothers following what may have been a disagreement with his father over the length of his hair and over his grades in college.
A four-hour bus ride brought the Chicago White Sox to Fort Lauderdale Stadium just before noon today and Dick Allen was on the bus.
Jean Yazvinsky, a ballet dancer and teacher who headed his own ballet school in New York from 1944 to his retirement in 1960, died Sunday in Griffin Hospital in nearby Derby. He was 81 years old.

A massive research project has been under way in the city administration for nearly nine months on "causes of welfare dependency," proposing to find "major policy alternatives for the reform of the welfare system and its related institutions."

A Bronx man found guilty in January of the fatal shooting of a part-time driver for The New York Times. and the wounding of another part-time driver was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to up to 20 years in prison.

The New York Press Photographers Association announced yesterday the winners in its 37th annual competition in conjunction with an exhibition of these prize-winning photographs of 1972 at The Mill at Burlington House, Avenue of the Americas and 54th Street.

An accounting firm has determined that the B. B. Walker Company of Asheboro, N. C., sustained a loss of about $7.6million in commodity trading accounts handled by Bartlette B. Walker, the company's founder and chairman who committed suicide last week.

A Beacon, N. Y., shoe merchant, tentatively sentenced last Nov. 10 to 20 years in prison for bomb threats to the liner Queen Elizabeth 2 and American Airlines, was given a final 10-year sentence in Federal Court yesterday.

Mrs. Marjorie Goetze Campbell, president of the board of governors of the Mansfield Training School, a 1,500bed school for mentally retarded, died yesterday at the Middlebury Convalescent Home. She was 70 years old.
With Ondine and Buccaneer leading the way, 13 big Class A yachts began pursuing Lightnin today in the 811-mile, Miami-Montego Bay race.
Bobby Joe Keesee's sister said today that he walked out of her home in Albuquerque, N. M., in May, 1970, for "not over an hour" to get his car repaired.

The Nixon Administration has agreed to sell Israel four squadrons of combatjets and to help the Israelis set up production of an advanced jet fighter of their own design.

The Senate Judiciary Committee, in a direct challenge to President Nixon, voted unanimously today to call his chief legal counsel, John W. Dean 3d, as a witness at its hearings on the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
A Soviet spokesman said today that it was "high time" to sign a World War II peace treaty with Japan but addedd that much "depends on Japan's approach to this problem."
A massive research project on the "cause of welfare dependency" is being conducted by New York City in an attempt to find "major policy alternatives" for reform.
There was no doubt that Carlo Maria Giulini, guest conductor with the Philadelphia Orchestra on Monday night in Philharmonic Hall, could get whatever he wanted out of the orchestra.
The Temporary State Commni'sion to Evaluate tile Drug Laws yesterday released its promised alternative to Governor Rockefeller's proposed legislation to heighten penalties for drug traffickers.

Frustrated Japanese commuters protested a slowdown in service today by going on a rampage. It started during the rush hour this morning when a train that was packed to overflowing because of a nationwide union slowdown pulled into the Ageo station north of Tokyo.

A Federal appeals court reversed today the conspiracy and bribery convictions against former Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, and left it up to the Government to decide whether he should face a new trial.
Orvin Granville Andrews, president of the Day Publishing Company in New London, Conn., and a newspaper executive for 59 years, died here today. He was 84 years old.

The Volvo Corporation of America, accused of unfair and deceptive advertising by the Federal Trade Commission, agreed today to refrain from saying, without reasonable proof, that its cars were more economical than others.

The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had begun recalling nearly 8,000 light trucks in an attempt to find about 250 that have defective brake hoses that could result in a partial loss of brake power.

The State Assembly's plan for a quiet day of ceremonies honoring West Point generals and themselves veered into uproar today as a black Democrat kept insisting that they take note of racial friction at a Buffalo high school.

May potato futures, which dropped the daily permissible limit of 35 points on Monday, lost another 35 points yesterday in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract fell from 8.50 cents a pound to 8.15.
A 22-year-old Hungarian Army sergeant serving with the International Commission of Control and Supervision defected here over the weekend and has been granted asylum by Australia.

The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it would seek reconsideration of a court ruling in Philadelphia delaying the application of a new S.E.C. rule on institutional membership in securities exchanges. Syria's first permanent Constitution since 1961 was endorsed by 97.6 per cent of the voters in a national referendum that ended early today, the Syrian Government announced.

President Lon Nol of Cambodia will shortly dissolve Parliament and hold new general elections, it was officially announced here today. The government communique containing the announcement did not set a date for the elections but said they would take place shortly.

The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that all applications by property owners for reduction of their real-estate-tax assessments and the notes of the assessors were open to public inspection.

Kenneth Pichette, a jockey from Warren, Mich. was suspended for five years by the Maryland Racing CoMmission today after being found guilty of having a battery in his whip before a race at Bowie Race Course.

The State Social Senrices Commissioner, Abe Lavine, said today that his department was secking legislation that would permit the sale of contraceptives to persons under 16 years of age and that would mandate that local social welfare districts offer full family-planning services.

Two suspected bank robbers were arrested yesterday by a police lieutenant who pursued them in a taxi after its driver rejected the robbers' efforts to enlist his services in a purported escape attempt.

With the final scheduled American withdrawal from Vietnam only two weeks away, there is still little prospect of a true cease-fire as both the Communists and the South Vietnamese continue to violate many of the basic provisions of the Paris peace agreement.

The body of an 8-year-old Harlem girl, missing since Sunday, was found in a narrow shaft behind her home yesterday in a spot that had been searched Monday and found to be empty of all but trash and garbage.

John E. Zuccotti, chairman of the City Planning Commission, yesterday announced a sixpoint plan designed to win the support of the Clinton community for the proposed convention center along the Hudson River between 43d and 47th Streets.
A 55-year-old widow from Hackettstown has just completed her sixth day in virtual solitary confinement at the Warren County Jail here for refusing to pay a $1,145 fine.

The Korvette departmentstore chain announced that it would open its first new store in the metropolitan area since 1967 in the Flushing section of Queens late this year. The new store, now under construction, will be a two-story, 135,000 square unit occupying a square block on Kissena Boulevard.

Phil Roberto and Floyd Thomson scored tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 2-0 triumph and extend the Buffalo Sabres' victoryless streak to five games.
President Nixon today nominated Dr. Charles C. Edwards to be the Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
Dr. Hector J. Campora, President-elect of Argentina, said today that he would shortly visit his mentor, the former President and dictator Juan Domingo Peron, in Madrid.

Secretariat, last season's Horse of the Year, is scheduled to work at Belmont Park this morning at 7:30. Lucien Laurin, the colt's trainer, said the Meadow Stables' 3-year-old would drill three-eighths of a mile and gallop out an extra eighth.

Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday the arrests of three persons - the head of a Brooklyn day-care center, a welfare recipient and a Department of Social Services typist - on charges of grand larceny in three separate cases.

Charles H. Foster, a manufacturer's representative for precision-machine parts, died yesterday at his home, 236 Berry Hill Road. He was 61 years old. Mr. Foster was a 1932 graduate of Dartmouth.

The House voted overwhelmingly today to postpone indefinitely the imposition of the Supreme Court's controversial new rules of evidence for the Federal court system By a 399-to-I margin, the Representatives agreed to give Congress as much time as it needed to rewrite the evidence code and then enact it as a regular law.

Nine Cubans rescued from a sinking Cuban fishing boat are being held in "protective and friendly custody" in Key West, Fla., by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, a State Department spokesman said today.

Ferdinand M. Bissell, a retired vice president of the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, died Friday in a San Juan nursing home. He was 68 years old. Mr. Bissell, a 1925 graduate of the Fordham University School of Business, had been an officer of the Chemical Bank and of the American Trust Company before joining the Banco Popular in 1952.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the.over-thecounter market finished slightly lower yesterday in slow trading as investors apparently awaited developments in the international monetary crisis.

Most of the faculty members of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University suspended classes for three hours today to attend a meeting dealing with problems of salary demands, tenure and productivity.

In his more than three decades as District Attorney of Manhattan, Frank S. Hogan has made that formerly scandal-ridden office a beacon of quality for lawenforcement agencies all over the country. Politics has been banished in staff appointments and in handling cases. Graduates of the "Hogan school" rank high in Federal, state and local agencies as well as in prestigious private law firms.

The state today unveiled the first of a series of tidal-flow maps that will form the basis for challenges to private ownership of property in sections of Newark, Elizabeth, Hoboken and other cities and towns.

The stock market continued churning indecisively yesterday in moderate trading and closed slightly lower. The Dow-Jones industrial average moved up 2.78 points to 978.85, but declining issues outnumbered those with gains, 724 to 647.

The United States relaxed its total embargo on arms shipments to India and Pakistan today, thus permitting the Pakistanis to receive some 300 armored personnel carriers, spare parts for previously supplied arms and some "nonlethal". military equipment.

George T. Bell, a former special assistant to President Nixon, died last night in his home here following a long illness. Before joining the President's staff, Mr. Bell worked for the General Electric Company and was later President of Geonautics, Inc., an engineering research concern.

All dogs can be obedience trained and can be taught to be watchdogs, but to become a security animal is something else, Joseph DeCosta, an instructor, told Dog Fanciers Club members at their luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

WASHINGTON--In the President's radio address on human resources, he spelled out three criteria to be applied in reaching decisions regarding Federal activities in the social-program area. First, control over decisions should, insofar as possible, be placed in the hands of those to be directly affected by the decisions.

The Federal Government eased the blockade of Wounded Knee today and agreed to allow food, fuel and medicine in as a spring blizzard roared into the area, closing roads throughout the southeast corner of the state.

South Africa's racial segregation policy will be modified for the Rev. Billy Graham's appearance in Durban Saturday. "This was one of the conditions laid down before he accepted the invitation to come to South Africa," one of the evangelist's aides said today.

Approximately 400,000 Philadelphia area commuters received a reprieve today with postponement of a threatened strike that would halt all bus, trolley and subway service.
The Federal Trade Commission yesterday ordered Litton Industries, Inc., to divest itself of Triumph-Adler, a West-German typewriter manufacturer acquired by Litton in 1969.

Terrorists threw grenades into a crowded Buddhist pagoda in a Mekong Delta village, shortly after last midnight, killing 10 persons and wounding 88, military sources said. First reports did not say whether any monks were among the dead or injured.

The Federal Government reacted politely, but coolly today to the $4-billion plan proposed yesterday by Premier David Barrett of British Columbia to transport Alaska oil and gas by rail to markets in the United States.

The chief Congressional sponsor of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution said today that opponents of the amendment were trying to use their opposition as a means of building a right-wing political organization among women.

Premier Golda Meir today offered King Hussein of Jordan guardianship over the Islamic holy places in the Old City of Jerusalem. But Mrs. Meir, speaking in Elath, Israel's southernmost city, reiterated that Israel rejected King Hussein's demand for sovereignty over part of Jerusalem.

Senator William Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, proposed today that the Government nationalize seven financially ailing railroads in the Northeast. His bill is the fifth introduced this session on the rail crisis.
