Two Japanese executives warned here yesterday that Japan's efforts to restrict exports could give only temporary, partial help in reducing the American trade deficit with their country. In 1973 this deficit topped $4-billion.

The Government today held consultaLions on monetary strategy amid indications that the lira exchange rate might be allowed to drop substantially lower than it has already in the month it has been floating.

Amid popping balloons and speeches by government officials, an $11-million, federally aided housing - rehabilitation project was dedicated in Harlem yesterday, and the first of nearly 400 families who will live there moved in.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., the world's largest distiller, increased earnings in the quarter and half-year ended Jan. 31 by more than 10.5 per cent from the year-earlier periods, the company reported yesterday. Sales in both periods set records, the company said.

The agenda for the extraordinary session of the United Nations Security Council, opening today in Panama, is "consideration of measures for the maintenance and strengthening of international peace and security in Latin America in conformity with the provisions and principles of the Charter."
Richard J. Coffee declared here this evening that the nomination of any of his major opponents for Governor could be a "disaster for the Democratic party in the November elections."

The Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture announced plans today to operate 102 Youth Conservation Corps camps this summer. The two departments plan to employ about 3500 young people aged 15 through 18 during the eight-week program beginning in late June.
A solid majority of the voters in the 17 Texas counties of the Trinity River basin rejected yesterday a property tax needed to support $150-million in site preparation bonds for a canal on the river.

The Vanderbilt knockout team championship, the premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, when into full gear here this afternoon, with 64 teams competing, 10 of which survived preliminary round matches yesterday.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., directors accepted yesterday a bid of $22.116 a share for four million shares of new common stock from a group of underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody. The underwriting group will offer the stock to the public at 22 1/2 a share.
President Nixon's plan to revive the death penalty seeks to circumvent the Supreme Court's or opposition to capital punishment by establishing a novel system for sentencing Federal criminals.

Turkish politicians and leader of the armed forces backed off from a confrontation today as Parliament postponed until Friday the election of a new national president. After four votes in Parliament last night, the election was deadlocked with neither the candidate supported by the military, Gen. Faruk Gurler, nor his main opponent, Tekin Ariburun, the Senate President able to win a decisive majority.
King Hussein announced today that he had commuted the death sentences passed against Mohammed Daoud Odeh, a leader of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, and 16 of his colleagues.

Robert V. Roosa, Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and one of the world's leading students of international monetary affairs, warned yesterday against attempts to find a quick solution to the present world financial crisis.

The Health Services Adminis tration released a study yesterday that contends that the sharp decline in the percentage of addicts seeking detoxification in city detention facilities reflects an over-all easing of addict-committed crime in the city.

HOUSE BUILDING Last season the Theater Development Fund, which was founded to help commercial theater gain audiences by subsidizing audiences, started a special project to build up houses and coffers of Off Off Broadway Theaters.

Miami Beach's water supply was declared free of contamination today, and health officials said drinking water need no longer be boiled. Dr. Milton Saslaw, director of the Dade County Public Health Department, said tests of 90 samples taken yesterday showed no contamination.

When you asked them why they lived in New York, they'd tell you: the opera, the array of restaurants, the movies, the Knicks. But now even these New York lovers, accustomed to such a rich diet of divertissements, are being forced to take an uncomfortable look at what it costs to have fun.

President Nixon, asserting that the only way to attack crime effectively is "without pity," urged Congress today to revise the entire criminal code in a way that, in many cases, would increase penalties and reduce the discretion of Federal judges in imposing sentences.

The Olin Corporation and the BASF Wyandotte Corporation announced yesterday that they would raise prices for chlorine and caustic soda by $5 a ton. Spot delivery prices go into effect immediately for Olin, and April 1 for BASF Wyandotte.

A line of Vietnam-era veterans, some symbolically clad in cast-off military clothing, filed before the City Commission on Human Rights yesterday to relate their experiences with unemployment, a lack of drug rehabilitation and public indifference.

Representative Bob Wilson of California, stepping down as chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, said today that his party's fortunes in the 1974 elections would langely depend on White House Support.

The defense sought today to portray the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers reform leader who was shot to death with his wife and daughter in 1969, as a bungled burglary in which the gunmen "panicked and slaughtered a family."

PERIOD--1, Winnieeg, Boyle (6) (Hull, Sutherland) 4:41. 2, Winnipeg, Hull (45) (Bordeleau) 7:01. 3, New England, Shechy (28) (Dorey, Pleay) 11:04 4, New England, Selwood (10) (unassisted) 13:04. 6, New England, Shechy (29) (French) 19:19. Penalties--Dorey, New England (3:24), Cuddie, Winnipeg (5:36), Ash, Winnipeg, (10:30), Woylowich, Winnipeg (11:55), Williams New Englnad (16:40).

More than 20 of the 35 Schrafft's restaurants, first established in New York in 1906, may be acquired soon by a restaurant organization largely known to the public only through the names of a number of New York restaurants it owns.
Three major brokerage concerns announced plans yesterday to form holding companies in the first moves of this kind for member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.

Irish Brandy of the Joe-Mar Stable had the benefit of a front-running ride under Kelly Castaneda in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and took the seven-furlong event by two lengths over Leo Fink's Pat Intent. The success was the second in a row, officially, for the fine 17-year-old rider from Bogota, Colombia.

Since March of 1968, there have been two prices of gold--the official price set by governments and the freemarket price set by traders and speculators. The official price of gold, following the second devaluation of the dollar, is now $42.22 an ounce. Only three weeks ago, when confidence in the dollar-and other paper currencies-was plummeting, the free-market price of gold soared to $95 an ounce, an all-time peak.

All dogs can be obedience trained and can be taught to be watchdogs, but to become a security animal is something else, Joseph DeCosta, an instructor, told Dog Fanciers Club members at their luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

" Applause" is the stagemusical version of "All About Eve," the brittle, bitchy film classic starring Bette Davis. "Applause" is not a classic. It is a loud and brassy Broadway musical, at its best when starring Lauren Bacall.

The president of the Rockefeller Foundation called upon government agencies and the public and private health sector yesterday to share the responsibility of making safe and humane abortions available to women throughout the country regardless of their ability to pay.

In Catholic High School Athletic Association semifinal games played last night at Fordham University, Power downed All Hallows, 62-49, and Molloy beat Holy Cross. 49-45, before a capacity crowd of 3,470.

President Lon No today ordered Government officials to prepare for a general election to replace the sixmonth-old National Assembly. The Government described the planned elections as a peace move. The date was not specified.
Mrs. Virginia Rojas Alou never wanted her sons to become baseball players. She wanted them instead to go to college. "She wanted a doctor in the family," Matty Alou said.

Refunds are up and so are income-tax filings in comparison with a year ago. More than a year ago it became apparent that many taxpayers would find themselves overwithheldd" because of an oversight in the payroll deduction tables provided by the Internal Revenue Service.
The 30-foot sloop Delphini became the first casualty of the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race last night when it struck a reef off the northeast point of Cat Island in Bahamian waters.
The New York Mets broke a four-game losing streak today with a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers, the only team they have beaten in the first week of springtime exhibition games.
James P. Maher, a former financial writer, editor and Wall Street broker, died yesterday at Brooklyn Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 345 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.

John E. Kilcullen, a 42-yearold bartender, interrupted his trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to plead guilty to extortion in the kidnapping of Emanuel Gambino, a nephew of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia leader.

Judge John H. Pratt of United States-District Court denied today a Government motion for a stay of his ruling that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare must promptly enforce desegregation in hundreds of schools in 17 Southern and border states.
The Senate, following its most tense legislative debate of the year, voted today to allow urban areas to spend their share of Federal highway money to build rapid rail systems.
A single-engine Cessna plane crashed late yesterday about a mile from the Westchester County Airport. Three persons were injured. The three were reported in fair condition at Greenwich Hospital.

Gussie Busch is the contented owner of a contented ball club this year, his 20th as head man of the St. Louis Cardinals. He treated his ballplayers as if each were a Stan Musial, his long-time pet and deservedly so. No one was cut in salary, many were raised and the Redbirds were the first to have all contracts signed.
After having promoted more than 2,000 boxing cards in 40 years, Harry Markson will retire March 31 as president of Madison Square Garden Boxing Inc.
Governor Rockefeller's attempt to forge a RepublicanLiberal coalition behind former Mayor Robert F. Wagner ran into a revolt yesterday by the Republican organization

A train carrying railroad workmen struck the rear of a stopped New York-toWashington Metroliner outside Washington today, injuring 12 persons. It was the first major accident for the high-speed passenger train since it began operations four years ago.
The New York Rangers got a lesson in how to play hockey in losing to the Black Hawks, 4-2, at Chicago Stadium tonight and Gene Carr got a lesson in boxing from Keith Magnuson.

Ballet and modern-dance stars from four New York companies will perform in Atlanta Friday in a special tribute to Dorothy Alexander, founder of the Atlanta Ballet and the National Association of Regional Ballet,
Tom Gorman of Seattie defeated Eddie Dibbs of Miami, 7-6, 6-4, and kept alive his bid for the $5,000 first prize in the Caracas roundrobin international tennis tournament today.

The health food industry has filed a $500-million damage suit against the Government, charging that attempts to regulate the business have resulted in abuse, harassment and economic hardship. The suit, which was announced today, was filled by the National Nutritional Foods Association.
Looking for "new challenges," Jack Kraft of Villanova accepted a four-year contract yesterday as basketball coach at the University of Rhode Island.

The police continued yesterday their investigation of the circumstancess surrounding the death of Felicia Bruce, the ??-year-old girl found dead Tuesday, two days after she left her home at 277 West 117th Street on an errand.
Herman M. Freydberg, a re tired plastics manufacturer who was a former president of the Westchester County Golf Association, died Monday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. His age was 70.

Representative Herman Badillo, who lost the New Democratic Coalition endorsement to Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, announced yesterday that two more coalition clubs had voted to support his own candidacy.

On the one side there is Janet Youngholm, a Princeton sophomore, who wants to play men's intercollegiate football at Princeton next fall. She is serious. "I love sports. I've never played football but the game has a certain grace and beauty which attract me."

The University of California, Los Angeles, opens the defense of its National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tomorrow night hoping to go on to a record seventh straight title and ninth in 10 years.

The state today unveiled the first of a series of tidal-flow maps that will form the basis for challenges to private ownership of property in sections of Newark, Elizabeth, Hoboken and other cities and towns..
Elisha Walker Jr., a financier, died yesterday of a sudden illness in Acapulco, Mexico, according to word received by relatives here. He was 62 years old and lived at 870 United Nations Plaza.

PURDY'S CORNER, N.Y.--Hamantaschen are plentiful now in this upper Westchester community, where a mother-daughter team has just finished baking more than a gross of the threecornered pastries in preparation for the Jewish holiday...
J. Steele Gow, retired executive director of the Falk Foundation, died yesterday in PresbyterianUniversity Hospital. He was 78 years old.

Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, announced yesterday the names of seven more food establishments that he said had violated the Health Code. Unless the violations are cleared up by a third and final inspection, the establishments face the possibility of being closed

The State's Court of Appeals cleared a major barrier for the Storm King power plant yes. terday when it upheld in a unanimous ruling the state's decision that the plant would not endanger water quality standards.

Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, called on Congress today to create its own Office of Budget and Management. Appearing before the Joint Study Committee on Budget Control, Senator McGovern offered a strategy by which he said Congress could regain control of the budget process from the President.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and three members of President Nixon's Cabinet waged a miniature version of the battle of the budget today on Capitol Hill. Nobody won.
In a move to help stabilize meat prices, the Agriculture Department proposed today to allow continued use of byproducts such as pork
The judge who sentenced two leaders of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers to jail for defying his order to end a strike reduced their sentences today after refusing to free them.

The number of persons who feel that too much is being spent for the national defense has declined to 42 per cent from the 50 per cent figure recorded two years ago, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

A lawyer representing insurgent Republicans told a Superior Court judge today that he intended to call the present and three former chairmen of the powerful Bergen County Republican Committee as witness in an effort to prove the state's primary election laws unconstitutional.

The San Diego Conquistadors, battling to wrest fourth place and a playoff spot in the American Basketball Association's Western Division, defeated the New York Nets, 108-98, before 8,264 fans at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

In rooms of Federal green, planners are already planning ways to celebrate the Republic's 200th anniversary in 1976. They are searching for historical events suitable for re-enactment. Reenactment is the staple of official celebration. Remember the 1960's? Re-enactments of Civil War battles often seemed as inescapable as street muggers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission published new data yesterday showing that the "crisis" in the investment corn pany business-with redemptions of shares far exceeding sales - is nowhere near as severe as it has been painted by Wall Street.

The Senate narrowly approved two bills today providing for a $650-million mass - transportation construction program by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, but the Republican leadership in the Assembly failed to muster enough votes for final passage by the Legislature.

The Bermuda government will ask Britain to appoint Lady Sharples as governor of this colony to replace her husband Sir Richard Sharples, who was shot to death Saturday, according to reliable sources close to the Bermuda cabinet.
The faculty of Rider College voted today to censure the college president, Frank Elliott, in a strongly worded statement expressing "a lack of confidence in the Elliott administration."

The Santa Cruz County grand jury indicted Herbert W. Mullin, 25 years old, for murder today in the shooting deaths of 10 persons here. Mr. Mullin is imprisoned without bail and did not attend the three-hour grand jury session at which 17 persons testified.
Courtaulds, Ltd., the large British fiber and chemical company, announced plans yesterday to establish a $60-million synthetic-fiber plant in Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland.

Michael G. Phipps, one of the outstanding polo players of his day, died of a heart attack last night at his home here. He was 63 years old. He was vice president of Bessemer Securities Corporation and a director of W. R. Grace Co.

The State Department of Health reported yesterday that 5 per cent of the restaurants and other food-industry establishments inspected between last Dec. 15 and March 1 had received unsatisfactory sanitation ratings. The department said it had inspected 749 establishments in the three-month period, of which 36 had been found to be unsatisfactory, 362 conditionally satisfactory and 351 satisfactory.

The United States announced yesterday that it was relaxing its embargo on arms shipments to India arid Pakistan and would allow Pakistan to receive some 300 armored personnel carriers and some "nonlethal" equipment and spare parts. The State Department said the new policy would not alter the military balance in the area, nor stimulate an arms race.

Public-school teachers in New Haven went back to the classrooms today, suspending their week-and-a-day walkout to allow negotiations to resume. All but 68 of the 1,365 classroom teachers were on the job this morning. Those who were absent reported sick.

William W. Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, rejoined Northeastern National Bank of Pennsylvania yesterday, this time as chairman of the board. Mr. Scranton resigned from the Northeastern board in 1971 to serve on President Nixon's Price Commission.

The United States relaxed its total embargo on arms shipments to India and Pakistan today, thus permitting the Pakistanis to receive some 300 armored personnel carriers, spare parts for previously supplied arms and some "nonlethal" military equipment.

The State's Court of Appeals cleared a major barrier for the Storm King power plant yesterday when it upheld in a unanimous ruling the state's decision that the plant would not endanger water quality standards.

North Vietnam released 108 more American prisoners of war today, including the officer who had acted as commander of prisoners captured in the North. They arrived aboard three Air Force C-141 Starlifter medical-evacuation jets after what was described as a routine turnover ceremony at Gia Lam Airfield in Hanoi.
King Hussein announced today that he had commuted the death sentences passed against Mohammed Daoud Odeh, a leader of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, and 16 of his colleagues.

A state commission's proposed alternative to Governor Rockefeller's pending legislation dealing with narcotics traffickers was generally praised today by leading Republicans here who are seeking tougher drug laws but who have problems with the Governor's plan.

The United States Secretary of the Treasury, George P. Shultz, today assured Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, that President Nixon was determined to overcome Congressional opposition to an easing of trade with the Soviet Union.

The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to prohibit grants of Government food stamps to strikers. Otto F. Wenzler, labor relations manager for the chamber, told a Senate Agriculture Committee that "misuse" of the food stamp

In an effort to avert a revival of inflationary psychology, the Administration plans to issue next week a statement outlining the probable course of farm and retail food prices for the rest of 1973, informed sources disclosed today.

Sgt. Maj. Leon L. Van Autreve was named today to become the Army's top noncommissioned officer. Sergeant Van Autreve, 53 years old, of Delphos, Ohio, will take over as the Sergeant Major of the Army on July 1, succeeding Sgt. Maj. Silas L. Copeland, who is retiring.

Kensington High School here was closed today for the second day in a row as groups of students milled about the hallways and refused to go to classes. The principal, Angelo J. Gianturco, said it was decided to close the school rather than to risk the possibility of confrontations among groups of students in the city's racially troubled school system.

Responding to mounting protests, the Nixon Administration backed down at least part way today from earlier plans to trim Federal outlays for state and local social services. The Administration's retreat was disclosed by Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, as he underwent questioning before a Senate subcommittee.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, announced yesterday that he had designated Hugh Sheridan as a special state mediator to deal with the continuing threat of a cemetery strike.
William J. McCabe, editor and publisher of The Rockland County Times since 1940, died at work this evening, apparently of a heart attack He was 64 years old and lived here.

It was 11 A.M. on Livingston Street in Brooklyn, and Samuel Kantor, a 55-year-old milkman on his day off, was carrying his son's typewriter to the shop for repair. He never really saw the man who attacked him.

A former stock broker, now a fugitive from justice, has been notified that he owes the Government more than $12.5-million in back taxes. Because the man, 52-year-old Henry Scharf, could not be served personally with a court summons, he was notified through legal advertisements published here.

How about a toned-down "The French Connection" setup as a television series? Judging by "My. Inside/Mr Outside," a 90-minute pilot feature for a projected serial, why not? It was shown last night on the Nations Broadcasting Company.

District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens denounced Deputy Attorney General Maurice H. Nadjari yesterday as "lawless" and as a "petty and irascible would-be prosecutor" who had sadisticallyy" abused witnesses called to testify before his grand juries.

Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz's just-concluded visit to Moscow was so hastily arranged that his hosts there were unable even to welcome him with proper diplomatic protocol. Mr. Shultz, who is President Nixon's chief economic adviser, went to Moscow in the midst of a continuing major international monetary crisis. Both facts testify to the importance of his mission.
Jacob S. Siefman, a certified public accountant and an executive of Stalite Dental Products Company in Hialeah, died today in Mount Sinai Hospital, Miami Beach. He was 69 years old.

To the Editor: This Administration, not, I am sure, through either ignorance or stupidity but through a combination of both, is beginning to dismantle one of the glories of post-World War II American history.
The United States temporarily resumed troop withdrawals from South Vietnam today to match the release of 108 American prisoners by North Vietnam, the American command announced.
University of Texas researchers reported yesterday the isolation of a "unique" factor from the blood of patients with cystic fibrosis. The researchers said the

The Da Capo Chamber Players believe that contemporary music deserves a second hearing. Too often works are given more or less prestigious premieres and then disappear forlornly back into their composers' desk drawers; the Da Capo Players fish them out again.

Hundreds of women responded to a classified advertisement for an administrative assistant to a president paying "to $20,000" a year. But Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged that at least 24 of the women hired by Universal Administrators, a "management service" at 200 Park Avenue, were hired and placed in other jobs-and never paid.

In an unusual announcement, the Society of Jesus said in Rome that its General, the Very Rev. Pedro Arrupe, had apologized to a close aide of Pope Paul VI for a letter written by an English Jesuit. The letter, published in The Observer in London last Sunday, was written by the Most Rev. Peter Hebblethwaite.

Francis A. Kenney, manager of transportation for the Sulphur Export Corporation, an affiliate of Texas Gulf, Inc., died on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Sao Paulo, Brazil. He was 46 years old and lived in East Brunswick, N. J.

Confirmation of Mrs. George L. Farkas as Ambassador to Luxembourg encountered a snag today when Senator Gale McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, called for a delay by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in voting on the nomination.

The owner of a grocery store in Jackson Heights, Queens, was shot to death last night when he tried to resist three holdup men. According to the police, three men, one armed wtih a .22caliber "Saturady night special" and another with a knife, entered the Spanish-American grocery of Alfonso Lam at 8725 Roosevelt Avenue at 9:35 P.M.
Last Sunday, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera was having lunch in a remote village in northwest Panama after having spent several hours listening to cattlemen there complain of drought.

Ulster will hold local government elections on May 30, under a new system of proportional representation, it was announced here today by the British Secretary of State, William Whitelaw. The elections will be the first since 1967.

President Nixon, asserting that the only way to attack crime effectively is "without pity,' urged Congress today to revise the entire criminal code in a way that, in many cases, would increase penalties and reduce the discretion of Federal judges in imposing sentences.

Liam Cosgrave, leader of the coalition that won the general election of Feb. 28, took office today as Prime Minister of Ireland. He named a Cabinet in which 11 of the 16 posts went to members of his Fine Gael and 5 to its Labor party partners.

Third-seeded Clark Graebner of New York overcame loss of the first set in a tiebreaker to upset top-seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4, in the $15,000 National indoor open tennis championship.

A bill that would permit the National and American Basketball Associations to merge and would free players from reserve-clause restrictions is to be introduced today in Washington by Senator Birch Bayh,

The last two American pilots held by China were released today and crossed the border into Hong Kong. They are Maj. Philip E. Smith of the Air Force and Lieut. Comdr. Robert J. Flynn of the Navy. Both men were shot down over Chinese territory during missions connected with the Vietnam war.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, expressed frustration today as he listened to proposals to restrict and to widen his bill to protect the rights of newsmen. "I can argue either side without convincing myself very much either way," he said, interrupting a witness at the sixth day of hearings before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

A 69-year-old widow was found dead yesterday in the bathtub of her apartment in the Clasons Point section of the Bronx. The police said she was fully clothed and her mouth was gagged and they tentatively termed the death a homicide.

The string bass is generally seen traveling in herds, grazing at the edges of the orchestra, but occasionally one breaks away like a rogue elephant and charges off on its own. Such a rebel instrument turned up at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, in the hands of a young virtuoso named Richard Fredrickson.
Dr. Andre Repond, a psychiatrist and former president of the World Federation for Mental Health, died last night. He was 87 years old.

The Senate, following its tenseest legislative debate of the year, voted today to allow urban areas to spend their share of Federal highway money to build rapid rail systems. The proposal, an amendment to an $18-billion, three-year highway construction bill, was passed by a vote of 49 to 44.

Soviet chess masters, led by Mikhail Tal, a former world champion, captured the first six places in the international tournament in Talkinn that ended today. The Swedish master Ulf Anderson was the only foreign entrant in the 15-round tournament to place in the top nine positions.

Norman D. Archer was sentenced to a three-year prison term yesterday for accepting a bribe to fix a criminal case while he was a chief assistant district attorney in Queens. Until a major investigation of corruption resulted in his indictment by a Federal grand jury last July 25, he had headed the indictment bureau in the office of Thomas J. Mackell, the Queens District Attorney.
President Suharto accepted nomination today to serve as President for a second term and agreed to the nomination of the Sultan of Jogjakarta, Hamengkubuwono, as vice president.

Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced today a bill that would abolish the death penalty under Federal law. The measure sponsored -by the Roman Catholic priest would substitute life imprisonment for all death sentences.

Otto Preminger, the film director; William S. Beinecke, the S. H. green-stamps' king, and C. K. McClatchy, vice president of The Sacramento Bee, found themselves on the prow of a sludge cargo ship on the East River yesterday, listening to a doomsday description of how New York City would run out of places to put its garbage by the mid-nineteen-eighties

President Nixon has decided to sell large amounts of metals and other commodities from the nation's strategic stockpile in an effort to drive down soaring prices, it was learned from authoritative Administration officials tonight.

John W. Dean 3d, President Nixon's chief legal counsel, declined today an invitation to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee in connection with the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d, Mr. Nixon's choice to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Robert T. Connor, Borough President of Staten Island and a lifelong Republican, switched to the Democratic party yesterday, and announced that he would seek its nomination for re-election.
Mrs. Elizabeth K. Willis, the widow of William H. Willis, who headed the executive recruiting concern in New York bearing his name, died Monday. She was 75 years old.

Being No. 2 in the Pacific-8 Conference has meant few rewards for Southern California's basketball team. Bob Boyd, whose Trojans meet Notre Dame Saturday afternoon in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison. Square Garden, has learned that in his seven coaching seasons.

Being No. 2 in the Pacific-8 Conference has meant few rewards for Southern California's basketball team. Bob Boyd, whose Trojans meet Notre Dame Saturday afternoon in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, has learned that in his seven coaching seasons.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the Nixon Administration's legislation to devalue the dollar, clearing the way for final Senate approval.
A member of the Hungarian delegation helping to supervise the cease-fire in South Vietnam arrived in Sydney today from Saigon as an immigrant, it was announced here.

A Federal Government office has retracted a statement that 32 defendants had pleaded guilty to illegal trafficking in animal skins. The retraction was made by the office of the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Fish and Wildlife, Parks and Marine Resources, which made the earlier statement in a news release on Feb. 21.
Leaders of the nation's mining industry said today that they opposed both strip mining control bills currently under study by the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.

A heavy snowstorm has apparently had the salutary effect of damping down the tensions at Wounded Knee that earlier in the week threatened a new armed confrontation as Department of Justice agents sought a way to reduce the "rebellion" in that remote Indian settlement in South Dakota.

The jury in the Pentagon papers trial continued its education today in how the United States gathers intelligence. One of the defense witnesses, for instance, was Dr. Allen S. Whiting, a consultant to Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security affairs.

A triumphal comeback for American artists in eclipse for and three decades was marked last night in an auction sale offering part of the Edith G. Halpert collection at Sotheby Parke Bernet, 980 Madison Avenue.

President Nixon today praised the narcotics agents who were instrumental in the conviction of a heroin smuggler who Mr. Nixon said had brought enough drugs into the United States to affect the lives of more persons than were killed in Vietnam
The state was urged today to begin immediately to draw up regulations fixing acceptable levels of noise for industry, transportation and other sources of sound pollution.
American Motors, the smallest of the major auto makers, aligned itself today with its bigger competitors in telling the Government it could not meet the 1975 auto pollution standards.
The fact that many black vaudeville dancers were also comedy dancers who became known as nondancing comedians on Broadway and television can make one forget what good dancers they were.
There were smiles and hugs-and a few tears-as Jerry Pectle was reunited yesterday with the foster family that had cared for him for five of his seven years.
The dismissal last year by State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin of perjury indictments against two retired policemen was. reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division.
Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson proposed today that the state take over New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation and severely restrict the kinds of bets it could accept.

A nonprofit organization of educators filed suit in a Federal court in Washington yesterday against the newest Government agency, the National Institute of Education, charging that it has been functioning illegally.
Robert Bongiovi, an alleged gunman who was with Joseph Gallo the night he was assassinated last April, was charged yesterday with a murder that the police said might have links to the Gallo killing.
Total business inventories rose in January by the largest amount since the current economic expansion began, but sales rose even faster, the Commerce Department reported today.

Bewildered and terrified the Biharis of Bangladesh are huddled in tents at packed camps around cities and ports They are dispossessed. "We have nothing, we are nothing," said a 20-year-old student, Mokhtar Hussain pounding his fist on a table in the camp at Mohammedpur north of Dacca. "We sit idle Who wants. us? No one. No one."

West Germany moved away from the United States dollar as its monetary measuring stick for the mark today and indicated that it expected Washington to acknowledge this step in a new arrangement to support the American currency.

A six-candidate field shaped up yesterday for the Democratic nomination for City Controller, a job more powerful than its unromantic public image might suggest. State Senator Harrison J. Goldin of the Bronx, considerably cooler than four years ago when his advertisements in the Controller campaign blared that was "the young dynamo," announced his candidacy to become the second Democrat officially in the race.

Pupil attendance in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn showed its biggest one-day gain yesterday since white parents began boycotting the area's eight schools on March 1 to protest the busing-in of children from another community. Officials of Community School District 18, which includes Canarsie, said 1,694 pupils showed up for classes yesterday, 173 more than on Tuesday. However, 8,042 pupils were absent at the eight schools.

The Government has begun to allocate some of its own offshore oil, so-called royalty oil, to refiners in the Middle West in an effort to avert a shortage of diesel fuel on the farm. Such a shortage could nudge farm prices upward, officials fear.

Struggling for a berth in the World Hockey Association playoffs, the Raiders struck early and late last night for a 5-1 rout over the Houston' Aeros. It was the next-to-last home game of the regular season for the New Yorkers, who close out their Madison Square Garden competition tonight against the Los Angeles Sharks.
During the night of May 25, 1969, the Premier of the Sudan, Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub, was awakened by his wife who told him that a military coup was taking place against him.

Robert T. Connor, Borough President of Staten Island and a lifelong Republican, switched to the Democratic party yesterday, and announced that he would seek its nomination for re-election.

For Con Edison 1973 is a milestone. It is the 150th anniversary of the founding of our corporate ancestor, the New York Gas Light Co., which in 1823 was chartered to provide gas service to lower Manhattan.

Westchester County Democrats tonight designated Mayor Alfred B. DelBello of Yonkers to ruri for County Executive. Mayor DelBello and the rest of the county slate were all designated by acclamation at a convention that presented a sharp contrast to the bitterly divided Republican county convention held three nights ago in the same hall here.

An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pursued a suspected bank robber and his girlfriend into an apartment complex today and was mortally wounded in a gunfight. The agent, Gregory Spinelli, 24 years old, died at Charlotte Memorial Hospital several hours after the gunfight, the bureau said. He had been shot in the head.

The comprehensive health center of Mound Bayou, an allblack town in Mississippi, is in trouble again and faces a cutoff of Federal funds. For the second time in a year, the fate of the center is in the hands of the head of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

Multimedia, Inc., said yesterday it intends to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 500,000 shares of its common stock, of which 100,000 shares will be sold by the company and the remainder by present stockholders.
A tired band of Raiders was easy prey for the Los Angeles Sharks last night. The New Yorkers bowed, 6-2 and, unwittingly, took a step in solving their playoff dilemma.
Third-period goals by Carol Vadnais, Phil Esposito and Bobby Orr sparked the. Boston Bruins to a 4-1 National Hockey League victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

The head of the New York Stock Exchange urged Congress today to require that brokerdealer commissions be determined by competitive negotiations and that members of all national securities exchanges be required to execute only public orders.

Pete McNab scored three goals and had three assists today in leading Denver University to a 10-4 victory over Boston College and a berth in the finals of the National Collegiate hockey tournament at Boston Garden.

With the exception of a few mutants such as "Martha" and "L'Elisir d' Amore," operas are infamous for the enthusiasm with which they explore the dark underside of the human soul (if you will allow so blurbwriterly an expression).

A 36-year-old Fire Department lieutenant who invented a device that can open most locked doors within a minute, and who has sold his device to more than 100 cities, cannot sell it to New York City because he is a city employee.

Sargent Shriver made public today a plan for ending poverty in the United States that he said he had given to President Johnson in 1966. Mr. Shriver said the plan had become a "casualty of the war in Vietnam."

One woman was killed and at least 26 persons injured, one critically, as a four-car Long Island Rail Road passenger train overshot the station here and smashed into a parked freight locomotive in a staging yard.
The United States and the Soviet Union will stage their second annual indoor track and field meet tonight in the Richmond Coliseum.

Bache Co., Inc., citing "tremendous inflationary pressures" on its business, reported yesterday a substantial profit decline for its latest fiscal year. Earnings for the year ended Jan. 31 fell to $7,341,000, or $1.01 a share, from the previous year's $12,322,630, or $1.88 a share. Revenues, however, showed a slight gain to $180,032,449 from $179,977,204.
South and North Korea, meeting for the first time this year in talks aimed at eventual reunification of their two countries, disagreed today on how to start the way to a single Korea.

Officials of the Smithsonian Institution told a House Appropriations subcommittee today that construction claims against the controversial Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden might increase the cost of the building by $4.6-million.

The Soviet Union has urged that the Nobel Peace Prize be given to President Tito of Yugoslavia. An article in Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, said the chairman of the Soviet Peace Committee, Nikolai Tikhonov, has written to the Nobel Committee, endorsing Western European support for the Yugoslav President.

He sits and swivels, cranks himself higher and lower, sometimes even lowers the back rest and reclines. In an old barber chair transported to the top floor of his brownstone, Al Hirschfeld is master of all he surveys on 95th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

Lieut. Gen Tran Van Tra, the chief Vietcong delegate to the truce commission, said tonight that "Americans were good soldiers, but they fought the wrong war." "They did not have the ideals our soldiers had," he added.

A United States Air Force hospital plane took off from Hanoi today with 32 American prisoners of war freed by the Vietcong. The Vietcong turned over 27 military men and five civilians shortly after noon at Hanoi's Gia Lam Airport. They then boarded a C-141 for the trip to the Philippines.

Lower Federal courts have had many cases involving the three-year-old National EnviTonmental Policy Act. Now a case that has reached the Supreme Court bears on two issues so important that the outcome could decide the future effectiveness of the act.
The official spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry said today that a proposal by Premier Kakuei Tanaka for a new Asian peace organization was a suggestion without any substance behind it yet.
West German Chancellor Willy Brandt disclosed today that President Nixon had told him the United States would contribute to an international compromise to support the dollar.

The five Presidents of the United States since World War II might have' found it difficult to agree on a number of things, especially in the conduct of foreign affairs. But when it came to the selection of a man to be trusted with a critical job, all five chose David Kirkpatrick

Two huge rivers of air flowed capriciously astray this winter. The result, according to government weathermen, was snow in the South, frequent mild temperatures in the North and other unseasonal weather in the nation.
Dr. Jan Librach, executive director of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America, author and former Polish diplomat, died Wednesday at his home here. His age was 69.
The City Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday passed a record $2.24-billion capital budget for 1973-74 and Mayor Lindsay immediately approved it.

John W. Dean 3d, the White House legal counsel who declined yesterday to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee, has also been invited to testify before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. But the reasons for the two invitations appear to be opposite.
The Bronx police arrested two men last night who they said had terrorized as many as 15 households in the Sounndview area over the last five months in predawn burglaries.

The New York Times, through its publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, has asserted ownership of the notes and files of one of its reporters, subpoenaed by the Committee for the Re-election of the President.

Providence and Maryland exploited the fast break for short spurts to beat Pennsylvania and Syracuse, respectively, tonight and move to the East Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

Theodore C. Sorensen, counsel to former President Kennedy, told the Pentagon papers trial today that when he left the White House he took with him many Government documents. The implication was that he then used 'those documents as material for the books he wrote about the Kennedy years and for articles he wrote on foreign affairs.

President Nixon said yesterday that he had expressed "concern" to Hanoi about the movement of military equipment into South Vietnam, and he warned the North Vietnamese not to take his words lightly. The president's warning, at an unscheduled news conference, was interpreted as a threat to resume bombing if the build-up continues.

The New Jersey Attorney General's office charged yesterday that the three largest auto companies in the nation were violating state and Federal antitrust laws by conspir,ing to raise the price of autos sold to the state and all other governmental purchasers. The charge was contained in a complaint filed in United States District Court here against the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.

Jerry Koosman continued his comeback bid for a spot in the Mets' starting rotation today by pitching five strong innings against the Dodgers and starting a four-run fifth inning that enabled him to gain credit for a 6-5 victory.

New Jersey may have to impose restrictions on automobile use unless it revises its proposed Automotive pollution levels to meet standards required by the Federal Government by 1975, Federal and state environmental officials warned today.

H. Ross Perot, the Texas millionaire who, with some associates, controls the stock brokerage house of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., drew some astonished gasps yesterday at the New York Society of Security Analysts when he disclosed the headline of another in a series of studiously homespun ads that he has reportedly designed himself.

The Yankees won their fourth straight game hee tonight, defeating the Minnesota Twins, 6-0, before 3,670 fans. The shutout, first of the spring for the Yanks, brought their exhibition won-lost record to 7-2.

The men who hammered out baseball's three-year peace treaty put too much time and effort into the job to let one man's arrogance and another's stupidity ruin it all. Otherwise, Leo Durocher, the practically peerless leader of the Houston Astros, and Spec Richardson, the Houston general manager, might be taking bows for one of the clumsiest efforts at sabotage this side of Watergate. A new force has arisen on the monetary scene - the power of oil money in North Africa and the Middle East. JERUSALEM--The executioners of Khartoum are of the same mental make as the assassins in the streets of Belfast. They are not alone in the world. They are part of the new international amuck-runners disguised as freedom-fighters, presented by perverted publicity as glamorous guerrillas, idolized by a disoriented community of alienated adolescents.
The Connecticut Senate, which never got to a vote on the women's rights Constitutional amendment last year because the House rejected the proposal, ratified the amendment today, 27 to 9.

Your average disk jockey, with the endless circle of programing the same "top 40" hit recordings that marks much of today's radio music, is probably suffering some kind of identify crisis, reduced as he is to a disembodied voice relating time, temperature and traffic conditions in the Holland Tunnel.
Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.
President Nixon voiced concern today about the movement of North Vietnamese military equipment toward South Vietnam and said Hanoi should not "lightly disregard" his words.

The sedate and prosperous British colony of Bermuda, sunlit islands in the Atlantic favored by nature, tourists and wealthy expatriates, is one of the last places in the world that one might expect the kind of mad political violence that has afflicted much of the rest of mankind lately.

New Jersey faces rationing of electric power within three years unless some method of controlling demand or increasing energy sources is found, William E. Ozzard, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, warned today.

A group of top executives from television, radio and outof-state newspapers ended a whirlwind tour of city officials and agencies yesterday, sitting around a table in Gracie Mansion and conveying favorable comments to the Mayor.
The National Education Association announced yesterday the appointment of Terry E. Herndon, executive director of its Michigan affiliate, as executive secretary of the national organization.
The president of the Ford Foundation has denied an assertion by the Central Intelligence Agency that New York City policemen were trained by the agency at the suggestion of the foundation.

As the H. Rap Brown trial ended its ninth week yesterday, State Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman threw out several sections of the 24-count indictment against the black militant and three co-defendants.

SYDNEY, Australia - During its brief history Australia swung from total dependence on Britain to heavy reliance on America. Now it is starting an experiment with independent nationalism. But it is less likely than imagined by some enthusiasts that a pseudo-isolationist move can long endure for, from its birth, this country has been sharply influenced by faroff events.

A Vatican scholar came out today against what he termed Italy's "archeological patriotism" and suggested that it should be made easier for foreign institutions to acquire legally and display ancient treasures dug up in this country.

Sea Bird, who swept the 1965 horse racing season in Europe with victories in the Epsom Derby and Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe and went on to become a leading sire, died of an day intestinal blockage at a stud farm in Western France today.

Of the 348 teams that started play in the New Jersey high school basketball tournament, only 14 remain-eight public school teams and six parochial school squads. The 14 teams will compete tomorrow and Sunday at Princeton's Jadwin gymnasium for seven state championships. LEACOCK, a retrospective of doucmentary films by Ricky Leacock, at the Film Forum, 256 West 88th Street.

Obviously, the Paris couture has given up its flirtation with the jeans and T-shirt crowd. Instead of such things as tie-dyes and patches, there are honest-togoodness real clothes. Coats instead of ponchos and blankets. Dresses, alone and with jackets. Even bona fide suits.

Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, has killed a department plan to distribute to public schools and colleges a controversial film advocating legalized abortion, it was learned today.

Two men were arrested today on charges of operating what the police called a slave labor camp for 27 migrant farm workers. "They were working against their will and were being held as slaves," one Dade County detective said.
Heinz Ullstein, a member of the third generation of Germany's Ullstein book-publishing family, died today after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

At least eight of the enlisted men scheduled to return early tomorrow from Hanoi are known to be bitter critics of the Vietnam war whose refusal to participate in camp life in North Vietnam provoked deep hostility among their fellow prisoners, according to military sources.

Twelve schools qualified all three of their fencers today for the final round of the National Collegiate championships at Johns Hopkins University. In all, 72 competitors, 24 in each of the three weapons epee, foil and sober, advanced to the round-robin to be held tomorrow and Saturday.
Senate Democrats today overwhelmingly approved a resolution urging President Nixon to bring home many of the 600,000 United States servicemen stationed around the world.
Eight nonaligned members of the disarmament conference here protested sharply today to the United States and the Soviet Union over the absence of "tangible progress."
With breezes freshening and skippers gambling, the Class A fleet began accelerating today on close reaches in the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race.

The Bangor Punta Corporation, a diversified holding company, announced yesterday that it had received an offer from the Ethyl Corporation to purchase 2 million shares of Bangor Punta's newly issued common stock at $15.50 a share, for a total consideration of $31-million.
Indiana, sparked by Steve Downing and John Ritter, defeated Marquette, 75-69, tonight and advanced to the final of the National Collegiate Mideast Regional basketball tournament.

AUDIO WITH VISION Radio station WBAI is going to capitalize on television this weekend. The listening medium is harnessing the looking medium for a video benefit to raise funds for WBAI. President Nixon emphatically rejected today the idea of putting controls on prices paid to farmers for their products, including meat. He also ruled out putting absolute ceilings on wholesale and retail food prices.

The City University chancellor, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, warned yesterday that if the City University followed the recommendations of a state task force and began charging tuition, the flight of middleclass families from the city would accelerate and racial an??agonisms would deepen.

The Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of the penal law providing that a person who sells obscene material in the course of his business "is presumed to do so with knowledge of its content or character."
Seven members of what the police called a youthful Chinese extortion gang were taken into custody yesterday by policemen n a stakeout as they allegedly accepted money from one of their victims.

The auction of the personal and gallery collection of American paintings and sculpture of the late Edith G. Halpert ended yesterday with receipts of $3,670,675, a total that has art dealers and collectors agog over the prospect of a significant new market in several decades of American art following World War I.

Satyajit Ray's "Days and Nights in the Forest" began a commercial engagement yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, at 60th Street. The Indian-made import was previously shown here once as an entry in the New York Film Festival in 1970.
President Nixon announced today that he had recalled Ambassador David K. E. Bruce from retirement to head a United States liaison office in Peking.

The three-day down-the-limit declines in soybeans futures came to an end yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. May soybeans, which dropped from $6.48 last Friday to $6.03 Wednesday, rose the 15-cent daily limit to close at $6.18. One factor was higher prices for soybean meal in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art signed a contract yesterday with the Louvre in Paris for the purchase of a medieval ivory comb. The purchase is believed to mark the first time in history that two of the world's greatest museums have bought a work of art for joint ownership.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., in an attempt to clarify an earlier statement, repeated his opposition today to the construction of a deep water oil port proposed by the Army Corps of Engineers off the New Jersey coast.

It has been a good week for women on television. Last night, Lauren Bacall. Tonight, Marlo Thomas and Lily Tomlin. Miss Thomas, perhaps best known as the cutesy-poo heroine of a forgettable series called "That Girl," has an hour, beginning at 9 P.M., on the American Broadcasting Company.

Elliot Young is the kind of fellow who really keeps his eye on the ball, or rather on the eyeball. His working days are spent watching what people are watching. There are worse things, and besides, some folk are paying money for the service.

A spate of selling moved into the stock market yesterday and sent prices tumbling in relatively light trading. The market tried to rise in the morning, but gave up the effort just before noon, sank rapidly in late trading and closed with fairly substantial losses.

Johnny Miller conquered the pressure of playing head to head with Jack Nicklaus, scored a six-under-par 66 and took the first-round lead today in the $130,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.
Arthur Wright, former managing editor of The TimesReporter, published here and in Bellows Falls, died yesterday ?fter a long illness. He was 53 rears old.

The Albany Medical Center has announced that a female health technician who said she had been subjected to "physical annoyance" two weeks ago by four Democratic Assemblymen undergoing free heart tests had accepted an apology on their behalf from Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, Democratic minority leader.

President Nixon's stated intention to sell a part of the nation's stockpiles of strategic commodities evoked amusement in the cash metals market, nervousness among speculators in materials for future delivery and anger among producers of the affected items.
One woman was killed tonight and 24 people were injured, three of them critically, when a Long Island passenger train smashed into a halted freight train here shortly before 9 P.M.

A study group appointed by Governor Rockefeller recommended yesterday that the state take over and sharply limit the activities of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation on the ground that OTB may "kill" the horse racing industry in the state.
Pre-tax book profits of corporations rose $6.2-billion in the fourth quarter of 1972 to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $101.9-billion, the commerce Department reported today.

Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none). ****La Goulue, 28 East 70th Street, 988-8169.
Joey Heatherton, the actress, has sued Playboy magazine for $2-million, charging that the publication invaded her privacy and unlawfully used a photograph showing her partly nude.

The French police arrested two men with Jordanian passports today in a car with 35 pounds of plastic explosive. The two were quoted as saying they were on their way for a bomb attack on the Jordanian Embassy.

To check rising industrial prices, the President has decided to sell large quantities of metals and other commodities out of the Government's strategic stockpile. As Mr. Nixon noted in his press conference yesterday, there are going to be "some squeals"-alleging damage to national security-from those who produce and sell to the stockpile, but the President rightly insists that the Government's hoards can be safely reduced to support the fight against inflation.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd. increased its quarterly profit for the first time in more than a year in the final quarter, reflecting a recovery in prices and general improvement in demand, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15-Following is the transcript of President Nixon's news conference today as issued by the White House: OPENING STATEMENT Be seated, please. Ladies and gentlemen, I have an announcement with regard to our liaison office in Peking.

Fire has destroyed 144 decorative panels by the painter Marc Chagall in this Riviera village, the police reported today. The fire, in a workshop housing the panels, which were to be installed next year as a huge fresco in the head office of First National City Bank in Chicago, may have been arson, the police said. The blaze occurred on Tuesday.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, supported by 73 other Senators, today reopened a Congressional drive to block a trade agreement with the Soviet Union until Moscow reduces its exit fees so that Jews and others can freely emigrate.

New Jersey homeowners, businesses and industries face the rationing of electric power within three years unless some method of controlling demand or increasing energy sources is found, according to William E. Ozzard, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

Two youths splattered a Soviet diplomat with red paint last night as was walking on East 72d Street, the police said. They added that the diplomat was uninjured, He was identified as Germon Kosenkov, second secretary o the Soviet Mission at the United Nations.
" Ed Sullivan's Broadway" is a flashy, splintery tribute to both Mr. Sullivan and Broadway, due for beaming at 8:30 tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
The Adolph Coors Brewing Company of Golden, Colo., may soon lay to rest the ubiquitous and environmentally hazardous fliptop of a beverage can.

More than half a million dollars was raised for the New York University Medical Center last night at a dinner at which the hosts were Mrs. Arthur D. Leidesdorf, who was Miss Israel in 1960, and Dr. James M. Hester, president of N.Y.U.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market continued to decline yesterday in light trading. Most analysts expect the lack of interest in the market to continue until investors have a better idea of how the new monetary float in Europe is going to work.
Since the kidnapping of her 5-day-old son by a hammerwielding assailant at noon on Jan. 3 in Harlem, Nanny Lee Armstrong, has moved to a new home in Brooklyn.

The Canadian Minister of External Affairs, Mitchell W. Sharp, arrived today on the first leg of an inspection trip to decide whether Canada should continue participation in the International Commission of Control and Supervision, the four-nation body charged with keeping the peace in Vietnam.
The Adolph Coors-Brewing Company of Golden, Colo., may soon lay to rest the ubiquitous and environmentally hazardous fliptop of a beverage can.

Marilyn Cochran of richmond, Vt., tossed aside caution on a steep run and won the women's giant slalom, and Jean-Noel Augert of France scored an impressive triumph on the men's slalom course in World Cup races today.
With breezes freshening and skippers gambling, the Class A fleet began accelerating today on close reaches in the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race.

The new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday called for important changes in the operations of the nation's stock exchanges to provide better investment opportunities for the public.

Short-term interest rates took another leap upward yesterday as the banking system continued to mobilize funds to meet soaring demands upon it. Banks were reported paying 7.20 to 7.25 per cent when writing 89-day certificates of deposit yesterday, up another five to 10 basis points from

Jurgen Fassbender dropped the first set 4-6, but stormed back to take the next two sets, 6-1, 6-4, against Clark Graebner to win the $3,000 singles prize in the National Indoor open tennis championships.

The United States formally presented its claims for compensation of trade losses in Britain, Denmark and Ireland to the European Common Market today. Herbert Propps, assistant special trade representative of President Nixon, raised the United States demands in the first of a series of meetings with the European Economic Community to renegotiate its external tariffs after the admission of the three countries.
Ludwig V. Kleinwachter, who was Austrian Ambassador to the United States in' 1951-52, capping a foreign-service career of more than 40 years, died Monday in Vienna. His age was 91.

Representatives of business and labor sharply criticized today the Governor's proposal to abolish the State Board of Standards and Appeals and empower- the State Industrial Commissioner to promulgate and enforce safety and health standards for industry.

President Nixon emphatically rejected today the idea of putting controls on prices paid to farmers for their products, including meat. He also ruled out putting absolute ceilings on wholesale and retail food prices.

The proposed Convention Center is the key to one of the most potentially dynamic development areas of Manhattan: the midtown West Side. With the adjacent new ship terminal, it is the beginning of realistic reconstruction of the entire area in the West Forties from the river to Eighth Avenue.
A famous New York team was in trouble this afternoon in the third round of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.
The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston today formally announced the appointment of Merrill C. Rueppel as its new director. Mr. Rueppel, who is 47 years old, is director of the Dallas Museum of Fine Arts.

Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff released today a study of one facet of the Corvair controversy concluding that General Motors Executives had not misled a Congressional investigation in 1966 as Ralph Nader had charged.

India has stopped further purchases of sorghum grain from the United States because of the "sad experience" in which poisonous seeds were found in a shipment of the grain, an official of the Food Ministry said here today.

To the Editor: In your March 3 issue President Nixon is reported as comparing opposition to American reconstruction assistance to Hanoi with post-World War II opposition to aid to Germany and Japan, while Flora Lewis gives reasons for Hanoi's ruling out an internationalized aid mechanism.

Dr. Howard Hathaway Aiken, who in the late nineteen-thirties conceived the design for the world's first large-scale computer, the Mark I, in cooperation with engineers of the International Business Machines Corporation, died in his sleep early Wednesday on a visit to St. Louis. He was 73 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
The unusually mild winter has proved to be a windfall for the government officials who pay the bills for snow removal. But for skiers and the people who sell ski equipment, it has been a disaster.

One man was killed and three persons were injured when a tornado raked across the northern section of White County in Eastern Tennessee early today. Most of the state was hit by severe thunderstorms and heavy rains.

The City Council approved yesterday without dissent a bill to require pharmacies to post prices of prescription drugs-a move consumer activists feel could save families with heavy medicine costs hundreds of dollars a year.

Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican of New York, has proposed a four-point program to deal with the nation's energy crisis. In an address to the Economic Club of New York on Wednesday evening, Senator Buckley warned against increased dependence on foreign sources of petroleum.

Astate commission studying eminent domain today recommended a "new uniform procedure to aid property owners" whose land is seized for public purposes and to eliminate the present "maze of conflicting procedures" that work to a property owner's detriment.

Mrs. Virginia Hogg of New Brighton, a marriage counselor, was married here this afternoon to Bruce B. Dayton, board chairman of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, a department store chain and real estate conglomerate with outlets in 30 states.
The guerrilla underground ended a five-week truce during the night, blowing up two police stations and throwing bombs at the homes of seven policemen.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 148.9 from 148.4 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 114.2 on March 14. 1972.
A predawn service in a Buddhist pagoda in the Mekong Delta was shattered today by a series of explosions that killed at least 17 people and wounded more than 80.
