A Federal warrant was issued yesterday for a 27-year-old citizen of Iraq suspected of being a member of the Black September terrorist organization and charged with planting a bomb in an automobile parked next to the El Al Israeli Airlines terminal warehouse at Kennedy International Airport.

The chief Federal negotiator trying to end the Indians' occupation of Wounded Knee suddenly left for Washington today to confer with officials of the Justice and Interior Departments. He is expected to return here tomorrow.
The Nixon Administration is considering a plan to expedite widespread abandonment of money-losing Northeastern rail routes, including many of the Penn Central.

Chic Young, creator of the comic strip "Blondie," died Wednesday night of a pulmonary embolism at the Apollo Medical Center in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 72 years old and had been in ill health for some time, remaining near his home in Clearwater, Fla.
The Federal Home Loan Bank board said today net new savings received in February were $1.6-billion compared with $2.7-billion in February, 1972, a decline of $1.1billion.
A Correction Department guard captain went on departmental trial yesterday on charges stemming from an investigation into the alleged sale of paroles to inmates at Rikers Island.

President Nixon announced today that he had recalled Ambassador David K. E. Bruce from retirement to head a United States liaison office in Peking. Mr. Nixon said the office would be established about May 1 with a staff of about 20 Americans, 10 of them at the expert level.

Dacapo, a branch of the German Electrola label, has come forth recently with a three-record set of Bruno Walter'sMozart performances from the nineteen-thirties (IC147-50178/80M, $17.94). The price is a bit steep, especially when compared with such domestic reissue labels as Seraphim, Odyssey and Victrola, and it is all the higher now that import distributors have been forced by the dollar's devaluation to raise their prices.
Seaman Apprentice John L. Rowe, convicted of assault and rioting aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk, has been fined $700 and reduced one pay grade.

Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, one of three candidates designated by the Democrats to run for chief judge of the state, is going after the Liberal party nomination, despite an agreement between Liberal party leaders and Republicans that calls for Judge Charles D. Breitel to be the candidate of the two parties.

A methadone maintenance clinic has changed a "peaceful and highly respectable' Yorkville neighborhood into a community of fear, according to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. And as a result, the Attorney General asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to dissolve the corporation operating the clinic and place the facility in the hands of a receiver.
About 120 guards assigned to the morning and afternoon shifts at the state's maximum security prison here refused to work today and were suspended for five days without pay.

President Nixon said today he had determined that "it will be safe for the United States to very substantially reduce" the Government's stockpiles of metals and other supposedly "strategic" materials and added that "we are going to go forward and do that."

A city magistrate dismissed disorderly charges against a small, labor-oriented community newspaper here today, declaring that the paper's constitutional right to a free press overrode police charges that its distribution on the streets was a public nuisance.

Unions and their problems are the subject matter of Emanuel Fried's "Brother Gorski," which opened last night at the Astor Place Theater. It was well-meaning but excessively heavy-going. Mr. Fried's heart is in the right place, but his playwriting isn't.
Superior Court Judge James I. Toscano upheld today the constitutionality of a section of the state's primary election law that had been challenged by insurgent Bergen County Republicans.
Carolyn Bockius Wyeth, widow of the artist N. C. Wyeth and mother of Andrew Wyeth, one of America's best known painters, died today of a heart attack. She was 86 years old.
Although problems of fundamental importance remain, the recently renewed monetary crisis has provoked tangible changes in European and Atlantic relations. It seems to have been a turning point.

There is rarely a sure thing in the market, but a special situation often comes close. That's why some sophisticated investors are now looking at a situation involving the shares of Continental Steel.

Spokesmen for environmental protection groups told the Senate Interior Committee today that the strip mining of coal in the United States, which a Government study has estimated is damaging 4,650 acres a week, would not have become a problem if there had been proper planning.
The new Congress cleared the way today for its first legislative confrontation with President Nixon by giving final approval to a bill that the White House has said would be vetoed.
Dr. Frank N. Elliott, the president of Rider College, said today tha faculty members who voted yesterday to censure him in a dispute on tenure were not aware that they themselves had set the rules.

The Senate, by wide margins, rejected efforts today to repeal the present limits on the size and weight of trucks and buses that use the Interstate system. The Senate then went on to pass an $18-billion, three-year highway construction bill that would allow metropolitan areas to use their share of the money to buy buses or build rapid rail systems.

The Federal Reserve System pumped more than $1-billion into the money market this week in an apparent attempt to stabilize short-term interest rates, the central bank's weekly statement showed yesterday.

Jack Friedman, senior partner in the accounting firm of Friedman, Alpren Green, died Wednesday in New York University Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 325 West End Avenue, and in Miami Beach and Putnam Valley, N.Y.
Justice of the Peace Mulford Winsor 4th said today that there were "a lot of unanswered questions" about the death last Feb. 11 of David A. Whiting, business manager for the actress Sarah Miles.

A study group appointed by Governor Rockefeller recommended yesterday that the state take over and sharply limit the activities of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation on the ground that OTB may "kill" the horse racing industry in the state.
Senators Claiborne Pelf and John O. Pastore, both Rhode Island Democrats, proposed today that daylight saving time be observed the year round.

A radically altered system for taxing commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations is undergoing final review by top Administration policy-makers before being proposed to Congress, probably in a few weeks.

Your children of Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a statement made public yesterday, disassociated themselves completely" from a book written by their brother, Elliott Roosevelt, which says that their father was intimate with a secretary, Marguerite (Missy) LeHand. when he was married to Eleanor Roosevelt.

WE HAVE ALL GONE AWAY. By Curtis Harnack. 188 pages. Doubleday. $6.95. It is one of the paradoxes of American literature that our writers are forever looking back with love and nostalgia at lives they couldn't wait to leave.

The prosecution began calling union organizers and pensioned miners to the stand today in an attempt to link the United Mine Workers and the defeated union president, W. A. Boyle, to what the prosecution contends was payoff money for the Yablonski murders.
The late Irvin S. Cobb is said to have described Union Station of St. Louis as one of the two ugliest structures created by man, the other being the derby hat.

The Most Rev. Edward L. Fedders, a Maryknoll missioner from Covington, Ky., died of a heart attack Sunday as he conducted mass in Pomata, a small community in the Juli prelature of Peru. He was 59 years old and had served in Peru for 29 years.
The Connecticut Senate, which never got to a vote on the women's rights Constitutional amendment last year because the House rejected the proposal, ratified the amendment today. 27 to 9.

This no man's town is too quiet. "Go back," shout two Government soldiers 50 yards up the road. Come back, the motorbike driver beckons, threatening to leave alone. He points across a meadow to where he used to live with his family of six, now dead, killed by American soldiers, March 16, 1968.

News Distributors, Inc., and Local 259 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters signed tonight a new contract that cleared the way for regular delivery of The New York Times and The Christian Science Monitor in the Boston area, a spokesman for the distributor said.
A parade on Fifth Avenue to honor veterans of the Vietnam war will be held Saturday, March 31, it was announced yesterday by the Home With Honor Committee, which is sponsoring the event.

Geraldo Rivera, the lawyerturned-newsman who has attained star status in local television, returned to WABC-TV's nightly "Eyewitness News" show last night after the settlement of what he called "a censorship dispute" with his employers.
President Nixon voiced concern today about the movement of North Vietnamese military equipment toward South Vietnam and said Hanoi should not "lightly disregard" his words.

The Philippines has notified its allies in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations that the renewed Moslem rebellion in its southern island of Mindanao is being assisted by foreign-trained troops bearing foreign-made arms.

Panama today denounced the United States presence in the Canal Zone as "neocolonialism" and warned that if peaceful change was not permitted in Latin America, Latins would be forced "to carry out violent changes."

John Cardinal Carberry, Archbishop of St. Louis, pledged $20,000 yesterday in support of a fight against liberalized abortion laws. Cardinal Carber ry announced the contribution at an organization meeting of the Archdiocesan Pro Life Committee.
The Nixon Administration is considering a plan to expedite widespread abandonment of money-losing Northeastern rail routes, including many of the Penn Central.
An explosion of unknown origin last midnight leveled an Offtrack Betting Corporation parlor and a Strauss auto-supply store on Jamaica Avenue in Quens Village.

In his first appearance in Harlem since he announced last Wednesday that he would not seek re-election, Mayor Lindsay told a meeting of 200 that he wished he had done more during his eight years in office but that the housing, education and crime situations were "better than they were before" he took office.

Mark Twain's "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" is not the great American novel that "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" is, but it is the great American book for boys, especially those who grow up in a rural Middle West where one has to manufacture the kind of local history and folklore that boys in the East, South and Far West take for granted.

Manette van Hamel is a happy woman these days. Her husband, Diederik, retired last fall as the Netherlands Consul General in New York and that means she finally has found enough time to devote to her sculpture-to-wear jewelry.
The dollar weakened today after strengthening earlier in the week, but the reason had less to do with the international monetary crisis than with a single company's need for dollars.

Weeb Ewbank, coach and general manager of the New York Jets, went shopping yesterday for a permanent inseason practice field for his football team. He was shown a possible site on the grounds of the Nassau County water pollution control plant in South Oyster Bay by Ralph Caso, county executive.
An Opposition member of the deactivated Northern Ireland Parliament, Patrick O'Hanlon, 28 years old, was arrested by the British Army in Newry today and accused of throwing stones at soldiers.
To most of the 17,663 fans at Aqueduct yesterday, the reports of the Delafield Commission might have been relegated to the "couldn't-care-less" category.
A famous New York team was in trouble this afternoon in the third round of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.
The Cambodian command announced today that Government forces had managed to push the front line south of the capital to a point 18 miles from the city.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner promised yesterday to announce no later than "early next week" whether he would run for his old office this year on the Republican and Liberal lines-and dropped a hint that he would insist on his own terms.

The Delafield Commission report issued yesterday doesn't promise any winners for New York's horseplayers, but it does promise them a new deal. After years of legislative indifference, neglect and contempt, ontrack handicappers may benefit

Farmers intend to plant 7.2 per cent more corn and 14.5 per cent more soybeans this year, crops that figure heavily in the Nixon Admipistration's strategy to curb the rise in food prices, the Agriculture Department said today.

Leaders of New York City's higher-education community attacked proposals to impose tuition at the City University of New York as an unfair double tax on city residents that would hasten the departure of the middle-class

Belle Marie, the evenmoney favorite, won the $54,300 Santa Susana stakes by five lengths over Tallahto today at Santa Anita. The winner, ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., returned $4, $2.40 and $2.40 for $2 across the board.

It seldom happens in these hairy youthful days that anybody chooses a wise old gentleman for a critical job, but President Nixon has done it again by picking David Kirkpatrick Este Bruce of Virginia to be the first official U.S. representative to the Communist Government of China.
President Nixon today defended the resumption of arms sales to Pakistan as the fulfillment of contractual commitments made before the India-Pakistan war of 1971.

Governor Cahill's bill that would create a New Jersey Transit Authority empowered to use surplus toll-road revenues for mass-transportation programs will be introduced when the Legislature returns Monday.
A Southern University coed who gave birth to a baby on an airliner was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on an attempted murder charge resulting from the birth.

Government officials say that the army's security agency has uncovered small secret organizations sympathetic to the Chinese Communists on two university campuses. In mid-February, during the college registration period, the agency, the Taiwan Garrison Command, took into custody about five students from Cheng Kung Provincial University in the southern city of Tainan, and two students, two faculty members, and a recent graduate from National Taiwan University in Taipei.

Doug Roberts scored in the final minute to. give the Boston Bruins a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight. The victory put the Bruins alone in second place in the East Division 2 points ahead of the New York Rangers.

Republican resistance to a Republican-Liberal nomination of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner for the mayoralty spread yesterday as Vincent F. Albano of Manhattan, the party's senior county leader in the city, declared that he would fight for a Republican rather than Mr. Wagner as the candidate for mayor.

TALLEYRAND. A Biography By J. F. Bernard 653 pages, G. P., Putnam's Sons. $12.95. No writer of historical fiction would have the audacity to create a character like Talleyrand. No one would have the courage to place him so continuously in the center of momentous events.

Xuan Thuy, head of the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, today brushed aside warnings by President Nixon about North Vietnamese troop and equipment infiltrations into the South in violation of the peace Agreement.
The Shah of Iran announced today that Western oil companies had "surrendered totally" and handed over "full control" of oil operations to Iran.
The Vietcong charged today that the United States was shipping war material into South Vietnam, bypassing the inspection required by the cease-fire agreement.
A military police detail yesterday removed classified material to a Government installation after an explosion and fire had demolished three commercial buildings in Queens Village.
Old crop soybeans-the soybeans that will be delivered before the new crop is harvested next fall-fell the daily limit of 15 cents a bushel yesterday in all deliveries, May through September.

Every year, the Bronx High School of Science leads the city in the number of Regents Scholarship winners, and this year wasn't any different. At least 539 seniors--about three fourths of its graduating class-will have the state scholarships, which are worth between $600 for one year and $1,000 for four years at a college within New York State.
Here in southern Florida, where the neon sprawl of Miami yields grudgingly to the state's big fertile plantations, the black field crew boss is a kind of king.

Plans to build a new orthopedic institute were announced yesterday by the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Medical Center and Beth Israel Medical Center. The projected 25-story, $50-million facility, to be known as the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopedic Institute, will be at 17th Street and Second Avenue on the Beth Israel Medical Center campus.
The Meadow Stable's Secretariat, worth $6,080,000 according to the terms of his recent syndication, will make his first start of the season today.
Shelley Hamlin shot a four-under-par 68 today in 30-mile-an-hour winds to take the first-round lead in the $25,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Orange Blossom tournament.
Mrs. Anne Souders, Who became a celebrated center of controversy after going to jail rather than pay what she considered an unfair fine, was released today after appealing for a new trial.

A few weeks before the elections here, a senior Argentine diplomat mulled over the prospects of a new Peronist government during a leisurely lunch at an outdoor restaurant. "Any government, even a Peronist, government, will have to be moderate," he said.

Nick Mileti, who owns the Cleveland Indians of the American League, the Cava.liers of the National Basketball Association and the Crusaders of the World Hockey Association, is continuing to branch out.

The Administration has rescinded the offer by L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to open the F.B.I.'s files on the Watergate case to all members of the Senate, Congressional sources said today.

The Nixon Administration today strongly opposed a call endorsed by Senate Democrats yesterday for a substantial reduction in military forces abroad. The Administration arguments were not new, but the vehemence of the reaction indicated that the question could become a major one between the White House and the Democratic majority in the Senate.

To study the future of thoroughbred and harness racing and the OTB in New York State, Governor Rockefeller last year named a commission with Charles B. Delafield, a former investment banker and retired vice president and treasurer of Consolidated Edison, as chairman.
The acting Commissioner of Education, John R. Ottina, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating some contracts awarded by the Office of Education.
Cut glass, that status symbol to millions bf punchdrinking, relish-eating Americans at the turn of the century, is making a glittering comeback on sideboards from coast to coast.

The appointment yesterday of David K. E. Bruce to head a United States liaison office here has strengthened speculation that Mr. Bruce's counterpart in Washington twill be Chang Wen-chin, one of Premier Chou En-lai's principal foreign-policy advisers.
The Nixon Administration urged Congress today to authorize $300-million in new Federal loan guarantees to finance continued rehabilitation of the nation's passenger train system.
Two contracts total ing more than $31-million have been awarded to the electric boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation for over hauling nuclear submarines.

Chimney Rock, a towering limestone landmark that rose hundreds of feet and guided pioneers across the Oklahoma prairie, lay crumbled at the bottom of Cimarron River Canyon today, apparently the victim of time and recent high winds.

" I just thought it would be like following St. Peter and the Pope into heaven." That's the way Walter G. Halpin described today his appreciation of the electoral lift he got from running on the same primary ballot line with Senator Clifford P. Case and former Representative Florence Dwyer in 1966.

Florence Calvert Thorne, For many years director of research of the American Federation of Labor, died today. She was 95 years old. Miss Thorne organized a research staff under William Green, then president of. the federation, in 1926, using volunteer workers at the outset.
Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

Leaders of Mailers Union No. 6 made a new economic proposal yesterday to the city's three major newspapers in an effort to obtain a contract settlement before the present agreement terminates at midnight March 30.

The dollar moved sharply higher in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday in reaction to the agreement among the major industrial powers to mop up some of the excess dollars in the world and assure "orderly" currency dealings in the future.
A detective was reported yesterday to have been badly beaten by men he had under surveillance as suspected of heroin dealers, and kept silent so he would not "blow his cover."

The Securities and Exchange Commission today turned to the United States Court of Appeals in San Francisco after failing in two attempts to obtain a permanent receivership eo liquidate the commodity option dealings of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc.

The South Vietnamese Government will hold new nationwide elections for village councils, reversing a ban put into effect last May during the Communists' spring offensive, a Government spokesman announced today.

Upsets continued in the $15,000 Altamira international tennis championships today. Zeliko Franulovic of Yugoslavia upset. Tomas Koch of Brazil, 6-4, 7-6, and Francois Jauffret of France surprised Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., 6-2, 7-6.
Mrs. Ruth Redmond, whose son, Hugh Francis Redmond, was imprisoned as an American spy for 19 years in China until his reported suicide in 1970, died yesterday at the age of 75.
The Department of Agriculture lists "good buys" for this month and next Besides being good buys, foods marked with "X" are also on the "plentiful" list.
A 10-year plan to increase the nation's fuel supplies and give private industry a bigger stake in solving the energy crisis was proposed today by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington.

Taking command with an 11-0 burst in the last quarter after an 18-point lead had dwindled to 1, the New York Knicks defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 109-98, before a capacity crowd of 17,505 at the Forum tonight.

Queen Elizabeth II opened a new London Bridge today, the third in almost a thousand years. The second one, unable to sustain modern traffic, was pulled down, shipped piece by piece to the United States and rebuilt in Arizona.

Watching Robert Joffrey's ballet company is rather like observing an endangered species. Since the City Center is withdrawing most of its support from the company there no longer seems any point in calling it the City Center Joffrey Ballet.
Harry Leith-Ross, an artist in oil and water-colors noted for his landscapes, died yesterday in a nursing home at Pinesville. His age was 87 and he had lived here almost 40 years.

The editor of North Vietnam's chief newspaper said today that his Government was not hiding any American prisoners and that a search would be started for all the missing and dead as soon as this was possible..
Maj. Floyd J. Thompson of the Army's Special Forces, who spent nine years in captivity, longer than any American military prisoner of war known, was released by the Vietcong in Hanoi today.
The Senate Finance Committee resumed today its usual practice of meeting in secrecy to draft legislation after giving open sessions a short but unproductive trial yesterday.

A resolution by the Oglala Sioux Tribal Council calling for nonresidents -- and specifically members of the National Council of Churches-to be expelled from the Pine Ridge Reservation went into effect today.

A law firm specializing in workmen's compensation claims returned to Federal District Court today to seek a contempt-of-court citation against the State Commission of Investigation and several of its officials.

The police have arrested the third member of a trio of Bronx men charged with terrorizing a neighborhood of the borough With a series ofrape-robberies extending over several months. According to authorities, the men entered apartments in the early-morning hours through fire-escape windows,

Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that the Paris monetary meeting, and the European decisions preceding it, "hive made a constructive contribution to the restoration of orderly conditions in exchange markets."
The United States Justice Department charged the Chicago Fire Department yesterday with discriminatory hiring and promotion practices.
TOKYO--One recent Sunday morning, a long line of people waited for three hours for the opening of an exhibition and spot sale of oil paintings" held in the large hall of a Tokyo hotel.
Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal and other consumer activists in 19 cities called yesterday for a nationwide consumer boycott of meat the first week in April to protest high prices.
South, Vietnamise and American officials say that Communist forces are engaged in a major build-up of supplies and military equipment in this critical border province northwest of Saigon.

Amazingly, Thursday's Carnegie Hall concert by Tom T. Hall, a country singer and song writer who has been around for eight years, was also his first appearance in New York. How the city's supposedly aware promoters and assorted music world wheeler-dealers could miss out on this major musical talent is a sad reflection on all concerned.

The State Board of Higher Education voted yesterday to establish New Jersey's first public school of architecture. It will be administered by the Newark College of Engineering. The 9-to-5 decision came after arguments by officials from Newark College -and Rutgers University, which had also asked the state for authority to administer the school.

The go-between in the killings of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter testified today that he was told that Mr. Yablonski "had to be killed" because he had sold out the United Mine Workers to the nation's largest coal company.

The Indiana Pacers extended their longest winning streak of the season to nine games tonight by turning back the New York Nets, 98-89. They climbed within 3 1/2 games of the Utah Stars in the battle for first place in the American Basketball Association's West Division.
The acting Commissioner of Education, John R. Ottina, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating some contracts awarded by the Office of Education.

Rank Organisation, Ltd., announced yesterday in London it has made a bid for the shares of the Oddenino's Property and Investment Company. The Rank offer values Oddenino's at about [Pound]35.5-million, or $87.33million.

Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan hailed today the recently negotiated 18-month national railroad labor contract, saying its 10.7 per cent increase in wages and benefits for over 500,000 workers in 15 unions "will fall within reasonable guidelines."

A bit of last-minute cooperation yesterday between New York and Connecticut Senators allowed New York's two Senators to escape having to cast a politically difficult vote on the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye, N. Y.,

Communist forces are building up supplies and military equipment in Tay Ninh; a critical border province northwest of Saigon, South Vietnamese and American officials' said yesterday. The Communists, the officials said, have also introduced advanced weapons never seen before in the Tay Ninh area, including Soviet-made 130-mm. artillery, which has a range of nearly 17 miles.

Sheriff's deputies and the Ohio State Patrol arrested a man whom they identified as the Pittsburgh Steelers' defensive tackle, Ernest Holmes, after a manhunt today in which a helicopter pilot was shot and wounded.

The International Controls Corporation, in a move widely expected, signed a consent decree here yesterday to sever itself from a $224-million fraud suit filed against Robert L. Vesco, its former board chairman, and 41 others by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A work stoppage by at least 150 guards at the state's maximum security prison continued for a second day today with no negotiations between corrections officials and the guards' union and no apparent signs of tension or disorder inside.
Among the hundreds of people who crowded into the elegant auction chamber of Sotheby Parke Barnet Galleries earlier this week was a dignified gray-haired man who sat unobtrusively in the second row.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal of mandatory life imprisonment for those trafficking in drugs may, to the untutored eye, seem Draconian. It offers, rather, an occasion for imagination and innovative planning.

A 29-year-old postman seized last night on suspicion of sexually abusing a dozen or more teen-age girls was described by the police as "nearly a twin" of a Queens assistant district attorney who has been accused of similar sex crimes.
Mrs. Virginia Knauer, the President's special assistant for consumer affairs, today issued at Mr. Nixon's behest the Administration's "battle plan" for saving money on food.

The tender by Britishowned Triumph American, Inc., for control of the General Host Corporation announced on Thursday marks the beginning of what some observers believe will be a rush by British companies to acquire control of asset-rich American companies whose shares are selling at depressed prices.
EIRE-BORN It's that day again, St. Patrick's, that is, and what to do about it in addition to observing the time-honored cliches of parades and speechifying?

Hans Hartleb of East Germany took the lead in the Nordic combined at the 75th Holmenkollen ski games by winning the ski jump today. Hartleb, who fell on one jump, had leaps of 286 1/2 and 250 1/2 feet for 224 points. The best two of three jumps count. Franz Keller, West Germany's 1968 Olympic champion, was runner-up with 215.9 points.
If Albert Blakelock (18471919) had been just a little better as a painter, his life could have supplied the raw material for an American legend similar to Vincent Van Gogh's.
The 211th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade. will begin today at noon. The marchers will step off at 44th Street and move up Fifth Avenue, turning east at 86th Street and disbanding at Third Avenue.

Mrs. Betty Ives Chadwick, widow of Arthur Chadwick of Weston, was married here this afternoon to Herbert C. Gstalder. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Shea in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.
Grover C. Washabaugh, athletic director at Westminster College for 24 years and its basketball coach from 1937 to 1955, died yesterday at Jameson Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.
John F. Ward, a former Speaker of the Maine House of Representatives and a former president of the State Senate, died today at the Millinocket Community Hospital. He was 68 years old.
Frederick W. Van Duyne Jr., an investment-consultant; died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday in Sanibel, Fla. He was 69 years old and lived also in West Falmouth, Mass.

John D. MacKenzie, former board chairman and president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, died yesterday in Rochester, Minn. He was 75 years old and had lived in Naples, Fla., since his retiremerit in 1963 after 43 years with the company.

Commonwealth policemen raided the headquarters of the nation's secret service, the Security Intelligence Organization, in Melbourne today. Government sources in the Federal capital, Canberra, said the police were seeking files on Croatian liberation movements operating in Australia.

Industrial production rose strongly again in February and housing starts continued at a high level, Government reports disclosed today. The Federal Reserve Board said the output of the nation's factories,

Ted Turner's yacht, Lightnin, unheard from for almost two days, crossed the finish line first tonight in the 811-mile Miami-to-Montego Bay race. The 39-foot Class C sloop finished at 10:47, New York time, completing the course in 5 days 10 hours 47 minutes 36 seconds.
Dean Witter Co., Inc., reported yesterday a sharp decline i earnings for its second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, citing "generally adverse market conditions" as a key reason.
Following is the text of the communique issued after the 14-nation monetary meeting in Paris today:

Two men who described themselves as unfrocked Byzantine priests were indicted in Federal District Court here today on charges that for years they stole ancient books, atleases and manuscripts from Yale Library to sell to rarebook dealers in New York and Chicago.
Earlier this season Mitchell William Sharp, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, appeared as a piano soloist with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra.

Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited not asset value applicable in the capital shares of dual-purpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices or last over-the counter dollar-to-dollar asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked of the capital shares.

The three-day Eastern Alpine championships began on an abbreviated note on Sugarloaf Mountain today. Because of melting snow, race officials staged a two-run slalom instead of the originally scheduled downhill event.

Edwin J. Gohr, a pioneer in petroleum-process research and a former vice president and director of the Esso Research and Engineering Company, died March 9 in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 785 Park Avenue.

A four-day hearing before the Senate Interior Committee on strip mining reclamation legislation ended today with conservationists urging strict Federal controls and mining industry representatives recommending standards that would not restrict production.

Dana Talafous scored a goal with 33 seconds left in a sudden-death overtime to give Wisconsin a 6-5 victory over Cornell in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey playoff tonight.

President Nixon certainly has every justification for expressing concern over the continuing violations of the Vietnam cease-fire agreements, inasmuch as the "rather serious consequences" he mentioned this week involve not only the truce in Southeast Asia but the stability of the American homefront.
The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York announced yesterday tht half of its executives would move their corporate offices and staffs to Hackensack, N. J., in June.

The three-day Eastern Alpine championships bekan on an abbreviated note on Sugarloaf Mountain today. Because of melting snow, race officials staged a two-run slalom instead of the originally scheduled downhill event.
Henri L. Froy, a 62-year-old investment banker at Abraham Co., Inc., who is trading Wal Street for Switzerland on Apri 1, will start two new careers in the process.

Will Christian Brothers Academy win its third consecutive state title? Will Bishop Eustace continue its amazing play in tournament competition? And, finally, which is the best team, Christian Brothers Academy or Bishop Eustace?
Burlington Northern, Inc., said yesterday it was prepared to enter a joint feasibility study with the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Pacific Railroad on the Milwaukee Road's request

Canceled Accounts, by Harris Green (Doubleday; $5.95). A missing person and Swiss bank accounts. Country Love and Poison Rain, by Peter Tate (Doubleday, $5.95) International intrigue and chemical warfare.

The National General Corporation reported yesterday higher earnings for the fourth quarter and the full year of 1972. The company announced net income of $11.5-million, or $2.27 a share for the quarter, compared with a profit of $5.2million, or 99 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

James W.Walsh, a certified public accountant, died of cancer Wednesday evening at his home, 23 Atlanta Avenue. He was 77 years old. Mr. Walsh, who was retired, had been a partner in Palmer, Walsh Co., since merged into Alexander Grant Co.,

The United States, and 13 other major trading nations agreed today on a loosely formulated package of measures designed to ease the problem bf excess dollars abroad and to assure the reopening of official currency dealings under "orderly conditions" on Monday.

The price of short-term money continued to soar yesterday, with the sharp upward movement of recent weeks accelerated by reports-later deniedthat the United States had agreed to foster higher interest rates in this country as part-of an international financial package negotiated in Europe.

All permanent registered voters are eligible to vote in community school board elections, on May 1. In addition, parents with children enrolled in city public primary schools may register as "parent voters" in the districts where their children are enrolledwhether or not they are already permanently registered voters. But they may vote in only one place.

A bit of last-minute cooperation yesterday between New York and Connecticut Senators allowed New York's two Senators to escape having to cast a politically difficult vote on the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye. N. Y.,

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that a seat sold at $125,000, the lowest price paid for a membership in more than a decade. In July, 1962, near the bottom of a bear market, a seat sold for $115,000.

The Nixon Administration today placed some of the blame for violence by Indians on the Democratic-controlled Congress because it did not pass legislation designed to give the tribes more self-determination and economic autonomy.
South Vietnamese and American officials say that Communist forces are engaged in a major build-up of supplies and military equipment in this critical border province northwest of Saigon.

Approximately 4,000 editors and writers for high school publications throughout the country gathered yesterday on the steps of Low Memorial Library at Columbia University for the second day in a threeday conference on how to improve their publications.

January, 1973--The events that were building toward the biggest monetary crisis since the realignment of international currencies in December, 1971, began during January when Italy, bothered by a weakening lira, decided on a two-tier currency market. The ensuing flight of dollars from Italy to Switzerland caused Swiss authorities to float the franc which in turn sent dollars surging into West Germany.

The pickup games had ended. The courts were deserted. But in the summer humidity, the teen-ager, whom Young had recruited, had been alone for half an hour, jumping and tapping a basketball against a backboard with his right hand, then with his left.

THIS session of Congress seems to be offering real reason to hope for enactment of a Federal law to protect collectors against fraud. Past efforts to obtain legislation prohibiting the manufacture and sale of unmarked replicas usually failed to get beyond the bill-introduction stage.

Even during a normal rush hour, a Tokyo commuter train yields nothing to a sardine can. Before entering a car, a passenger must decide whether he'll ride with arms up or down-there's no room to change position once he's aboard. For eight days, the rush hour had been abnormal; a slowdown called by a railway union had raised havoc with the already overloaded system.

That's why Readers Digest, which branched out into moviemaking with the tuneful "Tom" now at the Music Hall, is preparing to put Little Nell and her dear old Grandaddy through their musical paces.

Any Auden poem is a miscellany; Auden's form is the miscellany. A few years ago he published his Commonplace Book: odd things that had caught his eye, alphabetically arranged. United States intelligence officials in Saigon said yesterday that the Communists had more war supplies in South Vietnam than before their offensive last year, but that their combat units were far below fighting strength. They believe it unlikely that the Communists would attempt a major drive in the immediate future, but are concerned that the large build-up in military equipment could produce a significant increase in the level of fighting.

Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon yesterday sentenced two brothers who own a major Catskills hotel to five-year prison terms for income-tax evasion and castigated them as greedy millionaires who were "no better than a common thief."

Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill intended to wipe out sex from massage parlors. At the same time, enforcement officials geared to cope with anticipated subterfuges to keep prostitution going under the guise of other types of legal businesses.
Soviet-made robots 'will be rolling across the surface of Mars "in the near future," conducting experiments that are beyond.the capability of human explorers, a leading space scientist said today.

The value of the dollar was higher than expected in Tokyo foreignexchange trading today. This was the first full day of trading since the market was closed more than two weeks ago because of the currency crisis.
Mrs. Mildred A. Ridgeway of Houston wept again today for her eldest son, but this time her tears were for joy over his return from five years of Vietcong imprisonment.

It might be argued that this music season has produced more imaginatively planned, more carefully rehearsed and more splendidly played concerts than the one Michael Tilson Thomas conducted for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Sunday evening in Alice Tully Hall.

Returning from a six-day visit to Indochina, Mitchell W. Sharp, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, promised a "very quick" decision today on the issue of keeping Canadian observers on the International Commission of Control and Supervision.

An array of Congressmen, local-government officials and supermarket executives met yesterday to talk about rising food prices and wound up agreeing, more or less, that it is all the Federal Government's fault.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy disclosed yesterday that a special team of detectives was using a computer in its effort to track down the men who had stolen 398 pounds of heroin and cocaine from the Police Department.

Ed Stewart and Jerry Crego of Rochester rolled into fifth place in the doubles standing of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a 1,254 total. Ray Leist of Fort Wayne, Ind., moved into 10th place in singles with 661.

The late Ho Chi Minh would have had to telephone the Defense Department to determine whether one of the "top secret" documents in the Pentagon papers trial was genuine, a defense witness testified today.

Lee A. Packard was named today director of the division of market regulation of the Securities and Exchange Commission in a series of staff appointments announced by G. Bradford Cook, the agency's chairman.

A state fact-finder has recommended a 5.5 per cent raise for state troopers, which would put the top salary, including uniform allowance, at $15,607 a year. The State Troopers Fraternal Association plans an emergency meeting tomorrow night in East Brunswick to consider the recommendations.

WASHINGTON-Secretary of State Rogers has begun a quiet but intensive inquiry into the problem of protecting American ambassadors and their staffs in foreign capitals from the outlaws who, are now terrorizing the diplomatic community.

The Government's Export-Import Bank announced today that agreement had been reached with Soviet officials providing for $202.4-million in United States loans and guarantees for the purchase of American industrial equipment.

DENPASAR, Indonesia -- Russia's costly policy of seeking to purchase dominance in key strategic countries has been just as miserable a failure here in Indonesia, the world's fifthlargest nation, as it seems to have been in Egypt where armaments didn't manage to buy lasting political power,
The Supreme Court ruled today that its one-man, one-vote mandate need not be observed in electing officials of specialpurpose governmental bodies.
Top-seeded Marty Riessen defeated Jean Chanfreau of round of the Union Trust tennis tournament; The score was 6-3, 7-5.

The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Pamplona has invoked the church's special privileges in Spain to protect 11 priests of his diocese against legal proceedings for having delivered some of the strongest public attacks in recent times on Spain's political leadership.

The recent international conference for the protection of endangered animal species owes some part of its great success to the dramatic prosecution of a major fur dealer and civil suits against 31 others here in New York. The delegates in Washington were clearly shaken ...

A closed-circuit television surveillance system will be installed on a two-mile stretch of the Atlantic City Boardwalk by June to help cut crime. Mrs. Claire Ordile, the city's Deputy Commisioner of Public Safety, said yesterday that cable for the $50,000-to$60,000 municipally operated system already had been laid. The System, she said, will include $6,000 pan-andtilt cameras with ranges up to 400 feet. The cameras will be mounted on poles.

United States hospital sources said today that North Vietnamese interrogators had tortured Bobby Joe Keesee, the civilian prisoner of war released by Hanoi last week, possibly because they thought he was a spy.

Mrs. Roberto Clemente, here for the announcement of her husband's election to the baseball Hallof Fame, described today some of the heartaches since her husband's death a little more than 11 weeks ago.
Mike O'Callaghan said today that he flew to London last weekend for a two-hour private meeting with Howard Hughes over the future of the billionaire's Nevada gambling holdings.

ALEXANDER--Louise V. of Montclair, formerly of Hoboken, N. J., on Tuesday, March 20, 1973. Survived by 3 great-nieces and great--nephew. Service will be held at Arthur K Brown, Inc. (Home for Services), 56 Park St. at Claremont, Ave., Montclair, Friday morning at 11 o'clock.

Members of the Monreal and Canadian Stock Exchangess have voted in favor of merging the two exchanges, it was announced. today.The Montreal exchange vote was 54 to 8 in favor and Canalian exchange members voted 44 to 27 in favor.
Nightshirt workers throughout Denmark began walking off their jobs at midnight to launch Denmark's biggest industrial conflict since 1936.
Eleven weeks after he was killed on a mercy mission, Roberto Clemente was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame today in an: extraordinary special election.

Mailers Union No. 6 became lhe first of 10 newspaper unions yesterday to reach agreement on a new contract with the city's three major dailies. The tentative two-year agreement, which is subject to ratiFication by me'itbers, came 10 days before the March 30 expiration date for newspaper union contracts:

The Albany County District Attorney, Arnold W. Proskin, announced today that a grand jury would investigate an incident In which a group of legislators undergoing free heart tests allegedly harassed a young female hospital technician.

In a white paper, the British Government yesterday announced its long-awaited plan to insure a share of political power for Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority. The plan is aimed at reshaping Ulster's political structure, which for 50 years has been dominated by the mostly Protestant Unionist party. [Page 1, Column 1.1 Excerpts from the white paper are on Page 16.

Republicans ousted Democrats from control of Trustee Boards in three Westchester County villages yesterday, and Democrats took control from Republicans in a fourth community as voters went to the polls in New York suburbs to elect local officials.

CNA Income Shares, Inc., a newly formed closed-end diversified management investment company, yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed initial public offering of 7 million shares. The Continental Assurance Company, a subsidiary of the CNA Financial Corporation, is the investment adviser of the company whose offering would be managed by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation, duPont Glore Forgan, Shearson Hammill and Walston Co.

Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, warned yesterday that a "creeping disenthusiasm" for higher education was "now evident nearly everywhere in American public life" and was likely to have a serious impact on American science.

For the last two years, Joyce Rasmussen Balint has been the unseen mandolin player in Don Giovanni" and "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera. On Monday night she could be seen as well as heard at Carnegie Recital Hall, playing both the mandolin and violin.

Wealthier than they were a year ago, the cream of United States table tennis players is settled here to compete in the Eastern championships, which begin a three-day run Friday night at the State University, at Farmingdale.

James R. Schlesinger, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has begun the largest personnel cutback in the history of the agency. Unofficial C.I.A. sources estimated that at least 1,000 and possibly as many as 1,800 of the agency's approximately 18,000 jobs would be abolished by the end of the current fiscal year, June 30.

For a graduate of the In-stitute of Insurance Marketing at Southern Methodist University, Leon McBryde's life took a pretty drastic turn when he ran away from the 9-to-5 life to become what he had wanted to be since he was 8 years old, a circus clown.

David Toma has played a beggar, a banker, a junkie and a junk dealer, and now someone else is playing David Toma. Mr. Toma is a Newark detective whose disguises, used while tracking down illegal gambling, have led to nearly. 7,000 arrests and a fair share of publicity.
Mrs. Hale Boggs overwhelmed her Republican opponent today to win a special election and succeed her husband as a Democratic Representative of Louisiana. Mr.

A member of the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday proposed a relaxation of the regulatory agency's tight control over' rate-making procedures to permit .increases when carriers can show increased labor costs of at least 5 per cent in any year.

A suit resulting from the traffic death of Arthur Benvenuto, district principal of Honeoye Falls- Lima Central School, has been settled for $100,000. Justice Daniel E. Macken of . State Supreme Court approved a compromise settlement yesterday.

A delivery truck containing 104 cases of liquor valued at $10,000 was hijacked early yesterday morning, the police reported. They said two unidentified men accosted the truck and driver at East 138th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx.

Denver's Al Smith provided the spark near the end of the third period that helped the Rockets to a 113-97 victory over the Meniphis.,Tams in an American Basketball Association game tonight. It was 'the Tams' 13th straight, loss.

The United States intelligence community has reported a significant reduction in the number of North Vietnamese troops and the amount of equipment that have recently entered the infiltration routes toward South Vietnam, well-placed Administration officials said today.
