Will he or won't he? Only Senator John J. Marchi knows for sure. That was the consensus today among politicians who know the Staten Island Republican on whether Mr. Marchi would seek the Republican nomination for Mayor of New York.

A vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that a top official of the Central Intelligence Agency had "agreed with the recommendations" the corporation made to

With the surprising but not exactly original slogan of "I'm Chelsea. Fly Me," the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn is staging at the Brooklyn Academy of Music what it describes as a "minifeStival of fabricators, innovators, imaginators and trouble-makers," being flown in from their own backyards.

Administration hopes for a stable peace in Indochina, already jarred by the reported Communist military buildup in South Vietnam, are further threatened by the deteriorating political situation in neighboring Cambodia. Lon Nol's harsh crackdown on dissident elements, including members of the royal family, intellectuals, politicians and newspaper editors, suggests fear of an opposition far more sweeping and serious than that posed by the lone pilot who attempted to bomb the Presidential palace last Saturday.
TRIWUNG KIDAL, Indonesia--Misty volcanoes on the horizon. Groves of banyan, bamboo and fruit trees. A dozen hues of green. A crystal blue sky with cotton-puff clouds.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has decided to run for Mayor, high Republican and Liberal party sources reported yesterday. However, Mr. Wagner was said to be delaying an announcement so his candidacy would appear to be a draft rather than a result of an agreement with Governor Rockefeller and Alex Rose, the Lib. eral leader.
From 1929 until his death last December at the age of 69, the American artist Joseph Cornell lived and worked in a modest, white-shingled house on Utopia Parkway in Flushing, Queens.

TRIWUNG KIDAL, Indonesia-Health clinics have been scattered across Asia in recent years, but they are still scarce. Most people who go to them live within walking distance - a mile or two. Transportation costs money. Yet in East Java clinics are meant to serve people within a radius of 10

Panama accused the United States today of attempting to "maintain the status quo" in the Canal Zone. The charge followed a United States declaration of willingness to conclude a new Canal treaty promptly and give up a "substantial" part of the zone.
Summing up his opinion of the proceedings with a proud smile, Supreme Court Justice William 0. Douglas witnessed the swearing-in of his wife, Cathleen, as a member of the District of Columbia bar.

The Senate approved legislation today providing a tuition-free college education for Vietnam veterans who were prisoners of war or missing in action, as well as for their children and the children of servicemen who were killed in the war.
Policemen swinging clubs stormed into the Athens University Law School today to break up a sitin by 800 students demanding greater academic liberties.
Today is the last day the city's public primary schools will be open for in-school voter registration for the May 1 election of local school boards.

The ice improved and so did the curling today in the third round of the world curling championship as Canada retained its undefeated record. The Canadians. ran. into tough competition before subduing the previously unbeaten French foursome, 6-5.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy has agreed to speak at a July 4 ceremony in Decatur, Ala., honoring Gov. George C. Wallace, the Massachusetts Democrat's office confirmed today.
James R. Schlesinger, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has begun the largest personnel cutback in the history of the agency.
L. Patrick Gray 3d told Senators today that under new orders from Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst he could no longer discuss the Water-

Robert Clurman, editor of The New York Times Week in Review since 1969, will become an assistant foreign editor and deputy to the foreign. editor, James L. Greenfield; it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The Times.

The city's Department of Buildings yesterday approved -- and hours later Buildings Commissioner Joseph Stein revoked-an "alteration" permit for the contested Widener townhouse at 5 East 70th Street that called for "altering" the mansion by demolishing it and erecting in its place a 16-foot wall.
Patty Cake, the tiny gorilla baby that has drawn thousands to the Central Park Zoo, suffered a broken arm yesterday, either from the playfulness of her massive parents or from parental rivalry.
Incredible as it may seem, Vince Matthews still is climbing fences to train, although the competitive goals now are pots of gold, not gold-plated medals.
A dope test performed on the former world middleweight boxing champion, Emile Griffith, following his draw March 12 with Frenchman Max Cohen was positive, a French fight official said today.

The Senate approved tonight a one-year extension of the Economic Stabilization Act including a provision that could lead to a reimposition of Federal nor rent controls in New York and other major cities.

The Bankers Trust Company, whose prime lending rate remains at 61/4 per cent, voiced strong support yesterday for the commercial banks that raised the politically sensitive basic loan rate to 63/ per cent on Monday.

A leader of the Indians who have held Wounded Knee for 21 days said today that the Government had not responded to a proposal that President Nixon send a representative to hear the grievances of residents of the Pine Ridge Reservation.
Mike Kekich and Lindy McDaniel stopped the Cincinnati Reds on four hits today in pitching the New York Yankees to, a 1-0 exhibition victory, their fourth straight against National League teams.
After weeks of inactivity, field teams of the International Commission of Control and Supervision have started investigating the frequent violations of the cease-fire in Vietnam.

A Queens baker who won $9,956.10 at Roosevelt Raceway discovered sadly Monday night that three men who broke into his shop wearing ski masks and brandishing guns had a very hot tip: they knew all about his good luck.

FLANDERS, N. J., March 20-The national public links golf championship, coming to the metropolitan area for the first time since 1936, is scheduled for July 11-14 at the Flanders Valley Golf Club. The tourney annually attracts 4,000 or more entrants (the record is 4,174 in 1971) who play qualifying rounds at 52 sites before the field is reduced to 159.

The appointment of Milton W. Mays, president and director of the Continental Corporation and the Continental Insurance Companies, as 1973 general campaign chairman of the United Fund of Greater New York was announced yesterday by R. Manning Brown Jr., the fund chairman.

Ernest Holmes, defensive tickle for the Pittsburgh Steelers, was faced today with Federal charges stemming from a series of highway, sniping in Ohio last Friday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation renorted.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has decided to run for Mayor, high Republican and Liberal party sources reported yesterday.
The British Government today announced its long-awaited plan to insure a share of political power for the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.
The class champions of the seventh biennial Miami-Montego Bay yacht race are Lightnin, the over-all and Class C winner, Aura in Class B and Running Tide in Class A.
The New York Islanders, whose introduction into the rough and ready life of the National Hockey League has been long, hard and frustrating, could reach a milestone tonight.

One's daily life is basically the stuff of soap opera, distressing though the thought may be; And while occasionally wallowing in our own particulars, we are secure that artists keep a creative arm's distance from such indulgence in their work. It was with a sense of betrayal to find Yvonne Rainer's two weekend concerts at the Theafter for the New City hopelessly sentimental.

It was wall-to-wall decayed denim as more than 16,000 members of the youth culture crowded into the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I., on Monday-the final of three evening concerts featuring the Grateful Dead, one of the longest surviving and better groups to emerge from the great San Francisco rock-groupquake of the mid-1960's.
Spring arrived yesterday afternoon, and along with it came the first of a series of days set aside here this year to mark concern about the environment.
Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. today declared obscene the X-rated films "Deep Throat" and "Love For Sale," which have been playing at the Strand Theater in Keyport.
A gypsy cab driver was found shot to death at about 10 o'clock last night in the front seat of his taxi at 111th Avenue and 134th Street in South Ozone Park, Queens, the police said.
Another Life, by Derek Walcott (Farrar, Straus Giroux, $7.95). An autobiographical poem. Eugenio Montale: A Critical Study of His Poetry, Prose and Criticism, by G. Singh (Yale University, $15).
Stan Smith swept past Nikki Pilic today to gain the quarter finals of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tournament.

At the opening ceremony of the traditional Hastings international Tournament, Jim Slater-the British financier who made a lastminute $125,000 contribution to entice Bobby Fischer to go through with his championship match with Boris Spassky-came up with an offer of [Pound]5,000 to the first British player to win the grandmaster title.
Legislation to hold Federal elections on Saturdays rather than Tuesdays has been introduced by Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest as of March 15 rose to 18,538,449 shares from the month-earlier total of 17,902,968 shares.
When Cecile Parker was a student at Barnard College in the 1940's, she and her classmates spent their spare time knitting for the Red Cross.

A memorial service for Robert Cushman Murphy, the naturalist, who died Monday will be held Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Setauket Presbyterian Church, Main Street, Setauket, L. I. The service will be conducted in part by his son,

The Landmarks Preservation Commission announced yesterday-that it was planning to designate SoHo, the lower Manhattan district noted for its post-Civil War cast-iron fronted structures, as a historic site "during the early part of summer."
The city and the 5,200member Local 234 of the Transport Workers Union reached agreement early today on a contract that will keep buses, trolleys and subways operating.
It was the first "Cultural Night" of the year at the Mr. SWorD Foundation, and ice cubes tinkled in about 100 drinks as the evening's speaker strode to the front of the room to be introduced.

The United States District Court for the District-of Columbia blocked today efforts by President Nixon's campaign organization to compel 10 reporters and news executives to turn over notes and other unpublished material in the Watergate case.
The Saigon military command said yesterday that it-had opened a major attack to break the siege of a small outpost surrounded by Communist troops for more than a week.
The names of 128 players were put in nomination today for baseball's 40th anniversay All - Star Game, which will be held July 24 in the Harry S. Truman Memorial Sports Complex in Kansas City.
A New York company has dropped its request for special permission to import sealskins, normally banned under United States wildlife protection laws, the National Marine Fisheries Service said today.

Dick Sadler, manager of George Foreman, scoffed at reports yesterday that the world heavyweight champion was approached for a title defense against Muhammad Ali, the former titleholder, with each fighter to get $5million.

The city's community school boards are responsible for the policies and operations of all elementary and junior high schools within their districts. Each district board, which must hold a monthly public meeting, hires the district superintendent and the principals, and may hire the new teachers for schools with low reading scores.

" You may elect whichever candidates you please to office," said Boss Tweed, "if you allow me to pick the candidates." This admirable lesson in blatant bossism now is being applied to the New York mayoralty campaign, so openly that the smoke-filled room in which Warren Harding was nominated begins to look like a Sunday school class.

The board of directors of the American Association of Publishers met yesterday in the General Motors Building to discuss new Soviet laws concerning writers and issued a statement that called them "dismaying" news.
The Health Services Administration yesterday named 14 food-processing establishments as violators of the Health Code.

The Police Department, as part of its new effort to make the reporting of sex crimes easier and less humiliating for women, will set up next week a special telephone number, 577 RAPE, for women who want to report an assault but are reluctant to talk to a male policeman.
Administration officials said today that they expected Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, to visit the United States in June for talks with President Nixon.
Expressing its regret and disappointment, the United States tonight voted a resolution on the Panama Canal put before the United Nations Security Council. calling the

House Democrats agreed unanimously today to fight Administration efforts to cut back Federal aid for social services. The latest challenge to President Nixon's efforts to hold down spending came as the House Democratic Caucus instructed the Ways and Means Committee to "promptly report" legislation designed to block proposed cutbacks in social services.

An Air Force transport plane was shot at by two Libyan fighter planes over the eastern Mediterranean early today, the State Department announced. The plane was apparently on an electronic reconnaissance mission.

Willi Daume, West German vice president of the International Olympic Committee, said today he would visit China between March 30 and April 6 to discuss that country's participation in world sport. He said it was known that China was considering rejoining the Olympic movement, which it left in 1959. Before flying to China, he said, he will visit Montreal, Canada, and Los Angeles.

In a National Basketball Association game that Coach Red Holzman of the Knicks found "distasteful," his team threw away a 20-point lead and wound up losing to the Atlanta Hawks, 98-93, before the customary capacity crowd last night at Madison Square Garden.

New York State's requirement that, to vote in a primary, a voter must register in a political party eight to 11 months in advance, was upheld as constitutional today by the Supreme Court. The vote was 5 to 4.
Philippine troops, aided by helicopters and jet bombers, fought three sporadic daylong battles today against Moslem secessionist rebels around this provincial capital in central Mindanao.

The United Nations observed International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination with speeches today and by announcing pledges of $1,188,723 to help victims of racial bias in southern Africa. Twenty-one countries contributed to the total.

A 24-inch underground steam main ruptured yesterday morning on Avenue C near 15th Street, tearing a hole about 18 by 35 feet in the pavement and hurling debris that smashed windows of apartment buildings and parked cars. No serious injuries were reported.

In heavy trading live beef cattle futures moved down yesterday, perhaps because of easier supply conditions. Commodity analysts were not ready to say that recent record price levels had brought significant consumer resistance as yet, but at least some was indicated.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday assigned Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to help crush the last remnant of the Republican rebellion against Robert F. Wagner as Mr. Rockefeller's choice for Mayor.
The nation's output of goods and services surged by a record amount of more than $35billion during the first quarter of 1973, three leading economic consulting concerns said yesterday.
The National Weather Service called the ropical storm Agnes the worst disaster in American history.
The Kentucky Colonels handed the undermanned Memphis Tams their 14th straight defeat tonight, 131-109, despite a career-high 41 points by Johnny Neumann, who hit 18 of 23 shots from the field.
Brian Taylor returned to the New York Nets backcourt tonight after having missed 15 games, but about the only thing that resulted was a good workout for the rookie star.

Organizations representing black and Spanish-speaking policemen sought preliminary injunction in Federal District Court yesterday to halt the Police Department from hiring new patrolmen from existing lists or giving promotion tests.
Net deposits in New York State's savings banks continued at a lower pace in the first half of March, according to the Savings Banks Association of New York State.
" There is only one left," a young Pole said. "Nicolae Ceausescu may be the last one in the bloc who thinks the party is shaping society. The others know it's the other way around."

Two men, identified by the police as Yvon Calu and Marcel Pilette, broke into the office of the Caterpillar Corporation factory at Gosselifs, near Charleroi, on Feb. 25, stealing 120,000 Belgian francs, worth about $3,000.
By mid-March, alewives were beginning to nose up Cape Cod streams to spawn, and the same was true in brooks entering at least one salt pond and one lagoon on nearby Martha's Vineyard Island.

A public offering of 725,000 common shares of Indianapolis Power Light Company at $24.25 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and, Salemon Brothers. The company's stock closed at 24 1/4, down 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Federal Reserve Board recommended today that Congress authorize all banks and other financial institutions to create "family accounts" that would give check-writing privileges on interest-bearing savings accounts.

The Supreme Court held today that the states could finance their public school systems in part with property taxes that provided more money and better educational facilities for pupils who lived in wealthier districts.
Canada extended its unbeaten string to five games in the world curling championship today as the team, skipped by Harvey Mazinke of Regina, outclassed Italy a newcomer to world competition, 12-2.

Matthew J. Troy Jr., the unpredictable Democratic leader of Queens, wrote himself a classically balanced New York City political ticket yesterday-- Mario Biaggi for Mayor, Paul O'Dwyer for City Council President and Harrison J. Goldin for Controller.
Herbert Klein, the White House communications director, reaffirmed today President Nixon's support for the Equal Rights Amendment.

The United States District Court for the District of Columbia blocked today efforts by President Nixon's campaign organization to compel 10 reporters and news executives to turn over notes and other unpublished material in the Watergate case.
Eight tax preparers were arrested yesterday on charges of having prepared false Federal income-tax returns for thousands of clients in Manhattan, the Bronx and nearby communities.
Sir Donald Forsyth Anderson, chairman of the Peninsular Oriental Steam Navigation Company from 1960 to 1971 died yesterday. He was 66 years old.

Come this June, the degree of master of business administration will not be as much of a golden key to a top corporate career as it has been, Lester B. Korn, head of a major executive placement firm, warned yesterday.
The newly created State Commission on Cable Television made public today a set of proposed rules governing the franchising and operation of new cable television systems in New York State.

Despite showing excellent balance in its opening game, with six players scoring in double figures, Alabama's basketball team still needed a desperate 25-foot shot by Glenn Garrett as time ran out to overcome Manhattan, 87-86, Monday night in the National Invitation Tourment.

Soviet authorities, in a clear bid for American Congressional approval of trade concessions from the United States, sought to convey the impression tonight that the education tax on Jewish emigrants had been lifted permanently.

A funny thing about the healthy family appetite: it is somehow never appeased by a steady diet of soothing syrup in place of solid nourishment. It is all very pleasant to be told over and over by Administration experts that, if everybody just waits long enough, food prices will be coming down. But that doesn't fill any refrigerators or any stomachs either.
The loss of Rod Seiling was the price the New York Rangers had to pay for their 6-1 victory over the Minnesota North Stars last night at Bloomington, Minn.
The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors voted unanimously yesterday to oppose two bills currently before the Legislature dealing with access to public meetings and records.
President Nixon announced today that he would make $424million available to provide 776,000 summer jobs for youths, about $3-million more than the Federal Government spent for this last year.

The Associates First Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of Gulf Western Industries, announced yesterday that it would withdraw its tender offer for the shares of the Talcott National Corporation because of the opposition of the Justice Department.
Two children, one 2 years old and the other 7, died last night in a fire in a six-story Harlem apartment building, the police reported.

Frank Mahovlich scored the 500th goal of his career as the Montreal Canadiens clinched first place in the National Hockey League's East Division--their 16th first-place finishby defeating the Vancouver Canucks, 3-2, tonight.
The Ford Motor Conipany announced today that it had begun recalling 58,579 Ford Torinos, all 1973 models, to find an estimated 4,100 cars that might have a steering linkage defect.

Close bidding decisions in highly competitive auctions can swing masses of international match points. In the diagramed deal from the Vanderbilt final played Monday in St. Louis, both North players eventually had some thinking to do.

Declaring that the results had been "better than anticipated," the State Insurance Department asked the Legislature today for a four-year extension of an experimental "operating" system in which insurance companies set their. own premium rates for property and liability

Rejecting Governor Rockefeller's appeals, the Assembly approved a bill today to defer for one year any legislative action on a plan to control development on the 3.7 million acres of private land in the Adirondack Park.

It would be nice to believe that we now possess all the basic scientific facts needed for the conquest of cancer. We could then set up timetables of expected progress, hire the required hands, and confidently expect this awful scourge to disappear from the human vocabulary.
An unusual legislative move on the Senate floor last night has put back into the Senate's bill extending the Economic Stabilization Act a provision on corporate disclosure.

The deficit in the "basic" balance of payments in the United States lessened in the final quarter of last year. For the year as a whole it was $9.2-billion, almost unchanged from the $9.3-billion of 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.
Mari-Elizabeth Morgen, a Canadian pianist who played Bach's "Goldberg" Variations in her Town Hall debut three years ago, gave a Bach recital Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Redemptions of mutual funds topped sales by $203.7-million in February compared with $130.6-million in January, the Investment Company Institute reported today. Sales of mutual funds fell to $327.1-million from $535.4-million in January. Redemptions fell to $530.8-million last month from $666-million in January.

Art Williams will join the National League umpiring staff for 1973, the league president, Charles Feeney, announced today. Williams, 29 years old, will be the first black to umpire a full season in the league. He worked 19 games at the end of last season.

The Greek Government said today that it had ordered the expulsion of a correspondent for Dutch and Belgian news media, alleging that he was a "political instructor" who incited dissident students at Athens University.

Kuwait today sent troop reinforcements to the frontier to face reported Iraqi military concentrations there as several Arab efforts to mediate the bor. der dispute between the two countries were under way.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that Supreme Court decisions restricting the immunity privileges of members of Congress posed a "dangerous threat" to their continued independence and freedom to speak out.

Gordon W. Rule, the Navy procurement expert who was shifted to a minor assignment in December after assailing the White House appointment of Roy L. Ash and then refusing a demand that he resign, was returned to his old job yesterday.

Superior Court Judge James I. Toscano today dismissed charges by three insurgent Republicans that Bergen County Clerk Alexander Allan had given G.O.P. organization candidates preferential positions on primary election ballots.
Philip A. Loomis Jr., a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday he doubted whether the New York Stock Exchange would succeed in its avowed aim to abolish the "third market."

The Center for Marxist Education in New York City, which says its brochures publicly proclaim Communist leaders as speakers, was .declared today by the Subversive Activities Control Board to be a Communist-front organization.
Shecky Greene held off Twice A Prince to win by a length today in the $37,650 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

The state has received a $318, 970 Federal grant to pay for 12 new administrative court assistants. The aides will be as signed to 12 judicial administrative regions in the state with the aim of streamlining or modernizing court procedures.
Governor Cahill said today that he had abandoned his tax-re form program, which called for relieving local property taxes through enactment of a state income tax.

There was a time when the hoodlum dominated the screen and the cop was reduced to, at best, an innocuous nice guy doing his job, not too competently. Tough Jimmy Cagney usually stoleall the scenes from pleasant Pat O'Brien. On television these days, the cop has been elevated to undisputable stardom, but not without some curious smudges of sociological irony.

A Federal grand jury has returned 23 new indictments on felony charges, bringing to 54 the number of persons indicted in the 22-day occupation of Wounded Knee by armed Indians, a Government attorney announced today.
The Administration presented Congress today with President Nixon's legislative proposal to restore the death penalty for such crimes as aggravated homicide and wartime treason or espionage.
President Nixon announced today that he would make $424million available to provide 776,000 summer jobs for youths, about $3-million more than the Federal Government spent for this last year.
Syracuse University officials today called unauthorized and unwise the showing of the sex film "Deep Throat" over the university's cable television system two weeks ago.

A group of young men, most with beards and long hair and wearing field jackets and blue jeans, gathered around a metal wastebasket in the hearing room of the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street, yesterday and tossed typescript documents into the basket, setting the papers afire with a cigarette lighter.
Thousands of policemen seeking pay increases seized this city's police headquarters yesterday and clashed with the army when tanks smashed into the building last night.

United States District Judge Frederick B. Lacey recommended yesterday that the United States Postal Service begin an investigation of mail-order advertising campaigns for bust developers, diet pills and aphrodisiacs.
A man who has known his share of defeats and disappointments but has shown the ability to bounce back played host to a team of gymnasts yesterday.

Trucking industry and labor representatives declared yesterday that they would seek City Council and, if necessary, court action to block new city regulations for weight and size limits on trucks effective April 16.

The average yield on four-month commitments to purchase conventional mortgages rose to 8.020 per cent from 7.951 per cent in the previous auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association reported today. The range of accepted bids in yesterday's auction was from 7.975 to 8.250 per cent.
The head of the United States Corporation feels that steel-industry production this year could reach a record level of 100 million tons.
Plans for a $2-billion urban project providing new housing, industry and parkland on a 2,500-acre decaying waterfront site on the Hudson River were announced today by Jersey City.
A one-day labor stoppageby the crew of the Italian Line passenger ship Leonardo Da Vinci prevented the vessel from saling for the Mediterranean yesterday afternoon.
Crain Hanover, only a shadow of his former self, is still good enough to be the 3-1 morning-line favorite for tomorrow night's $6,000 feature trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

The special Manhattan grand jury investigating a $100-million loan-sharking ring in New York's garment center returned indictments yesterday against 10 men on charges of usury, conspiracy, contempt and perjury.

Newman F. McEvoy, a leader in the media advertising field, died last evening at Greenwich Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived here.
A state appeals court today upheld the perjury convictions of Gabriel Cattaneo, who held top posts in the Hudson County Sheriff's office.

Dr. Morton H. Halperin, who had general supervision of the Defense Department group that put together the Pentagon papers, testified today that one copy of the papers had been sent to the Rand Corporation for storage and that it did not belong to the United States Government.

The Government's antipoverty agency said today that it was investigating allegations that Federal funds were' used by a Long Island group to help underwrite a recent Washington demonstration protesting cutbacks in antipoverty funds.

Air Force lawyers are attempting to extend the doctrine of "privileged" communications to cover a former White House aide who has become a central figure in the Civil Service Commission hearings on the layoff of A. Ernest Fitzgerald.

Dr. Ephraim Katchalski, an Israeli neuroscientist, left Cambridge today after learning that he would be nominated to' be President of Israel by the dominant Labor party, sources at Massachusetts Institute of Technology reported.

Tanzania accused neighboring Burundi today of having killed 36 persons in a bombing raid on three villages in northwestern Tanzania.

Canada's industrial production index for January was 203.6 seasonally adjusted, unchanged from the upward revised December level but 7.5 per cent above the year-ago 189.4, Statistics Canada reported today.
Two Freeport patrolmen, suspicious about a missing air-vent cover, checked closer and arrested two men early today for allegedly burglarizing a doctor's office, the Nassau County police. reported.
England escaped with a draw in the second cricket test match against Pakistan today. It was the second draw in the threetest series.

Speculation is mounting that the Soviet Union; after going nearly two years without a manned mission in space, may be preparing to launch a Salyut space station in the next month or so--perhaps in time to upstage the American Skylab project.
Governor Cahill announced his candidacy for re-election today with a heated call to New Jersey's voters to reject him if they believed he or his Republican administration had been corrupt.

In rejecting by one vote yesterday the challenge to the system used to finance the public schools in Texas, the Supreme Court also gave a breathing spell to 48 other states under pressure to reform school financing, along with a setback to the reformers.

There has been a dramatic shift in financial thinking at home and abroad in the direction of more tolerance of floating exchange rates for currencies, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, the Chairman, of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today.
Two Lebanese soldiers were killed. and a third was wounded early today when an army checkpoint in the southeastern part of the country came under fire from unidentified armed men.
Rising food prices have forced most families to stretch their food budgets to the limit lately. Even in the White House, the Richard Nixons have instructed their kitchen staff to shop carefully.

The Board of Education took action last night to prevent the unauthorized creation of special non-Civil Service job titles that could be filled by personnel who hold "certificates of competency", rather than regular school licenses.

The Mets were given a day off on Monday. But Rusty Staub was out early at virtually deserted Huggins-Stengel Field for extra batting practice. After he had worn out three rookie pitchers and a pitching machine, he hopped into a car and hadTom McKenna, the trainer, drive him to the Payson Field complex for still more hitting against live pitching.

A dual champion--the rarest of breeds--came to the fore last weekend at the year's opening American Kennel Club field trial on Long Island. He was Sir Lancelot, a vizsla owned by Bill Goodman of Orange, N. J., and handled by Dennis Burjan.
Interest rates extended their new-found stability through a third straight session yesterday despite further disappointing data in the continuing fight against inflation.

The city's community school boards are responsible for the policies and operations of all elementary and junior high schools within their districts. Each district board, which must hold a monthly public meeting, hires the district superintendent and the principals, and may hire the new teachers for schools with low reading scores.
The patrons of New Jersey's food markets could bring about a swift reduction in food prices of as much as 20 per cent if they took a hard stand against shoplifting, a security expert said today.

A 24-inch underground steam main ruptured yesterday morning on Avenue C near 15th Street, tearing a hole about 18 by 35 feet in the pavement and hurling debris that smashed windows of apartment buildings and parked cars. No serious injuries were reported.
To the Editor: Commissioner Murphy's report on the increase in crimes against persons only confirmed what every New Yorker has known and what too many New Yorkers have experienced.
Western Airlines announced yesterday it has undertaken the largest re-equipment program in its 47-year history by signing a purchase agreement for seven aircraft and an option agreement for 15 more.

John Havlicek's 27 points led the Boston Celtics to a hardfought 106-105 decision over the Chicago Bulls tonight to give the Celtics the best victory total in their history. The Celtics have won 63 games against 14 losses. The previous club record was 62 victories in 1964-65.

The initial details released by the State Department are too sketchy to permit any solid judgment on the significance of yesterday's reported attack by Libyan Air Force jets against an unarmed United States Air Force plane over international waters. But if the report proves accurate, the attack would represent a dangerous new escalation of madness in the Middle East.
Huge losses in the Aerospace F-14 fighter plane program plunged the deficits of the Grumman Corporation to $71.4million in the fourth quarter
Union representatives and merchants urged the City Council. yesterday to pass two bills designed to. give local manufacturers an advantage on bidding for city contracts.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics confirmed yesterday what shoppers in the metropolitan area already knew-that runaway meat prices sent the cost of living soaring last month.

In a Protestant suburb of Belfast last night a man came upon some boys lighting a bonfire, a traditional means of announcing both good and bad news. It was because of the British white paper, they told him.

Frank S. Hogan, the Manhattan District Attorney, received the Liberal party's designation yesterday for re-election to a ninth term. Mr. Hogan, A Democrat, already has been designated by the Republicans and Conservatives.

Uruguayan security forces have announced the capture of four of the men involved in the 1970 kidnapping-murder of Dan A. Mitrione, an American police expert. The fifth man was killed in a clash with the police, they said.

President Nixon today declared Tennessee and New York as major disaster areas as a result of heavy rains and flooding last week that caused widespread damage to public and private property. The President acted at the requests of Governor Rockefeller of New York and Gov. Winfield Dunn of Tennessee.
A fast-breaking thief with no mercy in his heart stole a five-game block of Knicks playoff tickets here yesterday from a fan who had just purchased them.

The reimposition of Federal rent controls, as approved by the Senate on Tuesday, could have a significant impact in holding down rent increases in much of New Jersey, Connecticut and New York State outside New York City, Federal and state officials indicated yesterday.
Shecky Greene held off Twice A Prince to win by a length today in the $37,650 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park.
The New York Zoological Society's Osborn Laboratories of Marine Science was awarded a $100,000 grant today for continuing research into the antibiotic potential of the common sponge.

John A. McCone, the former head of the Central Intelligence Agency who now sits on the board of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation,, repeatedly denied yesterday that the company had anything "surreptitious" in mind when it offered the Government $1-million to help defeat Salvador Allende Gossens as President of Chile.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics confirmed yesterday what shoppers in the metropolitan area already knew-that runaway meat prices sent the cost of living soaring last month.
A projected nuclear power plant on Cayuga Lake would slightly, but not adversely, affect the surrounding environment, according to consultants to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

To Edwin Whitaker, a Toronto electronics executive, the Kentucky Derby has already been decided. "My horse and Secretariat are going to run one, two, and don't say I didn't tell you," he said yesterday.

Sordid, even against the dreary backdrop of earlier revelations, are the latest disclosures about the effort of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to block the democratic election of a President of Chile and to enlist United States Government help for that abortive project. On I.T.T.'s own testimony, it offered the White House and the Central Intelligence Agency a milliondollar contribution to underwrite a plan for preventing the election of Dr. Salvador Allende in 1970.

President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Wallace H. Johnson of the White House staff to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the land and Natural Resources Division. Mr. Johnson, 33 years old, would succeed Dale Kent Frizzell, who is being nominated to be solicitor of the Interior Department.
New orders for durable goods and manufacturers' shipments both rose in February but at a much slower pace than in the previous month, the Commerce Department said today.
Four men were arrested today and charged with operating a major loan-sharking ring in Suffolk County, District Attorney George J. Aspland said.

Football, which had faced deemphasis or even discontinuation next year at Syracuse University, was given a reprieve yesterday and probably will be retained at its present major intercollegiate level when Coach Ben Schwartzwalder retires after the 1973 season.
Patty Cake, the baby gorilla whose right arm was broken during a family tussle Tuesday, was reported to be resting comfortably in isolation in a baby's crib in the Bronx Zoo hospital yesterday.

A wheel that flew off a nine-ton refrigerator truck today rolled into a group of children waiting for a school bus, killing one of them. Twelveyear-old Barbara C. Merry of Rowley was pronounced dead on arrival at a Newburyport hospital.

We are no longer energy-rich. We have become energy-poor, and until we solve our energy shortage, the world's currency managers will distrust the dollar-even when our inflation rate is below that of other nations. They see that we have a new and progressing malignancy that plagues our hopes and even our treadmill efforts.

Several hundred professors and staff members of the City University of New York picketed on the Brooklyn College campus yesterday to dramatize their request for higher pay, smaller class sizes, job security and other improvements in work conditions.

Heavy selling in glamour stocks and blue chips sent the stock market into a tailspin yesterday and pushed most indicators of price action on the New York Stock Exchange to new lows for 1973.

Y., on Feb. 18.

The director of the Office of Safety of the Federal Railroad Administration said today that the brakes were inoperative on the last two cars of the train involved in last Thursday's fatal Long Island Railroad crash here.

An Air Force transport plane was shot at by two Libyan fighter planes over the eastern Mediterranean early today, the State Department announced. The plane was apparently on an electronic reconnaissance mission.

There are no easy answers to institutional change or expansion in New York. The hospitals and universities that have made the city great have often had disastrous impacts on their neighborhoods. Local communities, remembering past hurts, bitterly oppose institutions' plans.

About 3,000 former addicts are expected to be reached in an expanded work support program announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. The program, as introduced two years ago, covered about 400 former addicts.

Mrs. Margaret W. Price, who was national president of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. from 1963 to 1969, died of cancer today. She was 62 years old.

A housewife freed her hands from electrical cord binding yesterday and shot and killed two masked men who tried to rob her home and beat her husband.

Summing up yesterday in the 10th week of the H. Rap Brown trial, the defense attorney, William M. Kunstler, laid heavy stress on the legal concepts of "reasonable doubt" and "presumption of innocence."

Police Lieut. Edward L. Kerr was named to a second 90-day term as acting Police Director after the City Council failed tonight to confirm his permanent appointment by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson.

Foreign Minister Krister Wickman said today that It was important to improve Sweden's relations with the United States, frozen since Christmas time when Premier Olo' Palme criticized the United States bombing of North Vietnam.

A second farm labor con tractor has been arrested in southern Florida on charges of keeping workers in bondage. Federal sources said today that the Federal Bureau of Investi gation was investigating bothcases.

The New York Mets manager, Yogi Berra, staged a youth parade today, sending a trio of his young pitching hope fuls to the mound in an effort to determine which one, if any, might serve as his No. 5 starterthis season.

The man who supervises all the tellers at the Park Avenue branch of the Union Dime Sav ings Bank was arrested late Wednesday night and charged with stealing over a million and a half dollars from thebank's deposits.

Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that despite "some en couraging signs" from Moscow, he would press forward with his legislation to bar trade con cessions to the Soviet Union so long as emigration of Jewsand others was restricted.

President Nixon indicated in a report to Congress today that he would ask in his forthcoming trade legislation for almost un limited authority to raise or lower tariffs, including out right elimination of tariffs if this can be negotiated withother countries.

A coroners jury ruled to day that David A. Whiting, the 26-year-old business manager of Sarah Miles, the English actress, had died of an overdose of drugs. But the jurors said that they were unable to determine if the drugs had been takenintentionally or accidentally.

"Star Trek," the National Broadcasting Company televi sion series that developed a cult of devoted followers after it went off the air several seasons ago, will be back in the N.B.C. line-up next season--as an animated cartoon Saturday mornings.
Arthur Goldman, former own er of the Goldman All Seasons Hotel and Golf Club in West Orange, N. J., died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in EssexFells. N. J.

Even if Governor Rockefeller succeeds in getting former Mayor Robert F. Wagner the Republican party's mayoral nomination, the Governor will face defections among local G.O.P. leaders and rank-and file members, party sources inBrooklyn said yesterday.

National negotiations be tween the General Electric Company and two major elec trical unions representing 100,000 workers began on a low key yesterday with both sides expressing optimism about reaching a peaceful settlement before their presentcontracts expire on May 26.

Rolls Royce Motors, Ltd., maker of the luxury cars for which buyers wait up to two years, went on sale today to the highest bidder. The bids for the company, now in liquidation, must be in by May 1, with a down payment of about $17-million.
Fifteen persons and two tele vision documentaries received George Polk Memorial Awards for outstanding journalistic achievement at a luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

With the March soybean fu tures contract out of the way, interest focused yesterday on the May delivery. It shot up the 15 cents a bushel daily lim it during a wild session and then dipped to close at $5.80 a bushel, up 12 cents from Wednesday's closing price of$5.68.

Executive privilege is one of those subjects that is long on rhetoric and short on substance. It is not one of the central issues of our time, but merely a moderately interesting question that has attained importance largely be cause of other issues of conflict be tween the executive and the legislature.
The stock market absorbed a relentless drubbing yesterday and closed in its broadest de cline in more than 10 months. The selling appeared indiscrim inate and swept through virtually all sectors.
A 40-foot-high storage tank collapsed at a Baker's Yeast factory here today, covering a residential street with three to fourinches of molasses.

Ephraim Katchalski, one of Israel's best-known scientists, was nominated by the Labor party tonight as its candidate to become Israel's fourth Pres ident. The nomination by the ruling Labor party is tantamount to election.

Mrs. Pouncey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Rieger of New York and Easthampton, L. I., is an admissions officer at Columbia College, the firstwoman to hold that position.

A member of the city's police STRESS unit was arrested to day on a charge of second degree murder. Patrolman Raymond Peterson, 38 years old, a 12-year veteran of the police force, was charged in the fatal shooting of RobertHoyt, 224, on March 9.
A new dispute developed between the United States and the Communists yesterday over the release of the final group of Americanprisoners of war.

Miss Janet Serlin, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Serlin of Bayside, Queens, and Hallandale, Fla., and Ronald H. Garber, son of Mrs. Jerome Garber of Cleve land and the late Mr. Garber, were married here last evening at the Park Lane Hotel.

A new controversy over the return of American prisoners of war arose yesterday, with the United States' insistence that 10 Americans held in Laos be included when the last group of prisoners is released in Hanoi this weekend. United States sources say the return of the prisoners in Laos was part of an American-North Vietnamese understanding.

Chile's Cabinet resigned tonight, Interior Minister Carlos Prats Gon zolez told newsmen here. The 15 ministers offered their resignations so that President Salvador Allende Gossens Could reshuffle hiscabinet, General Prats said.

Bristling over charges that as a mayoral candidate he would be a puppet of Governor Rocke feller and Alex Rose, Robert F. Wagner yesterday issued a personal declaration of inde pendence from the Governorand the Liberal party leader.
Mrs. Hermine Braunstemer Ryan, a former guard-super visor in Nazi death camps during World War II, was arraigned here yesterday as a fugitive from West Ger many on unspecified murdercharges.
A group of 13 New York restaurants will support the planned consumer boycott of beef products by offering a 10 per cent discount to pa trons who avoid orderingbeef for dinner.

Organized labor, returning to power in the Democratic party from its "neutral" position in last year's Presidential campaign, won 10 of 25 vacant seats on the Democratic National Committee: in near-final maneuvering today.

Panama said today she would carry her demand for control of the Canal Zone to the United Nations General Assembly de spite an American veto of a similar resolution in the Se curity Council. The veto last night was only the third by the United Statesin the United Nations.
F. S. Moseley Co. and Esta brook Co., Inc., two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange founded in the nine teenth century, said yesterday they had agreed in principle tomerge.

Minnesota folded under the pressure down the stretch last night, went scoreless for 7 1/2 minutes and was upset by Ala bama, 69-65, in the quarter final round of the National In vitation Tournament before 17,640 at Madison Square Garden.

Senator James O. East land, Democrat of Mississippi, who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary ' Committee, an nounced today that hearings would start April 10 on a pro posed amendment to the Con stitution that would prohibitschool busing for integration.
Sen ate leaders tried today to round up support for a com promise campaign-disclosure bill, and said that a showdownon the bill could come Monday.

Leon ard Woodcock, the president of the United Automobile Workers, told the union's bargaining con vention today that problems in the plants would be major is sues at the upcoming negotiations with the auto companies.
New York University announced tuition raises yesterday in six of its graduate and professional schools for next year.
The long struggle for control of the South Viet namese people is entering a new and important phase, full of uncertainties and difficulties for both the Vietcong and theGovernment.

The Continental Illinois Nation al Bank and Trust Company of Chicago announced today, fol lowing a meeting at the Federal Reserve Board with Arthur F. Burns, its chairman, and other Government officials, that it would reduce its prime lendingrate from 6 3/4 to 6 1/2 per cent.

The New York Rangers put down the rambunctious Atlanta Flames tonight, 4-1, for their third consecutive victory. The triumph enabled the New York ers to remain tied with the Boston Bruins for second place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

Capitalism today, as frequently in the past, is the object of strident criti cism. Indeed, the variety of divergent sins placed upon its shoulders is truly remarkable. Inequitable wealth, pollu tion and consumer deception are themost common accusations.

John W. Sterett, a retired as sistant treasurer of the Union Carbide Corporation in New York, died yesterday in the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth. He was 79 years oldand lived here.

Lee Elder, center of a golfing controversy, scored a seven under-par 65 today to lead the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open by two strokes. The 38 year-old black professional from Washington had his best round on the pro tour since the 1969 Phoenix open and was only one above the Lakewood CountryClub course record.
Southern California's Steve Furniss set an American record tonight in the 200-yard individual medley in the Na tional Collegiate Athletic Asso ciation swimming championships.
Sanford D. Garelik indicated last night that he might run For re-election as City Council President instead of Mayor, and might do so on a ticketwith Robert F. Wagner.
Jack Solomons, the British boxing promoter, said yester day in London he had made "an astounding" offer to George Foreman to defend his world heavyweight cham pionship against MuhammadAli in London.

Lauritz Melchior, the operatic tenor, was eulogized here today for "his rare combination of artistry and humanity" in a formal Danish service attended by 500 persons.

"That's thrilling," said Matilde Bedford to President Nixon as she settled into his chair today. What enchanted the 90 year-old widow from Tren ton, was being seated behind the Presidential. desk during a meeting that Mrs. Nixon ar ranged after she read in a newspaper that Mrs. Bedford had met nine other, Presidents.

Mid western cattle and hog raisers said this week that they planned only modest expansions of their herds this spring, indicat ing that supplies of fattened beef and pork would be only slightly larger this autumn and that retail meat prices would be little changed from today'srecord-high levels.

Dr. Robert C. Atkins, author of the controversial best-seller "Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution," was named yesterday as a de fendant in a $7.5-million dam age suit charging that the diethad led to a heart attack.

Mrs. Annie Snell can re lax now, because her son, Matt, has decided not to play football anymore. The Republican primary fight be tween Governor Cahill and Rep resentative Charles W. Sand man Jr. was adjudged here to day as a clear test of whether a liberal incumbent can over come a conservative reaction.But it is also something else.

Agents from the bureau and from the Union County Prosecutor's office had worked with the state police for a year and a half on cracking the ring, thebureau said.

The Uris Building Corpora tion, one of New York's largest real-estate companies, an nounced yesterday that it had entered into preliminary nego tiations for the sale of all it sassets.
H. Lee Dennison, former Suf folk County Executive, was named to the State Council of Environmental Advisers today by Governor Rockefeller. Thepost is unsalaried.

A dispute seemed to be in the making yesterday among major domestic producers of stainless steel over the prices they charge for their materials. Allegheny-Ludlum Industries, Inc., said it would stand by in creases it proposed last week of 5 per cent to 7 per cent for stainless steel sheet and strip products, effectiveMay 1.

Legislation that would permit registration for Federal elections by a simple postcard was approved today by the Senate Post Office Committee. The bill, sponsored chiefly by Senator Gale McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, would require local officials to accept voter registration by postcard up to 30 days before a Presidentialor Congressional election.

Perhaps the most irritating thing that can happen to a top-ranked expert who has just lost a vital match by a small margin is to have a kibitzer approach him with a speech beginning, "You should have made that slam by ..." and find that he isright.

China has purchased four Western-made films, including "The Sound of Music" and "Tora, Tora, Tora," as a per ceptible but cautious relaxa tion appears to be taking place in Chinese movie-making.

A family of four had to spend $11,880 "to live at a moderate level" here last year - $790 more than in 1971, according to the Community Council of Greater New York. The 1972 total included $2,112 in income taxes, Social Security payments and disability insurance.

G. William Boutelle, assist ant to the president of the American Distilling Company of New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, today at his home on Huckleberry Lane. Hewas 49 years old.
"Scape-Mates," a production of WNET/13's Television Laboratory, is a "video fantasy" by Ed Emshwiller, a prominent figure in experimental film-making.

To the Editor: The Times errs when it states cate gorically in the lead editorial of March 12 that "the United States does not have the power to make peace in the Middle East...." The public is. ren dered an additional disservice by the concluding implication that American capability "to prevent war" in the Mid dle East "is the most that for the moment can be expected."

A Canadian author, who was blinded in a tank accident in Italy during World War II, ap pealed to countries throughout the world yesterday to give aspiring blind authors a fair chance "so that we do not have to feel that no matter what we do we have lost therace before we start."

Dr. Arthur Edwin Neergaard, a physician here for 50 years, died of a stroke Wednesday at his home, 120 East End Ave nue. He was 89 years old. Dr. Neergaard was graduated from St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., Yale and, in 1909, the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons,

Johnny Bucyk scored a pair of goals-his 38th and 39th-and assisted on three others tonight to power the Boston Bruins to their seventh. straight triumph, a 5-3 decision over the Minneensota North Stars.

The Reader's Digest, in an effort to help its 2,200 em ployes here cope with the rising cost of living, cut prices in the employe cafeteria this week by 20 per cent and gave everyonea raise of up to $640 a year.

The issues involved in medical experimentation on human beings have become exacerbated in recent years with the increase in public sensitivity to potential violation of the rights of persons involved. Now a trial under way in Detroit may set a new legal milestone in this hazardous area.
The New York Press Club urged Congress yesterday to pass legislation "that recogniz es the right of newsmen ab solutely to protect their con fidential'sources and information."

The Garden State Racing As sociation will have to pay up to $31.5-million for an out-of court settlement of a suit brought by a group of stock holders who sought its liquida tion. The settlement was announc ed today and it calls for the association to pay $2,100 to the stockholders for each sharethey own.

Northern Ireland's leading Roman Catholic op position group, the Social Democratic and Labor party, today gave a qualified welcome to the British Government's proposals for the future of thebeleaguered province.

Summer is an uneasy time for every mayor. With students released from high school, unable to find sum mer jobs and drifting along with older youths already unemployed, the risk is great that street-corner idleness will escalate into mischief and then into blood-stained riots. For several years the Federal Government has successfully damped down this danger by providing spe cial money to hire young people for temporary summerjobs on public projects.
The Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, ruled today that local governments had to pay certain expenses of divorce proceedings for indigent per sons receiving welfare payments.

The man who supervises all the tellers at the Park Avenue branch of the Union Dime Sav ings Bank was arrested late Wednesday night and charged with stealing over a million and a half dollars from thebank's deposits.

The Cost of Living Council, in its latest effort to curb the surge in food prices, told all meat packers today that any increases in their costs must be passed along only on a dollar for-dollar basis. It also directed the packers to pass along anydecreases in costs.

Seventeen- year- old Marita Redondo of National City, Calif. forced third-seeded Evonne Goolagong into errors with a hard ground stroke and upset the Australian star, 6-3, 7-5, to night and advanced to the quar terfinals of the $25,000 Akrontennis tournament.
A five-alarm fire at a waterfront pier and warehouse last night destroyed from 50 to 60 automobiles and caused damage estimated in the mil lions of dollars, fire officialssaid.

The average weekly wage for factory workers in the met ropolitan area dropped $2.43 to $159.17 in January from a December, 1972, level of $161.60, the Department of La bor reported yesterday. The decline, a spokesman for the Bureau of Labor Statistics said, was attributed to a slightdrop in the average work week.

David C. Alexander, Ken tucky-born horse-racing and mystery writer, died Wednes day night in the Veterans Ad ministration Hospital here after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 143 WestFourth Street.

President Nixon asked Congress today to abolish in sanity as a defense in Federal crimes and to revamp the crim inal code completely. The death penalty would be brought backand obscenity laws redefined.

Amid cheers and jeers and some resounding speech-mak ing, landlord and tenant spokes men yesterday assailed - for very different reasons--New York City's rent-control pro gram at a City Hall hearing on a bill to extend the control lawfor three years.

Albert Pass, the highest-rank ing official of the United Mine Workers Union yet charged in the Yablonski murders, testi fied today at the trial of one of his alleged co-conspirators that legitimate union expenses had been paid with $20,000 that the Government charges financed the killings.

A former bank vice presi dent was indicted here yester day on charges of evading in come taxes on $278,000 that he allegedly received to ar range almost $75-million in loans for a major constructioncompany.

Pierre Boulez, recently re engaged as music director of the New York Philharmonic, will shift his programing ideas next season. Instead of concentrating on two com posers (this season they areHaydn and Stravinsky),

When the bell rings, Paul Kallai, the jockey, usually is snug-up on a thoroughbred's mane, hustling out of the starting gate. But when the bell rings Monday night at the Spec trum in Philadelphia, the 38 year-old Kallai will come striding out of his corner for his first professional prizefight.
The New Jersey Fluoridation Study Commission recom mended yesterday that the state require fluoridation of alldrinking water. In its final report to the Governor and

The Senate Armed Services Committee agreed today to de lay for one more week the pending promotions of more than 4,800 Air Force officers. This seemed to end a Senate impasse stemming from last year's hearings on the unauth orized bombing of North Vietnam.

Coming off a three-game winning streak in which they have limited St. Louis, Minnesota and Atlanta to one goal each, the New York Rangers will storm Boston Garden today for a do-or-die game against the Bruins (2 P.M., Channel 9 and WNBC radio).

The dollar maintained its strength against Europe's floating currencies today, the fifth day of trading under the new monetary arrangement. On most major money markets the American currency rose slightly above the closing figures of Monday,
Onion turned in one of his front-running efforts and maintained the pace all the way to win decisively in a one-mile race at Aqueduct yesterday.
Top-ranked Rod Laver struggled to a three-set triumph over Dick Stockton today, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5, leading the way into the semifinals of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tournament.

In his first major address since becoming chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, G. Bradford Cook has set forth a policy of increasing competition to make the investment process work better for the investor.

Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for a grand jury investigation to determine whether Governor Rockefeller and other high-ranking state officials illegally coerced Republican leaders here to endorse Robert F. Wagner as their mayoral candidate.
President Nixon liberalized restrictions on oil imports today in a signal to distributors and motorists that the Administration expected a gasoline shortage this summer.
Three of the nation's largest banks, acting in apparent defiance of the Nixon Administration, announced yesterday increases in their prime lending rates to 63/4 per cent from 61/4 per cent.

Jean-Noel Augert of France won the men's slalom today in the World Cup ski racing at Heavenly Valley as the battle between Gustavo Thoeni of Italy and David Zwilling of Austria for the season championshi was forced into the final event of the series, the giant slalom here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON - John D. Ehrlichman, Mr. Nixon's top domestic lieutenant, has floated the notion that "there is no way" of raising large amounts of revenue through loophole closing other than through "digging into the average taxpayer's exemptions or charitable deductions and mortgage credits (sic)."
The General Host Corporation charged in Federal court here yesterday that Triumph American, Inc., was violating Federal laws in attempting to gain control of the corporation.
The United Auto Workers adopted today a list of demands that gives negotiators a "degree of flexibility" for facing auto company bargainers in contract talks this summer.
The United States Ambassador, Horacio Rivero Jr., a retired admiral, is caught in an embarrassing controversy here over the Spanish Navy's rejection of three much-used American warships.

A northbound auto-train crashe dinto a stalled Seashore Lines bus at a crossing in the center of this town today, injuring 10 persons, one of them critically. The police said the train, carrying passengers and their cars from Florida to suburban Washington,

An air and sea search continued last night in rough seas and moderately high winds for signs of the Norwegian freighter Norse Variant and her crew. The 541-foot vessel radioed Thursday that she was sinking in the Alantic, 150 miles off Cape May, N. J., and that the 30 men aboard were abandoning shin.

Mayor Lindsay, during a tour of Brooklyn neighborhoods yesterday, told community groups that "the great hope of the future of the city" rested on the continued growth of their organizations and closer ties with city Hall.

The State Department is expected to send a Latin-American specialist to testify before a special Senate subcommittee investigating the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's activities in Chile.

The president of E. P. Dutton Co., Inc., said yesterday his company was in the advanced stages of negotiations toward the purchase of Saturday Review Press, a division of Saturday Review Industries, Inc., which is in-financial difficulties.

Wes Unseld dropped in a 15footer with three seconds left in the game tonight as the Baltimore Bullets clinched the Central Division title in the National Basketball Association with a 106-104 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.
The inventor of Tajmir, which was patented this week, calls it the first major textile fiber developed since World War II. Carl E. Barnes,
BANNER WEEK You don't have to be a flag-waver or even a Betsy Ross, but you are free to drop by any time today through next Friday to make a banner of your own choosing. Where?

G. Bradford Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a delegation from the New York Stock Exchange today that he believed they would be less worried than they are now about the commission's plans for a new central securities market once they had seen the details.

Kathy Whitworth and Sandra Palmer were among 32 golfers who survived match play today in the $100,000 Sears Women's Classic. . The field will be cut to 16 players tomorrow who will compete in an .18-hole medal play round Sunday.

Villanova University named Roland Massimino, who has been assistant at the University of Pennsylvania for the last two years, as it's new basketball coach yesterday. He replaces Jack Kraft, who left last week to accept the head coaching job at Rhode. Island.

Two suspended subway-car inspectors renewed their charges of widespread waste and malfeasance at the 240th Street car barn yesterday before the Mayor's Subway Service Watchdog Committee, and were called "liars" and "cheap publicity seekers" by union officials.

TOWARD A RECOGNITION OF ANDROGYNY. By Carolyn G. Heilbrun. 189 pages. Knopf. $6.95. Androgyny, as Carolyn Heiibrun uses it, "defines a condition under which the characteristics of the sexes, and the human impulses expressed by men and women, are not rigidly assigned. Androgyny seeks to liberate the individual from the confines of the appropriate."

Dr. Hilda Geiringer von Mises, emeritus professor of mathematics at Wheaton College and the widow of Dr. Richard von Mises, engineer, mathematician and a pioneer authority on powered flight, died Thursday in Santa Barbara, Calif.

When John Joseph Sirica was a young man struggling to put himself through Georgetown Law School, he worked as an athletic instructor at the Knights of Columbus gymnasium. He was also an amateur boxer.

Tom Webster had two goals and an assist tonight as the New England Whalers defeated the Chicago Cougars, 3-1, in a World Hockey Association game. The Whalers can clinch East Division crown with one more victory.

The United States hockey team fought back from a 4-0 first-period deficit tonight to gain a 6-6 tie with Yugoslavia in the Group B world tournament. The Americans, who opened the tournament yesterday. with a 6-4 victory over Japan,-gained a 5-5 tie on second-period goals by Gary Sargent and Earl Anderson and a 6-6 tie on Chuck Ness's score with five minutes left.
Metropolitan area Senators and Representatives who generate a lot of mail themselves are beginning to bristle over rising numbers of' complaints about poor mail service.
American warplanes continued their intensified bombing throughout Cambodia today in support of government troops, the United States Pacific Forces Command said.
The United States auto industry sold a record of 280,701 new cars in the March 11-20 period. This was an increase of 29.5 per cent from the 216,726 cars sold in the mid-March period last year.

Learning to live with Dow (unfortunately called "the Market" by many of us) is like learning to live with a healthy but aging gray mare. Just to look at her inspires respect for her size and strength, but if you look into her mouth, you discover that her teeth are no longer sharp, nor is she as powerful or healthy as she once was.
The New York State Department of' Education and the Attorney General's office have served Dr. Max Jacobson with II charges of unprofessional conduct and fraud in the practice of medicine.
The stock market stumbled through an erratic session yesterday in fairly heavy trading and closed with a modest decline after recording a sharp loss at mid-day.
All is not well in the world of food critics, especially with a Jimmy-comelately to the business named Jim Quinn.
Governor Rockefeller announced his support yesterday of the Home With Honor Day parade that will be held here next Saturday to honor veterans of the Vietnam War.
A second person has died here of blood poisoning suffered after receiving an intravenous solution that has now been recalled by the manufacturer.

Moslem rebels fighting Government troops in this Mindanao province have demanded that old Moslem feudal leaders and provincial officials be ousted before the insurgents negotiate with President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

Lieut. Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak, who is living under heavy military guard in his luxurious villa, said last night that there was "only a slight margin of difference between the protection they are giving me and house arrest."
Bergen County, continuing to boom industrially, commercially and residentially, could be near a development crisis, according to environmental scientists.

President Nixon's chief adviser on telecommunications has reported that the three major television networks have resisted White House pressure to cut down voluntarily on the number of programs they rerun.

The retrospective exhibition of paintings and constructions by Nassos Daphnis, at Leo Castelli's downtown gallery, 420 West Broadway, consists of 15 works, one each from the last 15 years of the artist's production.

Twenty former directors of the Penn Central Transportation Company and the estates of two other former directors have agreed in principle to settle 18 lawsuits brought against them by scores of stockholders of the bankrupt railroad for alleged dereliction of duties to the injury of individual stockholders.

Participants at the third Hudson River Symposium, which ended a two-day session here today, offered a much brighter picture of cleaning up the Hudson than they did at their last symposium four years ago.
Top-ranked Rod Laver struggled to a three-set triumph over Dick Stockton today, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5, leading the way into the semifinals of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tournament.

The investigation into the leath Feb. 11 of David A. Whiting will be marked close, policee Chief J. T. Cromwell said today . The desert town police chief said that a review of the situation and consultation with investigators had indicated that further inquiry would be of no benefit .

The American Hospital Supply Corporation and the Wells National Services Corporation have agreed in principle for the acquisition of Wells in exchange for about $27-million of American Hospital Supply stock.

Consumer resistance to high food prices -- especially meat prices, which have soared since the beginning of price stabilization in August, 1971--is beginning to have an effect in the food markets of the New York metropolitan area.
Andrew and his pint-sized architectural cronies build a tree house in a Bronx day care center. Ellen molds clay animals at home with her mother. Who is better off?

What has the General Host Corporation, the food and tourism company, got that Triumph American, Inc., and Meshulam Riklis, the chairman of RapidAmerican Corporation want?

The National Federation of Priests' Councils voted at a four-day meeting here this week to exercise its "corporate responsiibility" by sending a representative to the stockholders meeting of General Electric April 25 in Denver.
World record auction prices were set today for paintings by Canaletto and Pieter Brueghel the younger at a $3.15-million sale of Old Masters at Christie's.

The booming field of crafts is finally having its day. Or rather, its week. Mayor Lindsay has proclaimed March 26 through April 1 as the city's first Craft Week, under the sponsorship of the New York State Craftsmen.
Anyone who still needsconvincing that the stock market is in bad shape need only look at the 20 most active stocks of the week.
A Federal jury convicted Hugh J. McGee, a Washington lawyer, today on charges of lying during a grand jury investigation of former Representative John Dowdy of Texas.

Carl Holty, an artist whose career spanned half a century and who retired three years ago from the faculty of Brooklyn College, died Thursday at Midtown Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 327 Central Park West.

Arthur J. Sloss, retired board chairman of the American Sponge and Chamois Company, Inc., in Long Island City, Queens, died yesterday at the Surrey Hotel, 20 East 76th Street, where he lived. His age was 90.

The State Industrial Commissioner, Louis L. Levine, said today that total employment in the state in February was 7,690,000, an increase of 25,000 over the January total and 75,000 more than in February, 1972.

The first of five midtown "massage parlors" and pornography shops to receive eviction notices in the city's current Times Square cleanup campaign was padlocked yesterday and the others face eviction today, a spokesman for Mayor Lindsav said.
Earl H. Curtis, an executive vice president and member of the managing committee for the Security Pacific National Bank here, died Tuesday at his home in San Marino. He was 53 years old.
MINNEAPOLIS-In winter, snow melts upon touching the heated pavement of the Nicollet Mall, the eight-blocklong hub of the downtown shopping district, raising small clouds of steam.

Food prices have been rising at record levels recently. Questions on what prices have been rising and why, who has been profiting, what is being done about it and what are the shortterm and long-term outlooks were put to Government, industry and consumer authorities over the last two days.

To the Editor: Low-cost housing, if not a dirty word, at least is rarely uttered in political society. There is obviously no simplistic answer, political or otherwise, to the disquieting problems of housing those unable to find reasonable shelter in the marketplace.
The prosecution sought today to establish that William J. Prater gave another defendant in the Yablonski murder case $23,000 "to keep his mouth shut" about the killings.

Doak Sheridan Campbell, former president of Florida State University who presided over the school's growth from a women's college to a coeducationall university, died of cancer today at Tallahassee Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old.

Warning of a "critical situation," the State Board of Regents established a task force today to go to New York City and help reverse the "continued decline" in reading achievement by many pupils there.

Consumer resistance to high food prices - especially meat prices, which have soared since the beginning of price stabilization in August, 1971-is beginning to have an effect in the food markets of the New York metropolitan area.
The investigation into the assassination of the British Governor and his aide has spread to the United States, a Scotland Yard investigator said here today.

Dr. Regina Chanowicz Kesler, a pediatrician of Paramus, N.J., who had been on the staffs of the Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital and Valley Hospital of Ridgewood, N.J., died Monday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. Her age was 44.

A key figure in the Watergate conspiracy said in a letter read in court today that he and other persons caught spying on the Democrats last year had been under "political pressure to plead guilty and remain silent."
