A Toy Is Born, by Marvin Kaye (Stein Day, $6.95). A look at some toy inventors and makers. Becoming: An American Odyssey, by Andrew Goldstein (Saturday Review Press, $4.95). On coming of age during the nineteensixties.
The White House reaffirmed today its support for L. Patrick Gary 3d as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as indications mounted that Mr. Gray's chances of Senate.

Senator William Proxmire has discovered that even admirable candor can be costly. Setting a praiseworthy example, he published his income tax return and revealed--among other facts--that he had deducted as a medical expense the $2,758 cost of his much-publicized hair transplant operation.

Representative Henry S. Reuss said yesterday that the Administration should encourage direct European and Japanese investment in American industry as "the best bet for achieving balance-of-payments salvation."
Having second thoughts about his second crop of hair, Senator William Proxmira has decided to amend his 1972 tax returns to eliminate claims that his hair transplant qualified as a medical expense.

The Ford Foundation renewed support for public interest law firms yesterday by awarding supplemental, twoyear grants totaling more than $700,000 to three such firms for continued work in the environmental field and for "encouraging more responsive and innovative action" by Federal agencies.
William F. Ganfort Jr., a photographer on the staff of The Home News here, died early today in St. Peter's General Hospital after suffer ing a heart attack two weeks ago. He was 66 years old.

The barbed wire is coming down in Hue, and some people are dismantling their bunkers. That is not to say that peace is in the air-far from it-but there is a palpable feeling of respite from the war, and the most optimistic residents hope that it can be made to last.

Millions of dollars' worth of equipment and property of Egyptian enterprises in the Sinai was looted by Israelis in the months after the June, 1967, war, according to a confidential report prepared by the Israeli State Controller.

One of the oldest and largest suppliers of fluoridated water in New Jersey described today the cost of adding the chemical to community water systems as "minimal" and indicated that it could not be considered a factor in deciding the issue of Fluoridation.

Phil Regan, 66 years old, a former singer and Hollywood actor, was found guilty today by a Santa Barbara County Superior Court jury of giving a bribe to County Supervisor Frank Frost to help expedite a multimillion-dollar residential-recreational complex on the Pacific oceanfront near here.

The Kentucky Colonels kept their championship hopes in the East Division of the American Basketball Association alive tonight by beating the New York Nets, 115-91, before 9,597 at Nassau Coliseum, a season-high for a Net's game.
J. Frederick Huge, "grocer and artist," is one of those rediscoveries that are, still to be found in American attics, provincial museums, public libraries and historical societies.
Dr. Sandor S. Feldman, clinical professor emeritus of psychiatry at the University of Rochester, died today at Genesee Hospital. His age was 82.

Thirty three refugees were killed and 65 wounded early today when Communist forces fired a rocket into a resettlement camp in Chau Doc Province 95 miles southwest of here, the Saigon command reported.
An unscheduled walk-on stole the show at last night's performance of the musical "Seesaw"--much to the delight of the audience, which greeted the novice with surprise and applause.

Two British soldiers were shot to death an dtwo others were injured whn gunmen raided an apartment where they were attending a party in Belfast tonight. They were the first members Of the security force to die since a lull in fighting began six days ago.
A 1969 Federal Court suit over Rick Barry's basketball services ended today when a judge approved a disputed contract Barry had signed with the Golden State Warriors.

Warning of a "critical situation," the State Board of Regents established a task force today to go to New York City and help reverse the "continued decline" in reading achievement by many pupils there.
At least seven men were killed and 75 injured in armed clashes, apparently between rial political groups that had assembled to observe a national holiday today.
Miller Barber, who has won seven times on the pro golf tour, overtook Lee Elder today to share the 36-hole lead at 139 in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans onen tournament.
The Justice Department yesterday gave John Lennon 60 days to leave the United States, ruling that he was "deportable" because of a disputed conviction for possession of hashish in England in 1968.

Dr. Frank C. Mathers, whose method of fluorine production was used at Oak Ridge National Laboratories in the separation of uranium isotopes, died today. He was 92 years old. Dr. Mathers joined the Indiana University faculty in 1903 and had been professor emeritus of chemistry since 1950.

Following Is weekly Histine of the unaudited net asset value applicable In the capital shares of dual-purpose Investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are dosing listed market prices or best over-the counter dollar-to-dollar asked priches for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.

Sabino L. Dewey, adopted son of Dr. John Dewey, the philosopher and educator, who himself had been active in vocational education, died yesterday in the Huntington Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived here.

A three-alarm fire damaged the top floor of Public School 26 in the Bronx last night. It was discovered shortly after 8 P.M. on the top floor of the four-story school, at Burnside Avenue and Andrews Street. There were no reports of injuries.

In a scrubby valley here in this empty, wind-swept plains country, a band of young Indians and their allies are dug in, armed and painted for war, while on the hillsides around them a Federal force of armor and automatic weapons stands nervously.

A follower of Charles Manson has been sentenced to 10 years to life in prison for raiding a surplus store to get guns to free him. Catherine Share, 30 years old, and three other Manson followers were convicted Thursday of robbing a Covina beer

POTTSTOWN, Pa.-The bee stings in Washington and the pain is felt in Pottstown, too. The Government clamps Les Whitten, Jack Anderson's aide, in jail for eight hours, and the clanking jail door is heard round the world.

The militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, in the sharpest and possibly most damaging rebuff so far to the constitutional proposals issued by Britain on Tuesday, announced tonight in Dublin that it would keep on fighting.

John Mosler, former board chairman of the Mosler Safe Company, was named here yesterday as one of five new court-appointed directors to run the International Controls Corporation of Fairfield, N. J. The New Jersey electronics concern, which had been named along with Robert L. Vesco, its former chief executive, in a massive fraud suit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission last November, agreed to the new board in a consent decree it signed earlier.

Three bandits handcuffed the wife and daughter of.a Queens antique collector to a bathroom pipe yesterday morning and then leisurely looted their home of an estimated total of $100,000 in antique Tiffany lamps, cut glass and silver, the police said.

It was a most unusual Washington party. Soviet Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin did the fox-trot with Pearl Bailey and asked her "to Russia with love." The French Ambassador, Jaques Kosciusko-Morizet held Miss Bailey's microphone as she teased him for pronouncing his own country "Frahnce" instead of Frantz."
Defying Governor Rockefelle the Brooklyn Republican Executive Committee yesterday overwhelmingly rejected the Governor's choice for Mayor, Robert F. Wagner.

The British Government's White Paper on the future of Northern Ireland pleased the leaders of opinion on this side of the Irish Sea The press and the politicians of both major parties gave it the adjectives of highest British praise: fair, practical, reasonable.

The United States military plane fired on by two Libyan fighters over the Mediterranean two days ago was flying in a 100mile "restricted air zone," declared by Libya but rejected by the United States, the State Department said today.

Participants at the third, Hudson River Symposium, which ended a two-day session at Bear Mountain yesterday, offered a much brighter picture of cleaning up the Hudson than they did at their last symposium four years ago.
The New York State Department of Education and the Attorney General's office have served Dr. Max Jacobson with 11 charges of unprofessional conduct and fraud in the practice of medicine.

The University of California, Los Angeles is expected to have less trouble winning its seventh straight National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship this weekend than it did after reaching

The Bank of England cut its minimum lending rate today from 8.75 per cent to 8.50 per cent. The move could eventually induce commercial banks to cut their lending rates, now among the highest in Western Europe, but this may not happen.
Glenn W. Turner, founder of the "Dare to Be Great" empire, has agreed to settle nationwide litigation' against him for about $5-million.

A Long Island luncheonette owner recruited youths to steal the better cuts of meats from supermarkets, sold the meats in his business as prepared foods and delivered them to private customers at half-price, the police charged today.

Israels right-wing opposition party demanded yesterday a debate on a Government report that millions of dollars of equipment and property owned by Egyptian enterprises in the Sinai desert had been looted by Israelis in the months after the June, 1967, war.
The United States and the Soviet Union today signed an agreement for joint water-pollution studies aimed at cleaning up some of their major lakes and rivers "for the enjoyment of future generations."

Governor Cahill told a gathering of editors and publishers today that the press must find some method of "selfdiscipline" if it expects government to enact broad laws shielding newsmen from being forced to testify about their sources of information.

Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersay, made public a personal financial statement Friday showing assets of $754,872. The statement, which Federal law does not require to be made public, showed an income for 1972 of $58,058. The statement showed no liabilities.

Seven Yankees are hitting better than Bobby Murcer, the richest kid on the block, but that situation pleases him as much as the condition of his mending right hand. The way Murcer figures it, the higher the batting averages the more chance there will be runners on base when he comes to bat.

A flabby Boy Scout-camp counselor complete with stopwatch in hand and baggy sweatsuit, furiously blowing a whistle while observing his, inept athletes execute a routine-practice-in short, everybody's stereotDye image of a coach.

A key figure in the Watergate conspiracy said in a letter read in court today that he and other persons caught spying on the Democrats last year had been under "political pressure to plead guilty and remain silent."
The United States and the Communists remained deadlocked today in a dispute over the release of the final group of American prisnners of war.
The Saigon Government has moved several thousand people in the Central Highlands, against their will in many cases and despite strong protests from American officials.
The nine finance ministers of the European Economic Community took a common position today on the parity adjustment mechanism they would like to see in any future fixed-rate monetary system.

Steve Furniss 'of Southern California, Mike Stamm of Indiana and Indiana's 800-yard free-style relay team set American records tonight as the Hoosiers extended their lead in the second night of competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming and diving championships.

Governor Cahill told a gathering of editors and publishers today that the press must find some method of "selfdiscipline" if it expects government to enact broad laws shielding newsmen from being forced to testify about their sources of information.

The 1972 figures are in on wine imports. The United States imported 37 million gallons of table wines- an extraordinary increase of 44 per cent over 1971. We took 10 million gallons from France, an increase of 41 per cent over the previous year; 7 million gallons from Spain, an increase of 115 per cent, and 6.5 million gallons from Italy, a boost of 38 per cent.

The Soviet press disclosed yesterday that construction of its major 1,100-mile pipeline linking rich Siberian oilfields with Eastern Europe had fallen behind schedule, causing work crews to have to double their pace to meet the deadline for putting the pipeline into operation this summer.

It was only a few years back that opera in conceit form was one of the staples of the New York musical scene. Now only the Opera Orchestra of New York conducted by Eve Queler is around to resurrect those dear, dead operas of the past.

Putting old feuds behind it, the Democratic National Committee accepted by acclamation today a slate of 25 new members, including eight labor union officials who refused to endorse Senator George McGovern, the party's Presidential nominee, last year.

Gov. Dale Bumpers signed into law today a bill to reinstate the death penalty in Arkansas. Under the bill, the penalty would be reinstated for specific crimes, but capital punishment would not be mandatory.

A recovery in the last hour erased some earlier losses yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-theCounter market. However, the late upturn was not enough to stop both lists from finishing lower on moderate trading.

Gov. George C. Wallace told about 500 applauding high school students in the Alabama House chamber today that views of other sections of the country had become closer to those in Alabama and the South.
Last July a group of citizens in Detroit became annoyed at the smoke. belching from a power plant. They brought a suit in State court as citizens of the community to stop the emissions.
Dorothy Colman Mott, the widow of Howard S. Mott, a banker and investment manager, died today in a nursing home in Westwood. She was 82 years old and lived here.
Crash tests indicate that the most popular imported auto mobiles are about as susceptible as American-built cars to "needless damage" in lowspeed collisions, Congress was told today.

Mrs. Constance Agate Dann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford S. Agate, was married here at noon yesterday to Harold M. Austin, a vice president in charge of network television sales at the Paramount Pictures Corporation.
Morton H. Halperin, a former Defense Department official, said today that he did not have either written or oral permission to take "top secret" documents with him when he left Government service.

A husband and wife were found murdered in their Bronx apartment yesterday morning--three days after their married daughter reportedly received an anonymous telephone warning to "keep cool if you want to se your mother alive again."

From the backyard of his family's ranch-style home on a hill overlooking the city, Ernie DiGregorio can see a red-brick dorm on the Providence College campus. Almost romantically, it was the only college he ever had eyes for. "I had letters from about 200 schools, but I didn't even, open some of them," he says. "I didn't even visit any other college."

After being directed by a Federal judge to "work it out over lunch," Nassau County officials yesterday agreed to permit the New York Raiders to have three first-round dates in the Nassau Coliseum if the Raiders qualify for the World Hockey Association Playoffs.

Alfred Chapin Rogers, who was formerly on the staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and had served as a librarian of the Winterthur Museum of Wilmington, Del., died yesterday at his home in Camden, S. C. His ae was 63.

Stephen West, a curlyhaired, big-boned bass baritone out of the Rocky Mountain region, stood at the center of the stage at the Metropolitan Opera House in a brown coffee - with - cream suit, feet spread, large hands slightly raised.

No one has emerged with credit from the extraordinary United Nations Security Council session in Panama City. Panama's military ruler, General Omar Torrijos, may have scored a propaganda point by forcing the United States to veto a resolution on the Canal that was supported by thirteen nations;
The meager supply of Gothic and Renaissance antiques and the superabundance of modern, mass-produced interpretations have not, as expected, checked the recent surge of interest in these styles.
The united States and the Communists remained deadlocked today in a dispute over the release of the final group of American prisoners of war.
The magic of a tiny Soviet teen-ager named Olga Korbut attracted 19,694 fans to Madison Square Garden last night--the largest crowd to see a gymnastic event in the Western: Hemishere.

Federal District Judge Charles R. Richey granted the Democratic National Committee permission today to add seven more Republican campaign officials, including James W. McCord Jr., convicted bugging conspirator,
Alexander's Inc., one of the metropolitan area's largest retailers, had its third consecutive quarterly decline in earnings for the second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 10.
Three of the nation's largest banks, acting in apparent defiance of the Nixon Administration, announced yesterday increases in their prime lending rates to 6 3/4 per cent from 6 1/4 per cent.
Gas workers voted tonight to end their token strikes and slowdowns, which were intended to gain pay increases over the limits set by the Government to halve inflation.

Today--The Hill, Route 124, North Salem, N.Y. Regular, maiden, amateur-owner and green working hunters; open and limit jumpers. 8:30 A.M.

George V. Higgins won't like the way reviewers are going to scrawl "genre" all over his new novel. He told an interviewer he doesn't think he's writing crime stories. He says he's writing "about people, a number of whom have a tendency to break the law." He's right.

MORE than 40 years have passed since that terrible day in August, 1932, when, at the age of 65, the American painter Alfred H. Maurer hanged himself in his father's house on West 43d Street. For some 40 years preceding that grim denouement, Maurer had been an artist of steady

The decision of the Board of Estimate last Thursday to approve a $965,000 project to repave and beautify nearly a mile and a half of Eastern Parkway, in Brooklyn, brought up a subject that has disturbed Brooklynites for a long time.
BAY SHORE, L.I.--The plant that housed the Stratos division of the Fairchild Hiller Corporation is getting a new lease on life after having been idle for two years.
Construction is to begin in the fall on the conversion of an old factory in the Bush Terminal area of Brooklyn into the new home of the Lutheran Medical Center.

Sweden took the world curling championship from Canada today, taking a 6-5 extra-end decision in the final game. The Swedes, skipped by 29-year-old Kjell Oscarius, took four ends in a row--the fourth through the seventh--as Harvey Mazinke and his Regina rink had a cold streak.

TOTOWA--Comes spring cleaning, and a lot of household walls will get either a new coat of paint or a new layer of paper. All this makes the people at Best Brothers happy, for the concern not only manufactures a washable paint, which it sells for $5.98 a gallon, but also sells wall coverings.

It took some doing, but Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, is finally free to marry the woman with whom he's been living for three years. It's the latest turn in a long, twisting matrimonial road for the 55year-old writer. In 1945, he married Natalya Reshetovskaya, but when he was sent to prison camp, they were divorced by mutual consent-which is permitted in the Soviet Union.

Like all of Horatio Alger's stories, this novel has a great deal of the marvelous about it. By one of those freak chances which give an Alger plot its air of wonder, "Silas Snobden's Office Boy" remained unpublished as a book during the author's lifetime, hidden as a serial in The Argosy, a boys' magazine of the eighties and nineties.

The story is set in 17th-century Germany during the period of the Thirty Years War. Krabat, a 14-yearold Wendish beggar, is enticed by a voice in a dream to a mysterious mill, which is really a school for black magic.
DeeDee Bridgewater is working as a single at Sam's Jazz Upstairs, Second Avenue at 64th Street, where she appears Friday and Saturdays, backed by a trio.
President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto has issued a proclamation declaring that Pakistan's exclusive fishery zone would extend 50 nautical miles from the coastline instead of 12.

A man who bought a used rental car that was sold to him as "a demonstrator model" and which he was later seriously injured and his wife killed, has received an award of $897,000 from a State Supreme Court jury last week.

WAYNE--Despite an extraordinary growth in population in the last two decades--from 12,000 to 52,000--this town has managed to control its costs by the careful addition of huge shopping centers along busy highways and attractive industrial plants that are well spread out.
GARDEN CITY-The Nassau Library System would gain $155,000 under Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget, but its director says that is not enough.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, called today for a top-level Western meeting soon to avert a "serious crisis" that he said was threatening to drive North Altantic allies apart.

Where does the Kertuffel family live? "Atip the top of an obscure Ozark.... In the very heart or, better said, the very liver of Poop's Peak." What relativistic truth is confided to the reader about the Kertuffel family?

THE THIEF WHO CAME TO DINNER, directed by Bud Yorkin from a screenplay by Walter Hill and starring Ryan O'Neal and Jacqueline Bisset, got 3 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Archer Winsten, Post:

The United States Coast Guard is asking for public comments on proposed changes in its regulations governing the operation of nine Long Island drawbridges to cut down on summer traffic jams to South Shore beaches and long waits for boaters.

Ed Westfall slapped in a shot from about 10 feet out at 12:03 of the third period to give the New York Islanders a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game before a standing room crowd of 14,665 at the Nassau Coliseum tonight.
A new attempt to break the deadlock over the release of the last American prisoners of war yesterday succeeded only in producing new Communist demands.
Ken Maynard, the white-hatted cowboy hero of some 300 Western movies, died yesterday at the age of 77.
Harvard University has received a $3-million gift to build a new dormintory in Harvard Yard on the site of Hunt Hall.
The first radical new bus design since 1959 is in the scalemodel stage, and three versions are ready for a nationwide tour in May to test public reaction.
The head of District 19 of the United Mine Workers contradicted today the testimony of W. A. Boyle and two former union officials charged in the Yablonski slaying.

When a man boards his boat, he looks forward to matching his skill and strength against the sea. But, unless he is the rare sailor who takes an entirely monastic view of life, he will also have a female to contend with, be she wife or girlfriend.
Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:
Two more major banks, one in New York and the other in Philadelphia, bowed to the Nixon Administration yesterday and reduced their prime lending rates to 61/2 per cent from 63/4 per cent.
Across the United States, the spread of heroin addiction appears to have slowed significantly. Indeed, in some places heroin use seems to have leveled off or even dropped.

Pay increases slowed down last year in key professional, administrative and technical occupations to average 5.5 per cent in New York State and 6.7 per cent in New York City, the regional Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported.
Under a scorching African sun, 50,000 kneeling Moslems bow toward Mecca, their heads touching the red dirt, in praise of God.
ANYONE starting this spring for the first time on the delightful project of gardening should go outdoors and sit quietly in an open, natural place and just think about what is there.
Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Olonoff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Raimi H. Olonoff, to Richard Slater, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Slater of Armonk, N.Y.
7:30-8 A. M., WABC-AM: Message of Israel. Interview with Mrs. Leonard Minkoff, National Vice President of Womens' American ORT.

WASHINGTON--Is Phase 3 a failure? Concern for its future was widespread last week in the wake of a report that consumer prices had soared by 0.8 per cent in February-the largest rise since the Korean War-and that supermarket prices alone leaped by 2.4 per cent.
The Carolina Cougars defeated the Memphis Tams, 143-129, today and clinched tie for first place in the American Basketball Association's East Division. It was the Tams' 15th straight loss.

The local team of James L. Van Alen 2d and Jimmy Dunn won the United States amateur-professional handicap court tennis doubles championship today by defeating George Plimpton and Eddie Noll of New York, 6-5, 6-5, 3-6, 6-4, at the Racquet Club.

The angry reaction of the community may block the plan for a supermarket owner to turn over the second floor of his store building at the southeast corner of Broadway and 104th Street to a privately operated methadone clinic.
WASHINGTON -- The question before the Supreme Court last week: Is a school financing system based in part on property taxes unconstitutional? The Court's answer: No.

Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Isham Collins of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Minturn Collins, to Livingston Ludlow Biddle 4th, son of Mr. Biddle Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Washington, and the late Mrs. Biddle.

ALBANY--Vito P. Battista took a deep puff on his everpresent huge cigar, blew out a stream of smoke, hunched over his desk and said: "Here I am, up here five years voting for their lousy bills. I'm simply being used up here. I want to get the hell out of here."

THE four-day 17th annual Metropolitan New York Numismatic Convention, one of the premier events of the year in the East, will open Thursday at 1 P.M. in the Barbizon Plaza Hotel, 101 West 58th Street. The dealer bourse and exhibit area will remain open to the public until 10 P.M.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.--A converted 57-foot ChrisCraft Constellation has embarked on her new role as mother ship for the ultimate in scuba-diving adventure.
A Federal district judge late today ordered the guards around Wounded Knee to allow daily caravans of food to be taken into the tiny hamlet being held by dissident Indians.

Argentina clinched the South American Zone Davis Cup tennis series against Brazil today when Julian Ganzabal defeated Jorge Lehman, 10-8, 7-5, 6-4. The victory gave Argentina a 3-1 lead in the series. South Africa is scheduled as the next opponent for Argentina.
American tourists heading abroad this summer will discover that, as creaky as it may be, the good oldn American dollar is still the most widely accepted currency.
Coast Guard and Navy aircraft searched unsuccessfully today for an 88-foot yacht reported disabled and drifting off the coast of Haiti.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner last night turned down the chance to run for his old job as a Republican only a day before G.O.P. leaders were scheduled to offer it to him.
-Thallium sulfate, a dangerous poison banned from household use seven years ago, is still being sold in household formulations, the Environmental Protection Agency warned today.

Basil A. Patterson, the vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, says the formation of a national black political structure with state and local organizations would be a positive move toward gaining political power. for blacks.

The Carolina Cougars won their first American Basketball Association title tonight with an easy 124-113 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors. The triumph clinched the Eastern Division championship.
The number of individual shareowners last year registered its first decline in more than two decades-dropping by 800,000.

Fifteen years ago, Brazil's production of automobiles was zero. Today Brazil has the largest automotive industry in Latin America and ranks eighth in the world. Production passed 400,000 units last year, with threequarters of them Volkswagens, but the competition rising fast.

A major study by energy experts of the world's largest industrial countries pictures a decade ahead of growing dependence on Middle East and African oil sources, with rising prices and political risks overhanging needed supply.
Edward Steichen, the photographer, died yesterday at his home in West Redding, Conn., after an illness of several months. He would have been 94 years old tomorrow.

A 23-year-old Norwegian seaman, the only survivor so far of the 30-man crew of a freighter that sank in lashing seas off Cape May, N. J., on Thursday, was saved from the Atlantic yesterday after he had drifted three days and 120 miles alone on a life raft.

A HOT PROPERTY. By Judy Feiffer. 171 pages. Random House. $5.95. Nietzsche once remarked that "jokes are the epitaphs of emotions" and that's the trouble with Judy Feiffer's "A Hot Property." She measures out her characters' lives in punch lines. They're good punch lines, but she can't go beyond them,
The principle of one-man, one-vote, which was among the great pronouncements of the Supreme Court under Chief Justice Earl Warren, has just been diluted for the second time under his successor.
A sniper shot a British soldier and soldiers hit four gunmen with gunfire in three clashes in Roman Catholic areas of Belfast, the British Army said today.
Building a section of the Manhattan-Kennedy International Airport rail link through Forest Park in Queens will require the removal of 184 trees, some of them 40 feet tall and 200 years old.

The full drama of a punitive expedition by the Aegean fleet against a hostile Libyan city some 3,500 years ago has been revealed in a strip of miniature wall paintings found on the island of Thera, according to a leading Greek archeologist.

Miss Mervyn Winston Adams of New York, daughter of Mrs. Robert McCormick Adams of Chicago and the late Mr. Adams, was married here this afternoon to M. Robert Seldon of Ontario, Calif., son of Mrs. Mark Seldon of Miami Beach and the late Mr. Seldon.
A new professional track and field tour began officially last Saturday night in Los Angeles, but some of the old predicaments of the amateur circuit still prevailed.

President Nixon said yesterday that he had ordered United States forces to stay in Vietnam until all American prisoners of war have been released. Mr. Nixon's statement, issued by the White House press secretary, was an attempt to end the deadlock over the release of nine American captives of the Pathet Lao in Laos.
Three Swedish doctors have made a surprising discovery that challenges the basic medical concepts of the relationship between blood clots and heart attacks.

Israel announced today that she would send a sports team to Moscow. Deputy Premier Yigal Allon told the Cabinet that Israel would register up to 30 sportsmen in the so-called university olympics, to be held in Moscow in August.
Rain swept the Gulf Coast of Florida today, wiping out exhibition baseball over a wide area and disrupting the talent search for the New York Mets' pitching staff.

Suspense fans have a neat treat in store tonight at 11:30 with "A Prowler in the Heart" (silly title). The 90minute program fills the "Wide World of Entertainment" slot on the American Broadcasting Company. Dig it, sleuths.
President Nixon said today that he had ordered United States forces to stay in South Vietnam until all American prisoners of war have been released.
A man who was said to be interfering with the apprehension of a larceny suspect in lower Manhattan was shot and killed by a patrolman early yesterday, the police reported.

To the Editor: Early retirement may. be a desirable social objective, but the economics cannot be ignored. The cost of providing adequate benefits at the normal retirement age of 65 already represents 15 to 20 per cent of payroll for many private industries when the company cost of Social Security is included.
A prayer in the Dakota language, a message from a Sioux chief of another century and the modern folk songs of a Cree were heard yesterday in the cavernous Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Perhaps the greatest magnet for viewers of a colonial house is the ancient kitchen, primitively picturesque and evocative of a romantic past. In its own time, it was the hard-won lifeline to survival that many newcomers to these shores failed to reach.
Three weeks of public hearings have convinced Federal air pollution officials that there is no possibility of imposing a big reduction in Los Angeles Basin auto traffic to clean up the air.

A team of thieves immobilized several thousand burglar alarms in lower Manhattan by cutting cables and then burglar. ized a jewelry firm at 15 Maiden Lane yesterday of diamonds and rings valued at more than $100,000.

FLORES, Guatemala - The magnificent remains of the ancient Maya Indian civilization, a culture that attained astonishing intellectual and artistic heights as Europe sank into the Middle Ages, are being systematically decimated by looters to feed the growing art markets in the United States and Europe.

Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today that a confidential Justice Department report on grain dealings with the Soviet Union contained no reference to an alleged industry statement to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that appeared to contradict testimony by the Secretary of Agriculture.

Sanford D. Garelik is campaigning, listening to an old man who is full of grievances and a sense of having been dealt with badly. "Sandy," the old man is saying, "what can I do? The city is killing me."

Dal-Joon Lee of Cleveland regained his men's singles title last night at the Eastern Open table tennis tournament at State University here. The sixtime national champion defeated Rory Brassington of New York, 21-14, 21-13, 21-7.

The dispute over the release of the last American prisoners of war remained deadlocked yesterday, but United States officials privately expressed confidence that it would be resolved by Wednesday's deadline for the final pullout of American troops.

Abraham S. Wechsler, who was director of the New York State Division of Licenses from 1932 to his retirement in 1962, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, Miami Beach. A former resident of the Forest Hills section of Queens, he was 75 years old and was living in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

A season that began five months ago with several unanswered questions ended for the New York Knicks Saturday night with only one real question left: can they regain in the playoffs, which will start Friday, the sharpness and cohesion that characterize their best moments?

James A. Gordon, owner of the James T. Gordon Company, engineering manufacturers representatives, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Brewster, Mass.

For 48 years under J. Edgar Hoover, the Federal Bureau of Investigation was "above politics"-not unpolitical, as Mr. Hoover's intimates now confirm in fresh detail, but so nearly sovereign that it dominated relations with Attorneys General, Congress and sometimes Presidents.
A member of the Federal Communications Commission, Nicholas Johnson, accused the Nixon Administration yester of trying to intimidate the press because "they want the media to repeat, not report."

Carol Mann shot a five-under-par 68 today and won the $100,000 Sears women's golf tournament by two strokes. The finale of the threeday tournament was one 18hole round among the 16 survivors of two days of match play.
A 19-year-old girl was rescued early yesterday by two Queens firemen from her burning apartment at 110-20 73d Road in Forest Hills.

Carl Albert rapped the metal handle of a letter opener against his left palm. He furrowed his brow. He declared that it was bad enough for President Nixon to refuse to follow Congressional directions on spending, bad enough for the White House to withhold information from the Senate.
The spring sun is warming spirits in Prague this weekend after winter's gloom. Sidewalk venders of ice cream and flowers are back at their stands.

Tribal women wearing their best silver jewelry stood in rigid formation, American and Laotian flags fluttered bravely, and a village headman put the torch to a huge pile of dried poppies representing about 356 pounds of raw opium.

Theodore B. Goetz, retired vice president of Westchester Rockland Newspapers, Inc., died today at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old, lived at 105 Greenacres Avenue in Scarsdale and had been spending the winter in Delray Beach, Fla.

" That Championship season," the long-running drama by Jason Miller that originally opened off Broadway, last night won honors as the best play of the season in the Broadway theater's 27th annual Tony Awards, presented at the Imperial Theater.

Alistair Cooke, the British social historian, and Bill Monroe of the "Today" show on the National Broadcasting Company television network, were named today as two of the 22 recipients of the George Foster Peabody Awards for 1972.

Miss Hollis Adrienne Leach and Eugene Samuel Sunshine, graduates of Northwestern University, were married here this afternoon at the Greenwich Country club by Justice of the Peace Sheldon T. Coleman Jr.
The state will begin training local and county law enforcement officials this week to be able to recognize and investigate "white collar" crime.
Two more banks capitulated to the wishes of the Administration yesterday by rolling back interest charges on loans to large corporations.
Trailing by 13 points with nine minutes showing on the clock, the New York Nets not only overtook the Indiana Pacers today, but took them into overtime and defeated them,
Argentina clinched the South American Zone Davis Cup tennis series against Brazil today when Julian Ganzabal defeated Jorge Lehman, 10-8, 7-5, 6-4.

Consumers are confident about the current state of the economy, but have turned less optimistic about future business and employment conditions. This is the consensus of a nationwide survey of 10,000 families in January and February, the Conference Board reported.

Arthur Rous, president of the Federal Carton Corporation and senior vice president of the Grand-City Containef Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday at La Guardia Airport, on his way to a meeting of the directors of the Paperboard co Packaging Council in Chicago.

The invitations from Governor Cahill and the Commissioners of the New Jersey Highway Authority for the June opening of the Garden State Arts Center were embossed with gold and engraved on buff-colored cards that said all the proceeds would benefit the centers cultural fund.

The language of the Dakotas, the words of a Sioux chief and the modem songs of a Cree all penetrated the cavernous Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday as the Episcopal congregation held a "native American mass."

With funds remaining precarious, public television continues to carry its search for programing material to outside producers, in this country and abroad. Tonight's major offering on the national Public Broadcasting Service comes from Capital Cities Broadcasting produced and directed by Milton Fruchtman.

Miss Susan R. Gronko was married here this afternoon to Michael M. Shroder. Judge Edwin Cummer of the County Court of Sarasota performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's grandparents, MacKinlay Kantor, author of the novel "Andersonville," and Mrs. Kantor.

The hit of this Andean capital today was a walk. Some 25,000 persons trod through city streets in a 10-mile event organized by Andres Pastrana, the son of President Mlisael Pastrana Borrero, to aid a children's hospital.

Democrats and Republicans on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee agreed unanimously today with President Nixon that total Government spending in the next fiscal year should be held at $268-billion, though the Democrats said "Congress should make major reallocations with the Administration's proposed expenditure total."

The Constitution, by its silence on the matter, has relegated the responsibility for education to the states. From this interpretation that education is not a "fundamental" right guaranteed by the Constitution has now come a Supreme Court decision upholding the right of states to let their public schools be financed largely through property taxes.

Some loud and happy Memphis State fans, the members of the Memphis team, and their coach, Gene Bartow, are the only persons capable of imagining a Memphis State victory over the University of California, Los Angeles, in the final of the National Collegiate basketball tournament tomorrow night.

Before Ray Noble came to the United States and became so enmeshed in American show business that he wound up as an English-accented stooge on the Charlie McCarthy radio program, he led an English studio band that produced what seemed at the time to be the greatest pop records of the period.

Joseph Kennedy 3d, eldest son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was reported in satisfactory condition at a hospital here today after suffering chest, skull and neck injuries in an automobile accident.

Merce Cunningham's fullevening ballet "Canfield" has a knack for making news. When it had its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1969, there was some kind of electricians' strike (or people very like electricians - possibly stagehands) and the work had to be danced to silence. It has never since had it so good.

A staff sergeant with 18 years' Army service was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday in connection with the theft of $365,000 in small bills from the Army finance center at Fort Polk, La., the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

Mrs. Judith Ann Spackman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Spackman of Hastings, was married here this morning to Stewart Laundon Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Palmer of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

Mayor Lindsay's office an nounced yesterday the resignation of his Buildings Com missioner, the transfer of his Traffic Commissioner to the buildings job, and the elevation of a deputy police commissioner to the traffic post.

" This could be the Wounded Knee of New Jersey," said Murray Goodman, leader of a townwide protest against the dumping of raw sewage from seven communities into an open manole near a residential street.
Cindy, 23 years old, entered Browning's Pharmacy here one day last week, walked to the rear prescription area and said good morning to Walter Browning, the owner.

The Pentagon, the civil service and the nation will be better off now that Gordon W. Rule has won his battle to return to his sensitive post as overseer of Navy procurement programs. For three months he was the victim of a benighted attempt to oust and muzzle a toughminded senior expert who dared to criticize high Administration officials and policies in his area of specialty.

In a struggle to avoid demotion, Eintracht rallied to tie the Greek-Americans yesterday, while the Philadelphia Ukrainians ended Inter-Giuliana's hopes of repeating as division winners in the German-American Soccer League race.

Two years after the election of three radicals to the City Council, the Berkeley left has reassembled its political organization in the hope of capturing enough seats in the municipal election April 17 to win control of the nine-member City Council.
Garden State Parkway officials say they have succeeded in cracking down on motorists who fail to pay tolls at unmanned exactchange lanes.
The durability of the Porsche over rugged long-distance courses proved itself again yesterday with the victory of a yellow Porsche Carrera in the Sebring-Camel 12hour endurance race.

The young leaders of the rebellious Moslems in the southern islands of the Philippines have forged what appears to be a cohesive and disciplined guerrilla movement that Government forces have been unable to challenge seriously after a month of widespread fighting.
A "market basket" of foods from United States farms cost the typical family 2.5 per cent more last month than in January, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

LONDON-The Russians are really interested." That is the word beginning to be heard from some men concerned with the problem of nuclear arms control. They are talking about serious Soviet interest in negotiating limitations on MIRV's.
A Northwest Orient 747 was Stranded on a runway at Tampa International Airport today after blowing 14 tires on a landing from Chicago with 220 persons aboard.
The nation's chain stores and catalog houses continued to chalk up sizable gains in the sales volume during February, according to a survey of The Times completed over the weekend.
E. Miles Wilson, news editor of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette until his retirement last June, died yesterday in Shadyside Hospital. He was 70 years old.
Despite a frantic final 40 minutes played with desperation, the Rangers lost last night to the Minnesota North Stars, 2-1, and buried themselves deeper into third place.

New York State enrollment figures for the June primaries, announced yesterday by Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo, show Democratic registrations topping Republican by, more than one million--4,226,604 to 3,201,059-for the first time.
The last complete ground test of the Skylab space station was successfully completed today, improving chances that the nation's next manned spaceflight project can begin in May as planned.

" We're a David of an organization fighting a Goliath of big politics and big business interests," the Rev. Leonard Dubi, told 1,600 shouting, banner-waving, largely elderly delegates to the first annual convention of the Citizens Action Program today.

Paul Apostol, the former National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, eagerly awaited last night's start of the final round-robin of the international saber event at the New York Athletic Club since he had won 11 of his 15 preliminary bouts.
The telephones of some Eastern European and Middle Eastern embassies in Rome were tapped in Italy's widening wiretapping scandal, newspapers reported today.
The bond market managed to halt its long decline last week even as inflation, its mortal enemy, grew more rapacious.

Bobby Stevens, as unheralded as the Virginia Tech basketball team, dropped in a 20foot jump shot at the buzzer yesterday to give his team a 92-91 overtime victory over Notre Dame in the final of the National Invitation Tourament before a Madison Square Garden crowd of 13,103.
The Suffolk county police this morning recovered the body of the second of two fishermen who drowned yesterday afternoon when their 16-foot dory capsized in the ocean, off Moriches Inlet.
Edward Steichen, the photographer, died yesterday at his home in West Redding, Conn., after an illness of several months. He would have been 94 years old tomorrow.
The broad, leafy streets of this southern capital are pulsing with noisy outdoor rallies in the morning, party political meetings in the afternoon and mass processions in the evening.
Mark Winzenried ran a fast half-mile, Al Feuerbach made an auspicious shot-put debut outdoors and the U.C.L.A. 440 relay team blazed to a 40second clocking today in the Bruins' Meet of Champions.

A team of thieves immobilized several thousand burglar alarms in lower Manhattan by cutting cables yesterday and then burglarized a jewelry firm at 15 Maiden Lane of diamonds and rings valued at more than $100,000.

Stan Smith, bidding to become the king of pro tennis, beat top-seeded Rod Laver, 6-3, 6-4, today and captured the $10,000 first prize in the World Championship Tennis's $50,000 Peachtree Corners tournament.
Thomas Hart Benton came back to the "home country" this weekend, back to the town he left 67 years ago, early in the long career that made him one of the country's best known "regional" painters.
A 53-year-old woman was charged yesterday with firing a rifle at airliners using Stewart Airport to practice take-offs and landings.
If twice is enough to make a tradition, there is another annual sign that spring has surely come to Paris.
There used to be no ifs, ands and butabout the price of cruise ticket on liners sailing out of the Port of New York.

Responding to an aroused public concern about the state of Israel's environment, the Israeli Cabinet has voted to establish an Ecological Protection Service in the Premier's office to advise the Government on ecological problems.

News item: "Nellie Fox, coach of the Houston Astros and the American League's most valuable player in 1959 as a second baseman with the Chicago White Sox, is retiring. Fox, 45, said from his home in Chambersburg, Pa.: "I've just had it, living out of a suitcase. I'm at the point where I can retire, and I will. This year I plan to take things easy."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--There s little warrant for the belief that we know the laws of history well enough to make projections of any great reliability. Most of the turning points of history, great and small, were surprises to both their participants and. the analysts of the day, whatever their doctrine.

Miss Madelon Lubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lubin, was married here this afternoon to David J. Finkel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Finkel of London. Rabbi Bernard Schachtel performed the ceremony at the Lubin home.
The State Health Commissioner, Hollis S. Ingraharm, announced today that beginning next Sunday, the sale of glue without approved glue-sniffing deterrents in it would be illegal.
Three Israeli Arabs and two Jews, key members of a Syrian-sponsored espionage and sabotage ring, were convicted today in Haifa of treason and other charges.

Carl Christian Mose, sculptor and art teacher, died yesterday of a heart attack at his farm home near here. He was 70 years old. Among his works are a statue of the "Eagle and the Fledgling" at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, a statue of Stan Musial at the Busch Memorial Stadium in St.

Mr. Nixon's statement, issued by the White House press secretary, was an attempt to end the deadlock over the release of nine American captives of the Pathet Lao in Laos.

The Bergen Bridge Center in Teaneck, N. J., last week strengthened its claim to be considered the most enterprising metropolitan - area club by organizing a "Danish" evening. This did not refer to the nature of the refreshments, and might more properly have been called a "Swedish" evening, since the principal ingredient was a "Swedish barometer."
Thomas Hobart of Buffalo was elected president of the infant New York State United Teachers union today, and Albert Shanker was elected executive vice president at the Union's first convention.
Cale Yarborough, who led through all 500 laps, won the Southeastern 500 Winston Cup Grand National stock car race today before 30,000 fans at Bristol International Speed-day.
James Marcus showed his instructor how it's done when the 12-year-old youngster rode Beau Geste to the special jumper championship today at the Equitation Lodge horse show.

A physician at Harlem Hospital at West 135th Street and Lenox Avenue was charged last night with having tried to rape a 24-year-old woman patient after having summoned her over the intercom system to the hospital's deserted 11-th floor library.
Jack Nicklaus sank a 4 1/2-foot birdie putt at the second extra hole of a sudden-death playoff to defeat Miller Barber and win the Greater New Orleans open golf tournament today.
James W. McCord Jr. has provided Senate investigators with the names of participants in the Watergate conspiracy who have escaped prosecution, it was announced today.

MARBLETOWN, N. Y.-- And now, the case of the Marbletown seal. How did the 271-year-old silver artifact pass from the hands of the town fathers of this Ulster County hamlet? What is it doing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it has been on display since 1933?
Usually reliable sources in Uganda say that Uganda has purchased 80 French armored personnel carriers to be equipped with surface-to-surface missiles.

Stan Smith, bidding to become the king of pro tennis, beat top-seeded Rod Laver, 6-3, 6-4, today and captured the $10,000 first prize in the World Champsionship Tennis's $50,000 Peachtree Corners tournament.

Sanford D. Garelik is campaigning, listening to an old man who is full of grievances and a sense of having been dealt with badly. "Sandy," the old man is saying, "what can I do? The city is killing me."

Mike Douglas has concluded a new agreement with the Group W division of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company for the production of the Mike Douglas television show. Mr. Douglas will receive $2million for another five years.

Alfredo Yabur Maluf, Cuba's Justice Minister, died here today. He was 55 years old. Mr. Maluf, who held the post since late 1959, was one.of the longest-serving ministers in the Government. He was a member of the Central Committee of the Communist party and president of the Council of Urban Reform.

The head of the American Jewish Congress charged today that Jewish communal organizations were "failing to meet their primary responsibility of providing American Jews with a basic Jewish education and a deep sense of identification with the Jewish people."
Presiden Nixon said today that he had ordered United States forces tc stay in South Vietnam until all American prisoners of war have been released.

De-escalation, if not elimination, of the Indochina war leaves at least two areas of recent conflict and unresolved grievances to challenge President Nixon's aspirations for "a generation of peace"- the Middle East and South Asia.

A 60-day freeze on all prices and interest rates was proposed today by a group of Democratic Representatives. Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, said he and other Democratic members of the committee would introduce the bill tomorrow.

The coming week is to mark a turning point in Vietnam as momentous as the declaration of cease-fire two months ago. By Wednesday all American prisoners of war are supposed to be released from captivity in North Vietnam. And, for the first time in a decade, there are to be no more United States military personnel on duty with the South Vietnamese armed forces.
The Senate killed a constitutional amendment today aimed at extending the term of President Cevdet Sunay. The proposal fell 19 votes short of the 123-vote, twothirds majority needed for approval.

Mrs. Dorothy Fay Mixter, widow of Dr. William J. Mixter, who was chief of neurosurgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, died today at her home here.

Proclaiming May to be Senior Citizens Month, President Nixon said today that it "is a time for all people to renew the recognition, the respect and the active concern which properly belong to older Americans." Mr. Nixon said that "most older people are not mere onlookers in our soceity.

What had been planned as a friendly good-by to an old friend turned into a rousing welcome for a prospective star yesterday as the New York Giants announced the signing of Brad Van Pelt at a send-off luncheon for Joe Morrison.

After a week of dispute with the Nixon Administration, the nation's bankers managed yesterday to put through a general increase in the prime, or mini- I mum, rate on loans to large corporations to 6 1/2 per cent from 6 1/4 per cent.

The prosecutor at the H. Rap Brown trial summed up his . case yesterday, accusing defense lawyers of diversionary tactics, speculation and innuendo.
An advertisement in magazines says: "Millions of women find it easier to face cancer of the cervix than face a Pap test in a doctor's office."

Indictments against the Seattle 7 have been dismissed, bringing an end to the turbulent conspiracy case that began three years ago.

The Central Intelligence Agency and a special Senate subcommittee agreed today on an unusual arrangement whereby a C.I.A. official will testify tomorrow about his dealings with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in connection with the political situation in Chile.

Proving again that it's not what a player shows a manager in spring training but what the manager is looking for that counts, the Yankees cut six pitchers today. Three had allowed a total of only two earned runs in 19 exhibition innings.

Eleven days before the baseball season starts, a subtle change is taking place in the New York Mets' relationship with Willie Mays: For the first time, they need him more than he needs them.

Bill Walton put on one of the greatest performances in college basketball tournament history tonight leading his University of California, Los Angeles team to its seventh straight National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

Smith Kline French Laboratories and Esquire, Inc., were among the companies yesterday announcing stock repurchase plans. The former plans to repurchase about 124,000 of its common shares. The first working session at the ministerial level of, the Committee of 20 nations set up to negotiate world monetary reform began here today. No decisions, other than procedural, were expected from this session.

George Rosier, senior partner in the law firm of Hellerstein, Rosier Rembar, died of a heart attack yesterday while oh vacation in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 64 years old and lived at 3 East 71st Street.
Vietcong and Saigon delegations met today for about two hours but failed for the third time to agree on an agenda for negotiations leading to national elections in South Vietnam.

With the enthusiasm of a farmer trying out a new tractor, President Nguyen Van Thieu bounded through an American-style agricultural exhibition here today in the heart of South Vietnam's rich rice lands.
George Sisler, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, who twice batted over .400, died today at St. Mary's Health Center here. He was 80 years old on Saturday.

Last June's Hurricane Agnes halted oyster reproduction and killed most of the softshelled clams in Chesapeake Bay, but there is at least one happy note in the dirge of destruction: Surging flood waters created several new islands near the mouth of the Susquehanna River, and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources hopes that plantings of grasses and other plants "will stabilize the. islands and provide resting areas for waterfowl and other wildlife."
William Joseph Kennedy, 49 years old, of Brooklyn drowned in the rapids of the Delaware River at nearby Skinners Falls yesterday when a canoe overturned, authorities reported.

Not many people knew it, perhaps, but Sunday in New York was Country Music Day, officially declared so by Mayor Lindsay. The reason for the accolade was the Philharmonic Hall appearance of the Tammy Wynette-George Jones Show, the first in a "Country in New York" series..

New York University's School of Engineering will be merged with the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute to form a new engineering school. The new institution will be staffed by members of both faculties and will use Brooklyn Poly's physical facilities. A new board of trustees will be assembled to represent both institutions. A 28-year-old Bronx man was shot to death last night by one of three holdup men who robbed his wife of $450 in the hallway of the apartment building where they live in the Highbridge section. The couple's 8-year-old son witnessed the killing.

WASHINGTON - "Adoption agencies," the single parent said bitterly, "play God, and would rather give babies to a couple even though one-third of present marriages end in divorce. My situation is stable and known, which is not true for a divorced parent, often living on $120 a week."

The Treasury Department said today it would impose a "countervailing duty," effective May 11, upon imports of refrigerators, freezers ahd certain other refrigerating equipment from Italy. The action results from a finding that Italian exporters receive a subsidy on the refrigerating equipment they send to the United States. The Government said that this gave the Italian imports an unfair competitive advantage.
