Henri Deering, concert pianist, who made his debut at Carnegie Hall in 1925 and had played in most European capitals, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Avenue and 72d Street. His age was 78 and he had lived at 831 Madison Avenue.

City high school students who are 18 and older will now have the right to see their school records, including medical and psychological reports as a result of a directive issued yesterday by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

The 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform agreed in principle today that the new system should "remain based on stable but adjustable" currency values but that floating exchange rates should be permitted in "particular situations."
It was 10:20 P.M., and the curly-haired star of the restaurant's floor show was 20 minutes late. You see, the therapy group she leads in Brooklyn had run overtime.

If Manager Ralph Houk is the executioner at cutdown time, Pete Sheehy is the executioner's messenger. Sheehy, the clubhouse chief, is the one who tells the condemned that the executioner wants to see them. Frank Tepedino didn't wait for the message.

Officials of newspaper craft unions here said yesterday that they had been notified that El Diario-La Frensa, one of the country's largest Spanish-language dailies, would end its printing operation in New-York City after Friday.
The Anita, a Norwegian freighter carrying 32 crew members, has been reported missing off the New Jersey coast in the vicinity where another Norwegian freighter, the Norse Variant sank Thursday.

The defense in the Pentagon papers trial attempted to refute today the theft charges-which they consider the most difficult ones to disprove. However, the 13th defense witness was for the most part a hostile one.
Louis R. Stein, a news editor in United Press International's Latin - American department, died Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 51 years old.

NEW HAVEN-All wars seem to require heroes around which civilian populations can cleanse themselves of guilt and reassert immortalizing principles. But this may be the first war in history in which returning prisoners of war have been selected for that role.

This is the last of three articles on the Maya antiquities. By ROBERT REINHOLD The hieroglyphic writing of the ancient Maya Indians, the most highly developed writing to emerge in the New World before the Spanish conquest, is slowly yielding its secrets after having baffled scholars for centuries.

Robert D. Foothorap, former associate treasurer of the Board of National Missions of the United Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, died yesterday at the Montrose Veterans Hospital. He was 59 years old.

Children who watched "The Electric Company" television program, particularly those in the first and second grades, did better in learning how to read than children who did not watch the program, according to a report released yesterday.
Howard Hunt Jr., a conricted. Watergate conspirator who is a former consultant to he White House, appeared for more than an hour today before a Federal grand jury.

Monumental are the platitudes uttered in behalf of "sound planning." But there will be no planning, sound or otherwise, in the huge southern third of Staten Island unless' the State Assembly passes the Marchi bill for a South Richmond development authority.
The management of The New Yorker magazine made it plain yesterday that it would have been pleased to have the entire population of Chicago restricted to quarters for the day.
Sir Noel Coward will be buried Thursday in a private ceremony at Firefly, his Jamaica mountaintop estate, his private secretary said. A public memorial service will be held later in London.

The board of trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company has approved in principle the issuance and sale of additional shares of common stock. The exact size of the issue will be determined next month and the public offering is expected to be made late in May. In response to a question, an executive said the company plans to raise "$120million plus."
Trying to make up for lost time, State Senator John J. Marchi, who entered the mayoral race on Monday, began to select his running mates yesterday.
Four member brokers of the National Association of Securities Dealers have been expelled and 12 individual members disciplined, the regulatory body for the over-the-counter market said yesterday.
Negotiators stepped up efforts today to bring an end to the month-long take-over of Wounded Knee by dissident Indians as their confrontation with Government forces became virtually open warfare.

A labor dispute that has shut the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., since March 1 was resolved yesterday when 250 members of Local 343 of the Hotel, Restaurant and Bartenders Union voted to accept a new contract. The terms were not announced.

Bernard Fensterwald, a maverick lawyer and periodic battler against the secret machinery of Federal law enforcement, began advising James W. McCord Jr. about three weeks ago and apparently provided the tinder that has touched off the new explosion of Watergate charges.
Negotiators stepped up efforts today to bring an end to the month-long take-over of Wounded Knee by dissident Indians as their confrontation with Government forces became virtually open warfare.

Home Box Office, Inc., in association with Video Techniques, Inc., will show the first National Basketball Association playoff game between the Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets on Friday via closed-circuit telecast from Madison Square Garden.
The USLIFE Corporation announced yesterday that it had made a proposal to acquire the Standard Security Life Insurance Company of New York for stock valued at approximately $24-million.

Prosecutor Sherwin D. Lester has declined to take before a grand jury insurgent Republican charges that the Bergen County G.O.P. has violated the election laws by illegally supporting organization candidates in the primaries.
Mayor Lindsay will permit to become law a bill that sharply restricts the city's use of income-tax returns to verify the incomes of families in city-assisted middle-income housing.

City Health Commissioner Joseph A, Cimino reported yesterday that because of staff shortages the physicians and nurses assigned part-time to public schools could no longer give preschool youngsters the physical examination and immunizations required by law before a child is admitted to school.

Dr. Bertram R. Levy, director of the budget at New York University since 1967 and a former assistant dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, died yesterday after' a long illness at his home at Westfield, N. J. He was 40 years old.

The last of the prisoners are about to be freed; the United States expeditionary force in Vietnam is in its final hours. But for the men who carried the American presence into the mountains and jungles of Vietnam, this post-war era opens with a legacy of disillusionment and maladjustment.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a motion here yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to dismiss a court challenge by the PBW Stock Exchange of the commission's controversial "80-20" rule.

The Central Intelligence Agency commissioned polls to determine the probable outcome of the presidential election in Chile in 1970, Edward M. Korry, former United States Ambassador to Chile, said today.

John A. Donaldson, a retired vice president of Montgomery Ward Co., mail-order house, and a former vice president of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, died yesterday at his home here. He was 78 years old and lived also in Naples, Fla., and formerly had lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

The International Controls Corporation, recently severed from a $224-million fraud suit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Robert L. Vesco and 41 others, yesterday got a new board chairman. Mr. Vesco was formerly chairman of the Fairfield, N. J. electronics company.

Dr. Henry Vaccaro, an Asbury Park Councilman, was indicted for manslaughter by selling methadone "in a gross and negligent manner" to a narcotics addict. Dr. Vaccaro was charged with 18 counts, including 14 counts of illegally distributing, dispensing and selling drugs.

East Germany virtually clinched the World Class B ice hockey championship today by beating Rumania, 4-2, and emerging as the only undefeated team in the tournament. The victory against the previously unbeaten and surprisingly strong Rumanians was achieved in the last seven minutes of the game when the German team captain, Ruediger Noack, scored twice, the last goal with 39 seconds remaining.
Chesapeake Industries, Inc., said today a planned vote by stockholders on the proposed merger of Chesapeake into A. J. Industries, Inc., had been delayed.

Consumer protection officials here and in Philadelphia have begun investigating the activities of a California-based burglaralarm company that enlists distributors through a pyramid sales scheme similar to others that have come under fire in New Jersey and in other states.

Mrs. Maria Alves Martins, a sculptor known under the single name Maria, died yesterday in Rio de Janeiro. She was about 75 years old. She was the widow of Carlos Martins, who had been Brazilian ambassador and dean of the diplomatic corps here.
A Brooklyn grocery owner was shot to death last night when apparently resisting a robbery attempt by three men who escaped with a wallet containing $30.
The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would delay for a year implementation of a land-use plan for 3.7 million acres of privately held land in the Adirondack Park.

Ben Hogan, who hasn't played much tournament golf the last few years, has some advice for other golfers. "Don't ever grow old," he said. "My knee won't let me play, and I've got bursitis in my right shoulder."

Blacks have made it onto the ships ol Columbus and into the history of the succeeding four centuries, and Indians are no longer mere savages to be conquered so that white settlers can civilize the land. But women are still largely ignored, and Mexican-Americans have little to contribute to American history.

In a quiz-show setting complete with a small band and a Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey Circus clown named Buttons, officials of the New York State Lottery yesterday announced the winning numbers for the top price in the $200-a-week-for-life contest.
The Detroit Tigers obstained a former Cy Young Award winner, Jim Perry, from the Minnesota Twins today in a straight one-for-one trade for a minor league pitcher, Dan Fife.

The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned no price increases for 1973 model cars and trucks built in North America. But Ford said it was raising prices on its imported trucks and three cars with components built overseas.

Bipartisan leaders of a House subcommittee offered today to forgo questioning of John W. Dean 3d about the Watergate conspiracy if Mr. Dean, the White House legal counsel, would testify on the issue of executive privilege.

When Governor Rockefeller assigned Charles B. Delafield and eight others to find out what ailed New York racing and what to do about it, Hot Horse Howie Samuels said it would be a pleasure to work with that "distinguished" body. Later, when the Delafield Commission's scrutiny of his Offtrack Betting Corporaion made Samuels uncomfortable, he dropped "distinguished" from his vocabulary. He suggested that M. Donald Grant,
Saying she was mistaken, the former wife of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has retracted a statement attacking the Nobel Prize novelist for his behavior toward her.
Two favorite, long-running children's theater companies have introduced new shows into their repertories - the Paper Bag Players with "To the Rescue" and the Bil Baird Theater with "Band-Wagon."

A change in approach and exit ramps designed to meet community objections moved the $200-million convention center along the Hudson River between 44th and 47th Streets a step closer to the construction stage yesterday.
As a new tourist season approaches, Government and tourist officials here are more optimistic now than at any time in the last five years about Washington's crime problems.

" The River Niger" flowed into Broadway last night, and "The River Niger" is big, wide and deep. It is one of the best black plays to be seen hereabouts, and should be at the Brooks Atkinson Theater for a long, long time.
The White House said today that the United States would continue bombing in Cambodia until the Communist forces in that country stopped their military operations and agreed to a cease-fire.

Now that the last of the American prisoners and troops are on their way home from Vietnam, it would be useful if President Nixon would tell the country what authority he thinks he has to carry on military action in Indochina rather than leaving the explanation to Senator Barry Goldwater.

NEW CANAAN, Conn.,-Enthusiasm runs high at the New Canaan Nature Center, where children and adults are collecting sap from sugar maples and turning it into rich syrup in shallow evaporating pans over a crackling open fire.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that Roosevelt Dunning would succeed Benjamin Ward as deputy police commissioner in charge of community affairs.

President Nixon vetoed a $2.6billion vocational rehabilitation bill today, describing it as part of a threatened "Congressional spending spree" that would dip into "the pocketbooks of millions of men and women."

Dr. Robert H. Morrison, who played a leading. part in the expansion of colleges and universities in New Jersey as Assistant Commissioner of Higher Education, died Sunday in Chula Vista, Calif. He was 89 years old.

The Mozarteum Orchestra of Salzburg played nothing but Mozart at its first New York concert on Monday night in Carnegie Hall, which came as no shock. The orchestra. from the Austrian town where Mozart was born never performs anybody else's music, possibly to make amends for the indignities he suffered while he lived there.
External Affairs Minister Mitchell W. Sharp announced today that Canada would keep its 290 cease-fire observers in Vietnam for at least 90 days more.

China made a sweeping group of proposals today on a law of the sea. One proposal would require that only an international body be given the power to exploit directly the resources that lie on the sea floor or beneath it.

Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the Soviet Union was actively testing three new intercontinental ballistic missiles and might deploy 60 improved multiple-warhead versions of an existing missile during the summer.
Continued flooding near Phoenix, Ariz., compelled the United States Auto Club yesterday to postpone again the opening race of the championship season. Meanwhile,

The Boston Celtics scored the first 10 points of the second half tonight to break a tie and then outlasted the Atlanta Hawks for a 117-110 victory in a preview of the first-round National Basketball Association playoffs.
" American air power is necessary and indispensable," said Maj. Gen. Sosthene Fernandez. "Yes, you can say indispensable," he repeated with emphasis.

" Holding onto that float was| the only thing on my mind," Stein Gabrielsen said last night before flying home to Norway. The 23-year-old seaman had been asked by a television reporter to describe what went through his mind during the three days ahd nights he had clung to a square, orange slab of rubber.

The oldest man on Active Army duty, Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, former director of the Selective Service, retired in a 17-gun-salute ceremony outside the Pentagon, The 79year-old general, who headed the Selective Service from 1941 to 1970, was praised by Secretary of Defense Ellot L. Richardson as a man "who marshaled two generations of
Albridge C. Smith 3d, a partner in the law firm of Smith Lambert, died of a heart attack today in Princeton Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 62 Hodge Road.
The Anita, a Norwegian freighter carrying 32 crew members, has been reported missing off the New Jersey coast in the vicinity where another Norwegian freighter, the Norse Variant sank Thursday.

Eleven weeks after they went on trial for armed robbery and attempted murder, H. Rap Brown and three co-defendants watched the jurors file out of the courtroom yesterday afternoon to consider their fate.

The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had concluded an agreement with Sonatrach, the Algerian National oil company, for a joint crude oil exploration and development project on 2.3 million acres in Central and Eastern Algeria.
Heishiro Ogawa, Japan's first ambassador to the Communist Government in Peking, is a polished, experienced dip1omat with what the Japanese consider the right combination of pedigree and credentials.

The Rhodesian Government's plan to establish "Bantustans" - semiautonomous black African tribal regions like those in South Africa-was attacked today by the African National Council, a black antiGovernment group.
To the Editor: The problem with statistics is that they may often be bent to support either side of an argument. Taken out of full context they may indeed be something less than informative.

The big circus, all made up of blare and spangles, came to town last night. It pitched a tent of memories in Madison Square Garden and carried everyone present, who was not already there, back to his childhood.
Air-pollution control officials began yesterday to estimate the cost of achieving clean air here and, as expected, there was some public grumbling.
Brian Gottfried, a rookie on the World Championship Tennis tour, surprised Roy Emerson today with a 4-6, 6-4, 7-6 upset in the first round of the $50,000 Holton tennis tournament.
Ambassador Chen Chu of 'China arrived in Tokyo today aboard a Chinese airliner to take up his post as the Peking Government's first envoy to Japan.
Government sources here denied today that France was selling armored troop carriers to Uganda but acknowledged that France would furnish that country spare parts for its French-built military planes.

A recommendation that the Cahill administration mandate the statewide flouridation of all drinking water showed every sign today of becoming a campaign issue in the Republican gubernatorial primary election.
Mrs. John N. Mitchell said yesterday that she thought somebody was trying to make her husband "the goat" for the Watergate scandal, and that she was not going to let that happen.

Two Senate bills banning the use of poisons in predator control programs met opposition today from a wool growers association. If either bill became law, it "would impose a strangulation hold on an already struggling predator control program,"

JAZZ The Manhattan School of Music isn't a place that sticks to one note; its musical taste is universal. For two years now, Rusty Dedrick, who worked with, among others, Benny Goodman and Claude Thornhill, has been on the faculty, teaching jazz, all sorts of improvisations.

The United States trade deficit worsened in February after a sharp improvement in January, even though exports in February topped the $5-billion mark in a single month for the first time, the Commerce Department reported today.

Several times every week Police 'Lieut. Norbert H. Campbell visits senior citizens' clubs to talk about the shady games some people play, confidence games in which the losers are generally old people and the stakes are their savings.
The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would investigate the broadcasting of allegedly obscene radio and television programs.
Le Pavilion, the quintessence of sophistication and haute cuisine for about 30 years, was invaded by the bourgeoisie yesterday as the defunct restaurant put up all its goods for auction.
Sir Rudolf Bing, the actor, sat on a bench in the corridor of the New York State Theater looking decidedly tense. He glanced around desperately. "Has anyone got a cigarette?" he asked at large.

Governor Rockefeller's foray into the chaos that passes for New York City politics has all the earmarks of an absolute disaster, many of his fellow Republicans agreed yesterday. Yet, most of them added, over the long haul, all may not be lost for the Governor.

A group of Democratic Assemblymen today proposed an amendment to the recently enacted no-fault auto insurance law that would limit insurance companies' profits to 5 per cent or less on underwriting premiums and to 7 per cent or less on their investment portfolios.
Following is the statement issued today by the Finance Ministers of the Committee of 20 negotiating world monetary reform:
Negotiators for the Newspaper Deliverers Union and the city's three major dailies intensified their efforts yesterday to agree on a new contract to replace the one expiring at midnight: Friday.

The Oscar awards were a cabaret-and sometimes a political platform-tonight, as "Cabaret," the musical evocation of a decaying Germany in a pre-Nazi era swept eight awards including best director, which went to Robert Fosse.
The handsome villa at El Biar occupied by the Black Panthers ever since the party became an accredited liberation movement in Algeria in September, 1970, is shut and deserted.

A 78-year-old woman whom neighbors describe as senile and "childlike" was "beater nearly beyond recognition" early yesterday by two mer?? who robbed her three-room apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

The General Tire Rubber Company had record safes and profits in its first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28. All divisions and subsidiaries contributed. The results Were announced yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Akron.
The Essex and Morris County Prosecutors announced today the indictment of seven persons, including the president of a suburban branch bank, on charges of operating a "large scale" loan-sharking ring.

New York's two largest banking concerns expect to report higher profits for the first quarter .of 1973, their chairmen told their annual meetings yesterday, but due to the Nixon Administration's efforts to hold down the prime rate, the gains will be largely or entirely due to overseas operations.
The bond market, which has been celebrating spring by casting aside all its extreme gloom about higher interest rates, climbed fairly exuberantly yesterday.
Robert M. Carr, senior partner of the New York accounting firm of Lutz Carr, has been elected president of the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., it was announced yesterday.

The announcement by Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey that he will seek the G.O.P. nomination for a second term gives Republicans in that state a chance to affirm support for his generally enlightened policies. In the G.O.P. primary four years ago, Mr. Cahill emerged a narrow winner over Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. of Cape May.

The Supreme Court ruled today that states cannot impose income taxes on Indians who live and work on a reservation but that they may tax the gross receipts of any business the Indians operate elsewhere.

Bill Walton refused to discuss his record performance of 44 points, his injured left ankle, or his future as a professional athlete last night after he had led the University of California, Los Angeles, to its seventh straight National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship and its 75th victory in a row.

The Grumman Aerospace corporation disclosed today that it would lay off 1,000 workers this year from its staff of 24,000 in an effort to meet a goal of reducing its operating expenses by $25-million in line with demands of the Department of Defense over the F-14 fighter plane.
Alfred Firestein, president and chief executive officer of Max Factor Co. and a grandson of the founder of the cosmetics firm, died of a stroke last night. He was 48 years old.
TOKYO-Japanese internal development and American external trade are directly linked in the mind of Kakuei Tanaka, this country's pragmatic Premier. His thesis can be simply stated.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market turned in their best performance in about six weeks yesterday. Both lists made good advances in heavier trading.
Dr. Leo K. Yanowski, professor emeritus of chemistry at Fordham University, died on Monday. He was 71 years old and lived at 279 East 203d Street, the Bronx.
The Roman Catholic news agency Kathpress said today that a priest has been reported executed in Albania for secretly baptizing a child. Albania is Communist-ruled and religious rites are outlawed.
District Attorney Frank S?? Hogan of Manhattan said last night that his office was investigating tax assessment reductions of $100,000 or more granted by the city's Tax Commission.
The white team registered a 4-0 victory over its black opponents tonight in the first clash between the races on a South African soccer field in the South African Games.

The price of gold rose on the London market today to$91.50 an ounce, a record for official trading, before dipping at the close. During the dollar crisis, gold had gone to $95 an ounce in unofficial dealings.

Marlon Brando's decision to use the Academy Awards ceremony as a platform for his outspoken political views comes after a long career of activity on behalf of racial minorities and other unpopular causes.

EVENING IN BYZANTIUM. By Irwin Shaw. 368 pages. Delacorte. $7.95. I enjoyed "Evening in Byzantium." It's a real "old pro" performance, full of smooth and knowing moves. Irwin Shaw takes you through this story like an excel lent host showing you over his commodious house.

The White House said yesterday that the United States would continue bombing in Cambodia until the Communist forces stopped their offensive military operations and agreed to a cease-fire. It clearly indicated that United States military operations would continue there after the last American troops are withdrawn from South Vietnam tomorrow. [Page 1, Column 1.]

East Germany virtually clinched the World Class B ice hockey championship today by beating Rumania, 4-2, and emerging as the only undefeated team in the tournament. The victory against the previously unbeaten and surprisingly strong Rumanians was achieved in the last seven minutes of the game when the German team captain, Ruediger Noack, scored twice, the last goal with 39 seconds remaining.
Two investment banking concerns based in Pennsylvania-Butcher Sherrerd of Philadilphia and Singer, Deane Scribner of Pittsburgh--announced yesterday they were exploring the possibility of merger.

Consumer protection officials here and in Philadelphia have begun investigating the activities of a California-based burglaralarm company that enlists distributors through a pyramid sales scheme similar to others that have come under fire in New Jersey and in other states.
The final stage in the release of American prisoners of the Vietnam war began yesterday as 32 who had been held by the Vietcong were freed in Hanoi and flown to Clark Air Base.

President Nixon vetoed a $2.6billion vocational rehabilitation bill today, describing it as part of a threatened "Congressional spending spree" that would dip into "the pocketbooks of millions of men and woman."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has slowed the movement toward fully negotiated brokerage commission rates because of unprofitable conditions on Wall Street, G. Bradford Cook, the new chairman of the S.E.C., disclosed yesterday.
The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to legislation to extend the Solid Waste Disposal and Clean Air Acts for one year while Congress studies their effectiveness.

Air-pollution control officials began to estimate the cost of achieving clean air here and, as expected, there was some public grumbling. The grumbling came at a meeting in DowntownBrooklyn, the first 'of a series of workshops being held by the Federal, state and municipal officials on the plans they have prepared to meet Federal standards to bring back to this area by 1975 air that is healthy to breathe.

The Senate passed a bill today challenging the Administration's plans to end several major health programs. The vote was 72 to 19. If supporters of the measure can keep that margin they could override a possible Presidential veto. A nearly identical bill before the House has the unanimous support of the health subcommittee considering it, but the bill's prospects before the whole House are nnt vet clear.

Air-pollution control officials began to estimate the cost of achieving clean air here and, as expected, there was some public grumbling. The grumbling came at a meeting in DowntownBrooklyn, the first 'of a series of workshops being held by the Federal, state and municipal officials on the plans they have prepared to meet Federal standards to bring back to this area by 1975 air that is healthy to breathe.

A man from Ghana and his New York-born wife have been accused of swindling the Republic of Equatorial Guinea out of $1.2-million by pocketing more than half of the proceeds of $2.25-million in cocoa-bean sales to a Wall Street concern.

The Aluminum Company of America filed a $43.5-million suit yesterday against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Tishman Realty Construction Company in connection with the building of the World Trade Center.

The withdrawal of the remaining American troops in Vietnam resumed yesterday. The first planeload of 78 men, showing no sign of emotion, silently boarded an Air Force C-141 jet transport late in the afternoon at Tan Son Nhut Airbase.
A Federal judge ordered the Nixon Administration today to take the first step toward releasing impounded money appropriated for a new veterans education program.
Le Pavilion, the quintessence of sophistication and haute cuisine for about 30 years, was invaded by the bourgeoisie yesterday as the defunct restaurant put up all its goods for auction.
E. Howard Hunt Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator who is a former consultant to the White House, appeared for more than an hour today before a Federal grand jury.
The White House said today that the United States would continue bombing in Cambodia until the Communist forces in that country stopped their military operations and agreed to a cease-fire.
The signs of shortages of material and personnel are everywhere in the economy and the voices of those affected are becoming louder.
A suspended police lieutenant accused of withholding information about police protection of gamblers was sentenced to prison yesterday and denounced as a traitor to society.
A strong surge of buying swept into the stock market yesterday, sending prices sharply higher on rising turnover. The Dow-Jones industrial average leaped 17.01 points to close at 944.91.

Ben Hogan, who hasn't played much tournament golf the last few years, has some advice for other golfers. "Don't ever grow old," he said. "My knee won't let me play, and I've got bursitis in my right shoulder."
In a new order, the Federal Aviation Administration virtually outlawed today supersonic, flight over the United States by civilian aircraft, effective April 27.
President Suhanto announced tonight the formation of a 22-man Cabinet whose composition generally underlined his preoccupation with development efforts.
Seven leaders of a furriers union were indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiracy, extortion and threats of violence in "a pattern of racketeering activity" in the city's garment district.

It clearly indicated that United States military operations would continue there after the last American troops are withdrawn from South Vietnam tomorrow. [Page 1, Column 1.]
William J. Prater's lawyer said today that the former United Mine Workers organizer found guilty of murder in the Yablonski slaying hoped to win a new trial and reversal of his conviction.

Several times every week Police Lieut. Norbert H. Campbell visits senior citizens' clubs to talk about the shady games some people play, confidence games in which the losers are generally old people and the stakes are their savings.
The Islanders said goodby to the Nassau Coliseum tonight as they ended their first home season in' the National Hockey League' by bowing, 3-2, to the Buffalo Sabres.
Once upon a time-back before 1964--corporate executives were paid salaries plus bonuses, and often they received something called a stock option as well.
The Treasury auctioned $1.8-billion of 346-day bills today at an average rate of 6.615, up from 6.051 at the preceding sale of such bills Feb. 22.

About 5,000 people gave the Memphis State basketball team an emotional welcome home today. The Tigers returned from St. Louis, where they had lost to the University of California, Los Angeles, 87-66, in the final of the National Collegiate tournament.
The you-are-there newsreel documentary format works very well indeed for "Peary's Race for the North Pole," an engrossing hour starting at 10 tonight on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Pace College capped its 67year climb from humble origins as a trade school to the top rung in higher education yesterday when the State Board of Regents designated it a fullfledged university.
State legislators, employes and administration officials will join the national meat boycott next week whether they want to or not.
The navigation season on the St. Lawrence Seaway opened today, and Great Lakes grain shippers applauded the earliest opening in its 14-year history.

Dr. C. Doris Hellman, professor of history at Queens College, died at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday morning. She was 63 years old and lived with her husband, Morton Pepper, a lawyer, at 176 East 77th Street.
Rod Laver played listlessly, but good enough today to eliminate Roy Barth of San Diego from the $50,000 Holton tennis classic, 6-2, 7-6.
At about 2 P.M. Dec. 2 Hershel Byrd heard a terrifying roar and the sound of snapping trees. His house, near Montevallo, Ala., began shaking, and he ran out to see if a tornado was approaching.
Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester, called on President Nixon last night to cooperate with Congressional investigations of the Watergate affair.
Eight women from Great Neck began their historical tour of New York buildings here at 10:30 yesterday morning with a stop at a bubblecovered tennis court, circa 1972, under the 59th Street bridge.

The expected return today of the last American combat troops and prisoners from Vietnam should be an occasion for universal relief and rejoicing, marking the end of the long and anguished United States intervention in Indochina. To most Americans it is inconceivable that this country would again become militarily involved in a regime so remote from any vital national strategic interest.

The steel industry in North America took steps yesterday to do away with much of the red tape that goes with its sales efforts. Spokesmen for the American Iron and Steel Institute, an industry trade association, outlined a new program,
The obligation to insure that financial statements "have integrity Written between all the lines" rests with management, said Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the General Electric Company.

His reputation as a redneck had been earned. For seven years,the short-tempered Lou Piniella had gone fuming through the minor leagues, leaving behind him a trail of broken bats, cracked helmets and kicked water coolers. Managers kept inspecting him in spring training before dispatching him to the minors with the empty promise: We'll keep an eye on you.
Amid increasing turmoil and an Opposition boycott, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto is facing his most serious political crisis since taking over this deeply troubled nation in December, 1971.

In a decision that will mean an infusion of at least $53-million into the ailing economy of Long Island, two aeropsace companies there have been chosen to build the wings and tail fin for the nation's manned space-shuttle vehicle.

The Swedish Government made public today its proposals for a constitution that would remove the King's residual powers but retain him as chief of state, lower the voting age from 19 to 18 and guarantee citizens the right to hold demonstrations.
Seven reputed Mafia figures were indicted yesterday on charges of having' operated a so-called "bustout" scheme that bilked 30 wholesale food dealers of $50,000.
Dean Prentice swept the puck past a kneeling Wayne Stephenson in the third period tonight to give the Minnesota North Stars a 3-3 tie with the St. Louis Blues.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, asked Congress today to "roll back prices to where they were last December" to assure labor's cooperation in Phase 3 of the Administration's wage-price Stabilization effort.

Bangkok -- Thanomjit Sukhothai, Thailand, outpointed Choi Yong-ho, South Korea, 10 rounds, bantamweights. London--Ken Buchanan, 136 1/2 pounds, Scotland, outpointed Hector Matta, 137 1/4, New York, 10.
Wiretapping on a grand, international scale is an accepted fact of diplomatic life, a defense witness testified today at the Pentagon papers trial.

The State Department of Environmental Protection announced today it would hold public hearings on April 6 and April 19 on proposed regulations to restrict development of 6,600 acres of wetlands in Mercer and Camden Counties.

The commander of Philippine Government forces fighting Moslem guerrillas in this area said today that routine antimalaria spraying had been stopped on a large guerrilla-held island south of Mindanao so that malarial mosquitoes would thrive and help debilitate the rebels there.
The Cabinet today approved the draft of a bill to reform marriage laws that would establish the equality of the sexes in terms of family names and the right of a woman to work.
Francis B. Thurber, who served with the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, died in Princeton Medical Center today.

Alfred J. Ranieri, a Bronx lawyer who got his job on the city's Tax Commission through the intervention of his local John V. Lindsay Association coordinator, was elevated yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to the acting presidency of the commission.
Railway carmen broke off negotiations with the Port Authority Trans-Hudson railway system last night and threatened to strike at midnight Saturday.

Despite grumbling from Capitol Hill, Secretary of Defense Richardson insisted yesterday that President Nixon has clear constitutional authority to continue bombing in Cambodia to cleanup a "lingering corner of the war." The assertion came as several Senators challenged the President's authority to keep up the bombing once American troops are withdrawn from South Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Earl Weaver and Frank Cashen, Baltimore's manager and general manager, respectively, watched their team take the lead in this year's Gold Coast championship tonight, then took their Yankee counterparts to dinner as the payoff for last year's spring series outcome.

Enthusiastic about the unexpected usefulness the B-52 bomber demonstrated in the Indochina war, the Pentagon is seeking nearly $200-million to extend the life of about five squadrons to preserve the plane's nonnuclear capability through the nineteen-seventies.

With hockey's finest forward putting in the goals, and a 44year-old netminder keeping out the opposition's, the Boston Bruins clinched second place in the National Hockey League's East Division last night by defeating the Rangers, 6-3.
An advance United States team will leave for China on Saturday to make :arrangements for the opening of the new United States liaison office in Peking in May, the State Dtpartment announced today.

If Governor Rockefeller has as much political stubbornness as he is credited with, the Legislature's action to delay the recommendations of the Adirondack Park Agency gives him a fine opportunity to exercise that attribute in the public good. He has forthrightly opposed the bill; now that it has been passed by both houses, he should veto it without a qualm.

Fifteen, years ago, Mrs. Frangoise Firminhac bought a pair of American cocker spaniels and became the first Frenchwoman to register the breed in her native land. "An American had a pair before me, but he didn't show," she said here during a recent show.

The number of judges in the state has increased 16 per cent over the last five years, but the number of cases they have to handle rose by as much as 159 percent in some categories during the same period, the administrative director of the courts said today.

Enthusiasm cooled off yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market as prices finished slightly higher to mixed. In the previous session, both f markets had made large gains.

Since last November, the cost of money has been climbing steeply. The securities markets have been in a state of apprehension over the continuing rise in interest rates. But the nation's continuing balance of payments problem and the upsurge of inflation both argue for letting interest rates rise higher.
Vyacheslav Chornovil, a leading Ukrainian dissident, has reportedly been sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment and exile on charges of "anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda."

A big gain in nonresidential building in February increased the Dodge index of construction contract value to a high of 191, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
John Warkentin of the Southern California Striders captured the United States Track and Field Federation decathlon with 7,612 points today. Roger George of Fresno State was second with 7,557 points.

FROM THE LATIN A new opera opens tonight, in concert version, with two performances, at 8 and midnight, at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street (CI 7-7459). It's about a blind and deaf young man, but, no, it's not "Tommy," the rock opera done not long ago by The Who.

Eleanor Steber has returned to New York concert life with quite a flourish, and the theme of her second Tully Hall recital this season, on Monday night, was a big one--"American Song From the Revolution to Man in Space."

The rudder of the British-built Concorde 002 prototype was smashed against the top of a hangar today as the huge supersonic airliner was being towed out for tests. Officials said that the craft would be grounded for some time as a result of the accident.
An explosion last night rocked the third-floor headquarters of the Center for Cuban Studies at 186 West Fourth Street, in Greenwich Village, causing extensive damage but no reported injuries.
Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, has purchased about 1.1 million shares of the Talcott National Corporation, which through its subsidiary is primarily engaged in financing and factoring.

One hundred of the Indians holding the historic hamlet of Wounded Knee have offered to surrender, a Government spokesman said today, but hard-core dissidents, vowing to die, are said to be keepping them in the village at gunpoint.
Senator Marlow W. Cook, Republican of Kentucky, accused the National Collegiate Athletic Association today of limiting its player eligibility investigations to black athletes only.
Texaco, Inc., as group operator, said today it had discovered potentially significant gas sands in the Gulf of Mexico about 100 miles south of Morgan City, La.

There were no unusual good-bys yesterday when Dr. Harvey B. Scribner left his office at the Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, but it was probably the last regular day in office for the 58-year-old School Chancellor.

Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange "lost money" in the aggregate during the first two months of 1973, compared with a net profit of about $250-million in the same period last year, a closed meeting of New York Stock Exchange members was informed late yesterday.
The Government reported today that its composite index of leading economic indicators, a measure of the country's economic growth, increased a substantial 1.8 per cent in February.
A 2-year-old girl was burned to death today while apparently playing with matches in the back seat of an abandoned car parked in an alley in Hempstead.
When Siegbert Tarrasch remarked, more than a halfcentury ago, that "before the end game, the gods have placed the middle game," he was objecting to the snobbery of ultra-positional chess.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, asked Congress today to "roll back prices to where they were last December" to assure labor's cooperation in Phase 3 of the Administration's wage-price stabilization effort.

Considering that Elden Turcotte has only a threehorse stable at Roosevelt Raceway these days, the 31-year-old Canadian-raised trainer has been faring surprisingly well. Despite the small string, Turcotte has scored four times in 11 starts.

The State Legislature approved an $8.77-billion state budget tonight in voting that generally followed party lines as the Republican majority rejected Democratic demands for an immediate tax cut as imprudent and premature.
The office of State Comptroller Arthur Levitt has found that financial procedures and records of North Country Community College in Saranac Lake were "inadequate" from 1966 to 1971.

The stock market tried valiantly to sustain its two-day-old rally yesterday and almost lost the battle before buying interest perked up late in the afternoon and enabled most price indicators to close virtually unchanged.

State Senator Joseph L. Galiber formally entered the crowded race for the Democratic nomination for City Controller yesterday with a promise to seek "performance and accountability at every level of government."
Bobby Hull's 51st goal of the season and second of the game gave the Winnipeg Jets a 4-3 sudden-death overtime victory over the Chicago Cougars tonight in a World Hockey Association game.

Competing in high school crew is no easy task in New Jersey. The scholastic oarsmen have to go far afield to find competition, since there are only five varsity teams in the state and the training regimen, which began March 1, is not for the weak-willed athlete. Costs for putting a crew on the water are high and the training and travel are timeconsuming.
Fears of possible Federal action to restrain retail prices and the threat of a consumer boycott of meat next week combined yesterday to further unsettle the nation's commodities markets.

The Assembly passed and sent to the Senate today a bill that would require every pharmacy to post a state list of the 150 most frequently ordered prescription drugs and the pharmacy's current retail prices.

Steak does not yet cost $100 a pound, but 'meat prices have jumped enough lately so that many people are cutting back on their consumption of top round and chops. Some cooks have been eliminating.meat entirely from their families' diets, either because they can't afford it any more or as a protest move.

A survey by the International Institute for.Strategic Studies found that the. threat of "the burgeoning power and changing tactics of Middle Eastern oilproducing countries" seemed to "overshadow almost all military threats" to North America, Europe and Japan.

Willie Mays calls him "Slim." The rest of the New York Mets call him "Stork." Twenty five years ago his mother named him George Basil Theodore. And today, Manager Yogi Berra named him to the Mets' 25-man varsity--the only rookie of 1973 to make it.

A preview of the debate to come between District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and William J. vanden Heuvel as they battle each other for the Democratic nomination for the office of Manhattan District Attorney emerged yesterday as each of the men held news conferences in their campaign headquarters.

Doubts were raised here yesterday about whether air-pollution control officials had the political power to reduce automobile traffic and implement other controversial strategies designed to bring healthful air back to the region.
Fifteen years ago, Mrs. Francoise Firminhac bought a pair of American cocker spaniels and became the first Frenchwoman to register the breed in her native land.

The 60-day first phase of the Vietnam ceasefire came to an end today with fighting continuing, peace-keeping machinery in a state of disarray and the prospects for real peace in South Vietnam apparently remote.
Despite the continuing dim outlook for peace in Vietnam, a certain relaxation has begun to appear in the austere life of the country as the first two months of the cease-fire come to an end.

Violent crime increased slightly in 1972, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today, but property crime dropped so sharply that the nation experlenced its first over-all reduction in the crime rate since 1955.

Lucien Laurin, the crack trainer who has the Kentucky Derby favorite, Secretariat,under his charge, is seeking to expand his hoped-for domination of the 3-year-old thoroughbred scene. He saddled the Hillstead Farm's Voler for yesterday's feature race at Aqueduct, and the filly scampered to a 41/2-length victory in the six-furlong sprint.

As the second production in the ABC Theater series, "Pueblo" will be shown this evening, from 9 o'clock to 11, on the network of th American Broadcasting Company. The play was originally produced at the Erera Stage in Washington.

Genevieve Pietro has found an answer to a question that must have puzzled many widows: Who is responsible for the mortgage on jointly owned property after a husband dies? The significance of the Pietro case, aside from its rarity, is that houses,
In the Cadet Chapel here this evening, Miss Ellen Malvina Censer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Censer of Eastchester, became the bride of Capt. Robert Bruce Cato, U.S.A. The Rev. James Ford,
Mario Andretti escaped injury today when his car hit a wall during tire tests at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
A financially independent lawyer complained to the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights today that she could not get a bank loan without her husband's signature.

Three former servicemen were sentenced to 18-month prison terms. today by United States District Judge James E. Doyle for the bombing of Camp McCoy, a Wisconsin Army Reserve training base, in July, 1970.
Pierre Messmer was reappointed Premier today after the cabinet submitted its resignation to President Pompidou.

The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends plans to announce in two to four weeks guidelines for operation of a new dual prime lending rate for banks and expects the present prime rate of 61/2 per cent not to be increased in the meantime.

In a decision strengthening the authority of Government administrators, the Supreme Court overruled a lower court today and reinstated a penalty imposed on a dishonest stockyard operator by the Department of Agriculture.
A self-described gambler identified by Federal officials as a reputed heroin distributor was indicted yesterday on charges that he failed to file tax returns and concealed his income.
A special grand jury empaneled by Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's anticorruption prosecutor, questioned District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens for more than three hours yesterday.
An official of the Central Intelligence Agency has testified that in 1970 he proposed to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation a
American Airlines proposed yesterday to cut the cost of excursion fares across the country by more than 20 per cent.

Australia snatched victory from the West Indies in the third cricket test today, winning by 44 runs and taking a 1-0 lead in the fivematch series. The first two matches were drawn. The West Indies needed only 66 runs in the afternoon and had five fit batsmen to get them.

" Take your choice," declares the United States Chamber of Commerce in full-page newspaper ads. "Control spending or raise taxes." That, the ads continue, is how "President Nixon laid it on the line to Congress and the American people."

Sy J. Schulman, executive officer in Westchester County of the state's Urban Development Corporation resigned today to become. chief operating officer for the Westchester County Association; a private organization of businessmen.

Over a course still showing effects of last week's snow, the $210,000 Greater Greensboro open starts tomorrow with Lee Trevino returning to competition. After a two-week tour absence, Trevino is in the field of 147 that will play the Sedgefield Country Club layout under winter regulations.

The members of the Common Market were reported yesterday to be interested in creating a common front with the United States and Japan on oil matters to give consuming nations bargaining leverage against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
President Nixon's economic priorities were challenged anew today as the Senate voted to reinstate temporarily a lowinterest emergency loan program the Administration halted abruptly last December.
Australia snatched victory from the West Indies in the third cricket test today, winning by 44 runs and taking a 1-0 lead in the fivematch series. The first two matches were drawn.
The United States sought to extend the -life of the FourParty Joint Military Commission in South Vietnam, but failed to gain Hanoi's support, an Administration official said today.
Israel announced plans today for the largest and costliest military Parade in her history to commemorate the 25th anniversary of her independence.
An official of the Central Intelligence Agency has testified that in 1970 he proposed to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation a series of steps that it and

On a complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission today, Federal District Judge George L. Hart Jr. enjoined the Frigitemp Corporation and four of its officers from violating the registration and anti-fraud provisions of the Federal securities laws. .

TEL AVIV -- Should Israel be a Jewish state, or a state with a mixed population? Of course, there will never again be a Jewish state without Arab. minorities. We cannot even think about such an eventuality.

The operations of New Jerseys largest passenger, carrier, the Bureau of Pupil Transportation of the Department of Education, have become so complex that they are being turned over to a computer program that promises to save time and money.
Imamu Amiri Baraka warned candidates for office in New Jersey today that black voters would "actively work against" them if they did not "openly" support the Kawaida Towers housing project here.

Port authorities in southwestern Sicily said today that a Libyan plane dropped three bombs near an Italian fishing boat in international waters yesterday as it strayed into the midst of Libyan vessels on a military exercise.

President Nixon sent to Congress today a reorganization plan designed to make the Government's "all-out global war on the drug menace" as well organized as the heroin traffickers who elude Federal agents every day.
Trading in the securities of the Equity Funding Corporation of America was suspended for 10 days yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission following a sharp decline in the company's stock.
Lawrence Bernard played his cards very close to his vest recently when he announced the formation of the Leisure and Recreation Group, whose first project was to be a magazine.

A Government panel concluded today that a Federal syphilis experiment involving Alabama black men was not justified. But the committee decided to note in its final report the context of the times 40 years ago
Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, legal subcommittee--10:30 A.M. Committee on Peaceful Uses of the Seabed, subcommittee on conference on law of the sea-10:30 A.M.

The two most representative political forces of Northern Ireland's Catholic and Protestant communities have given qualified approval to Britain's White. Paper. These developments do not mean that volatile Ulster is at last on a fixed course toward stability and peace; but coupled with other recent events, they give badly needed momentum to the British proposals and revive hope for a gradual evolution from current deadlock and bloodshed.

The Chinese diplomats at the United Nations, as virtually everybody knows by now, are what's socially fascinating in New York these days, and they don't make many public appearances. Last night, however, 10 of them were lured to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
At its first meeting outside the City Hall area, the City Planning Commission yesterday ended its hearings on several proposed map and zoning changes in Queens.

The 60-day first phase of the Vietnam ceasefire came to an end today with fighting continuing, peace-keeping machinery in a state of disarray and the prospects for real peace in South Vietnam apparently remote.
The team physician for the Boston Celtics reported tonight that Don Chaney would probably be able to play next Sunday when the Celtics open their playoff series with the Atlanta Hawks.

Customs inspectors at all Italian frontier points, seaports and airports began a 12-day strike today, embarrassing the Government, irking most of the nation's labor leaders, frightening housewives and delighting smugglers.
Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson maintained today that the President had clear constitutional authority to continue bombing in Cambodia to clean up a "lingering corner of the war."

Malcolm McTear Davis, editor for the last 23 years of Travel magazine, died of hepatitis yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 226 East 70th Street. Mr. Davis, who attended the University of Georgia, was sports editor of The Atlanta Constitution before Navy service in World War II.
Two cash boxes containing $11,900 were discovered missing from the Harlem Savings Bank branch at 3815 Broadway, at Fort Washington Avenue, the police reported yesterday.

The City Council Committee on Civil Service and Labor approved a measure yesterday giving the city's 5,100 auxiliary policemen and policewomen a $75-a-year uniform allowance if they put in at least 126 hours the preceding year. Citing "an outstanding job of civilian cooperation in lessening crime," the committee agreed that the allowance was warranted. Its members amiably debated proposals for a $50 and a $200 annual uniform allowance.
The Coast Guard announced yesterday the suspension of its search for two Norwegian freighters and their 61 missing crewmen, "pending further developments."

Miss Sarah M. Cole and Thomas P. Peacock, a partner in the New York law firm of Nickerson, Kramer, Lowenstein, Nessen Kamin, were married here yesterday evening. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home by Civil Court Judge Berton S. Sherman.
Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson maintained today that the President had clear constitutional authority to continue bombing in Cambodia to clean up a "lingering corner of the war."
The Communists freed 49 more American prisoners in Hanoi today, including a charter pilot. held since 1965, one of the civilian American prisoners held longest by the Vietcong.
The Communists freed 49 more American prisoners in Hanoi yesterday, including a charter pilot held since 1965, one of the civilian American prisoners held longest by the Vietcong.

There is a mystery and glamour to Pirandello plays. They are always so bright intellectually and yet so absorbing dramatically. Perhaps best of all is his "Enrico Quattro," which, under the English title of "Emperor Henry IV," arrived last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.
Three days after he ruled out a mayoral candidacy under Republican banners, Robert F. Wagner indicated yesterday that he was also inclined to pass up the Democratic mayoral primary.
Officials of several city agencies conferred privately yesterday in City Hall to explore methods of checking the inflation that has sent costs for beef, fowl and pork soaring 27 per cent in a year.
Gov. Jimmy Carter restored the death penalty in Georgia today when he signed a bill that opponents say is unconstitutional.

Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that, although it was not the commission's job to censor broadcasting, it had been forced to begin an investigation of obscene sex-oriented radio talk shows.
Julius Erving made his debut as a coach today and masterminded the Virginia Squires to a 121-106 victory over the New York Nets in the American Basketball Association's season finale tonight.
Two days before departing on a trip to the United States, President Nguyen Van Thieu formally inaugurated a new political party yesterday in an effort to consolidate his control over South Vietnam.
Congressional auditors today attributed $19.1-billion in weapons cost overruns on efforts by the military to get too much too fast, inflation and errors in estimating costs.

Harry W. Albright Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks, sharply criticized yesterday some of the advertising practices of a number of the largest mutual savings banks in the state-including by inferthe Bowery Savings Bank the nation's largest.

To the Editor: The recent introduction of a State Assembly bill by Republican Charles D. Henderson and Democrat Stanley Steingut to restore free tuition at State University could not have come at a better time. With the Keppel Commission's report still being debated and discussed, one wonders if the way both city and state universities could have parity would be for neither system to charge tuition.

A television poll of "civic activists" throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut shows that 64 per cent of those questioned favor statewide taxes to replace the financing of schools through local property taxes.
A professor of constitutional law and a wartime Premier's daughter were detained by the military police today in the latest wave of security arrests in Athens.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today the appointment of Arthur L. Amolsch as director of public information.

Negotiators for the city's three major daily newspapers have a heavy schedule of bargaining talks with newspaper unions in the next 48 hours, but neither side appeared to be expecting any strike action when current contracts expire at midnight tomorrow.

A 72-hour northeaster last week washed 'out more sand from New Jersey's beaches than any storm since 1962. The storm missed the coast by 150 miles, but it gave rise to high, sand scouring waves that appeared to have done most of their damage at Atlantic City and Harvey Cedars beaches. Atlantic City's Engineer, Joseph Borrasso, said the storm washed out sand from about half the city's beach.

A week ago-addled perhaps by a warm wind that brought with it the sweet aroma of an awakening salt marsh-this writer predicted that migrating striped bass would arrive off Cape Cod and the outlying islands much earlier than usual.
The Negro Ensemble Company opened its four-week Dance and Music Festival on Tuesday evening at the St. Marks Playhouse with the Morse Donaldson Dance Theater.

Anyone for glass-fiber tombstones, self-lighting cigarettes, fog eliminators or zipper pullers? More than 500 inventors from 26 countries have these and hundreds of other items on exhibition at "Patexpo '73," which runs through tomorrow at the New York Hilton.

The State Legislature approved an $8.77-billion state budget tonight in voting that generally followed party lines as the Republican majority rejected Democratic demands for an immediate tax cut as imprudent and premature.
Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan accepted an invitation today to visit Moscow for a meeting on joviet-Japanese relations.

Two levels of government have yet to decide on two critical issues that will influence the ecological future of Newark's virtually untouched 35,000-acre watershed area at, the conjunction of Morris, Passaic and Sussex counties, 35 miles west of the city.

Thomas J. O'Reilly, who retired in 1956 after many years on the legal staff of Texaco, Inc., died at Montefiore Hospital on Tuesday. He was 84 years old and lived at 2869 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx.
Dave Cowens scored 13 of his 23 points in the third period defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 120-101, tonight in the last game of the National Basketball Association's regular season for both teams.

In a decision that will mean an infusion of at least $53-million into the ailing economy of Long Island, two aeropsace companies there have been chosen to build. the wings and tail fin for the nation's manned space-shuttle vehicle.

One of the jurors deliberating the fate of black militant H. Rap Brown was excused from further service yesterday because of ill health. The development came an hour after the State Supreme Court jury began its second day of deliberations following a trial that lasted more than 10 weeks.

The Right Rev. William J. Scarlett, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Missouri from 1930 to 1952 and a social and theological liberal, died yesterday at Boston Hospital. He was 80 years old and had lived for many years at Castine, Me.

New York bridge enthusiasts who visit Israel can count on a warm welcome and may meet some old friends, judging by the recent experience' of Sol Seidman, who has been in the top rank of New York players and administrators for many years.
Holmes and I were seated in our Baker Street rooms in a blue funk, he swabbing his dottle with cocaine whilst I watched Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce playing Holmes and myself on the telly.

The State Department announced today that the Arena Stage Company would put on "Our Town" and "Inherit the Wind" during its visit to the Soviet Union this fall-the first dramatic presentations in the 15-year history of the Soviet-American cultural exchange.

Chris Evert unveiled a smashing new tennis dress and a serve to match, and Linda Tuero showed that parapsychology can pay off on a tennis court last night in the opening round of the $30,000 Lady Gotham tournament at Felt Forum.
Fred Taylor ended two weeks of speculation yesterday when he announced he had turned down an offer from Northwestern University and would remain as basketball coach at Ohio State.

Clark R. Mollenhoff, a former Presidential aide, cast aside any question of executive privilege today when he produced a surprise batch of memos, some internal White House documents and one document marked "confidential"...
By coincidence, 1976 marks not only the 200th anniversary of the American Revolution, but also the 200th anniversary of the Soviet Union's Bolshoi Theater.
James W. McCord Jr. said in a closed Senate hearing today that John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, had prior knowledge of the Watergate plot, Congressional sources said tonight.
Mikhail K. Kalatozov, a movie director, died yesterday at the age of 69. Mr. Kalatozov, a Georgian, started in the film industry as a technician in 1923.
Interest rates on local government bonds declined yesterday as the tax-exempt sector outperformed the rest of the ?? fixed-income securities markets.

The prospect of Chinese players competing at Forest Hills and Wimbledon has been raised by a press report from Peking that a national tennis tournament was held in Shanghai from March 11 to last Saturday.
Unable to raise enough money to give him "a chance of winning," Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he was withdrawing as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
The list of musical marriages that are made in heaven would surely include that of the Philadelphia Orchestra and Sergei Rachmaninoff.
A plainclothes policeman who was said to have sought a payoff from a Harlem numbers entrepreneur was sentenced yesterday to a year in prison. Charles Lee, 40 years old,

Democratic legislators vowed today to continue their fight to repeal vacancy decontrol, which permits landlords to raise rents on rent-controlled apartments that become vacant, and to allow New York City to enact more stringent rent-control regulations than permitted by the State Division of Housing.

Halsey, Stuart Co., the investment banking subsidiary of the Lincoln National Corporation, saw its earnings drop sharply in 1972 to $203,000 from $2.1-million in 1971, the annual report of the parent company disclosed yesterday. Revenues declined to $13.5-million from $18.1.millinn.
At a dinner party here not long ago, an old hand in this city's legal circles was talking about a fellow lawyer who tells clients he has connections at the White House.
Mikhail K. Kalatozov, a movie director, died yesterday at the age of 69. Mr. Kalatozov, a Georgian, started in the film industry as a technician in 1923.
Interest rates on local government bonds declined yesterday as the tax-exempt sector outperformed the rest of the ?? fixed-income securities markets.

Pace College announced that it has become Pace Uniyersity, and disclosed tentative plans for a $20-million I. M. Pei-designed tower opposite City Hall to house the university's law, nursing, education and graduate schools.
Westerners traveling through East Germany reported today that they had witnessed a gun battle in the Thuringian mountains, apparently between Soviet Army Deserters and Soviet military policemen.

The national track and field committee of the Amateur Athletic Union voted unanimously today to continue its policy of no competition in track and field with the Union of South Africa. It said it would not issue travel permits for competition in. that country. The ruling applies to individuals as well as teams.
" The joy in theater comes through discovery and the capacity to discover," writes Joseph Chaikin, founder and director of the Open Theater, in his book, "The Presence of the Actor."
A plan designed to eliminate strikes and "crisis bargaining" was presented here today by the executive board of the United Steelworkers Union.

A former infantryman who served in Vietnam charged yesterday that, he had lost an eye damaged in combat after the Veterans Administration denied him medical treatment because he had an undesirable discharge from the Army.

Maj. Robert Peel of the Air Force, a former prisoner of war fn Vietnam, apparently fell asleep at the wheel and crashed his new $10,000 sports car against a utility pole early today, the Tennessee Highway Patrol aid.

Four of the recently released prisoners of the war in Vietnam have been selected for promotion to general or admiral, the Defense Department announced. Named for promotion to brigadier general were two Air Force colonels John P.
Curtis A. Haines, a retired vice president of the Electronics Systems Group of GTE Sylvania, Inc., died Tuesday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Clearwater Beach.

A committee of priests and lay people charged at a news conference yesterday that the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was ignoring the needs of its Spanish-speaking parishioners, although they constituted more than half of the 1.8 million people in the archdiocese.

Ever since Glenn Gould recorded Bach's "Goldberg Variations" 18 years ago, he has been friskily expanding his horizons, with varied reactions from the musical press. His Bach, Schoenberg, Prokofiev and Scriabin-plus such eccentricities as Byrd, Gibbons, the Liszt transcription of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony and contemporary Canadian composers-have generally been welcomed with enthusiasm.
The United States dollar gained in world money markets today. Gold weakened.

James Joy Jr., business manager for Utility Workers Local 1-2, warned Consolidated Edison yesterday that his union must have a contract settlement by noon tomorrow to avert a strike threatened for midnight Saturday.
Vice President Agnew defended this country's role in the Vietnam war last night, describing it "as one of the most unselfish missions ever to be undertaken by any nation in defense of another."

Alfred J. Ranieri, a Bronx lawyer who got his job on the city's Tax Commission through the intervention of his local John V. Lindsay Association coordinator, was elevated yesterday,by Mayor Lindsay to the acting presidency of the commission.

In importing Monteverdi's "L'Incoronazione di Poppea" from the Caramoor Festival, where it was staged in 1968 by Gerald Freedman, the New York City Opera made a great contribution to New York's musical life.
The Johns-Manville Corporation, a multinational producer of building materials, is planning to increase its capital expenditures this year to a record $84-million from $74.3-million spent in 1972.

The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it would resume the issuance of 12month convertible standby commitments on April 2. Fannie Mae suspended the issuance of these commitments on March 20 due to unsettled market conditions.

Plans are advancing for a new afternoon newspaper in New York City. John M. Shaheen, a millionaire industrialist who has contributed to Republican campaigns, is reported by newspaper sources to have bought presses, negotiated with the Lithographers Union, inquired about the costs of subscribing to wire services and agreed to purchase the old Morning Telegraph Building at 525 West 52d Street.

Quietly and in no evident fear of an uprising, President Nixon has done to the Subversive Activities Control Board and the Internal Security Division of the Justice Department what Presidents Kennedy and Johnson did not quite dare to do. He has killed them-the first by dropping it entirely from the budget, the second by simple order of his Attorney General.

A week ago-addled perhaps by a warm wind that brought with it the sweet aroma of an awakening salt marsh-this writer predicted that migrating striped bass would arrive off Cape Cod and the outlying islands much earlier than usual.

Niles Trammell, former president and chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, died yesterday in North Miami, Fla. He was 78 years old.

The 38-year-old black golf professional from Washington, who fired an opening 65 in the Greater New Orleans open last week, turned in a career record seven-under-par 64 in the $210,000 Greater Greensboro open to lead by one stroke. President Anwar el-Sadat has proclaimed himself Military Governor General, which gives him the authority to use emergency powers in case of national crisis. The accumulation of new political powers in the hands of the President came two days after his announcement that he was taking over the premiership in addition to the Presidency.

Two hundred men, women and children protesting Federal cutbacks in day-care funds tied up traffic on the Triborough Bridge yesterday morning. Six persons were arrested and three policemen received minor injuries. The demonstrators, some carrying infants, surged onto the Manhattan spur of the bridge at about 8 A.M. shouting, "We want day care, not welfare!" They finally marched off the bridge, and traffic returned to normal at about 10:30 A.M.

Responding to mounting criticism, the White House indicated today its readiness to compromise with the Senate's investigation of the Watergate case on the issue of furnishing witnesses and information from President Nixon's personal staff.
