Public television was accused today of promoting liberal bias and at the same time, of encouraging conservative propaganda. The Senate communications subcommittee heard testimony on proposed legislation to authorize a two-year $140-million budget for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the agency that oversees and helps finance public radio and TV.
The controversy over television blackouts of sports events took another twist in a dispute over the televising of tomorrow's Muhammad Ali-Ken Norton heavyweight fight.
Representatives of the country's public television stations voted today to form themselves into a new and what they hope is a stronger, central organization known as the Public Broadcasting Service.

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial today upheld a former reporter's right not to Reveal the sources of his in formation. However, the ruling was not made on constitutional grounds, but on the grounds of materiality to this case.
Jerry Hoses' three run home run in the seventh inning powered the Yankees to a 4-1 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight. It was the new reserve catcher's first homer in a Yankee uniform.
Profit taking weakened most prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market. Prices had advanced for the four previous sessions.

Children living in the largely black Tilden Houses projects in Brownsville will be phased out of the Canarsie-East Flatbush school district in Brooklyn over the next eight years, under a plan adopted unanimously last night by the Board of Education.

The state's business establishment and environmental interests clashed head-on today in a debate before the State Senate Judiciary Committee on a bill that would enable individual citizens to file damage suits against environmental polluters.
Government leaders in Jerusalem are considering measures to curb Christian missionaries, who are said to have become more aggressive in Israel with the appearance of- the "Jews for Jesus" movement.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 30-Henry (Hank) Schmidt will retire from Montclair State College in June, but for Schmidt there is no day-dreaming of bouncing around the waters near Cape Cod in his boat with a stiff summer breeze in his face. He is too busy for that right now. Schmidt started a new department at Montclair State last February and is the first director of intramurals and sports recreation. By graduation day in June,

Dave and Stuart Pruzansky, brothers from Passaic, N. J., pinned their opponents in the second period last night to highlight the first round of the 15th annual Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships at the New York Athletic Club.
Manufacturers' inventories rose strongly again in February but sales increased just as fast, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Soviet Union's Minsisterr of Culture, Yekaterina A. Furtseva, gave President Nixon a landscape painting in the White House and at a news conference later defended the ban in her country on works by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Soviet Novelist who won a Nobel Prize in 1970.

President Nixon today accepted with "deepest personal regret" the resignation of Ellsworth Bunker as United States Ambassador to South Vietnam and announced that he would name a career diplomat, Graham A. Martin, to the Saigon post.

The Alaska National Guard, under examination by the Air Force Office of Special Investigation and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for alleged misuse of Government aircraft, was shaken fate yesterday by Gov. William A. Egan's report that some of the charges against guard officers were true.

Members of Congress from both parties and spokesmen for the meat packers and supermarkets voiced disapproval today of the ceilings on meat prices announced last night by President Nixon in a reversal of policV.
Mrs. Jill Warburg Maass and Dr. Allan Murray Cartter were married here today at the home of the bride by Rabbi Gershon Fischer. The Rev. Richmond Grant, an Episcopal priest, gave a blessing.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, in his capacity as acting governor, today signed into law a bill delaying until July 1 the starting late for a new Housing Court within the Civil Court in New York City.

Responding to mounting criticism, the White House indicated today its readiness to compromise with the Senate!s investigation of the Watergate case on the issue of furnishing witnesses and information from President Nixon's personal staff,

The Bergen County Republican Committee and two of its offshoots urged a Federal Court today to dismiss a suit filed against them by Representative Charles W. Sandman on the ground that it raised "serious" constitutional issues.

Hours after receiving Government approval of a plan to offer a new kind of coast-tocoast fare as low as $89.50 one-way, Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it was shelving plans to offer the new bargain.

President Nixon ordered last night a ceiling on the price of beef, veal, pork, mutton and lamb at the processing, wholesale and retail level but not on the price of meat on the hoof or any other foods. Here are some questions raised by the President's action and tentative answers drawn from statements by Administration officials and consumer and industry experts.

A Federal judge has ruled that $50,000 contributed by the New York Telephone Company to a campaign for the transportation bond issue in the state's 1971 election was an illegal political contribution.

Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell, a retired commander of the New Jersey National Guard and a former State Senator and Assemblyman, died of a heart attack a Burlington County Memorial Hospital Wednesday. He was 80 years old and lived in Lumberton.

An early spring storm carrying heavy snows and rains moved across the South and Southwest yesterday. Snowfalls of up to 22 inches clogged New Mexico cities and the storm threatened to dump more water into the flood-swollen Mississippi, United Press International reported.

" What you do a lot, you do well," was Jerry Lucas's explanation of his pinpoint shooting from long range last night as the Knicks jumped off to victory in their first playoff game against the Baltimore Bullets.
Mayor Lindsay named Betty Furness as the city's new Consumer Affairs Commissioner yesterday. She replaces Bess Myerson, who resigned after four years in the job.

Vincent Bracciale Jr. who has won more races this year than any other jockey in North America, rode four winners at Pimlico Race Course today and ran his total to 11 for the week and 133 for the year.
The dollar showed continued strength in heavy trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market this week, causing a revision in earlier predictions of its eventual parity with the yen.
A Federal judge has temporarily restrained New York State from implementing a new law mandating a computerized surveillance of prescriptions for narcotics and other frequently abused drugs.

Superior Court Judge Max Mehler today set a trial date of Oct. 15 for Robert L. Vesco, former chairman of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., on charges that he acted improperly in gaining control of the once-powerful mutual fund empire founded by Bernard Cornfeld.

A "last-ditch" offer from PATH officials was overwhelm ingly rejected yesterday by the Brotherhood of Railway Car men, which has threatened to strike the 14-mile commuter line at one minute after mid night tonight.
Huang Chen, one of China's most seasoned diplomats and a figure of marked importance within the country's Communist party, was named yesterday to head China's liaison office in Washington.

LONDON --Before one can grasp what a Moslem is, one must first be aware of what modern man has become. It is precisely the abysmal ignorance of the so-called educated man in our society that makes the crucial question of existence difficult of approach. Cursed with a superficial verbal coherence the educated man feels entitled to expound and express himself endlessly.

The New York Mets broke camp today and started a meandering trip north with 25 players and several major problems. Their immediate destination was West Palm Beach, where they were to stay overnight until meeting the Yankees tomorrow in Fort Lauderdale.

Governor Cahill has proposed a $12-million mass-transit plan for Bergen County that would convert the Penn Central freight tracks on the old West Shore division into an express bus commutation line to the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel.

Other coaches have had easier transitions from college to professional basketball. John McLeod of Oklahoma got the coaching job with the Phoenix Suns yesterday with the assignment of injecting some life into a team which has dropped to a 38-44 won-lost record. In the midst of widespread confusion in the meat industry today, packers, wholesalers and livestock feeders said they expected President Nixon's new ceiling on beef and pork to keep supermarket prices at their current high levels and do nothing to bring them down in the future.

At least 50,000 marchers are expected to parade north through the canyons of midtown Broadway today to honor the men who served in Southeast Asia during the 12-year Vietnam war, parade officials said yesterday.

The judge in the Watergate case pressed the Government today to summon more witnesses before a Federal grand jury "in view of substantive developments" in the conspiracy. He did not identify the potential witnesses.
The Consolidated . Edison Company and two unions representing its 18,000 employes reached agreement on new twoyear contracts yesterday, averting a strike threatened for midnight.

Today marks the end of Red Cross month-the time of year when the Red Cross conducts its annual appeal in residential areas to supplement funds raised in the business community through the United Fund of Greater New York.
President Anwar el-Sadat looked for all the world this week like a ship's captain clearing the deck and battening down the hatches for a storm--or a battle.

The videotape recorder on the Earth Resources Technology Satellit (ERTS-1) has apparently failed and the spacecraft's earth surveying will now be limited to North and South America, the National Aeronutics and Space Administration announced yesterday.

Betsy Cullen of Tulsa, Okla., in her ninth year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, scored a fourunder-par 69 at the Woodlake Golf Club today to take the first-round lead in the $30,000 Alamo open tournament. Three strokes behind at 72 was long-hitting Betty Burfeindt of Canaan, N. Y.

After years of obscurity, controversy and internal discord, the American Film Institute will be in the limelight tomorrow night, when President Nixon comes here to present its Life Achievement award to John Ford, the director.

African nationalist guerrillas killed a white farmer in the Wedza area, about 70 miles southeast of Salis, bury today, according to headquarters of the security force here. The headquarters statement said that security forces were searching for a guerrilla gang known to be in the area.
With little dressmakers no longer flourishing, and not too many women adept at wielding a scissors and needle, an individual look is hard to come by. The stores are trying, however.

" Chinese ceramics have suddenly become the rage, both here and abroad," reported Ralph M. Chait this week, looking amazingly refreshed after a three-week buying trip in Europe that would have exhausted anyone half his 81 years.
Aerodex, Inc., said today that the armed services' Board of Contract Appeals had awarded it $5.13-million on a disputed claim for overhaul work on J-57 military jet aircraft engines.
Two 14-year-old boys and one 15-year-old were charged with murder yesterday in the bathtub drowning of a 16-yearold friend in his father's apartment in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

Edward Steichen left his imprint on photography by insisting that it could become an art-in portraiture, in commerce, in battle and, finally, in the service of the human family. His photographs of celebrated people ranged from Rodin to Garbo; his combat pictures on the carrier Lexington are part of the annals of war.

Robert M. McGlotten, a special assistant to Peter J. Brennan, the Secretary of Labor, urged minority contractors here yesterday to de-emphasize efforts at obtaining ghetto housing-construction projects and concentrate instead on getting work "where the money is."

Two major Wall Street brokerage firms-Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., and Loeb, Rhoades Co.-said yesterday they had made substantial employe layoffs as a result of a decline in business.

Fifteen of the 18 House members from New York City, who sometimes have enough trouble moving their own bills through Congress, have joined in a lobbying effort to try to block a bill in the New York State Legislature in Albany.
Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz estimated today that 1973 beef imports would be a record 1.45 billion pounds, up 8 per cent from last year.

Miss June Driscoll, daughter of Mrs. Thomas J. Driscoll of Rutherford and the late Mr. Driscoll, was married this evening to Robert G. Mayer, a widower, of West Orange. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Mayer of New York.

Richard J. Pietschmann, a sound technician for television and motion pictures, who concentrated in recent years on recording specials and documentaries for the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of a stroke Wednesday at the Nassau Community Hospital in Mineola. His age was 62, and he lived here.

Lucius Allen scored 9 of his 20 points in a decisive third quarter tonight, leading the streaking Milwaukee Bucks to a 110-90 victory over the Golden State Warriors in the first round of the National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoffs.

Marty Glickman, who has been broadcasting the Giants football games over radio station WNEW since 1961, has been signed to broadcast the Jets games next season for station WOR. He will replace Merle Harmon, the WOR Jets broadcaster since 1964.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie was designated today by Democratic Congressional leaders to respond next Monday night to the address made by President Nixon last night.
A Bangor grocer who was tired of explaining rising food prices to his customers went to jail today for selling milk 2 cents below the price set by the Maine Milk Commission.

President Nguyen Van Thieu is preparing to set out for the United States tomorrow, and officials at the presidential residence say that his principal purpose is to obtain directly from President Nixon the minimal assurances underwriting the survival of a non-Communist South Vietnam.
A Vietnam veteran, described by police as a heroin-addict who kept saying he wanted to die, fired 23 shots into the walls and ceiling of a Bronx methadone clinic yesterday, the police said.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns conceded openly for the first time today that his successful effort to hold the prime lending rate at commercial banks below other market interest rates "has been encouraging an excessive and potentially unhealthy expansion of bank credit."

Owen I. A. Roche, an author and consultant on international affairs, died last Saturday after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.

Dan Issel scored Kentucky's first 13 points and added 30 more to lead the Colonels to a 129-101 victory over the Virginia Squires tonight in the first game of their American Basketball Association East Division playoff series.
The Bank of Japan today raised its official discount rate by an unusually large 0.75 point to 5 per cent from 4.25 per cent, effective Monday, bank governor Tadashi Sasaki announced today.

President Gustav Heinemann signed a disputed pension reform into law today, provoking a constitutional test. The amended bill was rejected by the conservatives in the upper house of Parliament, where the Christian Union parties have a 21-to-20 vote majority. The upper house is made up of representatives of the 10 state governments.

Four high Rockland County officials, including the chairman of the County Legislature, have refused to sign waivers of immunity in a major grand jury investigation of official corruption according to the County District Attorney, Robert R. Meehan.

Several large oil companies have started putting a limit on or trimming gasoline deliveries because of shortages in crude oil. The eighth annual Capt. Ronald Zinn Memorial 10-mile walking race will be held today on the Asbury Park (N. J.) boardwalk. The race is expected t attract at least three United States Olympians, and some of the East's top competitors, as well as many novices in the sport.

And, because Japan is a sagacious, remarkably disciplined and homogeneous nation, this peaceful policy is well along the road to success.

A 25-year-old jazz drummer, a former mathematics student born a Russian and a Jew, is ending the first week of a hunger strike a the Soviet Embassy here that he hopes will bring enough pressure on the Soviet Government to force it to allow the emigration of his wife's parents and sister.
Betsy Cullen fought off a bad case of the jitters and a strong charge by Betty Burfeindt today for a two-stroke victory in the $30,000 Alamo open Ladies Professional Association tournament.
Leaders of the diverse consumer groups making up the meat boycott movement said yesterday that their projected week-long effort to drive down prices had gotten off to a good start.

American military deserters can no longer expect automatic asylum in Sweden, a high Government official said today. "Sweden has no reason to accept deserters now that the Vietnam war is over and the soldiers no longer risk being sent to a war scene," said Kjell Oeberg, general director of the Swedish Immigration Board.

The juvenile justice system of New York City has slipped into confusion and despair, caught in a crisis so severe that judges and jailers alike often say they are harming more children than they are helping.
The Chicago Tribune reported in its editions today that a Federal grand jury had traced more than $150,000 in alleged cash kickbacks made to the late Illinois Secretary of State Paul Powell.

"Wonder what Clay's gonna say now," he said to Howard Cosell. "That I took all the fight outta him?"

Suits asking for more than $16-million for deaths and injuries suffered when a plane crashed into an ice cream parlor here last September have been filed in state and Federal courts.

Charles J. Rosenbloom, a philanthropist and president of the Rosenbloom Finance Company who played a role in the creation of the State of Israel, died today in Jerusalem. He was there to celebrate his 75th birthday on April 17 and to attend a harp recital by his wife, Mrs. Lucile Johnson Rosenbloom.

The name on the door of the Chancellor's office on the 10th floor of the Board of Education headquarters building in downtown Brooklyn still reads "Harvey B. Scribner" and will for three more months. Inside the office and those occupied by his key aides there is a bustle of activity and a pretense that things are pretty much as they have been.

Mrs. Maria L. Campbell, who recited a nursery rhyme on one of Thomas A. Edison's first experimental phonograph records in 1877, died yesterday at Community Memorial Hospital. She was 103 years old and lived in Beachwood in Ocean County.

Freddie Lewis scored 30 points to lead Indiana to a 106-93 American Basketball Association victory over the Denver Rockets today. The victory gave the Pacers a 2-0 lead in the four-of-seven-game Western Division first-round playoff series.

The wide popularity of the impressionist and' post-impressionist French painters was dramatically underscored yesterday when some 15,000 persons turned out on a damp day for a preview at the National Gallery of Art.

Supporters of the rival Greek Cypriote leaders, President Makarios and Gen. George Grivas, tosssed bombs in two separate incidents today as the island marked the 18th anniversary of its independence struggle.

Mrs. Caroline Lejeune Thompson, who as C. A. Lejeune was one of Britain's most respected film critics, died today. She was 76 years old. With Anthony Lejeune, the only child of her marriage to E. Roffe Thompson, she wrote a television play, "Vicky's First Ball."

Gail Goodrich and Jerry West scored a total of 63 points, leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 108-93 victory over the Chicago Bulls tonight in the Western Conference playoff series. Los Angeles now leads, two games to none.

The subways are getting an unexpected gift today: $74-million from people who travel in automobiles. That is the amount of operating surpluses of 1972 from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority being turned over to the New York City Transit Authority to help defray a deficit expected to total more than $200-million this year.

An organization of ItalianAmerican professional and business men said yesterday that the actor Marlon Brando was guilty of "a blatant contradiction" in refusing an Academy Award because of the way American Indians are 'depicted in movies after he had played in the gangster film "The Godfather."

The Newark Museum is pondering the surrender of a fourth-century Roman mosaic that, it has been told, was stolen from an archeological site in Syria. It was sold to the museum two years ago by an unidentified New York dealer.

Brian Oldfield set an unofficial world indoor record of 69 feet 11/2 inches in the shot-put tonight and Kip Keino won the mile run in 4 minutes 4.4 seconds at the third meet of the professional International Track Association. A crowd of 6,365 turned out at the Cow Palace.
Stan Smith broke service at love against top-seeded Rod Laver today in the final game of the championship match to win, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, and take the $10,000 top prize of the, Holton tennis tourney.

The World Hockey Association upheld tonight a protest by the Minnesota Fighting Saints and scheduled a game between the Saints and Alberta Oilers to determine the fourth team in the league's West Division playoffs. It will be played Tuesday or Wednesday at a site to be determined.

Pekingopened its new Friendship Store for foreign residents and visitors today. The store's star item was in the supertax bracket range -- an exquisite piece of green jade set in a gold ring, costing about $95,000.
Jack Walters of Lake Placid and Sheila 'Young of Detroit, both former Olympians, won seniors' titles today in the Diamond Trophy indoor speed skating championships.

Suzanne Silvercruys, sculptor, painter, lecturer and author, died here yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment, after becoming ill while on a lecture tour. She was 74 years old and lived in Tucson, Ariz.
Curt Flood, who unsuccessfully challenged baseball's reserve clause before the Supreme Court, says his efforts made people aware of "what the ballplayer is up against."

Members of Local 333, United Marine Division of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. National Maritime Union, voted 3 to 1 yesterday to ratify a threeyear contract and ended the threat of a strike by tugboatmen in New York harbor and adjacent waters.

The National Football League opens its annual meetings here tomorrow with rules changes and selection of postseason game sites the major items on the agenda.

Public interest groups are pressing a record number of proposals for corporate action at the annual stockholder meetings that are now beginning. But at the same time the corporate social-responsibility movement is broadening its tactics. As specialized public-interest groups proliferate, coalesce and sometimes bicker, corporate challenges are increasingly taking a legalistic turn. Lawsuits are being filed. Petitions are being made to government agencies that regulate corporations and industries.
Bob Nystrom and Bill Harris scored third-period goals tonight to give the New York Islanders a 4-4 tie with the Atlanta Flames in the final game of the season for the two expansion teams.
Senator Walter F. Mondale said today that 276 individuals with incomes in excess of $100,000 in 1971 had paid no Federal income tax for the year.
David Pearson survived a duel with Cale Yarborough today and gunned his Mercury to victory before 72,000 persons in the Atlanta 500-mile stock car race.
Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia said today he would seek the normalization of relations between the three countries of the subcontinentIndia, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

Harriet Newhall, director of admissions at Mount Holyoke College from 1939 to her retirement in 1958, died Tuesday in Springfield, where she had been living. She was 80 years old.

Vladimir Vysotsky, a young movie star and dramatic actor who has built a wide following among young people with his throaty, underground songs that often parody Soviet life and the Establishment, has been officially scolded for giving illegal concerts.

The siego of a South Vietnamese ranger camp ended its fifth week today, the Government said. It also reported several small clashes in the Saigon region and said that seven civilians were killed in other attacks.

The investigation into the dismissal three years ago of A. Ernest Fitzgerald from his post as Air Force Deputy Assistant Secretary calls for speedy resolution. Mr. Fitzgerald deserves public exoneration and reinstatement if he was fired for entirely political reasons; as the evidence strongly suggests. The American people have a right to demand that public servants who fight against waste of the taxpayers' money are rewarded rather than punished for their efforts.

Bobby Woodhouse took a mudbath as the field got away for the third race at Aqueduct yesterday when his mount pitched him to the sloppy track. But the 23-year-old rider didn't let that mishap interfere with the rest of his riding assignments.

Juvenile crime is skyrocketing, and the city's juvenile justice system finds itself able to do little to stem it. Recidivism is so high that a Legal Aid Society defense lawyer says it's "almost perfect," that judges of the Family Court call their tribunal a "revolving door" and that child after child graduates from the juvenile system into the jails and prisons for adults.

Although I decline with thanks the protection offered me by President Nixon's declaration extending executive privilege to all former White House aides, no previous White House counsel could be unmoved by the plight of the present counsel, John W. Dean 3d.
A Vietnamese bandit dressed as a policeman who had been robbing American officials and civilians in downtown Saigon was caught today when one of his intended victims pulled a gun.

Chancellor Willy Brandt, rejecting an accusation by the Opposition conservatives that his Government was fostering antiAmericanism, issued a fourpoint declaration of loyalty to the Atlantic alliance today.

The Kremlin yesterday ordered a reorganization of the Soviet Union's industry in a continuing search for an efficient system of managing the country's vast Governmentrun economy. The reform is the most comprehensive since 1965, and is to be carried out over a three-year period. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany will visit Israel for four days in June in the first visit to the Jewish state by a German head of government. Mr. Brandt was in Israel in 1960 when he was Mayor of West Berlin.

Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation said today that it would raise some Western and Midwestern fares 10 or 12 per cent and reduce some fares in other areas as much as 19 per cent April 29.

About two years ago, an alert, mature 13-year-old boy created a minor sensation by winning a title in a NassauSuffolk sectional tournament. Now even more alert and even more mature, Bobbie Levin has created a major sensation by becoming the youngest Life Master ever, beating by a month the record set by Joseph Livezey of Springfield, Pa.

Two state environmental projectsone designed to insure that much of the state's farmland remains so "in perpetuity" and one to plan for the state's still undeveloped land masseswere announced today by Governor Cahill.

Jacques Plante, 44 years old and still going strong, will be in goal when the Boston Bruins open defense of the Stanley Cup against the New York Rangers at Boston Garden tomorrow night.

President Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu ol South Vietnam opened a twoday conference here today in what the White House called an "atmosphere of friendship and cordiality."

Two hundred of the more affluent commuters of the struck PATH line avoided congested roads and crowded trains today by taking a panoramic trip to lower Manhattan in a 120-foot fishing boat.

An evolving understanding of the chemical messengers that control the activities of individual body cells may lead to new ways to treat such diverse diseases as psoriasis, asthma and cancer, it was reported today.

Regular riders of PATH, the Port Authority Trans-Hudson commuter railroad, found other ways to get into and out of Manhattan yesterday on the first weekday of the strike by 214 members of the Brother-hood of Railway Carmen. But it was not always easy.

Dr. Ernest L. Hettich, professor emeritus of classics and director emeritus of the library system at New York University, died on March 20 at his home in Sandyston Township, Sussex County, N. J. He was 75 years old.

Joseph E. Knight, a Democratic party official in Illinois for 40 years, died today in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 61 years old. Mr. Knight, who was Democratic party treasurer in Illinois in the nineteen-fifties and sixties, was involved in two legal actions charging officials with wrongdoings.

Declined to review a decision that attorneys' fees in stockholders' actions should be based by the court on amount of time devoted to the case rather than dollar benefit conferred on clients. (No. 72-1121, Ellis v. Flying Tiger Corporation.)

CLEVELAND -- "It's difficult to be Jewish alone," remarked 20.year-old Cindy Pearlman. "That's almost a cliche here," added Miss Pearlman, who lives with 10 other young people, most of them students at Case Western Reserve University. "But, well, watching each other pray, you pick up this incredible warmth."
The Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, Inc., yesterday released a study predicting a gasoline shortage of 125,000. barrels a day in this year's second and third quarters.

The Two-Party Joint Military Commission, which began operating as a peace-keeping body only five days ago, was threatened with collapse today in a dispute over a besieged South Vietnamese ranger outpost.

The Cleveland Indians obtained Leo Cardenas, an experienced shortstop, from the California Angels today in exchange for Tom McCraw, an infielder-outfielder and Bob Marcano of the Tribe's Triple A affiliate in Oklahoma City.
Henry Kearns, chairman of the United States Export-Import Bank, visited Soviet officials at three agencies today to explore trade possibilities, the United States Embassy said.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie declared tonight that Congress would resist any effort by President Nixon to assert "one-man rule" over the Government.
Officials here are conceding that Pakistan is better off economically without her former eastern wing, which is now Bangladesh.

Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today he "wouldn't be surprised" if President Nixon vetoed any legislation that would freeze prices, rents and interest rates, and urged Congress simply to extend the President's existing economic control authority.
The faces and comments of two genuinely beautiful people, the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his widow, Coretta, light up the home screen for an hour tonight at 10 over Channel 9.
The value of new construction. put in place in February was at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $135.3 billion, the Commerce Department announced today.

An investment officer for Manufacturers Hanover Trust snatched a pistol from a guard in the glass and marble lobby of the bank's uptown headquarters on Park Avenue yesterday, stepped back and killed himself with one shot in the head.
Oliver Hurd Everett, an investment broker, died of cancer today at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N. Y. He kas 56 years old and lived here.

Joseph Cardinal Lefebvre, former Archbishop of Bourges, died there today at the age of 80.. Cardinal Lefebvre first studied law, but changed to theology after World War I, in which he was seriously wounded and taken prisoner.

The plays of Rochelle Owens seem difficult because they are written so simply. They are naive in their disregard of convention and freedom from sophistication or even common sense. Her latest work, "The Karl Marx

Now in its second year, the New Directors-New Films series currently at the Museum of Modern Art comes as something of an old friend and a cultural ornament -- in a movie season not overloaded with cultural ornaments, or old friends.

Top-seeded Marty Riessen displayed superb passing shots to defeat Ray Moore of South Africa, and Arthur Ashe and Ken Rosewall won easily in the first round of the $50,000 River Oaks tennis tournament today.

On Oct. 27, 1971, a bank supervisor's unhappiness turned to joy when he won $25,350 on an exacta at Yonkers Raceway, enabling him to make restitution of $6,665 he had embezzled to cover his earlier gambling.

April showers-with only occasional lapses into the heavy rains of the weekend-came New York's way yesterday, producing minor problems for motorists, puddle obstacles for pedestrians and reflections on rain-slick streets for windowsitters.
The Government proposed today Federal safety inspection standards for the nation's nearly 100 million used cars, including uniform brake, tire and steering tests.

The Philippine Supreme Court rejected a series of protests today and declared that "there is no further obstacle to the new Constitution," which gives President Ferdinand E. Marcos the right to rule indefinitely until new elections are called.
ANKARA, Turkey -- Across the bleak Anatolian plain of central Turkey, the fields that stretch as far as the eye can see are lightly greening with spring wheat. sprouting among patches of snow.
Ken Rojek, Bohack's meat manager, sold only $35 worth of meat until noon. "It's like my meat has some disease," the man at Hill's supermarket said. "Nobody'll even touch it."

Collectively, The Grand Union knows everything about performing except when to stop. After two and threequarter intermissionless hours at the Dance Gallery Sunday evening, it released a limp and soggy audience.

The Washington Star-News began publishing the complete newspaper today by a photographic process. Star-News executives said the use of photocomposition -- known as "cold type" would reduce the time between the writing of an article and its appearance on the newsstand and would also reduce costs.
Massachusetts plans to ask permission to exhume the body of Ellen Reich, who was murdered last year while attending Emerson College in Boston. Miss Reich was buried in a cemetery in Hackensack.

Regular riders of PATH, the Port Authority Trans-Hudson commuter railroad, found other ways to get into and out of Manhattan yesterday on the first weekday of the strike by 214 members of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen.

It has been claimed that tactics is 99 per cent of chess. General principles will not reveal the final blows of a mating attack, nor enable one to recognize the moment for a fork, pin, or a materialwinning X-ray.

Eigh: present and former New York City policemen were found not guilty by a Federal jury today of charges they took payoffs to protect an $8-million numbers racket operating on both sides of the Hudson River.

First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. appealed his conviction today for killing civilians at My Lai in South Vietnam. In requesting the hearing before the United States Court of Military Appeals, the military's highest court, Calley's lawyers relied in part upon a recent Federal court decision striking down a portion of the Uniform Code of Military Justice.

Steve Sobel, a 40-yearold attorney who once starred at Columbia University as a saber specialist, has helped to make New Jersey one of the most active fencing centers. As a result of his efforts and those of other fencing enthusiasts such as Evelyn Terhune of Mahwah, Irwin Bernstein of Westfield and Denise O'Connor of Bayonne-all top regional competitors-New Jersey now has a large number of devotees.

The highest-ranking American diplomat held prisoner in Vietnam said today that despite torture and four and a half years of solitary confinement, he advocated giving American economic aid to North Vietnam "to generate a stable peaceful coexistence" between the two countries.

The rain was coming down like bathwater yesterday when a woman in orange slacks-her eyes blazing, her dark hair tied squawlike in two tresses--accosted a shopper coming out of the Finast supermarket on Tompkins Avenue in Staten Island.
Dr Louis N. Katz, a medical re searcher who pioneered in de termining the cause of harden ing of the arteries, died today He was 75 years old.

The highest known sum ever paid for the paperback rights to a single book, $1.5million, is being spent not for a trendy conjugal manual, not for a steamy historical novel, not for a fat White House memoir, but for a cookbook that first came out in 1931: "Joy of Cooking."

To the Editor: The March 3 news article on the tragic public school integration problems of Charlotte, N. C., cites local and regional factors underlying recent violent behavior of black and white students toward each other.
An explosion that killed seven persons, injured 19 others and demolished a building Saturday night was caused by a bullet fired into a gas meter, Fire Chief Bert Lugannani said tonight.
Residents of the Jamaica neighborhood where Dr. Thomas W. Matthew's Interfaith Hospital is situated said last night that they hoped it would be closed permanently.
Faced with a restraining order and a show of force, members of the Third World Coalition left the Brandeis University administration building tonight after occupying it for about nine hours.
The water of the Mississippi River is higher than it has been in a generation and the Army Corps of Engineers is fighting with increasing anxiety to keep it in its levees.
Triumph American, Inc., announced yesterday it was withdrawing its recent cash tender offer to buy 51 per cent of the outstanding common stock of the General Host Corporation for $19.8-million.
While capacity crowds scream in delight at Knickerbocker playoff games, there are cries of disappointment and anger from thousands of basketball fans about the method of distributing tickets.
Billy Haughton, one of harness racing's most respected driving figures, made a brief return to New York racing tonight at Roosevelt Raceway with two triumphs in six races.
Vladimir I. Bukovsky, a dissident found guilty of anti-Soviet activities and sentenced to imprisonment and banishment in January, 1972, has completed his prison term, a dissident source said today.

Raissa Struchkova, a senior Bolshoi Ballet ballerina, and the husband-wife team of Yuri Vladimirov and Nina Sorokina will lead a group of 70 dancers from the company and 60 students and recent graduates of the Bolshoi's ballet school in a four-week engagement here.

Schools in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn were alive with the sounds of children yesterday as pupil attendance returned close to normal following the calling-off over the weekend of a month-long boycott by white parents.
Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate majority leader, dined on roast beef. His counterpart in the house, Thomas P. O'Neill of Massachusetts, settled for a slice of melon and a cup of black coffee.
Cut-rate air charter travel began across the Atlantic today, on a flight from Manchester, England, to Toronto for as little as $112 round trip.
Postmaster General Elmer T. Klassen suggested today that Congress was intervening in Postal Service operations by considering legislation to reduce postage for magazines and newspapers.
The union representing the state's 3,500 prison guards and another 3,500. workers in the state security unit yesterday announced tentative agreement on a new one-year contract with the state.
The surrender of Wounded Knee by insurgent Indians could come in two or three days, Assistant Attorney General Kent Frizzell said tonight.

THE CALL GIRLS by Arthur Koestler. 167 pages. Random House. $5.95. Arthur Koestler used to write like a novelist who wanted to be a scientist: now he writes like a scientist who wants to be a novelist. It has been 22 years since his last novel, "The Age of Longing," and one feels immediately in "The Call Girls" a noticeable stiffness in the author's joints. Characters speak eagerly, brightly,
Industrial gold began to flow into Japan through private channels today as imports, previously handle by the government, were liberalized for the first time since World War II.
The Supreme Court declined to review today a decision barring Federal officials from authorizing construction of the Trans-Alaskan oil pipeline.

Branding the city's Housing and Development Administration "counterproductive" and "severely wanting," a state study group urged yesterday that the superagency be dismantled and replaced by a new system that would include a Deputy Mayor for Housing.

Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said today that he did not recall having offered a "substantial" sum of money to the Central Intelligence Agency in 1970 to help prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens as President of Chile.
Robert L. Vesco filed suit in San Jose criminal court today charging a New York lawyer with malfeasance and defamation.

No one can dispute Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson's assertion that "it would be very difficult" for the Cambodian Government of President Lon Nol to survive without the massive American air support it is currently receiving. The commander in chief of Cambodia's crumbling forces has said as much.
Nearly 40 cars of a Southern Railway freight train derailed yesterday and ammonia gas leaked from several of the tank cars, forcing evacuation of about 300 persons from a mobile home park.

The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's final program of its season on Sunday afternoon at Tully Hall turned out to be another of the group's routinely extraordinary events. One might possibly imagine superior performances of these pieces, but for consistently adventuresome programing and unassuming, refined musicianship, the society is hard to beat.
United Nations authorities say they have been caught by surprise by the Vietcong's appointment of a diplomat to represent the Provisional Revolutionary Government at the United Nations.

A special offering of 38,750 common shares of the Hospital Corporation of America at 17 1/2 per share was made yesterday by Bear Steams Co. The company's stock was down 3/4 at 17 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Forty-eight per cent of Amer-I icans consider television 'the most believable of the four major media, according to a survey taken by the Roper Organization for the Television Information Office of the National Association of Broadcasters.

Four manufacturers in the fur industry pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they had paid off union officials to permit violations of labor agreements in the city's Garment District. The pleas were made in Federal Court here by Karl Schwartzbaum, Sam Sherman, Harry Hessel and Sol Cohen, who were indicted last week with seven officials of the Furriers Joint Council. The seven union officials had pleaded not guilty earlier.
John Baum is no stranger to benches. He has spent more time sitting on them than playing in National and American Basketball Association games. He waits for the big moments to prove himself.

Queens Transit Corporation, which operates buses in Queens and to and from Manhattan, was struck by drivers yesterday in a dispute over the suspension of an employee, but a spokesman said that service was restored shortly before 6 P.M.
Although the meat boycott is on, nearby April live cattle futures delivery held steady yesterday at the close of trading, showing little change from Friday.

The Yankees and the Mets played their second game on a makeshift baseball field at City Park stadium tonight, but when they come here two years from now, they'll play the first baseball game in the $151-million Superdome. Furthermore, it's conceivable the Yankees could play some regular season games as the home team in the Superdome in 1975.

The General Public Utilities Corporation expects to increase its installed generating capacity by "some 87 per cent" over the next eight years, William G. Kuhns, president, told some 250 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at One Chase Manhattan Plaza.
President Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam opened a twoday'conference here today in what the White House called an atmosphere of friendship and cordiality."

Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said today that he did not recall having offered a "substantial" sum of money to the Central Intelligence Agency in 1970 to help prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens as President of Chile.

George Meany, A.F.L.-C.I.O. president praised today the nostrike agreement by the United Steelworkers union that appears to assure labor peace in the basic steel industry for the next four years. "It seems to be an

The dollar continued to strengthen in European money markets today and the price of gold dropped below Friday's rate of $90 an ounce. The pound sold at $2.4757 just before the close, a net loss of 18 points on the day. But the pound did well against most European currencies.
A major housing program to rehabilitate 2,100 buildings in three depressed neighborhoods--two in the Bronx and one on the Lower East Side--was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
The European Economic Community agreed tonight to set up its own "central bank" later this week after a complex compromise resolved a dispute between Britain and this tiny duchy.
Dr. Nathan B. Eddy, who was widely known for his research on pain-relieving drugs, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 82 years old.

James Green is an energetic black civil servant in his 40's who signed on with a sales outfit called the P.R.I.C.E. Club in July, 1971. He had visions of finally making "big money." Today, James Green

The greater part of a secret grand jury report urging sweeping revisions in the methods by which Suffolk County condemns private land for public use was ordered sealed forever today by a County Court judge.

Prices finished lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market in quiet trading. Brokers noted that many investors remained on the sidelines because of a lack of encouraging news.

An unqualified shield bill for newsmen was posted today by the Nebraska Legislature. The vote was 39 to 6. However, Gov. J. J. Exon reserved comment on whether he would veto the measure, sponsored by Senator John Savage of Omaha, a retired Omaha World - Herald - News photographer.
Dear Critic, who my lightness so deplores, Would I might study to be prince of bores. Right wisely would I rule that dull estate But, Sir, I may not, Till you abdicate.

The construction of a vast array of medical facilities over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday. The vote was 18 to 4, with the Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx opposed.

Governor Rockefeller said tonight that a disposition in the Legislature for tax cuts this year, a movement fostered in large measure by the Republican majority leaders, was "unwise and irresponsible."

John Havlicek of the Boston Celtics, Bob McAdoo of the Buffalo Braves, Billy Cunningham of the Carolina Cougars and Brian Taylor of the Nets were the pro players honored yesterday at the Metropolitan Basketball Writers' Association's 40th annual awards luncheon at Mamma Leone's.

A nine-month voyage from the Arctic to the Antarctic by the research vessel Knorr has led to the discovery that carbon dioxide produced by the smokestacks of the Northern Hemisphere is being "inhaled" by North Atlantic waters and "exhaled" by the South Atlantic.

The first Federal Design Assembly, the Government's initial move to upgrade design in all of its agencies, attracted about 1,000 top Federal and state administrators and design professionals for the opening session here tonight.
A coalition of child care interests has named April 10 National Working Mother's Day and is urging mothers to take their children to work with them on that day.
Supermarkets in the New York metropolitan area began to feel the impact of the meat boycott by consumers yesterday, as shoppers shunned beef, pork and lamb to protest high prices.
Jascha Horenstein, the conductor, died today in a hospital here at the age of 74. He had entered the hospital last week for heart surgery.
After 53 hours of jury deliberation, the defense requested the California Court of Appeals to order Judge Morton Colvin to declare a mistrial in the Ruchell Magee case and, dismiss the jury.
The United States described as "largely unsubstantiated" charges by a group of United Nations experts that Portugal was waging chemical warfare against the rebels in her African territories.
Juvenile crime is skyrocketing, and the city's juvenile justice system finds itself able to do little to stem it.
Thanks in large part to President Nixon, Prime Minister Heath has found himself under increased pressure here on two major domestic issues.

There have been musicians in our time who devoted part of a concert to improvisation. It is hard to think of an entire concert devoted to improvisations. But that is what the. French organist Pierre Cochereau did at the console of the Philharmonic Hall organ on Sunday night.

" It's a beautiful new world down there. I'd like to do more of it." This sentiment comes from a man usually concerned with the more mundane world of Congress, Representative Robert P. Mathias, Republican of California.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. and the White House engaged today in a blunt and spirited exchange over the Watergate case. The clash held significant implications for the current Congressional investigation of the affair.

Sales and earnings of the Coming Glass Works for its first fiscal quarter ended March 25 were the highest for any 12-week period in the company's 122-year history. Profits were 36 per cent above a year earlier on a sales gain of 22 per cent, the company announced yesterday.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose today to the highest levels since mid1970.

lb Thomsen, the 47-yearold president of Goodyear International, was named yesterday to the additional post of an executive vice president of the company's parent, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Mr.

TOUGHKENANON, Pa. -- The ancient Chinese called mushrooms the divine fruit of immortality. Russian peasants are said to talk to them and Buddha reportedly ate a bowl or two before being translated to nirvana.

Ron Boone and Zelmo Beaty combined for 52 points tonight in leading the Utah Stars to a.107-93 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors in the first game of their American. Basketball Association playoff series.

Governor Rockefeller, in a cautiously worded statement, today reaffirmed his support of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner as a candidate for Mayor of New York City despite Mr. Wagner's refusal to run for his old office on the Republican line.

The outflow of dollars front United States banks during in international monetary turmoil this year was about $2.5-billion but the bulk of it was in loans to foreign banks that drew or existing lines of credit, a member of the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Two American soldiers, armed with light machine guns and M-16 rifles, holed up in a hilltop police box 'here for nine hours today demanding honorable discharge from Army service and a safe trip out of South Korea.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union agreed today to attempt settlement of their dispute that threatened the upcoming basketball series between the Soviet Union and the United States.
Reduced fares on rapid transit lines went into effect today to begin a 90-day experiment to try to increase ridership during offpeak hours.

" He has a touch of magic," said Willis Reed, shaking his head ever so slowly as if he still couldn't believe some of the things he had seen on the Madison Square Garden court. No one could have fashioned a more appropriate description of the antics of Earl (the Pearl) Monroe than the one offered so elegantly by the captain of the Knicks.

The Federal Reserve Board's yearold technique for controlling more accurately the nation's money supply "is alive and well" despite some fears outside the Reserve that it was not working, a board member said today.
Jacob D. Fuchsberg lost a court effort yesterday to extend the time allowed for filing petitions for chief judge of the Court of Appeals in the Democratic primary elections scheduled for June 4.
The Police Department announced yesterday the suspen-: sion of five detectives who were accused of accepting a $15,000 bribe on Sept. 21, 1970, for not arresting a Queens couple on narcotics charges.
Net corporate capital outflows amounted to $1.478-billion in 1972, a drop of $2.934-billion from 1971 levels, the Commerce Department reported today.
Ieronymos withdrew his resignation as primate of Greece's Orthodox Church today after being told that the Holy Synod, the church's cabinet, had "ordered" him to stay on.

Nobody who remembers the Depression of the nineteen-thirties will be impressed by the heroism of boycotting meat for a single week. During all the years of that era there must have been one or two pieces of beef, a pan-fried steak somewhere in 1934 or 1935 surely, but if so it left no imprint in memory.
In a rare joint appearance at a news conference yesterday, five Democratic mayoral candidates endorsed a - "freedom march" for Soviet Jews and shadow-boxed with each other on municipal issues.
" They're just plain, lousy crooks who are capitalizing on the boycott," remarked Joseph Rothenberg, owner of the meat store at 1040 Third Avenue, between 62d and 61st Streets.

Four years ago, Robert F. Wagner in effect pulled the rug out from under Herman Badillo when the former Mayor entered the Democratic mayoral primary at the last minute and thus divided the liberal Democratic vote with Mr. Badillo so that both lost to Mario A. Procaccino.
Four guards were reported injured before the state police helped quell a prisoner uprising that also left heavy fire damage at Rhode Island's Adult Correctional Institutions this afternoon.

After some sharp differences over women's liberation, the Assembly today passed a bill that would end longstanding strictures requiring certain women to work fewer hours than men and preventing a woman from returning to work sooner than a month after giving birth.
In a move to end discounting the Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it would charge the full list price on aluminum ingots "as existing commitments expire and as new orders come in."

Wayne Valley, the major owner of the Oakland Raiders football franchise, filed a suit today seeking to dismiss Al Davis, who runs the team for him so successfully. Valley alleged that Davis and a minority owner, Ed McGah, arranged a new sweetheart contract for Davis as the club's managing general partner without Valley's knowledge.

Pro football averaged a record 57,395 fans for regular season games in 1972 and attracted 15,059,364 over all, including playoffs and preseason games, according to National Football League figures released yesterday. The total was an increase of 4.78 per cent over 1971.

The American Can Company and the Weyerhaeuser Company yesterday announced the signing of a letter of intent for the sale of American Can's pulp and paper mill at Rothschild, Wis., to Weyerhaeuser. The sales price was not disclosed.

The credit markets remained on the defensive yesterday, continuing to exhibit disappointment that the Administration did not take stronger pricecontrol steps Thursday night than to impose ceilings on meat.

The stock market tumbled sharply yesterday in the slowest trading in nearly six months as investors stayed on the sidelines awaiting further developments in the Nixon Administration's fight against inflation.

John Lennon, announcing the appeal of an order to leave the United States by May 21, sought yesterday to show that the Justice Department's legal arguments in the action against him had made it "not just a John-and-Yoko case" but one where "many cases hinge on the outcome."
Rodriguez, the little Puerto Rican, snared his biggest golfing check as he won the Greater Greensboro open by a stroke today with a 17-under-par 267.
A judicial inquiry into large-scale wire tapping practices here has brought the arrest of more than 20 persons, but while there is increasing talk about the
Hector David Castro, one of El Salvador's most distinguished diplomats and a former Ambassador to the United States, died yesterday at the age of 78.

With a Senate committee vote nearing on L. Patrick Gray 3d to be permanent director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Representative Les Aspin charged today that the Nixon Administration had used the F.B.I as a "political peeping Tom" since taking office in 1969.

A State Department spokesman said today that Cambodia was not a formal ally of the United' States since they were linked by no treaty or alliance, but that the two countries were allied in the sense that they had been "fighting a common enemy for the past three years."
The Equity Funding Corporation of America, rocked by widespread reports of major financial irregularities in a life insurance subsidiary, hurriedly reshuffled its top management yesterday.

The greater part of a secret grarid jury report urging sweeping revisions in the methods by which Suffolk County condemns private land for public use was ordered sealed forever today by a County Court judge.

Renata Tebaldl swept onto the stage of Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, the glamorous opera diva from head to toe. No other opera singer of the last 25 years inspires quite the same kind of love and devotion from her fans, and needless to say everything she sang, a short chronological survey of the none-too-nourishing Italian song repertory, was received with unmodified rapture.

Never underestimate the power of the embattled consumer. Outraged by President Nixon's belated decision to fix ceilings on meat prices only after they had soared to the highest levels in history, millions of Americans are seeking--almost spontaneously-to impose their own discipline on the marketplace by refusing' to buy steak, chops or other cuts of meat at the present wildly inflated prices.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. and the White House engaged to day in a blunt and spirited exchange over the Watergate case. The clash held significant implications for the current Congressional investigation of the affair.

The United Nations Human Rights Commission approved today the draft of a convention that would make apartheid, the racial segregation practiced in South Africa, and similar policies of racial segregation a "crime against humanity."

Although many store buyers are in Paris, things haven't been exactly dull on Seventh Avenue. Closings -or the rumors of closings--of several well-known American design houses are keeping tongues wagging and telephones ringing.

Branding the city's Housing and Development Administration "counterproductive" and "severely wanting," a state study group urged yesterday that the controversial superagency be dismantled and replaced by a new system that would include a Deputy Mayor for Housing.

Government analyses concluding that disclosure of some of the Pentagon papers did not damage the national defense were presented to the jury today for the first time in the trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr.
Supermarkets in the New York metropolitan area began to feel the impact of the meat boycott by consumers yesterday, as shoppers shunned beef, pork and lamb to protest high prices.

As a time-capsule report on what the American academic establishment has been up to in musical composition during the last 30 years, Sunday night's program of Arthur Berger's works at Carnegie Recital Hall might serve surprisingly well.

The Rutgers University Law Schools at Camden and Newark are not complying with academic and financial-need guidelines established for the distribution of education aid under the State's 1968 Economic Opportunity Fund, a state legislative "watchdog" agency charged today.

The construction of a vast array of medical facilities over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday. The vote was 18 to 4, with the Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx opposed.
The newly elected National Assembly, responding to demands for a more effective legislative forum, elected Edgar Faure today as its President.
John Baum is no stranger to benches. He has spent more time sitting on them than playing in National and American Basketball Association games. He waits for the big moments to prove himself.

President Nixon and the Western White House are not taking part in the meat boycott and an expensive cut of beef was on the menu for a dinner tonight in honor of President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam.
The Supreme Court declined to review today a decision barring Federal officials from authorizing construction of the Trans-Alaska oil pipeline. Without issuing any opinion on the project, the Court

The Supreme Court agreed today to review charges by a group of Illinois blacks that state judges and law' enforcement officials there had systematically discriminated against them in conducting investigations, setting bail and imposing sentences.
The first parole ever given to a man in state prison who had been condenmed to death was disclosed here by the State Parole Board.
Limiting his speech because of his broken jaw, Muhammad Ali, still in a San Diego hospital, called his wife, Belinda, in another hospital Sunday and learned she was in satisfactory condition.
To some observers, the sight of New York's thoroughbred and harness-racing leaders sitting down together for lunch might suggest a' meeting between the Irish Republican Army and the Orange Society.
The Kremlin ordered today a reorganization of this nation's industry as part of a continuing search for an efficient system of managing the vast Government-run Soviet economy.

State Social Services Commissioner Abe Lavine said today that the state had unnecessarily paid at least $50-million last year in Medicaid funds for people who instead should have had their medical bills paid by private health insurance.

ITHACA, N. Y. -- Two spawning rainbow trout hovered side by side on the edge of a run in the creek, and as we watched from a wooded bank eight feet above them, an ecstatic shudder went through the smaller fish, the male.

Typographical Union No. 6 and the city's three major dailies are scheduled to resume contract talks today. The newspapers and two other unions, the Newspaper Deliverers, and Pressmen's Union No. 2, are expected to continue their talks soon also in an effort to reach agreements on new contracts to replace the pacts that expired last Friday.

Gerald Driscoll of San Diego and Bill Buchan of Seattle, both former world champions in Star Class sailing, have been named skipper and assistant helmsman, respectively, the 12-Meter yacht Intrepid's America's Cup campaign.
A retired Argentine rear admiral and a United States business executive were kidnapped today in separate incidents.

The Senate voted today to set stiff mandatory prison sentences for nonaddicted persons convicted on Federal charges of selling hard drugs or anyone convicted of using firearms to commit a Federal felony.
Brazil's military leaders have entered their 10th year in power with a satisfied show of accomplishment but with no sign that they are ready to restore civilian rule.
The National Broadcasting Company will present nine new series, four of them half-hour situation comedies, in its prime evening viewing time schedule next season.

George E. McDonald, president of Mailers Union No. 6, said yesterday that he had received a ruling from the Cost of Living Council rescinding a rollback, from 15 per cent to 8 per cent, of a wage increase in the first year of a contract for 43 mailers employed by the AlcoGravure Division of the Publications Corporation, in Hoboken. N. I.

The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down the state's system of financing public school education today on the ground that it failed to fulfill an 1875 mandate in the state's constitution for equal educational opportunity.
A man was arrested for allegedly throwing an explosive device shortly after four stores in the downtown business district here caught fire tonight.

In the first action of its kind under the Phase 3 wage-price control program, the Cost of Living Council has blocked part of a new labor contract involving the International Association of Machinists. The two-year contract between the union and North Central Airlines covers about 600 mechanics.

To save a few tens of millions of dollars during each of the next several years, the White House has proposed ending the Federal research training grants for graduate students in the biomedical sciences. What apparently neither the Administration nor the general public realizes is that these grants have been the seed money from which have come many of the world's outstanding medical researchers.

Fresh rains and storms raising the Mississippi River to what was feared would be its highest crest since 1844 left at least 7 million acres of land under water yesterday. Sixteen deaths have been linked to the floods.

Aaron Rabinowitz, a pioneer in public and private housing and real estate development, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at the Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue at 69th Street, and in Westport, Conn.

George Foreman was offered a guarantee of $1million to defend the world heavyweight championship against Jerry Quarry in Madison Square Garden on June 20, the Garden announced yesterday.
Dividend increases in the first quarter of 1973 outnumbered those of a year ago by 47 per cent and 43 per cent for the month of March, the Standard Poor's Corporation reported yesterday.

An attempt to repeal New York City's vacancy-decontrol rent law was defeated by the Republican majority in the Senate late today after lengthy, sometimes caustic, debate and despite the fact that the measure had the support of all of the city's Democratic and Republican Senators.

For the first time in 25 weeks, Laotian Government and Communist negotiators did not meet today for their regular Tuesday session, and there were signs that efforts to form a coalition government had entered a critical phase.

Net proceeds of the offering will be used to repay a bank loan incurred for working capital and other corporate purposes.
