Shoppers here and across the country, still irate at the high prices of meat, gave no indications yesterday of waning enthusiasm for the three-day-old boycott, which has sharply curtailed business at thousands of butcher shops and meat counters.
The adoption of a two-point proposal for judicial reform aimed at the "appointment of the best" judges and "weeding out the rest" was urged upon the Legislature yesterday by a citizens group.

The Appellate Division, ruling that "we do the best we can in an imperfect world," upheld the constitutionality of the state's bail system and reejected charges that the system was anti-poor-people and inconsistent.

The Equity Funding Corportion of America, once the darling of institutional investors, signed a consent decree with the Federal Government yesterday in the wake of a widening scandal that may involve the sale of millions of dollars of fraudulent insurance policies.

United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, in what may be an extension of an investigation into the affairs of some suppliers to the Bergen County Republican organization, has subpoenaed at least eight of the county's major administrative officers to appear before a Federal grand jury.

The most provocative moments of the first Federal Design Assembly, which ended here today, came occasionally when questions were raised and criticisms voiced. Can Federal architecture be improved "as long as architects are selected on a political rather than a professional basis?" asked Richard Saul Wurman.
Committee on Peaceful Uses of the Seabed, subcommittee on conference on law of the sea-3 P.M. Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space-10:30 A.M.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, under increasing pressure to release the Pakistani prisoners or war, has abruptly sent a special envoy to Bangladesh in an attempt to break the political deadlock on the subcontinent.

The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down the state's system of financing public school education today on the ground that it failed to fulfill an 1875 mandate in the state's constitution for equal educational opportunity.

A Federal judge ordered the City of Hamtramck today to build housing and change its fair housing and zoning laws to give 4,000 black residents, forced out of the community by urban renewal, a chance to move back.
Pepsico, Inc., which had been restrained temporarily from exercising control over the Rheingold Corporation, got conditional permission yesterday to go ahead with its newly

Racing's first tribute to returning prisoners of war will be held Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway with a salute to Air Force Senior Master Sergeant Arthur Cormier and Army S. Sgt. Richard Perricone.
Eight Georgian 18th-century candlesticks on loan to the Brooklyn Museum were reported missing last night by the police, who said the silverware could be worth as much as $50,000.
The House Banking Committee voted today for a freeze on prices and Interest rates at their March 16 levels but approved a rollback in food prices to May 1, 1972.

A fresh effort to arrange an end to the siege of a South Vietnamese ranger outpost failed yesterday when South Vietnamese delegates to the Two-Party Joint Military Commission walked out of a meeting and accused the Vietcong of not negotiating "seriously."

A Minnesota surgeon announced here today the isolation of a mystery virus from human cancers of the urinary tract, a finding that he believes may be the strongest evidence to date of a virus that causes cancer in man.
An Army staff sergeant at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, and his wife were arrested yesterday on charges that they had beaten their adopted 18-monthold son into insensibility.

" I'll tell you one thing," Lou Hudson said, "He won't score 54 points again. I'll be ready to play." Hudson was referring to Boston's John Havlicek, who scored a career high 54 points as the Celtics beat Atlanta in the first game of their National Basketball Association playoff.

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would raise prices on stainless sheet and strip products by an average of 6 per cent, beginning May 1. The increases are in line with those posted last month by Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., and the Jones
No danger that faces the United States today is more serious than the possibility that a significant number of our people are losing faith in the validity and purpose of our Government.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan has begun an intensive public campaign in recent weeks to force the governing Labor party to adopt his controversial ideas on administering the occupied Arab territories as part of its 1973 election platform.

Shoppers here and across the country, still irate at the high prices of meat, gave no indications yesterday of waning enthusiasm for the three-day-old boycott, which has sharply curtailed business at thousands of butcher shops and meat counters.

The Equity Funding Corporation of America, once the darling of institutional investors, signed a consent decree with the Federal Government yesterday in the wake of a widening scandal that may involve the sale of millions of dollars of fraudulent insurance policies.
Thomas Bradley and Mayor Sam Yorty headed tonight for a onetwo finish in the first round of the Los Angeles mayoral election and a bitter battle in a runoff next month.
Motorola, Inc., demonstrated here yesterday the answer to telephone addicts' prayers --a hand-held, wire-less portable telephone weighing 28 ounces that can connect with any telephone anywhere.
A Detroit lawyer was shot and killed in a Detroit courtroom today after he pulled out a gun without warning, the judge sitting on the bench said.

The Massachusetts House formerly requested yesterday the retirement of Federal District Court Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. Opponents of the action argued it was a "censure" and almost a call for impeachment, actions outside the jurisdiction of the General Court.

The National Broadcasting Company does, I suppose, deserve credit. In this season of repeats, it turned out two original specials last night. One, from 8:30 to 10, was "Elvis: Aloha From Hawaii." The other, from 10 to 11, was "Ann-Margret-When You're Smiling."
The State Supreme Court ruled today that policemen may interrogate anyone on the street even though his conduct is not suspicious.

North Vietnam and the Vietcong said today that torture charges by former American war prisoners threatened to interfere with return of the bodies of prisoners who died in captivity and the search for United States servicemen listed as missing.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it has incurred charges totaling $19.7-million so far under its agreement to indemnify Merrill Lynch against certain losses arising out of the brokerage firm's acquisition of Goodbody Co.
Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst disputed today Senator Sam J. Ervin's contention that the Senate could have Presidential aides arrested for refusing to testify in the Watergate affair.
The stock market plodded through another listless session yesterday and some of the major indicators of price action on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to new lows for the year.
To gain a full measure of enjoyment from his journeys afield, the outdoorsman must be eternally inquisitive. And to merely observe is often only the first step; one must also question what he sees.
" Somebody must find a way to make modern, contemporary clothes or we shall end up boring people to death," said Emanuel Ungaro just before his ready-to-wear show today.
Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that a new division would be created in the Justice Department to speed the prompt and effective prosecution of narcotics offenders.

Fresh from a solid triumph in yesterday's primary, Thomas Bradley opened today the second round of his campaign to become the first black mayor of Los Angeles by declaring that race was an "irrelevant" factor in the election.

The towers are pure technology, the lobbies are pure sclimaltz and the impact on New York of two 110-story buildings and auxiliary structures with a projected population of 130,000 workers and visitors using a city-size amount of services is pure speculation.

The carmen's strike against the Port Authority Trans-Hudson rail system entered the fourth day yesterday with New Jersey computers to Manhattan employing alternative means of transportation more smoothly than the previous three days, according to PATH officials.
The Soviet press today demonstrated the delicacy of Leonid I. Brezhnev's forthcoming visit to West Germany by beginning the official publicity about it even before the date of the trip is fixed.
Four more rookie draftees have signed contracts with the Giants, the National Football League club announced yesterday.
The State Supreme Court ruled today that municipalities have the right to enact their own rent-control ordinances.
The last American prisoner of war to leave Vietnam said today, after a reunion with his wife, that he felt "just about the same as the first man who got out--there's nothing like freedom."
The $700-million World Trade Center, its two 1,350-foot towers the largest buildings in the world, was dedicated formally yesterday by Governors Rockefeller and Cahill.

The Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Enforcement filed complaints today against seven major airlines, contending that they had overcharged passengers on trips in which two or more airlines had been involved.
A pacifist Air Force physician who refused to perform his military duties was sentenced today to one and a half years at hard labor and fined $25,000 in a one-day court-martial.
Property damage estimated from the floodwaters of the Mississippi River system-swelling to 129-year record crestsclimbed toward $25-million yesterday.

In 1971 Congress approved an amendment to the Treasury Act which would allow every taxpayer to direct the Internal Revenue Service to allocate one dollar of his Federal income tax payments to a Presidential campaign fund, Now, in 1973, the evidence points to a deliberate effort to keep that provision a deep dark secret.

The most remarkable thing about the racing at Aqueduct yesterday was that a crowd of 19,013 attended the program. The weather, as it was all over town, was just short of execrable, and the most reasonable assumption, naturally, would be that even the hard core would bypass the Big A for one day.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's council has postponed until tomorrow or Saturday action on a request by the Amateur Athletic Union to use undergraduate players on the United States basketball team that will play the Soviet Union in eight games starting April 26.
Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today he favored a sudden-death playoff over a 2point conversion if any changes were made in National Football League rules.
If the housewife is confused about the reasons for the high cost of meat, she has nothing on Nicolo (Nick) Ottomanelli, who manages the Joseph Ottomanelli Meat Market on Manhattan's upper east side.

Kaufman and Broad, Inc., a leading builder of popularpriced housing, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 with increases of 25 and 41 per cent, respectively, over a year earlier.
Gov. Ronald Reagan's "work or else" program aimed at providing job training for welfare recipients is a failure, a legislative committee reported today.

" Sleuth" the Tony Awardwinning thriller by Anthony Shaffer, gave its 1,000th performance, yesterday at the Music Box Theater. The play, which opened Nov. 12, 1970, and is currently the longest running show on Broadway, opened first in London, where it is still drawing capacity audiences.

Paul R. Screvane, who was Deputy Mayor under Robert F. Wagner and who once opposed Abraham D. Beame for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, was introduced by Mr. Beame yesterday as his campaign manager in the current race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
President Lon Nol's younger brother, Brig. Gen. Lon Non, has resigned his Cabinet post, informed sources said today. This is expected to have little effect on his domination of the Government.
A Congressional staff study released today has concluded that retail food prices could rise by 10 per cent in 1973 "even if the Administration's best hopes for farm price stability are realized."
Judge John O. Newman ruled in Federal district court today that Connecticut must pay for a welfare recipient's abortion if a doctor certifies that it is necessary.
Acting on an anonymous phone call, the police removed a live bomb from a Greyhound bus yesterday, just as the bus was about to leave the Port Authority Bus Terminal for Cape Cod.
Skylab, the first American space station for long-duration manned missions, is now set for launching on May 14, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.
Six days after President Nixon ordered a ceiling on meat prices as his latest step to stem inflation, the national debate over rising prices was at a higher pitch than ever.

The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the police have the right to question anyone on the street even though their conduct is not outwardly suspicious. The 6-to-1 ruling reinstated a heroin-possession conviction that had been overturned when the suspect, Samuel Sheffield of Newark argued that Newark detectives had no cause to suspect him if criminal activity or to question him.
A $90-million academic center is planned to replace Lewisohn Stadium-the amphitheater and athletic field of City College that served as the city's summer cultural center for about half a century.
A special offering of 177,100 shares of Metromedia Inc. at 17 5/8 per share was completed yesterday, Bear Steams Co. said. The company's stock closed at 17 3/4, up 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Back in 1947, recalls Frank Herman of the Cable Television Division of Teleprompter, the big, established ad agencies with all the money to spend were so locked in with radio they all but ignored that new-fangled television. They left it up to new "swinging" agencies to take the plunge.

A. Ernest Fitzgerald told a Civil Service Commission examiner today that he was ostracized and isolated socially and professionally after he testified before Congress in 1968 on the large cost overruns on the C-5A military transport plane.

The Penn Central Company, the corporate shell that owns all the stock of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, proposed a plan yesterday in Philadelphia under which Congress would relieve all the railroads in the nation of local real estate taxes.
President Nixon's landslide victory last November has not changed the Republican party's national status as the minority party in American politics, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

The Eastern railroads by a 16 to 3 vote decided yesterday to join with the Western and Southern railroads in seeking a freight rate increase. The Chesapeake Ohio and its controlled subsidiaries, the Baltimore Ohio and Western Maryland, cast the negative votes and will not be party to a filing to be made with the Interstate Commerce Commission next week.

The Justice Department said today that executive privilege probably would not apply if Congress wanted to ask a White House aide if he had committed a crime-but that the decision on its application would be made by the President.

An architect who accused the Argentine heavyweight, Oscar Bonavena, of breaking his jaw in a hotel bar brawl last summer, sued the boxer today for $15,000. Norberto Bombicino alleged Bonavena hit him for personal reasons which, the police said, they did not understand.

The Nixon Administration's broadsides against television news have had at least one encouraging effect. Active and broad public attention is finally being generated about an important aspect of a mass medium that notoriously encourages passivity.

Prices continued to move mostly downward yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market in slow trading. This was the fourth consecutive session that both markets had declined.

Mr. L., the patient whose case has led a court here to examine the ethics of psychosurgery, took the stand today, and said that, after reading and thinking more about the technique, he did not now want to go ahead with a brain operation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that five firms and 14 individuals violated Federal securities laws in furthering a stock-manipulation scheme in shares of the Imperial Investment Corporation.

Only hours after voters rejected a state constitutional amendment that would have guaranteed equal rights for women, a group of State Senators moved today to rescind Wisconsin's ratification of the Federal equal rights amendment.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand--In one of the many new homes in a middle-class Wellington residential section the silverware is American, the stereo German, the toaster British and the shiny sedan in the carport Japanese.

Donald S. Luce, who along with two American Congreessmen discovered the "tiger cages" in a South Vietnam prison in 1970, told the jury at the Pentagon papers trial today that disclosure of information about the "strategic hamlet" and "pacification" programs in Vietnam did not damage those programs.
Two young terrorists killed an army, intelligence chief outside his home here today, after apparently failing to steal his briefcase or perhaps kidnap him, police reported.
On a gentle summer evening, a boy sat in the upper reaches of Lewisohn Stadium, waiting for the concert to begin. A stout man sat down close by and blew clouds of smoke from a freshly lit cigar.
A Federal District Court ordered today that a compromise desegregation plan be implemented for the Atlanta public school system.
After several recent challenges by the Democratic leadership to the accuracy of bill votes the Assembly approved a Republicansponsored rules change today that still left the Democrats unhappy.

Mayor Stanley Makowski is expected to appoint Thomas R. Blair Police Commissioner on Friday, two papers said today. The Buffalo Courier-Express and The Buffalo Evening News said that Mr. Blair, 58 years old, now a deputy commissioner, is to take the $26,000a-year post.
The State Supreme Court ruled today that municipalities have the right to enact their own rent-control ordinances.
Alvin W. Vogtle, Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Southern Company, was elected chairman of the Edison Electric Institute yesterday at

The Equity Funding Corporation of America, caught up in a multimillion dollar scandal over bogus insurance policies and besieged by bankers for the immediate repayment of $50million in loans, disclosed last night that it would petition the court today to file for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal bankruptcy law.
President Nixon announced today the formation of two commissions, one to promote safety in consumer products, the other to promote harmony in industrial relations.

Jack Nicklaus, the overwhelming favorite of his colleagues to repeat his Masters victory of last year, said today: "I'm flattered by their selection. It's a nice position to be in, and it will make me play harder."

Donald G. Downing, a former professor of mechanical engineering, who was also dean of admissions and students at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute, died today at Fairlawn Hospital. He was 68 years old.

The House Banking Committee voted today to roll back prices and interest rates to their level of last Jan. 10, but the vote gave no real clue to what Conpress will ultimately do about price, wage, interest and rent controls.
Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will become the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union when he goes to Kiev in September for the European equestrian championship.

IN A BIND That's what the New York Public Library' is in these days, and that's what the Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America is going to try to alleviate during its International Antiquarian Book Fair, which will run from today through Saturday in all the mezzanine public rooms of Carlton House, Madison Avenue and 61st Street. Proceeds from the $1.50 admission price will go to the library.
Two American journalists reported today that they had been held prisoner by the Vietcong for two days and released today in a hamlet near the northern provincial capital of Quang Ngai.

Alfred leS. Jenkins, the American official who will be in charge of preparations in Peking for the opening of a United States liaison mission there, predicted here today that there would be steady development in United States-Chinese relations from now on.

The acting director of the Harlem Model Cities Program, two subordinates and five others, including a candidate for the City Council, were indicted yesterday on Federal charges growing out of an investigation of Model Cities contracts.

Over tuna fish and coffee, at a table in the hallway outside their chambers, the judges of the Brooklyn Family Court are trading horror stories-a psychotic child sent home because the mental hospital had no place for him, a stabbing in the courthouse stairwell, a child who is an addict and another child whose mother doesn't want her.

Dr. Abraham Rieger, who had spent 68 years as a general practitioner in this city, died Monday at the age of 91. Dr. Rieger's career came to an end only six months ago when he was stricken with an illness, said to be one of the very few he had ever had.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People brought suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday in an effort to prevent the exclusion of children living in the largely black Tilden Houses in Brownsville from schools in Canarsie and East Flatbush.

Willie Wise pumped in 29 points tonight to spark the Utah Stars to a 103-92 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors in the second game of their American Basketball Association playoff. Utah now has a 2-0 lead.

President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that an engineering battalion composed of' Moslem Filipinos had been sent to help pacify the southern Mindanao region by working on electrification projects for Moslem communities there.

Sid Gary, who danced, sang and double-talked his way through the vaudeville circuits and was teamed with George Burns in 1917, died of a heart attack Tuesday while walking at Central Park West and 60th Street. His age was 72 and he lived at 20 West 72d Street.

Inspector Pearse P. Meagher, who retired in February after one of the most versatile careers in the New York Police Department, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 11 West 192d Street in the Bronx. He was 54 years old.
A very hard-working and rather talented cast (see listing) last night brought "a musical entertainment" by Hugo Peretti, Luigi Creatore and George David Weiss to the Eastside Playhouse.

Impressions of what happened in the Watergate affair, recorded after eight months of relatively diligent struggle with the newspapers: One night last spring three patriots named Hunt, Liddy and McCord fell to talking about what a terrible blow America would suffer if the U.S. Government should ever fall under the sway of a political party that recognized Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba.
Clark T. Chambers, a New York real estate broker until his retirement in the late nineteenfifties, died at his home here today. He was 93 years old and formerly lived in Plandome. L. I.
Heavy showers poured 1.35 inches of rain on New York City yesterday afternoon, breaking the old record of 1.31 inches for the date, set in 1911.

Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton ordered the police and the Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday to crack down on unlicensed limousines or "gypsy cabs" after a group of licensed drivers complained that weak enforcement was unfair to drivers who voluntarily complied with new regulations.

The merger of the 205-year-old New York Chamber of Commerce and the 75-year-old Commerce and Industry Association was formally complted yesterday, and David L. Yunich, chairman of the board of the new New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, declared that "from now on business will speak with a unified voice."

Music of the high romantic school was given very special treatment Tuesday night in Town Hall by Jennie Tourel and Earl Wild. It would be difficult to find two artists better suitto the occasion: Mr. Wild has long been in the vanguard of the romantic keyboard revival, and Miss Tourel illuminates anything she sings, no matter what the era.
Retailers and wholesalers wooed disgruntled shoppers yesterday in an effort to revive sales diminished by the four-day-old nationwide meat boycott.

Two shareholder resolutions calling for full disclosure of the corporation's efforts to support political campaigns and to influence governmental actions and policies will be included in the proxy statement of the General Motors Corporation for its 1973 annual meeting, the auto maker announced yesterday.

A man about to go on trial for the attempted murder of three policemen notified the judge by telephone yesterday that he would not appear, that he was "in a state of shock" because he had learned that he could be imprisoned for a minimum of 15 years, if convicted.
A Long Island woman said to be one of the first two shop owners in the state being jailed for being open on Sundays walked out of the Nassau County jail today after serving a three-day sentence.
The Minnesota North Stars stole the home-ice advantage from the Philadelphia Flyers with a 3-0 victory tonight in the opening game of a National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoff.

Massachusetts authorities were given permission yesterday to perform an autopsy on the body of Ellen Reich of Hackensack, one of seven women slain last year in the eastern part of Massachusetts. When Miss Reich's body was found last September authorities said she had been strangled. However, it was reported in Boston yesterday that new evidence showed she might have been shot.

Hawaii's strilking school teachers turned to the Legislature today in an effort to obtain a resumption of talks. The Hawaii State Teachers Association assigned more than 600 teachers to urge lawmakers to bring the school's administration to the bargaining table.
The Equity Funding Corporation of America, once the darling of institutional investors, rode high, wide and handsome through 1972 as a sort of financial services conglomerate.

The Pentagon said today that it foresaw no immediate Cambodian military defeat but held out the possibility that the United States would have to mount an airlift to the besieged Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh.
District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens yesterday made his fourth appearance before a special state grand jury investigating corruption in the criminal justice system of New York City.
Acting on an anonymous phone call, the police removed a live bomb from a Greyhound bus yesterday, Just as the bus was about to leave the Port Authority Bus Terminal for Cape Cod.

President Nixon's chief legal counsel, John W. Dean 3d, was dismissed from his first job with a Washington law firm in 1966 for what his employer first termed "unethical conduct" but later described as a "basic disagreement" over the firm's policies.
Ways and means of succeeding in international joint ventures were outlined yesterday by Sol E. Flick, executive vice president of the Bulova Watch Company.

A businessman for 33 of his 55 years, a former professional baseball player and career merchant, David Lawrence Yunich, chairman of the newly created New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, allowed an edge of resentment to harden his voice yesterday as the remarked:
" Somebody must find a way to make modern, contemporary clothes or we shall end up boring people to death," said Emanuel Ungaro just before his ready-to-wear show todav.
Support of the meat boycott by patrons of a highpriced store here appeared substantially less than among customers of a high-volume, lowpriced store.

Mayor-elect Paul R. Soglin, at 27 years of age the youngest Mayor ever elected in Madison, told a dancing, singing and shouting crowd of partisans at his victory celebration at the Labor Temple last night, "We're going to put everything together now."
Teen-agers smashed four national records today, on the opening day of the Amateur Athletic Union's indoor shortcourse swimming championships.
A receiver appointed by a Federal bankruptcy court will take control of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., a commodity options dealer, after a temporary receiver finishes his final accounting.
Following is the 70to-24 roll.call by which the Senate approved today that part of Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.'s amendment that would curb Presidential impoundment of funds appropriated by Congress:

Smooth technical equipment and a restrained, sensitive style will command a listener's attention in the music of most composers. This was the reason that Yizhak Schotten's second New York recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night was largely rewarding.
South Florida today suffered its second massive power failure in two days. The blackout was more extensive but slightly shorter than the one yesterday.

I am afraid none of us, and I include the representatives of the various Governments, have yet probed deeply enough into the interrelations between any comprehensive new approach on the monetary level and the nature of the changes taking place in the underlying economic process.
Fourteen seniors in the city's high schools have been named among the 325 winners of college scholarships under the National Achievement Scholarship Awards program for outstanding black students.
Mrs. Audrey Warner, the mother of two married children, was incredulous when she received a call from the State Lottery Commission, today.
Guerrillas wounded two British soldiers in sporadic sniping in Northern Ireland tonight and tried to blow up one of their favorite targets, a temporary customs post near Londonderry.

Dr. Frank Stanton, who retired as vice chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System last Friday after 38 years with the company, will receive the annual award of the Four Freedoms Foundation, it was announced yesterday.

The Equity Funding Corporation of America, caught up in a multimillion dollar scandal over bogus insurance policies and besieged by bankers for the immediate repayment of $50million in loans, disclosed last night that it would petition the court today to file for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws.
A growing alliance of publicly held companies yesterday announced a program to bring changes in the securities industry and focus attention on the problems of corporations of moderate size.
The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill extending to June 30, 1974, President Nixon's power to tax investment by Americans in foreign securities.

-South Korean officials have disclosed that one of President Park Chung Hee's most trusted officers, Maj. Gen. Yoon Pil Yong, has been arrested and is in prison awaiting indictment before a court-martial.
The smallopen boat chugged slowly down the Mekong River, the three of us straining our eyes in the blazing sun for any sign of life in the dense foliage on the bank.

The first production of Leonard Bernstein's Mass outside the United States will take place June 23 in Vienna. The work wil be performed by the Yale Symphony Orchestra and members of the company that presented it at the school, along with the Vienna Choir Boys and the Wiener Singverein.

In what appeared to be an attempt to improve strained relations with the United States, President Idi Amin of Uganda sent a message to President Nixon today praising him as "one of the most brilliant leaders in the Western world" for his efforts to end the Vietnam war.

Fabrics made of a new textile fiber with the characteristics of silk will be marketed in this country later this year by the Beaunit Corporation, Robert E. Smith, the company's president said yesterday.
Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, now on terminal vacation from his post as Chancellor of the city school system, will become a professor at the University of Massachusetts School of Education at Amherst.

" When I'm gone, boxing will be nothing again," once said Muhammad Ali, soaring off into a flight of fancy that usually accompanied each ego trip in earlier and better years. We shall soon see. If the former heavyweight champion of the world is not already gone, it's obvious that he is on the way.
The Mississippi River has not been kind to the people of Montz. Time and again it has nibbled away at their land and forced them to retreat behind new levees.

The Food and Drug Administration proposed changes today in the content, advertising and labeling of some antacid preparations, but generally supported the use of many of such widely taken patent medicines.
ROME, April 4--Secret World War II documents published by the Vatican today prove that aides to Pope Pius XII--and probably the Pope himself--knew of the Nazi slaughter of millions of Jews.
The Senate committee investigating the Watergate conspiracy said today that it had "no evidence of any nature" implicating H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, in any "illegal" activities.
Steak houses and restaurants known for their juicy cuts of beef are reporting a slight falloff in business this week and a "dramatic reduction" in the number of customers ordering meat dishes.
The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, reversing his earlier "go slow' attitude, proposed a series of court reforms today for initial legislative action this year.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation wants to keep for its permanent files the long distance telephone records seized from the syndicated columnist, Jack Anderson, and his associate, Leslie Whitten, the Government told the United States District Court today.

KIEN HOA PROVINCE, South Vietnam, April 2--The small open boat chugged slowly down the Mekong River, the three of us straining our eyes in the blazing sun for any sign of life in the dense foliage on the bank.

The State Real Estate Commission announced plans today to expand its staff and step up its investigations into complaints of blockbustingg" and other practices by real estate agents that violate state or local antidiscrimination regulations.
Mrs. Esther Matles, wife of James J. Matles, general secretary of the United Electrical Workers, an independent union, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital.

In the final chapter of a long and complicated murder case that began nine years ago, the young men known as the "Harlem Four" pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in State Supreme Court here in return for suspended sentences.
" Slavery exists-and we are the slaves," said Pat Robinson, a psychiatric social worker and one of several black women testifying at a hearing here on women's rights.
The dog show world was paid a high tribute by Pedro Rivero, when he said at a recent show: "Everything I have in the United States I owe to the sport."
The Tallinn International Tournament evoked great interest because it was the first event Boris Spassky entered since he lost the world title to Bobby Fischer last summer in Iceland.
Fred J. Gaertner, a retired partner in Jabel, Inc., a jewelry manufacturing concern in Irvington, died today in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 79 years old and lived at 305 Hartshorn Drive.

The House Appropriations Committee, in its first test fo the new House praftice of holding open committee meetings unless the pnael involved votes in public to close them, voted today to close a bill-drafting session.

The beauty of a good many highly praised Handel oratorios is hidden behind 18thcentury musical convention and can be uncovered only with much studious analysis. For this the average listener or even the contemporaryminded musician seldom has patience.
A Florida scientist has found that the male genital tract can harbor a virus that is suspected of causing cancer of the cervix in women.

After the Senate sustained his veto of the vocational rehabilitation bill, President Nixon issued a victory statement which, like his original veto message, had a curiously abstract and arid quality. Both documents addressed themselves very much to ideological dogma and very little to the human realities of this society in 1973.

Harvey Scribner came to New York a little short of three years ago to become the first Chancellor to preside over the newly decentralized school system. He leaves that difficult task with honor; he deserves the respect and thanks of the people of this city.

In the final chapter of a long and complicated murder case that began nine years ago, the young men known as the "Harlem Four" pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in State Supreme Court here in return for suspended sentences.

The Nets went to the movies yesterday to see what they did wrong in the closing minutes of Tuesday night's game that cost them victory in the third game of the playoff series with the Carolina Cougars.

The Travelers Corporation, parent of the Travelers insurance companies, expects a 10 to 15 per cent increase in earnings this year over 1972, Morrison H. Beach, president, said at the annual meeting in Hartford, Conn., yesterday.
The State Health Department is reporting a sharp rise in the number of measles cases in several areas throughout Connecticut.

Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, director of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia, has been named the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art. Although he will not take office until-Sept. 1, 1974, succeeding John I. H. Baur, the current director, he will join the Whitney staff on Oct. 1 of this year as associate director.
Bond prices wriggled higher yesterday in another lackluster trading session, with investors still finding little incentive to buy long-term issues while given very attractive shortterm alternatives.
The ruler of Sikkim, the tiny Indian protectorate in the Himalayas, has appealed to New Delhi to rush troops to control violent demonstrations directed against him.
Five Oregon State University wrestlers, defying expulsion from future international events, including the Olympics, competed today in the South African Games.

The Senate committee investigating the Watergate conspiracy said today that it had "no evidence of any nature" implicating H. R. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff, in any "illegal" activities.

With Dave Cowens and Paul Silas combining for 30 rebounds in the first half when the game was decided, the Boston Celtics routed the Atlanta Hawks, 126113, tonight for a 2-0 lead in their four-of-seven-game Naional Basketball Association playoff.

In the face of stiff opposition from Governors, the Nixon Administration said today that it was postponing its plan to begin withholding $689million in Federal welfare aid from states that make payments to ineligible recipients.
An auction sale of 413 ancient Greek coins belonging to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York brought about $700,000 in Zurich today.
A Brooklyn man, 6 foot 5 inches tall, and a woman he was living with were charged yesterday in Criminal Court with homicide in the beating death of the woman's 5-year- 4old daughter.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of fraud charges it has brought against the Equity Funding Corporation of America promises to be the most intensive undertaken by the agency since its creation in 1933, officials reported today.

The acting director of the Harlem Model Cities Program, two subordinates and five others, including a candidate for the City Council, were indicted yesterday on Federal charges growing out of an investigation of Model Cities contracts.

Chancellor Willy Brandt announced acceptance today of an invitation to consult with President Nixon in Washington on May 1 and 2 only 10 days before he is to receive the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Bonn.

To the Editor: Stephen H. Lockton said in his March 20 letter, "The American consumer has to learn to stop complaining. Let the farmer do his job, for otherwise prices will only be sustained indefinitely at high levels."
A medical team here has reported some initial success in experiments with electrified acupuncture as a treatment for drug addicts' withdrawal symptoms.

The Happy Appliance Company telephoned Mary Jones, a secretary for an advertising agency, and asked if she would be a guarantor on an installment contract. Her brother-in-law, Joseph Smith, wanted to buy a $600 color television set, payable over two years.

Inge Hammarstroem's three goals led Sweden to an 8-2 rout of West Germany today in the world ice hockey championships as Sweden kept pace with the Soviet Union as the only unbeaten teams in the two-week tournament. Hammarstroem scored his goals in just over 13 minutes of play. Finland downed Poland, 5-0, in today's other game.
Shortly after 4 A.M. today a police detail of 700 men-almost half of the Frankfurt force-removed 10 leftist students from a large house that they had occupied a year ago.

The average yield on four-month commitments to purchase conventional mortgages rose to 8.113 per cent from 8.029 per cent in the previous auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association reported today.
Louis M. Turco, president of the City Council was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on 10 charges of mail fraud and four charges of income tax evasion.
A power-play goal by a right wing, Yvan Cournoyer, at 4:27 of the third period tonight gave the Montreal Canadiens a 2-1 victory over the Buffalo Sabres and a 1-0 lead in their Stanley Cup playoff.

The appointment of Al Marlens as editor of The New York Times Week in Review was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, Sunday editor of The Times.
Ben Hogan received the William D. Richardson Award tonight from the Golf Writers Association of America.
Max Borgenicht, co-founder in 1928 and retired president of Borgenicht Brothers, manufacturer of children's dresses, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 and lived at 936 Fifth Avenue.

Iraq has pulled back military forces that crossed the border with Kuwait onMarch 20, and Foreign Minister Murtadha Said Abdul-Baqi of Iraq will come here Friday for negotiations, it was officially announced today.
President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam was greeted by Vice President Agnew and a friendly demonstration when he arrived today from Los Angeles.

The crudely lettered sign on the pushcart at Third Avenue and 29th Street says: "The hot dog man is in the candy stand." Correct; he is. I don't know why anyone should take a quizzical attitude toward that simple statement of fact. But several things in my neighborhood puzzle me.
Jacques Plante, who has the haggard look of a 44-year-old goalie, played like one tonight. He was beaten into submission as the Rangers trounced the Bruins, 6-7.
About 1,000 people marched quietly past the Lorraine Motel to City Hall Wednesday on the anniversary of the assasination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. five years ago.

The Senate's failure to override President Nixon's veto of a bill to aid the handicapped amply demonstrates that Congress, as now organized and led, cannot seriously compete with the White House on the spending issue. But the expanding executive dominance over the legislative branch can be slowed or reversed in other ways-and the continuing battle over L. Patrick Gray 3d is the best opportunity.

Mario Biaggi made history of a sort last night at the Lambs, the theatrical club. The Bronx Representative and mayoral candidate and the intended victim of the club's monthly satirical "Lambasting," arrived two and a half hours late and was ushered into a darkened hall being emptied of chairs and classes.

The Brooklyn Museum's new exhibition, "African Art of the Dogon," which opened yesterday, represents a new stage, a kind of rounding out, in our understanding of primitive art.

A recent development of interest to the devotees of the most modern of the strong-club systems is what might be called the Precision Club Club. In less than a month, the club built up a membership of more than 500 enthusiasts, who receive a bimonthly newsletter edited by Steven Altman and a copy of a recent book on the system.
The male division of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, in Westchester County, will be closed effective April 25, the State Department of Correctional Services announced yesterday.

Cincinnati, baseball's oldest franchise, will open the 1973 campaign today against San Francisco.

The Pentagon said today that it foresaw no immediate Cambodian military defeat but held out the possibility that the United States would have to mount an airlift to the besieged Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh.

Two thousand to 3,000 people demonstrated in Barcelona today in protest against the death of a construction worker shot by the police. They disrupted traffic, barricaded streets with stones and benches, chanted "Liberty!" and "Assassins!" and called for a general strike. No arrests were reported.

The particulars of Indrani's art, her enormous range of dramatic characterization and complex rhythmic "pure" dances are well known to Indian dance audiences, and so it was with some delight to see her honored formally with the key to the City of New York.

Victor Dolan, principal of Public School 298 in the Ocean Hill - Brownsville section of Brooklyn, died Tuesday in Deepdale Hospital in Little Neck, Queens, after a long illness. He was 45 years old and made his home in Little Neck.

Presidents Nixon and Thieu are agreed on the need for "appropriate vigorous reactions" to continuing violations of the cease-fire agreements by North Vietnam. But the question remains whether President Nixon was approprivately vigorous in reacting also to the continuing vionations of the truce terms by President Thieu.
STRASBOURG, France, April 4--Policemen and students battled until early this morning at Strasbourg University in a five-hour clash that left 75 persons injured, five seriously.

The Senate voted, 68 to 23, today to permit Americans to buy, sell or own gold for the first time since 1934 when Congress banned the private possession of gold at the request of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

A high school youth working out with his track team was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train at an unguarded crossing today.

Did the top executives of Equity Funding Corporation of America borrow an idea from Nikolai Gogol's nineteenth-century novel, "Dead Souls"? In Gogol's classic, the adventurer Pavel Ivanovich Chichikov tours the countryside of feudal Russia, buying "ownership"-at very low prices-of deceased serfs. His eventually frustrated scheme was to get rich by "mortgaging" these "dead souls" with a financial institution which believed they still lived.

Hope for solution of the Netherlands' 128-day Cabinet crisis was dashed today when Jaap A. W. Burger gave up his attempts to form a new government.

Ernest Fitzgerald, whose civilian job with the Air Force was abolished after he told Congress of a possible $2-billion in excess costs on the C-5A airplane contract, said today that his last days in the Pentagon were filled with meaningless work, isolation and an investigation into his personal life.

Gold closed steady on European markets today after a volatile session. The United States dollar weakened. The price of gold had jumped by more than a $1 to $92 an ounce in both London and Zurich this morning, but settled back to close nearly unchanged from yesterday's levels.

A member of Hell's Angels was found guilty today in the strangulation death of a Georgia motorcyclist and not guilty in the torture death of another.
Five months after its original mission was accomplished, the Committee for the Re-election of the President is still in business and about to enlarge its staff.

The error of President Nixon's premature decision to relax mandatory price-wage controls is no longer open to serious debate. The astronomic rise of wholesale prices in the second full month of Phase 3-even sharper than their alarming jump in the first month-betokens imminent collapse of the anti-inflation offensive the President initiated so effectively twenty months ago.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn awarded a total of $5,000 yesterday to eight white teachers who had sued the African American Teachers Association Inc., charging that they were barred from a "public meeting" at a Bedford-Stuyvesant school.
It has been said that money managers are preoccupied with the so-called super-growth stocks, stocks of companies that show 15 per cent earnings gains year after year.
The five-day-old nationwide meat boycott gave its first evidence yesterday of whittling prices at the retail level.

James T. Lynn, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said here last night that the Federal Government would implement fiscal policies to sustain housing starts for 1974 at about the same rate as in 1973.
The Parks Department is proposing to enclose Washington Square Park with a sevenfoot-high wrought-iron fence to combat muggings, vagrancy and vandalism in and around the park.

In his message on human resources, President Nixon said that the O.E.O.'s legal services program had done much in its seven-year history "to breathe new life into the cherished concept of equal justice for all." The President promised legislation to perpetuate legal services for the indigent through an independent corporation "with safeguards against politicization."

Two Harvard biochemists have found that a component of a defoliant chemical used by United States forces in South Vietnam has contaminated fish and shellfish in Vietnamese waters and they say it may pose longterm hazards for the human population.

President Nixon opened a new phase of the battle of the budget today by vetoing a bill that would have forced him to spend $120-million for a rural water and sewer grant program. Utilizing the device of impoundment, he cut off spending for the program last Jan. 1.
President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam pledged todayin his first American public appearance - that he would never, never" ask the United States to send troops back to Vietnam.
Richard Dufallo conducted a student ensemble in an appetizing concert of relatively recent music at the Juilliard Theater on Wednesday night. Mr. Dufallo,

Senator James H. Donovan, Republican of Chadwicks and a major opponent of abortion, held a public hearing today on a package of bills he is sponsoring that he hopes will provide women with alternatives to abortion.
The bond market extended its modest upturn yesterday, shrugging off another sharp increase in wholesale prices during March and reports of intensified fighting in South Vietnam.

The Iowa Theater Lab is heavily indebted to Jerzy Grotowski's Polish Laboratory Theater, not just in its choice of name but in its method of performing. The group's "The Naming," the second in the Chelsea Theater Center's minifestival of plays by visiting United States companies ("Fly Chelsea to Brooklyn" is the overall title of the series) is an exercise in nonverbal gestural theater.
An 18-man delegation of experts from the Western oil consortium comprising British, American, French and Dutch interests left here today after three weeks spent drafting a "complicated and detailed"

The Queens Republican organization, which met strong rank-and-file resistance when it endorsed-Robert F. Wagner, a Democrat, for Mayor, has now endorsed another Democrat, Borough President Donald ?? for re-election.

The influential New York Film Critics yesterday roundly criticized the withdrawal of Constantin Costa-Gavras's "State of Seige," the third offering of the American Film Institute's Festivalat the Kennedy Center in Washington.

One of the country's most important judgeships will change hands on May 28 when Irving R. Kaufman succeeds Henry J. Friendly as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
An advance party of American officials headed by Alfred le S. Jenkins arrived in Peking tonight to establish the first formal American presence here for more than 20 years.
Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.
The Government banned today the use of Violet No. 1, a food color widely used in drugs, cosmetics and to stamp meat grade marks, on the ground that it may cause cancer.

The floodwaters of the Mississippi River inched toward record crests yesterday, claiming six lives, leaving thousands homeless and bringing estimates of expected damage in Missouri and Illinois to $41million.

On the second floor, a printing press nicknamed Big Apollo churns out 20,000 "Boycott Meat" leaflets an hour. On the third floor, cartons containing 5,000 leaflets each are stacked on dollies along the hall, to be taken quickly from there down to the cars double-parked on Broadway.

A threejudge Federal Court struck down New Jersey's $19.5-million program of state aid to private and parochial schools on the ground that it violated First Amendment guarantees in the United States Constitution for the separation of church and state.

A big supply convoy under American air cover sailed up the Mekong River tonight to try to break through a Communist encirclement of the Cambodian capital with badly needed fuel, food and military equipment.
Zion Industries, Inc., filed suit in United States District Court today charging a rival fig-bar manufacturer with eliminating competition in the fruit-cookie industry.

The American Telephone Telegraph Company and Mrs. Ernesta G. Procope, president of the E. G. Bowman Company, 1424 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were honored last night by the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity at its 10th anniversary dinner at the Americana Hotel.

One of the country's most important judgeships will change hands on May 28 when Irving R. Kaufman succeeds Henry J. Friendly as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Spokesmen for tax-exempt foundations objected today to legislation that would provide Federal funding to states that want to supervise foundation activities more closely.

For the first time in the 17year history of the International Auto Show here, advocates of mass transportation will have an exhibit urging visitors to the show to leave their cars home and take a train or bus The show opens tomorrow at the Coliseum.

Darrell M. Trent, acting director of the Office of Emergency Preparedness, said yesterday in Washington that "if industry does its part, there should be no major national gasoline shortage this year," and that "the Federal Government holds the possibility of gasoline rationing as highly unlikely."

After two performances of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" at Versailles, the Paris Opera had a second gala reopening last night, this time in its own house with Gluck's "Orphee et Eurydice," flamboyantly mounted as a luxurious theatrical spectacle.

WOODSTOCK, N. Y.-A six-foot-high fence made of chain link and barbed wire with a locked gate has been erected and maintained here by private landowners, blocking public access to 500 acres of state park land atop Overlook Mountain.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 151.6 from 146.4 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 114.8 on April 4, 1972.

The Lindsay administration's top housing officials declared yesterday that local bills to repeal or suspend the controversial maximum-base-rent formula of the rent-control law were "ill-conceived and potentially disastrous" as well as illegal under state law.
The State Housing Commissioner, Charles J. Urstadt, learned last night that a resignation he had offered three weeks ago had been accepted by Governor Rockefeller.

ROSCOE, N. Y.-A few tenacious anglers were still in the bar of Douglas Bury's Antrim Lodge the afternoon of April 2, the day after the opening of New York State's trout season, but most had been driven home by rain that began to fall Sunday afternoon.

At a time when the Nixon Administration is dominating Congress on most domestic and international issues, Congress seems to have gained the upper hand on a key- question of foreign policy-the linking of a trade agreement with the Soviet Union to the problems of Russian Jews.

Mrs. Barbara Starkey Donovan, editor in chief of Bride's Magazine, and Donald Gibbs Tober, president of the Sugar Foods Corporation in Brooklyn, were married here yesterday afternoon by Judge Shanley Feeth of the Civil Court of the City of New York, in his chambers.

President Nixon today ordered a maximum effort by the Administration to push through Congress legislation necessary for the construction of the Alaska pipeline.

PATH riders using special trains and buses provided because of the five-day-old carmen's strike continued to commute with little difficulty yesterday, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Authority officials said 1,400 more riders used the alternative transportation arranged because of the strike, bringing the total to 41,400.

Two former officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in San Francisco on charges of soliciting a $200,000 bribe from a savings and loan institution, the Justice Department said.

Mrs. Doris Sweet Corwith, who was national president of the American Legion Auxiliary in 1939-40, and later a radio producer for the National Broadcasting Company, died yesterday in a Huntington nursing home. She was 76 years old and lived here.

Harold W. Tucker,, director of the Queens Borough Public Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, died Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 60 Brixton Road in Garden City, L. I.

Unable to adjust to a Ranger team that went through its paces as if programed through a computer, the Boston Bruins bowed tonight, 4-2, and the New Yorkers took an overpowering 2-0 edge in their Stanley Cup playoff series.
The estimated cost of rebuilding Yankee Stadium has jumped almost $7-million to $27.9-million in less than a year and before construction has started, Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday.

Six American Broadcasting Company television shows will not return next season, but the stars of two of them, "The Julie Andrews Hour" and "The Paul Lynde Show," will be back under different circumstances.

The mammoth financial scandal at the Equity Funding Corporation of America began to come to light with a telephone call early last month from a disgruntled former executive, according to Raymond L. Dirks, the man who took the call.

Charles E. Lawall, president of West Virginia University from 1939 to 1945, and later a top vice president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, died last evening. He was 81 years old.

The Senate today passed a strong campaign disclosure bill that promises criminal penalties and forfeiture of office for all elected state and local officials who wilfully fail to report all sources of funds spent on their campaigns.

Keena Rothhammer, a 16-yearold from Santa Clara, Calif., scored her second victory in two nights, and Shane Gould of Australia broke an American record tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor short-course swimming championships.

President Nixon, declaring that "the days of paternalism have ended," today urged the members of the Organization of American States to seek a "strong new relationship."

The land in the upper Middle West still looks a little bleak and winter-weary these early April days, but a hungry world is crying for fodder, and the outlook for the farmers out here is unusually bright.

Japan's Justice Ministry said today that the Government would invoke its price-control ordinance to clamp down drastically on speculations in, and hoarding of key consumer goods by major Japanese trading houses.

Billy Keller hit a 3-point basket with 14 seconds remaining tonight to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 97-95 triumph over the Denver Rockets and a 3-1 lead for the defending American Basketball Association champions in the four-of-seven-game playoff series.

Len Elmore, who played his high school basketball at New York's Power Memorialbefore becoming a star for Maryland's eighth-ranked team, has withdrawn his application as a hardship case in the approaching pro draft.
The Florida Supreme Court ordered state education officials today to stop withholding school aid from counties where real estate is underassessed.

The archeologist Yigal Yadin reports that one of the Dead Sea scrolls just deciphered in Israel contains a new, hitherto unknown version of God's commands to Moses and is far more puritanical than Biblical Injunctions.
Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have developed a way of producing human blood and blood-forming cells inside a living mouse.
The Cost of Living Council raised the possibility today that the price of hamburger could rise above the meat price ceilings imposed by the Nixon Administration.

Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan called today for the closing of two sugar cane labor camps in Florida, saying that "conditions reported to me yesterday by my investigative team were deplorable and disgusting."

Oscar Robertson made 10 straight field-goal attempts during one span, scored 34 points and led Milwaukee to a 113-93 victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight as the Bucks took a 2-1 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.
Sammy Davis Jr. has signed a long-term contract with the National Broadcasting Company that will give the television network exclusive use of his talents in all major TV appearances.
John J. Kenny, former Freeholder and political power in Hudson County, was sentenced to a maximum of six years in state prison today.

James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, was at the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after suffering chest pains while playing handball.

Juan Marichal scattered seven Cincinnati hits and Bobby Bonds and Chris Speier delivered key run-scoring hits as the San Francisco Giants defeated the defending National League champion Reds, 4-1 , today in the 1973 major league baseball opener.

When Assistant Attorney General Kent Frizzell arrived in Wounded Knee, S. D., last week to take over Government negotiations with insurgent Indians, the situation seemed hopelessly deadlocked and edging toward violence.
The South Vietnamese Government reported several big Communist attacks last night.
The lower house of Parliament spent a good part of the day today debating whether a wave of anti-Americanism" was sweeping West Germany, as Opposition conservatives assert.
Three Navy airmen told yesterday of having given information under torture to the North Vietnamese. But each said he had been able to offer some resistance and none seemed in any way apologetic.

Plans were disclosed here yesterday for a series of television programs that are to be broadcast into classrooms in atleast 30 states to help elementary school pupils deal with emotations and attitudes involving death, love, responsibility and other subjects not usually addressed in the schools.
The International Antiquarian Book Fair has opened in the Carlton House, on Madison Avenue at 62d Street, to place compelling temptations before bibliophiles through 6 P.M. Saturday.

Gov. ernor Rockefeller declared tonight that the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay, L. I., would be built despite opposition from the Interior Department and many local officials.

Gina Bachauer's performance of the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 9 in E flat (K. 271) Wednesday night at Philharmonic Hall was a magisterial one, and it went a long way toward redeeming what had been a rather plodding evening up to that point.
Moroccan authorities refused entry yesterday to Henry Giniger, the Madrid correspondent of The New York Times, who arrived by air from Paris.

Pioneer 11, an unmanned 570-pound spacecraft, roared away from the earth tonight on a 22-month, 620-million-mile journey to Jupiter.
A heavyweight golfer from Japan, Masahi (Jumbo) Ozaki, furnished the surprise in the opening round of the Masters tourney today by tying Jack Nicklaus for second place with a 69.

Dr. Robert A. Turner, who Pleaded Turner Associates, a consulting pharmacologist organization, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford. He was 56 years old.

James W. McCord Jr., who has refused for nine months to talk to reporters about the Watergate conspiracy, said today that he would hold a news conference on the subject in the next few days.
Mrs. Kate Butler Righter of New York and Buffalo was married here this afternoon to Bruce Exton Wallis, a vice president of the Price Paper Corporation in New York.
The Inter-American Press Association said today that public reaction to attacks on the press throughout the Western Hemisphere had been "shockingly mild."

The chairman of the Association of Minority Broadcasters told the House Communications and Power subcommittee today that a number of black owners of radio stations oppose the Federal Communication Commission's proposed license renewal legislation.

The unprecedented rush by corporations to acquire their own shares picked up momentum in the closing days of March and is continuing strong so far in April. The companies are attracted by relatively low prices for their stocks in the wake of a prolonged market decline, and, as one officer expressed it, "They find the purchase of their own shares a most advantageous investment."

The stock market continued to drift aimlessly yesterday in moderate trading and closed generally lower for the fifth session in a row. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 1.59 points and closed at 923.46, only a fraction above its 1973 closing low of 922.71 registered March 23. Most other price indicators finished at new lows for the year.

Directors of Mercantile Stores Company, Inc., declared yesterday a split in the common stock, two-for-one, subject to stockholder approval May 23. The board plans to place the new stock on a dividend basis of 80 cents a year.

The nation's rate of inflation in the last three months, as measured by the closely watched wholesale price index, was the highest since the Korean war and well above the worst inflation rate of the Vietnam war years, new Government. statistics showed today.

Robert R. Rousek, Assistant State Treasurer of California since 1969, has been names director of communications for the Republican National Committee.

Gene Clines delivered a pinchhit triple, driving two runs home and sparking a five-run Pittsburgh rally today that gave the Pirates a 7-5 victory over St. Louis in their 1973 baseball opener.

After a secret trial on undisclosed charges, a 28-year-old Rhodesian journalist was sentenced by a court in Salisbury today to two years' imprisonment at hard labor. One year of the sentence was suspended.

Two goals by Bobby Hull helped the Winnipeg Jets score a 3-1 victory tonight over the Minnesota Fighting Saints in the first game of their World Hockey Association best-of-7game quarterfinal playoff series.

A new face at the Philharmonic: Aldo Ceccato, young Italian conductor, handsome, exquisitely tailored. He got a few subdued wolf whistles from a pair of women in the audience when he came to the stage on Thursday night.

Representatives of eight major Protestant denominations voted unanimously today to shelve for the time being efforts to reach agreement on a detailed plan for their merger into a 22-million-member Protestant church.

Senator Edward W. Brooke, who had hoped to make an assessment of North Vietnam's postwar reconstruction needs, was informed by Hanoi today that he could not visit for the time being.

Some good players seem to believe in doubling the opponents in part-scores at the drop of a hat and then trusting to a combination of tight defense and poor declarer play to produce a plus score. This style has its successes in pair games, in which an occasional disaster can be shrugged off, but it is decidedly unsound in a team contest.

Alfred R. Glancy Jr., Detroit financier who was once a coowner of the Empire State Building, died today at Harper Hospital of injuries suffered when he was beaten by two men who broke into his home last Nov. 12. He was 65 years old.

Volkswagen, the perennial best seller, has a reputation for sticking to one body style, making slight alterations each year only when they are functionally necessary. The company prides itself on the basic Beetle shape. But this year, that conformity has been compromised.

Kuwait has told Iraq she will not consider leasing two islands in the Persian Gulf to the Baghdad Government, official sources said today.

RUDOLF Firkusny has the kind of career from which legends are not made. Ever since he came here from his native Czechoslovakia 35 years ago, the pianist has gradually and modestly laid the solid foundation for an international reputation that places him among the world's most respected and genuine keyboard artists.

The British Empire is alive and well and living in New Haven-theatrically speaking that is. After its earlier triumph with David Storey's "The Changing Room," Arvin Brow's Long Wharf Theater last night offered the American premiere of Peter Nichols's "Forget-Me-Not Lane."

C. W. Post won seven events and dominated the first C. W. Post College Relay Carnival. The meet, which attracted colleges and two track clubs, was the first major event of the outdoor season in the metropolitan area.

The "dialogue" between North and South Korea, intended to reunify this peninsula, has settled down after nine months into political trench warfare. The two sides are no longer sniping or maneuvering against each other. Instead, each has hardened his position and is pounding away at the other.

For Richard Nixon it was a duty performed a bit grudgingly-an invitation long delayed, a reception at the Western White House instead of the Washington greeting so eagerly sought by Mr. Thieu, a warm but relatively noncommittal welcoming speech.

Ten weeks ago, the usually passive and uncomplaining residents of a dilapidated Chinatown building, who for years accepted defective electrical wiring, faulty plumbing, falling plaster and boiler breakdowns, declared a rent strike. Remember their inimitable recordings, which included "Bei Mir Bist du Schoen," "Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree" and "Pistol Packin' Mama"? Eliot Elisofon, the photographer, painter and writer died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in University Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 145 East 27th Street.

St. Joseph-by-the-Sea, a Roman Catholic high school for girls in the Huguenot section of Staten Island, got a new lease on life last week when plans to close it next year were canceled, Parental interest and the strong possibility that the school will become co-educational were credited with turning the tide.
The loss of riders on the Long Island Rail Road following the 50-day strike that ended Jan. 18 was apparently less than half of what railroad officials had said publicly that they expected.

Bobby Bonds's two-run double in the 11th inning enabled the San Francisco Giants to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 7-5, in a rain-plagued game today. Bonds had homered in the seventh.

Samuel A. Adams, the Central Intelligence Agency analyst who testified about military deceit at the Pentagon papers trial, said in an interview today that he has apparently been discharged. The agency denied it.

The Government's top coal-mine safety official has been severely reprimanded for one of several free trips he took in the corporate aircraft of companies holding major contracts with his agency, the Bureau of Mines.

If you paid more than $108 a month rent in 1970, utilities included, you paid more than at least half the families in the United States.

The Federal Aviation Administration says that the number of air travelers caught for possession of guns and drugs and for other crimes has declined sharply since nationwide screening of all passengers at airports began three months ago.
Mrs. Mercedes Hirsh and William H. Friedman were married here this evening at the home of the bride by Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Temple Emanu-EI of Westchester.
TRENTON - A package ofbills that would dramatically change New Jersey's system of handling tax appeals is slowly making its way through the Legislature.
A steady rain forced postponement of the third round of the Masters golf tournament today, possibly jeopardizing Jack Nicklaus's chance of winning the event for the fifth time.

Every now and then, a railroad man for 26 years and a one-time trolley motorman, walks from his home to Rockaway Parkway and Avenue J in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn and pays his respects to the old trolleys of Brooklyn. His name: Nick Morrone.
CLINTON - The Brandt Theater chain has agreed to a six-week experiment during which it will show only general-audience movies at the only movie house in this town of 5,000.
Some years ago, a little blond-haired girl made a network willow for her mother. The design she stitched on it spelled out two of her mother's favorite homlie-"We shall see" and "It all depends."

Secretariat took a positive step in the direction of retaining the championship that he won last year, at Aqueduct yesterday. The Meadow Stable star, syndicated at a price-of $6,080,000, won the one-mile Gotham with a smashing record-breakine performance.

Mrs. Patricia Ann Turgeon, wife of James William Turgeon, an executive with the National Geographic Magazine, died today at the Princeton Medical Center. Her age was 46. Mrs. Turgeon was a graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown. N. Y.
President Nixon is expected to announce,the imposition of new fees on imports of gasoline and oil, according to Administration sources.
The Garden State Parkway's seasonal picnic areas will open next Friday. Only one area, Shoemaker Holly, is open the year round.

KAREL REISZ, considered one of Britain's brightest directorial talents because of his smashing success several seasons ago with "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning" and "Morgan!," has been depressingly absent from the film scene since 1969, the year of his butchered but beautiful "The Loves of Isadora."
Brooklyn is losing many of its younger physicians in a continuing exodus from the borough and, as a result, the average age of the remining general practitioners is estimated at 60.

The 11th Duke of Argyll, whose marriages and divorces made headlines throughout the world, died in a private hospital in Edinburgh today from the effects of a stroke. He was 69 years old, and he and the Duchess had lived in a Paris apartment for years, visiting Scotland only briefly.
Racism and prejudice have left deep scars on John Logan's mind, as painful as the six-inch-long welts on each of his muscular brown arms. And there are other blacks who have felt the same pain.

The New York Athletic Club elite eight-oared crew coasted to a 4-length victory over Manhattan College today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon. Perfect conditions prevailed with only a slight cross--wind as Johnny Killen, a 13year-old coxswain urged his much older teammates into a half-length lead in the first 300 meters.

Mayor Raymond Wojtowicz has announced plans to appeal a decision by a United States District Court in Detroit ordering Hamtramck to construct 530 new housing units for the residents-most of them black and elderly--who have been displaced by urban and industrial development in the city since 1962.

New 'York University is studying plans to build an athletic field house on a one-acre plot three blocks south of Washington Square Park. University officials said last week that the sports complex had top priority for new construction.

Top-seeded Mrs. Margaret Court, the current ruler of women's tennis, and unseeded Kerry Harris, who some people are touting as a possible successor, will meet tomorrow afternoon in an all-australian final of the $50,000 Max-Pax tournament.
