The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has adopted a regulation that prohibits noncancellable contracts for "future services"-such as health spa and reducing salon memberships, dance lessons and vocational school courses.

Six representatives of the two peace-keeping commissions , including two Vietcong officers, were killed when their helicopter was shot town by a Communist missile Saturday, a Vietcong spokes. man said last night. The three crewman of the copter, all Americans, also died.
A train hit a bus at a crossing south of Warsaw today, killing seven bus passengers and injuring five seriously, the Polish press agency P.A.P. said.

Sparky Lyle failed more times today than he did in any one month last season, and the Yankees failed to spare themselves the embarrassment of opening in New York tomorrow still looking for their first victory of 1973.

In the next few days China will send to the West a priceless collection of objects from archeological excavations since 1949, which will be shown first in Paris and then in London and may go to Canada and the United States.
Three armed men and a woman kidnapped a British tobacco company executive today less than 24 hours after an abducted American executive was released.

There have been mud baths for the body and mud packs for the face. Now it's mud treatments for the hair. Not the mud you might dig up in Central Park or your backyard, explains Bruno Demetrio, a mustachioed 29year-old hairdresser with sky-blue eyes who owns Le Salon at 16 West 57th
Summonses charging building violations were issued less than two weeks ago to the "owner or manager" of the buildings in Queens where a facade collapsed Saturday evening and killing three persons.

The 143d annual conference of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints concluded today as a handful of Indians gathered at the gates of Temple Square to ask the Mormons for $1-million annually for Indian programs.
Federal Judge Harry Pregerson continued his search today for a trustee for the troubled Equity Funding Corporation of America, which has filed under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The Soviet Union recently built a Long-range communications facility in the Somali Republic, on the east coast of Africa, through which naval headquarters in Moscow can directly control the movements of its warships throughout the Indian Ocean area, according to American military analysts.
The North Vietnamese Minister of State, Xuan Thuy, left here today for Hanoi after having headed his country's delegation to the four-year peace talks that led to the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

Just when Jack Nickiaus appeared to be making a move in the Masters tournament today, he splashed two golf balls into the pond in front of the green on the 520-yard 15th hole. He took a triplebogey 8 there.

Dr. Laurence Standle Foster, a chemist who did re search in World II for the Man hattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, died Friday in Mount Auburn Hospital in Cam bridge. He was 72 years old

James W. McCord Jr. has told a Federal grand jury that he believes that Kenneth W. Parkinson, an attorney for the Committee for the Re-election of the President, channeled cash payments to the Watergate defendants in return for silence after their arrest inside Democratic headquarters last June 17, sources close to the case said today.

The British Army said today that it had intercepted a report compiled by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army that alleges that large sums of money stolen to finance terrorist operations have been embezzled by leading I.R.A. officers.

Following are excerpts from a statement by Mayor Lindsay: Early in this past week, Governor Rockefeller made the latest in a series of illinformed and destructive statements about conditions in our city. Specifically, he said that "under the current administration, the city is experiencing rampant crime, deterioration of city services and loss of jobs."

DENPASAR, Indonesia - As tourism here in Bali inexorably expands, the commercialization of this green island's unique culture grows apace. However, those familiar with Bali aver, it is still alive, vital and flourishing, basically uncorrupted by money and new influences.

The head of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club has given his personal endorsement to offshore atomic power plants, such as those called for in a $1-billion program by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest electric utility. John A. DeWall, vice president of Central Sales for the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, died Friday of a heart attack in Chicago. He was 47 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

" Children of Trouble," a one-hour documentary shown last night on the National Broadcasting Company network, fired off a scathing inquiry on problem youngsters who are channeled through courts and correction facilities in New Jersey.
The Atlanta Hawks, moving with pride and a rare display of muscle, overpowered the Boston Celtics today and won, 97-94, before a hometown crowd that almost booed them off the court last week.
Senator Clifford P. Case, a New Jersey Republican, will be taking a middle-of-the-road stance in the state's G.O.P. gubernatorial primary. Frances Henderson, one of the Senator's legislative aides.

The Queens buildings where a facade collapsed Saturday evening, killing three persons, were cited for building violations less than two weeks ago. One citation charged that the parapet wall over the buildings, at 37-16 to 37-46 Junction Boulevard in Corona, was "out of plumb, leaning over the sidewalk and creating an unsafe condition."

TRENTON, April 8--The separate bank deposits of the State Republican Finance Committee and Governor Cahill's principal political fund-raisers in New Jersey have been subpoenaed in Federal and state investigations of Republican campaign funds, authoritative sources reported here tonight.

The meat boycott failed to crack the general level of prices last week either in the New York City or Hartford areas, the two places in the country where market analysts survey current retail food prices weekly. But there was evidence that consumers were making their voices heard.
Israel decided today not to permit individual Israelis or Israeli concerns to buy land in the Arab territories occupied since the 1967 war.
The death of Picasso reopens the question of the ultimate destination of his great painting "Guernica," which has been in the Museum of Modern Art since 1939.

The Federal bank - regulatory agencies warned the nation's larger banks today against abusing the practice of making advance loan commitments and announced a new system of information collection in this field.

A cosmic ray telescope was switched on aboard Pioneer, 11 today as the 570-pound spacecraft passed the 1.4-million-mile mark on its long flight to the planet Jupiter. The telescope, the fifth scientific instrument activated since Pioneer 11 was launched last Thursday,

Although rain and unseasonably ably cold temperatures corn bined yesterday to cut a plan ned 20-mile March of Dimes "Walkathon" to two miles in Manhattan, a hearty group of 6,000 participated in the fund-raising effort to fight birth defects.
While Cesar Cedeno was on his way to a .320 batting average for Houston last season, Hank Aaron, the Atlanta Braves' slugger, said, "The last player to come into the league with such ability was me."

The visit that Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, plans to make to Bonn next month for talks with Chancellor Willy Brandt has caused remarkable repercussions in East Germany, the Soviet Union's close ally.

Nestled in a Pacific Ocean inlet almost 600 miles south of Santiago, this sleepy fishing and agricultural center managed for more than a century to remain aloof from the political and cultural gyrations in the capital.

Manuscripts of two of Joseph Conrad's later novels, with extensive changes made in his own handwriting, are going on display at the New York Public Library today through Saturday.
Unofficial sources said today that Soviet military authorities had ordered a civil rights campaigner-Grigory Podyapolsky-to undergo psychiatric treatment for three to seven days.
Improbably but irresistibly, Ed Giacomin and the Rangers trounced the Boston Bruins, 4-0, last night to take command of their Stanley Cup playoff series, three games to one.

With the filing deadline just one week away, more than three-quarters of a million New Jerseyans have yet to file their income-tax returns. Those who expect refunds and put off filing until the last minute will have to wait longer to receive their checks from the Internal Revenue Service.

The insurgent Indians occupying Wounded Knee were reported today to have rejected an informal agreement, reached last night by four of their leaders and Government officials, That would have ended the occupation of the village tomorrow or Tuesday.

Three tankers and two cargo ships from a convoy of 18 vessels reached Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, yesterday with the first fuel that the city has received in two weeks. The tankers brought enough fuel to last for six days. Government officials had
Following a mostly snowless winter, the metropolitan area had a touch of April snow yesterday, along with the more familiar April showers.
Substantial growth in containership activities between the Port of New York and Puerto Rico has been forecast by a prominent Puerto Rican steamship official.
Only a crowd of 10,798 showed up yesterday at Cleveland Stadium for the Indians-Tigers game after a record American League opening-day crowd of 74,420 on Saturday.
An announcer for Radio Station KOTD was killed today in a car-train accident minutes after he telephoned the account of another fatal cartrain crash to United Press International in Omaha.

Mayor Lindsay accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of politically motivated "harassment" of the city government and of "callous indifference to sound management" in the way the Governor runs the state.

The late Bette Richart once wrote in a poem "Dazzle me like July but, oh, stay a little longer." The line came to mind at the end of Martti Talvela's recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night.

More than a dozen motorcycle gang members tracked down and taunted an ailing Vietnam veteran early today, then hauled the 22-yearold former Army Sergeant from his car and stabbed him four times in the chest, the police reported.
April 8-Three tankers and two cargo ships from an embattled convoy of 18 vessels reached this besieged capital late today with the first fuel that the city has received in two weeks.

President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said today that his country was concerned about the Cambodian situation. But when asked whether he was optimistic that there would be peace, he replied, "I'm very confident."

" Hey, Sunny, would you get me a voice-over for the 'fun' commercial with a typical announcer's voice, age range 27-33?" an account executive called out to Sunny Harnett. "And then get me a laxative voice, 45," he added, smiling.
The Soviet Union disclose today that Dr. Michael E. De Bakey, the American heart surgeon, had operated here on Prof. Mtislav Keldysh, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, early this year.

Bob Love pumped in 38 points and sparked a fourth-quarter rally that gave the Chicago Bulls a 98-94 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers today and tied their National Basketball Association Western playoff series at two games each.

Miss Wendy Meri Scheler, a graduate of Goucher College and a member of Phi Beta Kappa, was married yesterday noon to Kenneth Michael Borow, also a member of Phi Beta Kappa and a graduate of Johns Hopkins University. Rabbi Raphael

Miss Ann Hersh was married here this afternoon to Frank Brandeis Gilbert of New York. a grandson of the late Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the United States Supreme Court. Rabbi Theodore H. Gordon performed the ceremony in the Peale Club of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

The State Commission of Investigation concluded yesterday that a major program initiated by Governor Rockefeller and supported by President Nixon to toughen the prosecution of narcotics dealers in New York City has not been successful.
President Nixon has proclaimed April 8-14 as PanAmerican Week and hailed the Organization of American States for building-a climate of friendship and understanding. In his proclamation yesterday,

Whatever else he was, Pablo Picasso was the most potent single force In the art of the 20th century. Matisse and Kandinsky might rival him as second leaders in the most violent revolution since the Renaissance.
This small town was littered with wrecked cars and debris from shattered shop windows and houses today after 25 more bombs exploded during the night.

Curtis Mayfield, with a 15year-singing background. has moved completely into the area of radical soul singing if Saturday's program at Philharmonic Hall is any guideline. Mayfield recently had his biggest success with the music for the film, "Superfly," a leader in the black action films.

Three times last week Mexico City had power failures. The residents of this capital are used to them. They know their city grew too big too fast and that it cannot really provide all vital services to the eight million or so people who cluster in and around it.

Miss Naomi Chienna Friedman, daughter of Rabbi Morris Friedman, spiritual leader of Temple Hillel, and Mrs. Friedman of North Woodmere, was married here at noon today to Steven Bart Wolinsky. He is the son of

Gil-Perreault scored two goals tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Montreal Canadiens, 5-1; For their first victory in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs. The Canadians lead the first-round, fourof-seven-game set, 3-1.

Marilyn Cochran of Richmond, Vt., won the women's slalom today and her 17-year-old sister, Lindy, was third in the Dick Springer Memorial ski races. The victory, plus her triumph in the women's giant slalom Saturday, gave Marilyn, 23. the over-all women's award.
United States officials are studying three alternative courses by which Britain's aging arsenal of submarine-based missiles might be modernized to better enable them to penetrate Soviet defenses.
Howard Stevens is of toy size compared with most National Football League players but the 5-foot-5-inch, running back, a 16th-round draft choice, signed yesterday with the New Orleans Saints.

Lehman Brothers, Inc., may be shifting its leaders. Lewis L Glueksman, one of a dozen or so senior managing directors, is expected to become executive managing director, a position that seems clearly the No. 4 spot of the investment banking house.

They will meet in the fifth game tonight at the University of Wisconsin in Madison with the four-of-sevengame series tied 2-2. Milwaukee will need stronger rebounding from Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and will need to off Rick Barry's shooting. In Sunday's game Abdulcool Jabbar grabbed only 14 rebounds, his lowest of the playoffs, and Barry scored 38 points. Barry also held Bob Dandridge scoreless in the first half and to 10 points for the game.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has purchased what some critics consider one of the most important early cubist paintings by Pablo Picasso, who died on Sunday. Although the gallery declined to reveal the purchase price, it reportedly cost $1.1-million.
in the glow of his victory in the Masters golf tournament today, Tommy Aaron was told: "This has ruined your image." "That's all right," the 36year-old pro replied.

Forty thousand commuters began their second week of seeking alternative means of transportation as the Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH) strike continued. Officials of the striking Brotherhood of Railway Carmen said yesterday that their members were prepared to stay off the job "for a long time."

A group of 100 housewives and several men crowded into the basement of the public library on Main Street here this morning to pick up insider tips on how to get the most and the best for the least money at the retail-store meat counter.

John Richardson Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Educa tion and Cultural Affairs, urged a committee-of businessmen in volved in the arts yesterday to broaden their support to the arts and artists of foreign countries as a path to international understanding.
More than 500 publishers, authors and other citizens of the book world convened at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue last night to discuss and decry the weaknesses of the publishing trade.
Mario A. Prococcino withdrew yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for City Controller, saying he did not have enough money to run a citywide campaign.
A preacher and another leader in church snake. handling died early yesterday after drinking strychnine at a service that Cocke County officials said was a demonstration of; faith.

Mr. L., a mental patient confined for 18 years for killing and raping a nurse, was given his freedom by the Wayne County Circuit Court here today, but he begins his new life with .a possibility of being charged with murder.
The United States will admit 500 more of the stateless Asians who were expelled from Uganda last year, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees announced today.
The Soviet Union announced today that one of its leading test pilots, flying an advanced MIG-23 fighter, had beaten his own speed record in a closed circuit of 100 kilometers (62 miles).

So many applecarts were upset in music, the theater and the arts in general during the first third of this century that many artists still are trying to get past the debris and get on with their own generation's work.

As owner of the Hebo Food Market in this village near the scenic Pacific Coast, Eugene Wesley complains that Oregon's controversial "bottle bill," which requires a return deposit on any beverage container, is costing him money and adding drudgery to his day.

The S.S. President Wilson came home today for the last time to a welcome by a single fireboat and the strains of "California, Here I Come." The arrival of the ship closed out 106 years of passenger service by American President Lines.
The United States Postal Service, facing a possible walkout of mailmen in mid-summer, expressed opposition today to pending legislation giving postal workers the right to strike.

April 9-A tanker with fuel for this beleaguered city was destroyed today by rockets fired by Communist gunners, but three other supply vessels managed to slip through the blockade along the Mekong River and were reported to be approaching the city.

Two undefeated teams survive in the Greater New York Bridge Association's double knockout team championship for the Von Zedtwitz trophy: the Fecision Team and a sextet headed by Sandy Stern. They will meet later this month.
Benjamin Franklin Shepherd, who retired in 1960 as chief metallurgist of Ingersoll-Rand Company, died Sunday at his home in Phillipsburg, N.J. His age was 79.

Garment workers in the city began a week-long "informational picketing" protest yesterday at major stores and shopping centers as part of a continuing campaign of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union aimed at stemming the increase in apparel imports.

To the Editor: For two decades after World War II the United States was strong and wealthy, commanding admiration and inspiring confidence. Today, while militarily still powerful, it has lost its economic leadership of a group of industrialized entities and become a member in poorer health than others.

North Korea today made public a direct appeal to the United States Congress to have American military forces withdrawn from South Korea and "remove the obstacles lying in the way to Korea's peaceful reunification."

The leader of a small French group of ultraconservative Roman Catholics, the Rev. Georges de Nantes, announced at an outdoor press conference here tonight that he would formally ask the Vatican tomorrow to start proceedings for canonical impeachment of Pope Paul VI.

State and Federal investigations of the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign precipitated a new public dispute today between State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. and Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney.

Stockholders of the General Cinema Corporation were told at their annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., that the company's earnings are expected to continue upward in the second fiscal quarter ending April 30. No specific earnings prediction, however, was made.

The first four truckloads of Bergen County financial records subpoenaed by United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern arrived at the loading dock of the Federal Building here after District Court Judge Lawrence Whipple ordered them to be produced "forthwith."
Army flood control experts said today that surging waters of the Mississippi River were till safely contained by levees here, but they continued to prepare for higher water.

A slight drop in meat futures prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange at the end of last week was of short duration as live hogs and live beef cattle prices climbed sharply yesterday, with some months rising the daily permissible limit.
A 21-year-old teacher told a jury today that she had been raped at knifepoint in a cloakroom of School 12 here with her fourth-grade pupils in an adjoining classroom.
Canada's major chartered banks raised their prime lending rate today following al Federal Government move designed to tighten credit and improve Canada's foreign-exchange position.

On North Fourth Street in Brooklyn, a black banner reading "Save Our Homes" hangs from one of the neat frame houses as if the neighborhood were in mourning. On the same brick-facade Residence, a poster shows a giant octopus with buildings griDDed in its tentacles.
Fire raged out of control for several hours last night and early this morning, destroying much of the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge on Pacific and Arkansas Avenues.

A Federal judge began proceedings today that could lead to contempt charges against former Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher for a letter he wrote to another judge. The letter allegedly violated a court ban that had been imposed in part to protect national security.
Consider this: "This road climbs steadily into the ?? forested foothills above Elkin, where the white-clapboarded houses of Blowing Rock lie in the first summits of the Blue Ridge.

The Gillette Company of Boston said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire a minority interest in a Yugoslav company that will make razor blades and metal tape measures. It will be Gillette's first manufacturing venture in Eastern Europe.

The police said they arrested the driver of a car riddled with bullet holes today after the owner of a service station said he fired 15 rounds of ammunition into a car driven by a man trying to break into the station.

The indictment of a South Texas political leader, George Parr, on income tax evasion charges for the third time in his 47-year career apparently has not disenchanted the voters in the Duval County town he calls home.

The 1973 version of the Kansas City Royals-and baseball's 1973 version of electronic entertainment-will be unveiled in the Royals' new $43-million stadium tomorrow night. More thin 42,000 persons will view the game against the Texas Rangers. One of the major features of the plush stadium is the $2.75-million electronic scoreboard which soars 12 stories high. Against a well-chosen defense, consistently continued, it is unduly optimistic to expect success with a one-dimensional direct attack. Such strategy is correct only when there are clear-cut weaknesses to bear down on or when so much firepower is amassed that the opponent cannot offer sufficient resistance.

CARIB COMERS Jamaica is a young island nation in the Caribbean but its culture goes back centuries. Starting tonight at 7:30, Jamaican culture will be graphically illustrated by the 10-year-old Jamaica National Dance Theater Company on its first New York visit.

J. EDGAR HOOVER. The Man in His Time. By Ralph de Toledano. 384 pages. Arlington. $8.95. One can say what one wants about Ralph de Toledano's "J. Edgar Hoover: The Man in His Time"-and most of what one wants to say is derogatorv.
Sunday night's "Marriage of Figaro" by the New York City Opera at the State Theater offered two debuts, and it is probably as much a credit as a debit that neither of them stood out unduly.

The Federal Trade Commission today tentatively accepted a consent order prohibiting the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a Portland, Ore., based organization with a controlling interest in some 40 subsidiaries, from engaging in illegal reciprocal purchasing or sales arrangements.

Bond prices raced ahead again yesterday, extending a rally ignited late last week on the growing belief that economic controls would be tightened or extended, or that the Federal Reserve would act to keep interest rates in check and, thus, out of any Phase 4.

When the Yankees opened their 50th season at Yankee Stadium last year, Rusty Torres and John Ellis sat on the bench. Charlie Spikes was in their minor league training complex in Hollywood, Fla., and Brent Strom was with the Mets' Tidewater farm club in Norfolk, Va.

The anachronistic oil import quotas are soon to be declared officially dead-a welcome development, even if it comes three years or so after all life departed from them anyway. Unfortunately, with or without the quotas, or the import "fees" that are to take their place, it is now clear that the cost of fuels for American consumers is going to have to rise.
A car carrying a coed and three athletes from the University of Bridgeport went out of control and overturned on Route 17 yesterday, killing one student and critically injuring the others.
The Singer Company today began four days of product demonstations in a bid to stir Soviet interest in its products.
An apparent agreement designed to end the 41-day occupation of Wounded Knee, S.D., by a band of armed Indians fell apart before the eyes of a Congressional committee today.

Anthony De Balasy, a former I Hungarian diplomat and official of the World Bank, died Friday at his home here. He was 78 years old. Mr. De Balasy had served in the Hungarian diplomatic corps and as deputy chief of the political division in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Budapest.

The little old schedulemaker has already made April an easy month for the New York Mets by giving them six days off, one of which (the 30th) they'll use to play the Cadets at West Point, and the little old rainmaker, who always works so hard this month, could make the schedule even easier.

Canada's highest-ranking military official here has rejected Vietcong assertions that two helicopters carrying representatives of the international peace-keeping commission were shot down Saturday because they had strayed off their prescribed course.
The State Senate rejected a bill today that would have shortened the terms of members of the State Board of Regents from the present 15 years to five years.

Continuing Communist attacks against helicopters carrying peacekeeping observers over South Vietnam raise grave questions about the Vietcong contention that last Saturday's incident, in which four members of the International Commission of Control and Supervision were killed, was merely a "regrettable accident." The emerging pattern suggests a deliberate attempt to sabotage the peacekeeping effort.

Two persons died and three were injured yesterday in four accidents involving Long Island Rail Road trains. The accidents also caused two derailments that knocked out service on two lines for the evening rush hour.

David Garth, the political television consultant who packaged Mayor Lindsay's efforts in one Presidential and two mayoral campaigns, filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to collect more than $31,000 that he said the Lindsay 1972 Presidential campaign apparatus owned him.

WASHINGTON-In his most recent move in the "battle of the budget," President Nixon last week vetoed the rural water and sewer bill. This is one of the several measures moving through the Congress that, taken together, would add billions of dollars to the Federal budget.
Dominick Dominick, Inc., and Lombard, Nelson McKenna, Inc., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday they had agreed in principle to consolidate.
Moore and McCormack Company, Inc., and the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company announced yesterday plans for construction of a synthetic natural gas (SNG) plant at a
Edward W. Wendell, a designer of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and former Mayor of nearby Altamont, died Saturday at his home. He was 88 years old.
At a peak and moving better than any Ranger team during the Emile Francis era, the New Yorkers sail into Boston Garden tonight for what could be a clinching party against the Bruins.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld today a contempt citation against two reporters who printed testimony in violation of a judge's orders. The court said its ruling did not infringe on the right of a free press.
The State Charter Revision Commission yesterday reported that it had concluded that the city's government should be decentralized, but that it had not yet decided how or how much.
Reacting to the worldwide protests aroused by the secret trial last week of Peter Niesewand, a journalist, the Rhodesian Government said today that secret trials were held in other countries.

Leaders of a special Senate and House study committee have reached tentative agreement on major reforms in the Congressional budget process. The proposals, if enacted, would enable Congress to set an annual spending limit,...

Peace is at hand in the women's tennis feud, Walter E. Elcock, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, said yesterday. With another series of meetings scheduled for today in Boston between the U.S.L.T.A.

All flights by helicopters of the International Commission of Control and Supervision have been t temporarily suspended because of shooting incidents involving such aircraft, a commission s source said this morning.

A band of Arab guerrillas using a powerful bomb blew out the entrance to the apartment building housing the Israeli Ambassador yesterday and then attacked an Israeli airliner in an apparent attempt to hijack it before take-off.

The first gathering of opponents of the Portuguese regime to be allowed in four years issued an appeal last night for the end of the "colonial war" in Africa and the establishment of political freedom in Portugal.
A message from the Spanish Government was among the many expressions of tribute and condolence delivered to the family of Pablo Picasso, who died on Sunday in Mougins, France.
More than 200 Moslen rebels and at least 11 Government soliders were killed as the army drove insurgents from a southern Philippines town in two weeks of fighting, a police official said today.

The State Supreme Court ruled today that the form of government now in effect in Paterson, the only one of its kind in the state and perhaps in the nation, is unconstitutional. The system gives great power to appointed commissioners and little or none to elected Aldermen.

The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter this year, continuing the 1972 gains. Expanded production and a strong national economy, were factors in the advance, William W. Boeschenstein, president, said yesterday.

James Gallagher, director of amateur and college baseball relations in Bowie Kuhn's office, told the New Jersey college baseball coaches and writers today that coaches were to blame for college baseball's failure to grow. "Coaches don't go out to stir some enthusiasm about the sport," Gallagher said. "They, sit in the back seat and sort of play an inferior role.

The ceaseless feud between Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller has reached flashpoint once more. This is a feud that began appropriately enough during a citywide garbage strike. It has stayed at the level of its origins for five years-to the considerable discredit of both protagonists and to the even more considerable disadvantage of the people of this city.

The Government corporation that insures American businesses against losses from expropriation of their overseas plants today turned down a $92.5-million claim filed by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
Faced with increasing public criticism of dam construction, and a shortage of possible dam sites, Idaho's water planners are looking to the state's 'southern desert for new water.

A junior high school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was closed yesterday to cool emotions after pupils walked out of classes to protest a decision by the local school board to remove the principal.
A House subcommittee chairman says the White House is holding back a $1-billion list of military bases to be closed, possibly "to reward their friends or punish their enemies" in Congress.

Charles and Julia Tucker have a home where the buffalo roam only 90 minutes from Times Square in Dutchess County. Driving an old red pickup truck through the range on which the buffalo graze, Mr. Tucker came close to his herd of 37 animals the other day.

The United Auto Workers sent a close-to-deadline appeal to the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday to grant the auto industry a year's delay in meeting the 1975 limits on emissions of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons.

Forty thousand commuters began their second week of seeking alternative means of transport on as the Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH) strike continued. Officials of the striking Brotherhood of Railway Carmen said yesterday that their members were prepared to stay off the job "for a long time." Transport of New Jersey said it would provide extra bus service to ferry commuters between Jersey City and lower Manhattan.

An official of the Department of Agriculture was indicted by a grand jury today on charges of hiring a private detective concern to place an electronic listening device on the telephone of his estranged wife.

Leon Greenberg, president of Monticello Raceway, accused the management of Roosevelt Raceway yesterday of indirectly attempting to kill winter racing at Monticello. Greenberg referred to a bill recently introduced in the New York State Legislature calling for yearround racing dates at Roosevelt and Yonkers harness tracks.

Engelbert Humperdinck's "Konigskinder" received its first performance at the Metropolitan Opera in 1910, and everyone agreed that it was enchanting (more so than the Met's other world premiere that season.
The Cerro Corporation's copper products division announced yesterday that it was raising the surcharge on copper industrial and redraw tube 1 to 4 cents a pound, effective immediately.

A 14-year-old boy who was said by the police to be a passenger in a stolen car was killed today when the car slammed into a tree during a high-speed chase. The dead youth was identified as Frank Compolito of Syracuse.

Even on a chilly afternoon of 47,972 empty seats, the peanuts and popcorn and crackerjacks had a nostalgic flavor at Yankee Stadium yesterday as the New York Yankees celebrated the golden-anniversary baseball opening of the House That Ruth Built.

Governor Rockefeller defended today his criticism of the Lindsay administration and his mayoral campaign maneuverings by asserting again that the city was suffering from corruption, inefficiency and mismanagement.

This compact city of 500,300 people and 200,000 cars is in the throes of a revolution that has brought it free rides on buses, plenty of new walking space amid the palaces and churches of its well-preserved historic center and nasty traffic snarls on its outskirts.
The State Charter Revision Commission yesterday reported that it had concluded that the city's government should be decentralized, but that it had not yet decided how or how much.

State Police Detective James Challender walked a familiar path last month when he provided United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern with information that launched an investigation into the handling of campaign funds during Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign.

In a cautious change in policy, South Korean officials have disclosed that their Government is prepared to establish trade relations with China. The officials said that South Korea would be receptive to a trade offer from Peking and saw possibilities of a small but profitable two-way exchange.

A policeman is accused of corruption. Prices are soaring. A monetary crisis is developing in Europe. Irish rebels and troops are fighting. The State Legislature istalking about a crackdown on obscenity. A big Wall Street firm is in fraud trouble.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said yesterday his role as chairman of a foreign-based mutual fund was, at most, "a mistake in judgment." The'fund Is involved in a $30-million civil lawsuit in which Mr. Wagner and other prominent persons are accused of fraud and diverting funds.

There is no longer need to call Tommy Aaron a runner-up. Although he has had that role 14 times since joining the professional golf tour in 1961, the 36-year-old Georgian swept off with the prestigious Masters tournament title today by one stroke.
A group of Westinghouse Electric Corporation officials visited Soviet electrotechnical industry facilities in Leningrad today, the Tass news agency reported.

New York State's Department of Correctional Services has sounded many of the right notes in proposing a $276.9-million prison construction master plan. This is important, since New York is one of the major centers of imprisoned men;

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. told the annual meeting here that sales and earnings for the first quarter would set records. Charles B. McCoy, chairman and president of the huge chemical producer, said that the company expected to earn $136-million or $2.80 a share,
The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered a hearing today on staff charges of violations of Federal securities laws by Charles Plohn Co., a defunct New York broker-dealer.

Raymond L. Dirks, who first brought to light the burgeoning, multimillion-dollar Equity Funding Corporation of America scandal, said yesterday that he had been briefly dismissed and then rehired by his Wall Street firm over the weekend.

Sparked by a surge of buying in blue chips, the stock market climbed sharply yesterday in slow trading. The Dow-Jones industrial average soared 16.48 points and closed at 947.55, its highest reading of the day. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
Leslie Saalburg, an illustrator for leading magazines, died Sunday in Paris, where he lived. He was 77 years old. Mr. Saalburg's illustrations appeared in Vanity Fair, Vogue, Esquire and This Week.

Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale of these short-term securities. In last week's sale, the average rate for 3-month bills was 6.531 percent and the average rate for 6-month bills was 6.814 percent.

New York City police officials told a Congressional hearing today that the use of undercover policemen on the streets, dressed in a variety of disguises "to blend into the scenery, had probably deterred some street crime in the city.

The admission by the President's man, H. R. Haldeman, that he was responsible for intelligence during the Nixon campaign of 1972 is gravely damaging, for intelligence was the one commodity in which the campaign was poverty-stricken.
The Legislature approved today a bill allowing Nevada to become the first state to sanction the use of acupuncture on patients on a full-scale basis.

The Yankee Stadium shone with resplendent attractiveness in the bright sunlight yesterday, an elegant old dowager about to celebrate an occasion of considerable distinction. This is the golden anniversary year for the ancient ball park and a considerable number of parties will mark various phases of these year-long festivities. It is fervently hoped by the new Yankee management that they are better attended than was yesterday's home opener with its unimpressive gathering of only 17,028.
Workers and employers voted today to end Denmark's biggest labor conflict in 37 years. More than 260,000 workers are to return to work tomorrow after three weeks of strikes and lockouts.
President Nixon asked Congress today to appropriate $361-million more for the 1973 fiscal year, including $1.5million to set up the new United States liaison office in Peking.

The Central Intelligence Agency says it was wrong when it suggested that a representative of the Ford Foundation had initiated the suggestion that the New York Police Department go to the intelligence agency for training.
About 20 homes at Sodus Point, 30 miles east of Rochester, were surrounded by water today after weekend winds sent waves crashing ashore from Lake Ontario.

A group of 23 New England Congressmen today urged President Nixon to take immediate action "to permit the American footwear industry to survive." The nine Senators and 14 Representatives sent Mr. Nixon a letter urging the President to take alternative steps to aid New England's shoe industry which is under heavy economic pressure from imports.

An apology was disclosed today in the High Court from The Times to Lord Rothermere, his son and their newspaper chain for "unjustified charges" contained in an article written by a Times columnist, Bernard Levin.
Peter J. Brennan. the Secretary of Labor, asked Congress today not to intervene in a dispute between the Penn

The sheet metal workers' union announced today a new stabilize tion plan for the construction industry that would give union members a guaranteed income and other benefits in return for a pledge against featherbedding, slowdowns and other disruptive work practices.

Ken Rosewall fought back from two service breaks in the final set to defeat Fred Stolle, 3-6, 6-2, 7-5, in the final of the $50,000 River Oaks tennis tournament. The victory, the 38-year-old Rosewall's first on the World Championship Tennis tour, moved him into the lead of the croup B standing.

Israeli commandos attacked Arab guerrilla bases early today in Beirut and Saida, on the Lebanese coast. The raids, carried out in darkness, followed a Palestinian cornmando attack yesterday in Nicosia, Cyprus,

The flooding of the Mississippi River and its tributaries this spring is the second part of a double-barrel calamity for many farmers. The winter-long rains that damaged last year's harvest are now preventing them from planting this year's crops.

A teachers' strike that has left Hawaii's 181,000 public school children without normal classes went into its second week today. In resumed negotiations the Hawaii State Teachers Association was reported to have eased its pay demands to a 7 per cent increase Sept. 1 and an equal amount in September, 1974.
Argentina will play its South American Zone Davis Cup semifinal series against South Africa in Uruguay this weekend, a spokesman at the Argentine Tennis Association disclosed today.
Meyer Katzman, senior partner of Katzman Associates, architects at 147 East 50th Street, died Saturday at New York Hospital. His age was 70 and he lived at 60 Sutton Place South.

Anthony J. Russo Jr., one of the two defendants in the Pentagon papers trial, testified for the first time today and wept as he told how his feelings about the war in Vietnam, and finally his life, had been changed by a captured member of the Vietcong.

The Nixon Administration has submitted to Congress the equivalent of an Official Secrets Act that could bring down an impenetrable curtain over virtually all governmental activities related to defense and foreign affairs. The proposed legislation would give to the executive branch and its huge army of officials iron-clad protection from public scrutiny.

LONDON-Until recently investigators had studied individuals seen as mentally ill but not their social contexts. The focus had been upon the "patients," not the behavior towards them of other people; it still is in certain circles.
Sweaters. Sweaters. Sweaters. Long ones. Smooth ones. Fluffy ones. Sweaters with big, burly turtlenecks. Sweaters with necklines cutaway a bit to show the collar of the shirt underneath.
Tony Perez made three hits and drove in two runs tonight as Cincinnati defeated Atlanta, 8-7. The Reds pushed four runs across in the ninth inning to win. Two of the runs scored on Perez's third hit.
A House study group recommended today a $1-billion a year increase in research to meet the energy crisis, including an all-out attempt to replace petroleum with synthetic coal gas.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a slate of 10 candidates for twoyear terms on the exchange's board of directors, with the election to be held May 14. Seven of the candidates are already directors who will be standing for election to a second term, while three nominees have not previously served.
The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that it had begun construction of a new hydrometal lurgical plant for the production of copper at Anaconda Mont.

Soviet consumers, parched during last year's unusually hot and dry summer when beer and soft drinks often ran short, are being promised that Western-style tonic water and Pepsi are on the way to help quench their thirst.

Now that dozens of the world's top artists and weavers are doing rug-like tapestries, the nation's two top rug-makers were bound to return to what they pioneered in decades ago -- devising woven wall hangings.

The Securities and Exchange Commission softened today a rule restricting brokerage firms' payment of commissions to employes who solicit the purchase of securities other than for the account of the person paying the commission.

The first candidate for a New York City mayoral nomination to hire a priest for his press secretary is Albert H. Blumenthal, a Manhattan Democrat. The new press secretary is the Rev. Mark Corrigan, a Roman Catholic clergyman who has been working at City Hall since September of 1970.
Mike Quarry and Hal (TNT) Carroll, heavyweights, will fight in a scheduled 10-rounder, April 23, at the Felt Forum, Madison Square Garden

Israeli commandos attacked Arab guerrilla bases early today in Beirut and Saida, on the Lebanese coast. The raids, carried out in darkness, followed a Palestinian commando attack yesterday on Israelis in Cyprus.
British soldiers shot and killed a gunman today and a soldier died from wounds he received two months ago, bringing the number of dead in Ulster violence to five since Saturday.

Mayor Lindsay, in the second day of attacks on Governor Rockefeller, warned yesterday that the city would "not tolerate a Boss Rockefeller any more than we have accepted rule by anl local boss" and would reject "a new kind of politically regressive rule from Albany."

William F. Chapman, assistant general counsel of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, died Saturday in Long Island College Hospita after a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 25 Remsen Street in Brooklyn Heights.

Suzanne Troxell's soubrettecoloratura soprano is of a sort highly prized and much cultivated in German opera houses--very bright in timbre with a hard "ping" around the edges and colored with a rapid but not excessive vibrato.

Over at the American Research Bureau the thinking is that the big thrust of the 1970's for national advertisers will be toward local marketing. More and more, they believe, manufacturers will want to heavy up on promotion dollars in specific markets where they are needed.

Fortunate Harbor proved ready and fresh for the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Just in from a good campaign in California, the 4-yearold Robert Dodderidge colt broke the track record in the 6 1/2-furlong race, with a clocking of 1:15 1-5.
Weather: Cooler, chance of showers today; cold tonight. Cool tomorrow. Temp. range: today 37-46; Monday 37-55. Full U.S. report on Page 86.

The Queens District Attorney's office started a grand jury investigation yesterday to determine if criminally negligent homicide was involved in the collapse of a building parapet in Corona, Queens, on Saturday night that killed three persons.

WNET/Channel 13 has named Robert Kotlowitz director of programing and Frederick M. Bohen director of news and public affairs, it was announced yesterday by John Jay Iselin, acting president of the public television station.
Wine produced by five New York wine companies are "legal" in Ohio, state Liquor Department officials said today. The wines had been challenged in a court suit by Paul

Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, cautioned yesterday that "the auction-market system, which was created to serve all investors, must not be weakened by any of the proposed restructuring now being considered."

President Nixon will send his trade message and legislation to Congress tomorrow, the White House announced today. While the broad outlines of the legislation have already been indicated in the President's international economic report to Congress, it is understood to include numerous points of detail not previously disclosed.
Secretary General Waldheim has informed the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government that it may not open an office at the United Nations, qualified sources reported today.

The City Housing Authorty will open 28 new projects with 7,379 units this year, according to the authority chairman Simeon Golar, who said yesterday that the agency could have produced many more units for the effort expended.

Israeli commandos attacked Arab guerrilla bases early today in Beirut and Saida in southern Lebanon. Two prominent leaders of the Palestinian Fatah guerrilla organization were killed in the Beirut attack. The raids followed a Palestinian commando attack in Nicosia, Cyprus, yesterday. Governors. general. colonels. politi cians and baseball officials gathered torather solemnly yesterday to dedicate the biggest stadium in baseball, but it was a ball player who did the real dedicating. In the third inning. with two team mates on the base lines,

The dollar and gold weakened today on European money markets. Gold on the London free market opened at between $90.25 and $91, but after the official morning fixing of its price, it was quoted at $90.75, a fall of 25 cents from the close Friday.

In the first major change of the city's secretive realestate tax assessment system since it came under fire by the State Commission of Investigation seven weeks ago, tax commissioners have been directed to state in writing for public scrutiny their reasons for granting certain reductions in assessment valuation.
Mrs. Jeanne Elizabeth Meyer Feldmeir, a sculptor and the wife of Daryle M. Feldmeir, editor of The Chicago Daily News, died today in Billings Hospital. She was 46 years old and lived in Winnetka.
Surgeons implanted Americandeveloped nuclear - powered heart pacemakers in nine patients today. Eight operations were performed at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark and one was done.
Eugene S. Cooper, 44 years old, has been named president and a director of International Stretch Products, Inc. He succeeds Lester Cohen, who had previously been elected vice chairman.

Business at meat counters picked up yesterday, the first shopping day after the weeklong nationwide boycott, but retailers still encountered resistance to continuing high prices. Lists of ceiling prices for beef, lamb, pork, veal and mutton blossomed at stores.
While policemen and leftist demonstrators battled near St. Peter's Square, Pope Paul VI met President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam here today and urged him to release political prisoners.
Mario A. Prococcino withdrew yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for City Controller, saying he did not have enough money to run a citywide campaign.
Gov. James E. Holshouser sent word today to'Indians who staged a 100-mille march to Raleigh that he was willing to meet with a delegation tomorrow to discuss their demands.

Luis Aparicio of the Boston Red Sox said today a gang of extortionists had threatened to kidnap his 15-yearold son in Venezuela if they were not paid off. The shortstop, who resides during the offseason in Maracaibo, Venezuela,

The "little green card" from his local Republican club that can help guide someone to a summer job in a state park is also honored in seasonal hiring on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, officials said yesterday.

Leaders of a special Senate and House study committee have reached tentative agreement on major reforms in the Congressional budget process. The proposals, if enacted, would enable Congress to set an annual spending limit.
Before she was put to death, the girl said in Polish: "Remember me." The time, 1943. The place, Majdanek, a Nazi death camp near Lublin in Poland.
Josef Pavel, Interior Minister of Czechoslovakia during the liberal regime of Alexander Dubcek, Communist party leader, died today. He was 64 years old.

At least six days of idleness confront the New York Knicks as they wait for the Boston-Atlanta series to produce their second-round opponent in the National Basketball Association playoffs. The danger in that is they may lose the sharp edge their eight "regulars" displayed during the disposal of the Baltimore Bullets by four games to one.

State Police Detective James Challender walked a familiar path last month when he provided United states Attorney Herbert J. Astern with information that launched an investigation into the handling of campaign funds luring Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign .
Dr. Walter Hipp, a former New York ophtalmologist who had lived and practiced until last year in Sands Point, died Saturday at his home here. He was 74 Years old.

Sidney P. Nadel, former assistant Corporation Counsel who became counsel to the Board of Education seven years ago, died Sunday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 61 and he lived at 1970 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.

L'ETE (SUMMER), a comedy by Romain Weingarten, translated by Shepperd Strudwick 3d. Directed by Wendell Phillips; setting and lighting by William Strom; sound by Susan Ain; production stage manager, Peter von Mayrhauser. Presented by Margaret Barker. At the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street.
Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the National Academy of Sciences announced today a $15-million program to help improve emergency medical care throughout the United States.

In the first major change of the city's secretive real-estate tax assessment system since it came under fire by the State Commission of Investigation seven weeks ago, the tax commissioners have been directed to state in writing for public scrutiny their reasons for granting certain reductions in property assessment valuation.

A quiet but intense debate is developing in the Pentagon over which service will dominate America's nuclear arsenal and win the major share of appropriations. Reduced funds for research and development, procurement and construction in a period of modernization, qualified sources say,

Consider this: "This road climbs steadily into the thickly forested foothills above Elkin, where the white-clapboarded houses of Blowing Rock lie in the first summits of the Blue Ridge. The midsummer heat of the coastal plain is weaker there. Hawks and ospreys circle patiently on the foothill thermals.

Anthony J. Russo Jr., one of the two defendants in the Pentagon papers trial, testified for the first time today and wept as he told how his feelings about the war in Vietnam, and finally his life, had been changed by a captured member of the Vietcong.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income, before securities transactions, went up 29 per cent to $23-million from $17.8-million. Pershare earnings rose to 80 cents from 62 cents.

A movement to require simultaneous translation in all Federal courts that serve communities with significant numbers of non-English-speaking residents is taking shape in court reform and Congressional circles.

Manufacturers recalled more motor vehicles for correction of safety defects in 1972 than in any other year, the Department of Transportation reported today. The total of 12 million exceeded the previous record of 9.4 million, set in 1971, by 2.6 million vehicles.

The many ages, and the many faces, of Joan Crawford passed in review before a capacity audience of 1,500 in Town Hall on Sunday night. The audience watched a series of highlight scenes from her long screen career,

Governor Rockefeller defended today his criticism of the Lindsay administration and his mayoral campaign maneuverings by asserting again that the city was suffering from corruption, inefficiency and mismanagement.
The nation's highestranking former prisoner of war says that the P.O.W.'s in North Vietnam learned to recognize and appreciate the "real pros" among the guards who tortured them.
The Arkansas Supreme Court, in a 7-to-1 decision, struck down today, the major part of the state's abortion law. It retained a section allowing only licensed physicians to perform abortions.

An Orthodox Jewish group sued in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to enjoin News-day, the Long Island newspapers, from refusing to accept an advertisement that condemned intermarriage as "suicide, national and personal."

Management and players of the Philadelphia Blazers are infuriated at Bernie Parent. The goalie was the first name player to jump from the National League to the World Hockey Association and signed a long-term contract worth more than $120,000 a year with the Blazers.

A State Supreme Court justice dismissed yesterday a petition by Lawrence Shubert Lawrence in which he sought to regain control of the nationwide theater and real estate empire of the Shubert Foundation, Inc.

Steel production for the week ended Saturday resumed its upward trend after a one-week decline, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association placed the week's output at 2,967,000 net tons, a gain of 0.1 per cent over the 2,963,000 tons reported in the preceding week.

The lawyer for James W. McCord Jr. said today that his client had no first-hand knowledge that anybody "higher up" than the convicted G. Gordon Liddy knew of plans to wiretap Democratic headquarters at the Watergate office complex here.

A tanker with fuel for this beleaguered city was destroyed today by rockets fired by Communist gunners, but three other supply vessels managed to slip through the blockade along the Mekong River and were reported to be approaching the city.

The sale of the United States Embassy residence here, a simple matter in itself, has somehow become the center of an international controversy involving the United States, West Germany and the Brazilian state of Guanabara.
The Xerox Corporation introduced here yesterday two new products-a compact copier and an automatic facsimile system--as part of its promised line of major new products this year and next.
The Treasury said today it had found out that French-manfactured stainless-steel wire rods were being "dumped" on the American market in violation of United States trade laws.

Thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets today demanding the removal of the ruler of this Himalayan kingdom. The Indian Government took ovver the 'administration of Sikkim yesterday at the request

A band of Arab guerrillas using a powerful bomb blew out the entrance to the apartment building housing the Israeli Ambassador yesterday and then attacked an Israeli airliner in an apparent attempt to hijack it before take-off.
Secretary General Waldheim has informed the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government that it may not open an office at the United Nations, qualified sources reported today.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market posted their second con secutive advance yesterday in slower trading. Brokers termed the upswing primarily technical and observed that bargain hunters helped fuel the rise.
At least six days of idleness confront the New York Knicks as they wait for the Boston-Atlanta series to produce their second-round opponent in the National Basketball Association playoffs.

Congress established the Overseas Private Investment Corporation primarily to provide risk insurance to American companies with investments in the developing countries. Earlier this month, the O.P.I.C. president, Bradford Mills, made plain to a House subcommittee that the corporation would feel justified in rejecting an insurance claim where an investor was guilty of "actions that would create political problems and provoke expropriation" in a host country.
After months of incidents on the high seas followed by diplomatic protests, Britain and Iceland are moving toward a new round of talks on ending their latest "war" over fishing rights.

State and Federal investigations of the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign precipitated a new public dispute today between State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. and Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney.

More that 18,000 Peruvian anchovy fishermen returned to sea today. The military government has authorized the nation's 1,200 anchovy trawlers to make one fishing trip per day, four days a week, excluding Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays.

A group headed by a former Indianapolis 500 winner, Parnelli Jones, was reported today to be in line to become the new operator of the $25.5-million Ontario Motor Speedway, idle since financial difficulties shut it down last fall.
Commodity Options International, Inc., has agreed to a permanent injunction after the Securities and Exchange Commission charged it with violations of securities laws.

Johns Hopkins vaulted into the top spot in the national lacrosse rankings after trouncing Cornell, 17-8, last Saturday. The victory was the Blue Jays' fourth in four starts. Cornell slipped from eighth to 10th in the weekly coaches' poll.

STAMFORD, Conn.-During World War II, Staff Sgt. George Engelhardt found Army field rations such a bore that he decided to improvise, using his helmet as a pot and whatever he could find as his ingredients.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said yesterday his role as chairman of a foreign-based mutual fund was, at most, "a mistake in judgment." The fund is involved in a

This country's most intense and prolonged controversy of recent times culminated today when Prime Minister Norman E. Kirk directed the Rugby Unidh. to call off a proposed visit here by an all-white South African team.
If the Palestinian guerrilla movement had a foreign minister, Mohammed Yussef Najjar, i who was killed early today by c Israeli commandos, would have t been a likely candidate.

With 160 games left to play, Yogi Berra began juggling his pitching staff today as the New York Mets opened their first trip of the season with a postponement in 28-degree cold along the flooded Mississippi.

John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, reported yesterday that income for the first quarter this year totaled $20.8-million, or 75 cents a share, compared to $13.3-million, or 48 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

The President would be given unlimited authority, as part of trade agreements negotiated with other counties, to raise, lower or eliminate tariff duties. Tariff reduction or elimination would generally be spread over five years after finishing the trade agreement.

The Bank' of Montreal and the Mercantile Bank of Canada announced today interest rate increases sim. ilar to those announced yesterday by four other chartered banks.
A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was crushed to death in an elevator shaft yesterday as he and other children were playing on top of an elevator car, thPeolice said..

The Government was studying today a set of counterproposals--one of them reportedly inspired by a "vision" that appeared to a Sioux religious leader-for putting the Wounded Knee peace agreement into effect.
Terrorists bombed a Roman Catholic church early today for the third time in three and a half years, and guerrillas wounded a British soldier in an ambush.
North Korea asserted today that unless American troops were withdrawn from South Korea no progress could be expected in talks on easing tensions and the eventual reunification of the two Koreas.
Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, appeared to widen the Administration's definition of executive privilege today to cover 2.5 million employes o(f the executive branch of the Government.

Bill Hartack posted his second riding triple of the Pimlico meeting today. After taking the second race with Northern -Iusky for a $9.40 straight payoff, Hartack scored with two Frank Y. Whitr eley-trained horses: Special Affair ($2.60) in the sixth.

The daughter of Stalin, the former Svetlana Alliluyeva, was sued for divorce in Phoenix, Ariz., by William W. Peters, chief architect at the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation's communal school, Taliesin West, at Scottsdale, Ariz. Mr. and Mrs. Peters, who were married, after a 20-day courtship, on April 7, 1970, separated in December, 1971.
The Chilean Government said today it will soon issue a banknote in the largest denomination ever as result of this nation's skyrocketing inflation rate. Government officials said a1,000-escudo note,

The state's first effort to police the wide variety of practitioners in the mental health professions has become embroiled in professional controversy, The dispute over the issue, however, does not bring into question the urgent need for effective safeguards.
Two of the nation's electronic-electrical giants - the General Electric Company and the RCA Corporation-reported yesterday sharply higher firstquarter results.

The 51st baseball season in Yankee Stadium was launched Monday on a flood of literature that left the interesting impression that the team that opened the big playpen on April 18, 1923, was composed of two men named Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. This was not exactly the case, as witnesses of next Sunday's game with the Red Sox will discover.
The House Education and Labor Committee approved today a $4.5-billion two-year extension of a public jobs bill that President Nixon has vowed to veto if it is passed by Congress.

Agreement on a new contract covering about 136,000 state employes and calling for wage increases of $156-million over two years of a three-year contract was announced today by negotiators for the Civil Service Employes Association and for the state.
