Miss Roberta Korn was married here last night. to Dr. Arthur E. Helft. Rabbi Israel Schorr performed the ceremony at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklvn.

The United States will admit 500 additional Asians who were forced to leave Uganda last fall, informed officials reported today. Last year after President Idi Amin of Uganda ordered all Asians to leave his countryjhe United States admitted 1,500.
The Small Business Administration extended its disaster assistance program today to cover damage to the homes of farmers and other rural residents in disaster areas.
Police Superintendent Clarence B. Giarrusso of New Orleans disclosed today that six )olicemen wounded in the January gun battle at the Howard Fohnson's motel had been shot 3y policemen.

The Los Angeles Lakers,, defending their National Basket,ball Association championship, V took charge in the final 14 minutes tonight and defeated the Chicago Bulls, 123-102, to take a 3-2 lead in their four-of-seven- ,: game first-round series.
Ted Gross, the former Commissioner of the City southh Services Agency, admitted in State SUtpreme Court yesterday that he had accepted bribes during his 16 months in office.

The House Banking Committee today turned back an effort to prohibit mutual savings banks from paying interest on checking accounts. The committee voted 19 to 17 in favor of an amendment by Representative William S. Moorhead. Democrat of Penn.
A top military intelligence officer, writing in an unofficial Army journal, has called for reducing "duplicative" analyses by civilian intelligence agencies of threats facing the United States.

Ruth Rodney King Manley, who wrote short stories and poems in several leading national magazines, died last Tuesday in Doctors Hospital here after a heart attack, her family announced today. She was 66 years old.

Sedimentary deposits with an oil-bearing potential that may be as rich as those off the coasts of Louisiana, Texas and California have been found 30 to 50 miles off Long Island and New Jersey, the United States Geological Survey and Nixon Administration officials disclosed today.

The state police detective, James Challender, who touched off a Federal investigation last month when he gave information to United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, is now the target of a departmental investigation.

After a nine-year battle involving coerced confessions, multiple indictments, four trials and several stints in prison, George Whitmore Jr. was freed yesterday -- at the request of the Brooklyn District Attorney, who termed Mr. Whitmore's treatment by the law "a disgrace."
Clarence M. Mitchell 3d, a Maryland State Senator and a member of one of the South's most prominent black families, was indicted today on four Federal counts of income tax evasion.
Dr. Daniel Ellsberg took the witness stand late this afternoon to tell a jury of 10 women and two men why he disclosed the top secret-sensitive Pentagon papers.
Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst appeared to widen the Administration's definition of executive privilege today to cover 2.5 million employes of the executive branch of the Government.
A British charter plane crashed during a heavy snowstorm this morning while trying to land at Basel, in northwestern Switzerland. More than 100 passengers and crewmen were killed.
Ralph Houk always has said people forget spring training records once the season begins and this year, the Yankees are proving him right. But he didn't mean it exactly the way it has been happening.

The Administration proposed today raising the Federal minimum wage to $2.30 from the current $1.60 an hour by 1976, but also asked for the lower minimum Wage for youth that has been bitterly opposed by organized labor.
President Nixon asked Congress today to make several relatively limited changes to tighten the tax laws that apply to American companies with overseas operations.

Unlike a lot of other athletes, he's no snappy dresser. "You'll never call me a pacesetter," said Marques Haynes, the legendary dribbler for the Harlem Globetrotters who later operated his own barnstorming basketball team, the Fabulous Magicians, for 19 years.

"We ripple more," said Rex Nettleford, artistic director of the Jamaica National Dance Theater Company. The 11l-yearold West Indian troupe made its local debit last night, starting a run, through Sunday, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and there is no doubt that this is a special'kind of dance company.
Employes of the American Motors Corporation's Jeep plant in Toledo ratified today a settlement worked out by United Automobile Workers and company officials over the weekend.
Long-shot players hollered at her to bring home the bacon, but all Mary Bacon was able to bring home at Aqueduct yesterday was mud. "At least I'm getting a $25 mudpack for nothing,"
Burgess Owens, a personable young man who wants to be a dentist, began earning more money than many dentists take home when he signed a "multiyear" contract with the New York Jets yesterday.
Samuel Ungerleider Sr., chairman of the board of Ungerleider, Haidas Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart attack.

American-born microbiologists experimenting aboard an Israeli supertanker off Elath grew bac*teria that ate more than half the sludge, tar and oil in ballast water.during a four-day sailing, it was reported here yesterday.
Prince Norodom Sihanouk has declared in a speech in Hanoi that the insurgent groups in Cambodia would under no circumstances accept a cease-fire with the Government of President Lon Nol.
Premier Saeb Salam submitted his resignation today following a predawn raid by Israeli commandos in which three prominent Ralestinian guerrilla leaders here were killed.

J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., reported yesterday that its net t{ income before securities trans. actions in the first quarter in-; creased 19.5 per cent to $35,531,069 from the year-earlier Y $29,744,665. Per share earnings 7 rose to 97 cents frnm 81 cents.

An Invitation by inmates atWalpole State Prison to have their cells searched has been turned down by Norfolk County District Attorney George Burke. Mr. Burke said today, "One of the most important elements of a search is that of surprise.
Weeden Co. announced yesterday a net loss of $1,128,. 000 for the month of March, compared to a profit of $445,. 000, or 25 cents a share, in the same 1972 month.

SPECULUM MUSICAE, with Euoene Drucker, violin; Daniel Reed, violin and mandolin; Louise Schulman and Nobuko Imal, viola; Fred Sherry, cello; Donald Palma, bass; Nancy Freeman, harp; Paul Dunkel, flute; Joel Marangella, oboe; Virgil Blackwell, clarinet; Albert Regnl, bass calrinet; Julle Fevrs, basoon; Ronald Anderson, trumpet; Scott Kuney, gultar; Ursula OPpens, Piano; Richard Fltz, percussion; Janet Steele, soprano; Richard Frlsch, baritone. At Carnegie Recital Hall.

The House Post Office Committee has reported a sleeper bill ostensibly intended only "to clarify the proper use of the franking privilege by members of Congress." In reality, however, the bill would give incumbents ironclad protection to abuse this privilege.

Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, the Israeli Chief of Staff, said today that his forces' spectacular commando raid in Beirut this morning was staged in response to "the intensification, of terrorist acts in Europe and other places in the last months."
Formation of a provisional coalition cabinet in Laos will be announced within a month, Interior Minister Pheng Phongsavan said here today.

Eight years after he gave strong backing to passage of the landmark Racial Imbalance Law of Mmsachusetts, Mayor Kevin H. White of Boston declared today that hie law was not working and that it overemphasized the need for racial balance in the schools.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday directed the state to remedy the "inhumane and shocking conditions" at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded.
Italian home furnishings designers have been the innovators in recent years, so it wasn't really much of a surprise last night to find an Italian theme to Bloomingdale's new model rooms.

A single Communist mortar shell crashed into a vil lage 100 yards away, sending soldiers and their families running for ditches. Three persons were killed by a rocket last night, and everyone was nervous.

An initial offering of 331,220 shares of the Neutrogena Corporation common stock at $12 a share was reported sold out yesterday by Hambrecht Quist, San Francisco, managers of the underwriting group. All of the shares offered were sold for the account of Emanuel Stolaroff, chairman of the board of the Los Angeles-based manufacturer of skin care products.

The Government proposed today new safeguard devices for microwave ovens to prevent dangerous radiation leaks. Current rules specify that when the door of a microwave oven is open the radiation must shut itself off.
Alex Steve sat on the second floor of his house on the Michigan lakefront of Lake Erie last night and watched the waters engulf his first floor as he mixed anc sipped martinis.

Ten years after the first loss of a United States nuclear submarine,, the Navy still lacks a modern, worldwide' system for rescuing sailors trapped( undersea. A riew system is being tested, but it will not be ready for the fleet until mid-1974, about four years behind schedule. And it will not become global before 1978 at the earliest.
To the Editor: The White House has been laboring, without result so far, to produce a legal memorandum justifying President Nixon's continuing war in Cambodia.

The Assembly is expected to vote today on a bill that would strictly define the practice of psychological counseling and limit mental-health work to persons practicing under statelicensed supervisors.

Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, the Israeli Chief of Staff, said today that his forces' spectacular commando raid in Beirut this morning was staged in response to "the intensification of terrorist acts in Europe and other places in the last months."
Stewart R. Mott, the political big spender and Park Avenue penthouse gardener, says he particularly likes growing kohlrabi, ruby-red lettuce and the Chinese pea pods called snow peas.
A surprisingly docile House bowed to the wishes of the White House today by voting to sustain President Nixon's veto of a bill to finance water and sewer systems in rural America.

And Perhaps ... The Story ot Ruth Dayan, by Ruth Dayan and Helga Dudman (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6,95). Can't Read, Can't Write, Can't Takl Too Good Either; How to Recognize .and Overcome Dyslexia in Your Child, by Louise Clarke, introduction by Archie A. Silver. M.D. (Walker. S7.95).

Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress proposing trade reform legislation: The Trade Reform Act of '1973, which I am today proposing to the Congress, calls for the most important changes in more than a decade in America's approach to world trade.

The boxing team of Poland will open a two-week tour of the United States tonight by opposing the New Jersey Golden Gloves champions at the Elizabeth Armory. The Polish team, which arrived Sunday night and took over the entire Young Men's Christian Association building at Paterson, will also meet the United States team at the . Scottsman Hall in West Paterson on Saturday.

A Piscataway High School student who struck out in her attempts to make the varsity baseball team has started a Federal Court suit to change New Jersey's scholastic sports rules on ground that they discriminate against women.

Sedimentary deposits with an oil-bearing potential that may be as rich as those off the coasts of Louisiana, Texas and California have been found 30 to 50 miles off Long Island and New Jersey, the United States Geological Survey and Nixon Administration officials disclosed today.
Tne George PeaoWy AwarMwinning "Afternoon Special" programs for children on the American Broadcasting Company will be seen 12 times next season, it was announced yes.tardav.
The operator of an Ulster County camp pleaded guilty yesterday to conspir in a $10,000 bribe for two officials of the federally financed Model Cities program in Harlem.

Agreement on a new contract covering about 136,000 state employes and calling for wage increases of $156-million over two years of a three-year contract was announced today by negotiators for the Civil Service Employes Association and for the state.
John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, slid today that he favored endfig Federal price controls for new supplies of natural gas 'on the interstate market.

Expressing caustic skepticism about the "appropriate use of taxpayers' money," the City Council's Finance Committee yesterday held up approval of $150,000 in city funds to help furnish a luxurious hospitality center for apparel-industry buyers.

Greenbelt Consumer Services, Inc., a cooperative, operates 10 filling stations in the Washington area under the BP emblem. It pumps more than eight million gallons of gasoline a year, and it charges 2 or 3 cents less than. the going price.
While "public access" on cable television juggles nervously with publicity generated by charges of obscene programming, its basic concept continues to be advanced by the Teleprompter Corporation.

Frank D. Reeves, the first black to serve as a Presidential administrative assistant, died Sunday in Freedmen's Hospital. He was 57 years old and had been hospitalized six weeks ago after suffering a stroke.
Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's special envoy, arrived from Phnom Penh, Cambodia, yesterday to find truceobserver activities here at a standstill.
The City Human Rights Commissioner, Eleanor Holmes Norton, yesterday issued guidelines for fair campaign practices in local elections.
Traffic jams built up for the secondday in a row today at struck Xerox Corporation plants in suburban Webster and Henrietta as cars carrying nonstriking employes threaded through Dicket lines.

Deputy Chief David M. McCormack of Staten Island has been elected president of the 2,600-member Uniformed Fire Officers Association. Mr. McCormack succeeds Capt. Alfred Benway of the Bronx who is on the promotion list for battalion chief.

The United States began airlifting fuel into this besieged capital today. The first planes were scheduled to bring in only military fuel, American officials said, but they suggested that later flights might carry commercial fuel if efforts to ease the critical shortage here failed.

Carrying colorful bilingual banners and placards, 300 working mothers and their grade - school youngsters marched through the narrow streets of Chinatown yesterday to protest scheduled cutbacks in Federal support for day-care centers.
The Sun Oil Company and American Petrofina, Inc., announced yesterday 25 cent a barrel increases in the price they will pay for crude oil in west Texas.
A surprisingly docile House bowed to the wishes of the White House today by voting to sustain President Nixon's veto of a bill to finance water and sewer systems in rual America.

With 160 games left to play, Yogi Berra began juggling his pitching staff today as the New York Mets opened their first trip of the season with a postponement in 28-degree cold along the flooded Mississippi.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday directed the state to remedy the "inhumane and shocking conditions" at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded.

At this year's vegetable prices, a $3.10 investment for seeds could save up to $100 on grocery bills for a family of four, according to a garden plan outlined by the Dutchess County Cooperative Extension Service. The minimum plot suggested is 10 feet by 15 feet.
This north Georgia city of 40,000 welcomed home its golfing hero with a parade today-Tommy Aaron, the Masters winner. "We are crazy about him," said Joe Ragiand of the city's Chamber of Commerce,
New Yorkers who did not file city income tax returns because they earned $8,000 or less last year may be missing out on getting refunds, according to the City Finance Administrator, Richard Lewisohn.

President Salvador Allende Gossens said today that Chile would not compensate the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for its expropriated Chilean assets. Dr. Allende also contended that the Central Intelligence Agency had worked with I.T.T. to try to block his election in 1970.

Blue Shield of Greater New York has declined to renew the contract of its president, Dr. Leonard J. Raider, following a report by the State Insurance Department that criticized him for having allowed $15-million in reserve funds to be dissipated by too-low premiums for city emploves.

March retail sales totaled $42.27-billion, seasonally adjusted, 2 per cent above the upward revised February sales of $41.31-billion and 16 per cent higher than sales in March, 1972, the Government Department reported today.

Author- c Itative sources reported here ti tonight that the state and Fed- tf eral investigations of the financ- 1i ing of Governor Cahill's 1969 i Republican election campaign had narrowed down to Federal I~ charges that heavy contributors c wrote off their donations as g business expenses in violation ti of income-tax laws.
Mrs. Margaret Smith Wakelin, whose husband, Dr. James H. Wakelin Jr. was Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research and Development from 1959 to 1964, died here Sunday. She was 62 years old.
Loose Montreal fielding and a two-run homer by Willie Montanez helped Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies to a home-opening 7-5 victory over the Expos tonight.

Rene Robert scored at 9 minutes 18 seconds of the first sudden-death overtime period tonight to give the Buffalo Sabres a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens fdr their second straight National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff triumph after three straight losses.
Philip J. Rutledge, the highest ranking black in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today that he was resigning effective May 5.
Howard Cohen, the copy writer, and Bob Pasqualina, the art director, who created the much-talked-about Alka Seltzer campaign of a year ago, have now created an advertising agency.

Authoritative sources reported here tonight that the state and Federal investigations of the fin'ancing of Governor Cahill's 1969 Republican election campaign had narrowed down to Federal charges that heavy contributors wrote off their donations as business expenses in violation of income-tax laws.
Joe Notter, the jockey who rode the only filly ever to win the Kentucky Derby-Harry Payne Whitney's Regret in 1915 died today in Pilgrim State Hoasiptal. He was 82 years old.

The Kitty Hawk courts-martial have ended with a handful of black sailors still in Navy jails and others discharged, but with little light shed on what caused the racial disturbance aboard the aircraft carrier last October.

First-period goals by Jim Pappin and Stan Mikita sent the Chicago Black Hawks wheeling to a 6-1 victory tonight, eliminating the St. Louis Blues from the Stanley Cup playoffs in the National Hockey League.

Precident Nixon has sent his trade reform bill to the Congress at the worst possible time. For he is asking the House and Senate to grant him vast new powers to raise, lower or eliminate tariff duties precisely when the Congress is more alarmed than ever before about its loss of power to the Chief Execu, tive.

The CompUter Arts Festivar at the Kitchen, 240 Mercer Street, offered something of a media blitz Monday night Perhaps the most unusual item was Charles Dodge's -'!Speech Songs," in which simple phrases were synthesized and then particular variables (pitch, intensity, attack, etc.) varied to strikingly expressive effect.

Despite a windy day and a wet track, the customers turned out in numbers as Connecticut's first retail horsemeat market opened. today in this small beach resort community. Several customers and a group of radio, television and newspaper reporters and cameramen were waiting in the rain when Kent Carlson arrived shortly before 9 A.M. to test how the public would buy the idea and the essence of horsemeat.

In an unprecedented display of public disagreement, the 1973 National -Book Award judges announced yesterday that they had split the fiction prize between John Barth's "Chimera" and John Williams's "Augustus,"

Israeli commandos have struck a stunningly effective blow in the "war against terror" that was proclaimed by Premier Golda Meir after last fall's Munich massacre. Yesterday's swift, pinpointed attack against three key Palestinian guerrilla leaders in their homes in downtown Beirut and against other guerrilla targets inside Lebanon rivals in daring and brilliance-and in potential import -Israeli victories in three conventional wars against the Arabs.

A two-week Puerto Rican festival of music and dance, with the cellist Pablo Casals as a participant is a highlight of an ambitious new program worked out between the City of New York and the Carnegie Hall Corporation.

Although Pablo Picasso lived most of his liUfe in France and refused to return to his native Spain as iong as the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco was in power, he is being hailed here as one of the greatest of Spanish painters-albeit with world dimensions.
Ed Searcy, a 6-foot-7-inch junior at St. John's, was one of 11 players granted eligibUity yesterday under the hardship rule for the National Basketball Association college draft next Monday.
Congress, declared the Speaker of the House, Carl Albert, was "face to face with a confrontation that has been in the making for some time," the clash with President Nixon over spending.

A Coast Guard utility boat and apparatus of the North Bergen Fire Department, along with residents and motorists on Manhattan's upper West Side, watched a fire last night as it burned through a jumble if derelict barges and docks on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.

Ralph Nader said today that the Goveniment had "sold out" to the automobile industry and would announce tomorrow.that it was granting a one-year. delay in requiring achievement of the 1975 auto pollution control standard. .

Joseph Larkin, the driver of the school bus that was struck by a freight train, killing five students, was sentenced to five years' probation today by a judge who told him: "You will be punished for the rest of your life, and you deserve to be."

Partly sunny skies and cool temperatures will continue over Metropolitan New York today; cloudy, windy and cold weather, possibly accompanied by light snow or flurries, will cover the remainder of the Northeast and the lower lake region.

A House Banking subcommittee approved today a bill to make formal the 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar in terms of gold. The measure was amended to provide that, when the President finds that essential monetary stability has been achieved, the 40-year-old ban on ownership and trading in gold by private citizens will be lifted.
A. Howard Freund, a George Wallace supporter who ran unsuccessfully last year for the United States Senate, declared his candidacy today for Governor on the American party ticket.

Effective interest rates on Federal Housing Administration-Veterans Administration home mortgage loans in the first week of March were the lowest this year, the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported today.
President Nixon asked Congress today to make several relatively limited changes to tighten the tax laws that apply to American companies with overseas operations.
A gunman entered a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank in the Bronx yesterday and thrust a threatening note and a bag to a young woman teller on the job for the first day.

The state police detective, James Challender, who touched off a Federal investigation last month when he gave information to United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, is now the target of a departmental investigation.
The Internal Revenue Service ruled today for the first time that expenses for abortions, vasectomies and birth control pills are tax deduotible, including those foi 1972.

The Senate securities subcommittee approved legislation today that would abolish fixed brokerage rates by April, 1974, and requiring brokerage affiliates of institutional investors to conduct a 100 per cent public business to qualify for membership on national stock exchanges.
A former Cortland State College student has received a four-year Federal prison term for helping to set the Cortland draft board office afire in September, 1970 in an antiwar protest.

President Makarios today condemneed the Arab terrorist attacks on Israeli property in Nicosia, and told the Arabs and the Israelis to take their quarrels elsewhere. "Cyprus has its own problems" the Archbishop said in a statement.

SAINTS HAUNT Two Saints does not take its name from any particular deeds of virtue but from its address, 2 St. Marks Place (GR 79650), just east of' Third Avenue, where it does duty as a restaurant and, after 9, as a night spot, with eats and/or drink.

Marty Riessen, Arthur Ashe and. Australia's 'Ken Rosewall won first-round matches today in the $50,000 Cleveland tennis tournament. Riessen had trouble with Fred Stolle's volley game but came back strong to beat the Aussie, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2.

The Administration proposed today raising the Federal minimum wage to $2.30 from the current $1.60 an hour by 1976, but also asked for the lower minimum wage for youth that has been bitterly opposed by organized labor.

The Southwestern Investment Company, a diversified finan. cial services and insurance company, announced yesterday it had signed an agreement under which it would become a wholly owned subsidiary of the Beatrice Foods Company.
Bills providing a one.year extension of funding authority for the clean-air and solid waste-disposal laws were signed today by President Nixon.

President Nixon sent Congress today a comprehensive trade bill that would give him sweeping new authority both to raise and lower United States tariffs and other trade barriers as a prelude to forthcoming international negotiations.

Kenheth G. Agnew, who retired in 1961 as. president of Agnew Associates, Long Island City, Queens, died Monday in St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived at Port Jefferson Station.
Duane Bobick, Olympic heavyweight boxer, made his professional debut tonight, flooring Tommy Burns of Canada four times and stopping him at 2 minutes 59 seconds of the first round.

A Queens College psychologist, his wife and his son routed would-be robbers who sought to force their way into the family's home in East Norwich, L. I., yesterday. Two men were arrested, and two others were being sought. Two men wearing ski masks appeared at the doorway of the home of Edwin Kahn, a counselor at the college. Mr. Kahn recognized one as an acquaintance of his 20-year-old son.
MANILA--Throughout non-CommUnist Asia there has been a tendency in recent years to strengthen the executive power at the expense of the legislative and judiciary.

Following the recent return of the last of 588 American prisoners of war from Southeast Asia, the Department of Defense has begun to try to determine the status of 1,328 men still listed as missing in action in the Indochina war.
Premier Saeb Salam submitted his resignation today following a predawn raid by Israeli commandos in which three prominent Palestinian guerrilla leaders here were killed.

John Lord O'Brian, the distinguished lawyer, died today at the age of 98. Mr. O'Brian, who fell in his apartment last Wednesday and was taken to the George Washington University Hospital, died of heart failure there.
Raymond S. Fries was elected yesterday as a corporate vice president of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc. He will report directly to Robert J. Buckley, president,
A signed, voluntary confession of an 18-year-old Paterson youth charged with raping a 21-yearold teacher at knife-point at Public School 12 here on Jan. 28 was introduced as evidence at his trial.
The House Education and Labor Committee approved today a two-year, $4.5-billion extension of a public service employment program that the Nixon Administration wants to eliminate.

Thousands of youths protesting a visit by the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, today battled the police and stormed city hall in Bonn's most violent left-wing demonstration in five years.
The Government has started an investigation into the shadowy world of Australian professional boxing, following a report by a national medical association condemning the sport.

The arrest of a rabbi, a partner in a real-estate management business, and the company's bookkeeper on charges of bribing a city inspector to overlook housing violations was announced yesterday by Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta.

Dr. Henry Weinberg, an assistant medical examiner for 35 years until his retirement in 1953 and since then a consulting pathologist, died Suhday at St. Clare's Hospital. His age was 82 and he lived at 383 East Eighth Street.

PEOPLE WILL ALWAYS BE KIND. By WIIfrid Sheed .374 pages. Farrar, Straus Girouox $7.95. In Wilfrid Sheed's earlier novels, I always had the feeling that he had saddled himself with protagonists who cramped his. style,.,who weren't complex enough to give the author a chance to work up a sweat.

There is nothing much wrong with Nick Bellitto's new play, "The Soldier," which opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse. But then again, there is nothing much right with it. It is sincere and even serious but unoriginal .

More than 25 schools upstate were closed by three inches of blowing, drifting snow in a zone of St. Lawrence County from Ogdensburg to Canton. Heavy rains and thundershowers brought small streams to their brinks in the Lower Hudson Valley.

The United States began airlifting fuel into Phnom Penh, the besieged capital of Cambodia. The first planes were scheduled to bring in only military fuel, American officials said, but they suggested that later flights might carry commercial fuel if efforts to ease the critical shortage failed.

Hollywood Park announced today that it Would conduct horse racing on Sundays throughout its 15-week meeting, Opening tomorrow. The innovation will begin next Sunday, F. E. (Jimmy) Kilroe, the track's racing director, said.
Mayor Lindsay assailed Governor Rockefeller for the third day in a row yesterday as he announced the opening of 30 centers for retired and elderly people to be run entirely with city funds.
ON BOARD THE U.S.S. HANCOCK. -- Out on the flight deck none of the problerls are visible. The men are too busy arming, launchand landing aircraft, and the only concerns are for time and safety.
Bitter cold followed a record April snowstorm into the Midwest yesterday, hampering the work of clearing main traffic routes clogged by drifts as high as 10 feet.
Col. Clarence M. Young, an aviation pioneer who was architect of the Federal airways system 50 years ago, died today at the age of 84. He was the holder of United States Civil Air License No. 2.
William J. Prater, convicted two weeks ago in the Yablonski murders, has since given a full confession to the Federal authorities, implicating others.
Ed Searcy, a 6-foot-7-inch junior at St. John's, was one of 11 players granted eligibility yesterday under the hardship rule for the National Basketball Association college draft next Monday.
"I know full well many communities are frightened of the prospect of statewide land-use planning or statewide land-zoning. It flies in the face of short-run convenience and age-old traditions.

Andrei Voznesensky, the internationally known Soviet poet, has come under official attack for a new cycle of verse containing criticism of censorship, falsity, shallowness and conformity in current Soviet literary life, along with the suggestion that the Revolution has not lived up to its ideals.

Pablo Picasso's body was moved across his beloved southern France today from the villa where he died at Mougins north of Cannes to the chapel of the 16th-century castle dominating this village in the sere, almost forbidding hill country north of Marseilles.
Burgess Owens, a.personable. young man who wants to be a dentist, began earning more money than many dentists take home when he signed a "multiyear" contract with the New York Jets yesterday.
The Soviet Union is expected to buy sizable quantities of grain again this year, though not as much as in 1972, Department of Agriculture officials said today.

A Briton was sentenced today to five years at hard labor, four years of which were suspended, for "conspiring with 11 other persons to overthrow the Rhodeslan Government by violence or forcible means."
A lawsuit in Superior Court seeks to block further distribution of a buying guide that rates about 50 local drug stores as being good, average, poor or erratic In terms of their prices.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, today ordered an investigation into what he called the Administration's propaganda campaign against Congress over spending. Senator Muskie asked the Con. troller General, Elmer B. Staats, whether the alleged campaign, if undertaken at Government expense, violated any law, specifically antilobbying statutes.
Nine musicians assembled under the "Music from Marlboro" banner at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night and played Mendelssohn, Mozart and Faure.

Rick Barry sank a key A..Rash layup with 1:14 left to play Bmret and then scored on two free Ellis throws after the final horn to G. John give the Golden State Warriors MummlIn a 100-97 victory over the Mil- Russll waukee Bucks tonight.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said yesterday that he would announce today whether he would run this year for his old job in City Hall. He said he had postponed making such an announcement yesterday so he could consult with the some "leading Democrats" on his decision.
State legislators were cautioned by a seminar of drug specialists today against isolating the drug problem as a "demon" that could be treated apart from the broad range of society's problems.

President Nixon sent Congress today a comprehensive trade bill that would give him sweeping new authority both to raise and lower United States tariffs and other trade barriers as a prelude to forthcoming international negotiations.

The latest bond market rally lost some steam yesterday although strong momentum continued to carry some sectors forward. It was a session of consolidation, by and large, following the steep advanced in prices of fixed-income securities that began to take shpae last Wednesday.
A former high official of the Nixon Administration proposed today a single step toward making the tax laws fairer that he said could be enacted quickly.

Robert W. Hardy, a- witness the "Camrden 28" case, testified today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had used him as an agent provocateur to make sure the defendants revived and carried out their plans to destroy draft files here.

Gov. J. J. Exon signed today legislation to protect newsmen from being forced into disclosing the sources of news. But he said that he would have vetoed it had not the sponsor, Senator John Savage of Omaha, agreed to introduce a new bill this session containing suggested amendments.
HANS CHRISTIAN ANDERSEN with Danny Kaye, at 9:30 A.M. Saturday to aid Horace Mann-Barnard Nursery and Elementary School, at Loew's Tower East, 3d Avenue and 72d Street, $3. 86-2585.
The Soviet Union is expected to buy sizable quantities of grain again this year, though not as much as in 1972,

The United States began airlifting fuel into this besieged capital today. The first planes were scheduled io bring in only military fuel, American officials said, but they suggested that later flights might carry commercial fuel if efforts to ease the critical shortage here failed.
The nation's corporations continued yesterday to deluge Wall Street with a flow of strong first-quarter earnings reports and the stock market responded with another upsurge on rising turnover.

Probably the most popular of all the civilian tasks during World War II was the Victory Garden program. ' According to Richard R. Lingeman, in his book, "Don't You Know There's a War On?": "At its peak, there were nearly 20 million Victory Gardens in the United States producing 40 per cent of all the vegetables grown in the country.

It has been more than a week since the Soviet Union launched its Salyut 2 space station, and American observers are now wondering why astronauts have riot been sent out to occupy it - wondering if some serious trouble has developed.
William H. Honan will return next month to a senior editorship in the Sunday Department of The New York Times, it was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the Sunday editor.

This country's most intense and prolonged controversy of recent times culminated today when Prime Minister Norman E. Kirk directed the Rugby Union to call off'a proposed visit here by an all-white South African team.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--By valiant efforts the Supreme Court has managed to operate efficiently in the sense that it keeps abreast of its docket, schedules arguments promptly, and rarely holds an argued case for decision at the following term.
Ted Gross, the former Commissioner of the City Youth Services Agency, admitted in State Supreme Court yesterday that he had accepted bribes during his 16 months in office.
The Senate Judiciary Committee opened public hearings today on proposed constitutional amendments that would prohibit court-ordered busing to achieve racial balance.

Leverett M. Norman, an assistant professor in the library department at City College, where he was a specialist in charge of the institution's collection of Federal government publications, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital.
Preschool children romped through offices on Capitol Hill and in other parts of the country today in a working mothers' protest against proposed cuts in Federal day care funds.
President Nixon announced his intention today to nominate Bernard E. DeLury to be Assistant Secretary of Labor for employment standards.
Playing with the same confidence that .i has marked their domination of this Stanley .Cup series, the Rangers ignored Bruin shots and elbows tonight to post a 6-3 decision and gain the second round.

The Hartford City Council, stirred by some recent and highly publicized crimes, voted 7 to 2 last night to create a 50-man auxiliary police force of volunteers who would provide added protection in the city.

The Department of Justice, acting in behalf of the Bay Mills Indian Community west of Sault Sainte Marie, has asked the United States District Court here to enjoin the state from enforcing its fishing laws against the Indians.

Richard R. Shinn, 55, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, has been named chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, 63, who will retire from the top post at the nation's second largest life insurer which has assets of $31-billion. The Prudential Insurance Company of America is the largest.

Blizzards, which dumped from 12 to 15 inches of snow in some parts of. the Midwest, plus floods along the Mississippi, continued to influence prices of farm-commodities futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

After a nine-year battle involving coerced confessions, multiple indictments, four trials and several stints in prison, George Whitmore Jr. was freed yesterday - at the request of the Brooklyn District Attorney, who termed Mr. Whitmore's treatment by the law "a disgrace."

A new constitution, the third in Pakistan's 25-year' history, was adopted today by the National Assembly in Islamabad. All political parties represented in the 146-seat house supported the charter after President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto had agreed to Opposition demands for removal of what they described as dictatorial powers.

Emanuel Shapiro, president of Metro Associated Services, Inc., at 80 Madison Ave. nue, New York, died of a heart attack last night while on the way to his home here. He was 71 years old and lived at 40 Cushm an Road.

Did Al Unser win the Texas 200 by a dirty trick? Was his tactic unsporting? Were the fans justified in booing him? "There was nothing dirty in what I did," Unser said after his victory in the season opener of the United States Auto Club's Championship Trail last Saturday..

Did Al Unser win the Texas 200 by a dirty trick? Was his tactic unsporting? Were the fans justified in booing him? "There was nothing dirty in what I did," Unser said after his victory in the season opener of the United States Auto Club's Championship Trail last Saturday.

A proposal to develop three tracts of wetlands in Lido Beach, Seaford and Baldwin to serve as marine nature-study areas was announced yesterday by Presiding Supervisor Francis T. Purcell of Hempstead Town.
A policeman arrested last week on charges of trying to steal $80,000 worth of cocaine was Representative Mario Biaggi's chauffeur in the mayoral campaign.

The International Paper Company, the world's largest papermaking organization, had record first-quarter net earnings of $29.7-million, equal to 67 cents a share, Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president, reported to some 500 stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Robert M. Loeffler, a senior vice president of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the biggest mutual fund company in the nation, was named late yesterday as trustee for the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America, a financial services conglomerate now in reorganization under Federal bankruDtcv laws.

Blue Shield of Greater New York, the surgical-medical insurance plan, -has not renewed the contract of its president, Dr. Leonard J. Raider, who was recently criticized by the State Insurance Department for allowing $15-million in reserve funds to be dissipated.

Roosevelt Raceway will offer a "women's night" program on Wednesday, April 18, with reduced admission and a trotting pin for each woman paron. The admission price for women to the harness track will be more than cut in half.

President Nixon asked Congress today to permit him to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union without linking them to the lifting of its restrictions on free emigration or Jews and other Soviet citizens.

The Health Department has cited 18 more food establishments here for failing their second health-code inspection. If violations persist at a third and final inspection, closing orders could result for the offenders.

It was supposed to be a "meatless" Tuesday, but many stores in the metropolitan area reported meat sales near normal yesterday.

Senator George McGovern, the 1972 Democratic Presidential candidate, told a group of Democrats who gathered today to start work on a national charter for the party that the party reforms of which he had been a principal architect "did not fall" but "can be improved."
A physician for President Nixon, Gvemor Rockefeller and other prominent persons was indicted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of incometax evasion.

Thet Boston Celtics will have Don Chaney back tomorrow night for the first time since the regular season ended, and that may spell trouble for the Atlanta Hawks. The teams, tied at two games apiece, resume their four-of-seven National Basketball Association playoff series at Boston Garden. Chaney, a guard, has recovered from a pulled groin muscle and is reported "ready to go 100 per cent."
A 55-year-old lawyer found himself behind bars yesterday after he was arrested on a charge of slipping heroin to his client in a pen in State Supreme Court in Queens.

By now, it's hard to imagine the National Geographic Society turning out a dull television hour. Its third special of the season, "The Haunted West," to be shown tonight at 8 over the Columbia Broadcasting System, is warmly diverting.
Jeff Bennett ran the 440-yard dash in 48.1 seconds today to take the lead midway through the Texas Relays decathlon.

An 18-year-old Paterson youth was convicted today of raping a teacher in the cloakroom adjoining her fourth-grade classroom in Public School 12 here. Harold M. Stancil, the defendant, also was found guilty by a Passaic County court jury of robbing another teacher in the school on Jan. 28.
Flaring tempers and some confusion marked a hearing before the Board of Elections yesterday on objections to the nominating petitions filed by some community school-board candidates.

Lebanese policemen fired rifles and tear-gas grenades today to disperse a thousand student demonstrators who marched on the United States Embassy and cultural center in protest against Israel's attack on Palestinian guerrillas here.

Eli Lilly Co. yesterday said it had filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed secondary offering of 950,000 common shares on behalf of the estate of Ruth Allison Lilly, late wife of Eli Lilly, former chairman of the company.

The city sold $285,360,000 in serial bonds yesterday at a net average interest rate of slightly more than 5 per cent-a percentage low enough to gladden the Controller's office, which saw it as a vote of confidence in the city's finances.

Five of 22 former directors of the Penn Central Company who have agreed to settle 18 lawsuits brought against them by stockholders of the bankrupt railroad are being compensated for their expenses in the proposed settlement by concerns they represented on the Penn Central's board.

On the same day that President Nixon made the reasonable and necessary proposal that he be given executive power to raise or reduce tariffs, his Attorney General made the unreasonable and absurd claim that all 2.5million Federal employes could be directed by the President not to testify before Congress.
The 15 heart patients who received the first American-made nuclear-powered pacemakers at Beth Israel Medical Center were reported in good condition today.
Dr. Jack R. Goldberg, a former Commissioner of the City Department of Social Services, will become dean of the School of Social Work at New York University on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday.

The development of a radial tire using all fiber glass was announced early yesterday by the Mohawk Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio. The new tire will retail at prices slightly below those of steel-belted radial tires, the company said.

Mrs. Georgina MacKinnon, who held the secret recipe for Drambuie, the Scotch whisky liqueur, died at her home near here today. She was 89 years old.

The Federal Power Commission, in a step apparently designed to raise natural gas prices, began today a streamlined proceeding to establish a uniform national ceiling price for gas from new wells in all parts of the United States.
President Nixon asked Congress today to establish Federal standards for the improvement of private pension systems on which 35 million workers are relying for income when they retire.
The House voted today, 354 to 49, to make the "first systematic updating" of the Congressional franking law since 1775, but wrote few restrictions on the use of the frank.
Wendell Ladner led a late surge as the Kentucky Colonels outscored the Carolina Cougars, 24-8, in the last 6 minutes 20 seconds for a 113103 victory tonight.

A tightening of inspection, increasingly cooperative purveyors and public disclosure of unsanitary restaurant and food handling conditions significantly improved food handling sanistation in the last six months, a consumer expert said today.

Handwriting and fingerprints on a bogus court order sent to the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility in a scheme to free an inmate were examined here today by Ohio Highway Patrol investigators.

Boycott leaders from across the country, with none of their anger spent by a meatless week, crowded into a Congressional conference room today to organize a National Consumers Congress for a continuing fight against high prices.
A combination of Democrats and Nassau County Republicans today narrowly defeated an Assembly bill to permit voters within a county t determine if be built.

Two of the "Camden 28" were "old actors" who had participated in antiwar acts of civil disobedience before raiding draft files here, Robert W. Hardy testified under Government cross-examination today.

Earl Newsom, one of the most influential public relations consultants to private in dustry, died yesterday in Shar ?? (Conn.) Hospital. He was 7 years old and had made hit home in Salisbury, Conn., since stepping down in 1966 as se nior partner in Earl Newson Co., which he had founded in 1935.

The Admistration's new trade bill drew sharp criticism as well as strong endorsement from business leaders yesterday.
A man being held on murder charges in the deaths of two Boston-area women was indicted today for murder in connectio with the slaying of a third woman.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey treated his party's Charter Commission to a display of rousing campaign-style oratory today, denouncing the Nixon Administration as "government by proclamation" and warning Democrats to stop acting like "a back-alley brawling outfit."

Patrick V. Murphy, who announced last month he would not serve as Police Commissioner beyond the end of Mayor Lindsay's term, will become the head of the Police Foundation in Washington, effective May 7.

In an unusual action that focused on the question of who has control over the state budget, Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had vetoed two changes made by the Legislature in his newly approved budget for 1973-74.
Two former Senators who oppose President Ferdinand E. Marcos have been transferred from an army camp near Manila to another camp 70 miles north of the capital, the wife of one of them says.

The White House announced today that Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's special envoy to Indochina, would meet with the President tomorrow morning immediately upon returning from a four-day assessment of the military situation in Southeast Asia.
The McCrory Corporation and the Lerner Stores Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the merger of Lerner into McCrory. The transaction is valued at about $110-million.

The Committee for Economic Development, a business-oriented research and education group, proposed today a broad plan for American health care, including universal coverage by some form of health insurance.
Two legal scholars and a former Attorney General argued before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that President Nixon had no constitutional authority to continue bombing in Combodia.

William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, gave automobile makers today an additional year to produce new cars meeting the 1975 standards for reducing emissions of hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide, the two major exhaust pollutants.
Anne Armstrong, Counselor to President Nixon, said today that the Watergate affair was hurting the Republican party across the nation.

A Federal judge branded the Nixon Administration's efforts to dismantle the Office of Economic Opportunity as "illegal" today and ordered a halt to curtailment of the program in the current fiscal year.

Profits of the majority of the leading industrial companies that reported yesterday results for the first quarter were not only at new records but also the increases over the initial three months last year were the highest in several years.

Although some members of the Maryland Department of Natural Resources admit that the state's decision to ban the use of lead shot for waterfowling by the opening of the 1974 hunting season has not endeared them to all sportsmen, it is clear that a similar nationwide restriction is not far away.

A sign of the time: For several months Waltham schoolboys have been using an outdoor basketball court as a street hockey ring. The Celanese Corporation realized a 20 per cent increase in first-quarter operating earnings on a sales gain of 15 per cent, John W. Brooks, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday at the Essex House. An extraordinary gain of $51-million raised the net income by 62 per cent, he added.
Three years after President Nixon declared it wasteful, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton says the Board of Tea Tasters is still operating at a cost to taxpayers of $117,250 this year.

The names of 1,118 winners of four-year National Merit Scholarships were announced yesterday. The recipients were the first of three groups to be chosen from about 14,000 finalists in the annual competition sponsored by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

Mayor Lindsay urged 300 members of the city's community boards last night to master the "exquisitely complex" process of one of government's most arcane institutions the capital budget-before they could hope to wield more power in city affairs.
William Reiber, director of marketing for the Chrysler-Simca automobile company, died today at the American Hospital. He was 52 years old.
Dr. Jean Piaget, the Swiss child psychologist, has been named the first recipient of the Kittay International Award for psychiatry, which consists of a $25,000 prize.

Carleton L. Marsh, a lawyer and civic leader, died yesterday in the Stamford Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived on Gilliam Lane in Riverside.

Perhaps Brad Park will have another dream that will enable the Rangers to skate past the Chicago Black Hawks the way the New Yorkers dismissed the Boston Bruins. The Rangers and Hawks began a second-round Stanley Cup series tonight at Chicago.

Insurgent Republicans filed a suit in Superior Court today asking that State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. be enjoined from "further delay" in presenting alleged election irregularities by the Bergen County Republican organization to a grand jury.

A Criminal Court judge, the former administrator of the Housing and Development Administration and a current deputy administrator of the agency were found guilty of contempt and fined yesterday for their delay in setting maximum base rents for more than a million apartments.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called today for a Congressional investigation of Defense Department decisions to shut down numerous military bases. He introduced legislation to set up a Senate commission.

Chancellor Willy Brandt forcefully rejected today the demands of extreme leftists within his Social Democratic party and affirmed its centrist political position and its commitment to the Atlantic alliance and to the stationing of American troops in West Germany.
Price increases of 2 per cent on all industrial tires and tubes and of 3 to 6.8 per cent on selected truck tires and tubes were announced yesterday by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

Passover begins Monday night and observant Jews all over the world will commemorate the miraculous escape of their ancestors from Pharaoh's tyranny at ritual seder meals. Seders, no matter where they take place, are more or less the same, with matzoh replacing leavened bread as a reminder of the hasty departure from Egypt, when there was no time to allow bread to rise.

Australia took only 21 minutes this morning to score 30 runs for a series-clinching cricket test victory over the West Indies. Taking their second innings score -to 135, they won the fourth test by 10 wickets for a 2-0 lead in the five-match series.

The Treasury Department today took action in three cases involving the question of whether certain Japanese imports were being sold in the United States at less than fair value. In one, the department said it had been determined that roller chain from Japan was being "dumped" and that duties would therefore be assessed on such imports, which amounted to about $14-million in 1972. The roller chain does not include bicycle chain.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today it had relaxed rules affecting nationwide lending and participating practices of federally insured savings and loan associations.
Daniel L. Monroe, a partner in the New York investment firm of Ingalls Snyder, died at his home here yesterday. He was 69 years old.
Legislation that would have rolled back all prices, rents and interest rates to their level of last Jan. 10 was scrapped today in the House Rules Committee.

A Manhattan grand jury reported yesterday that the escape last fall by seven from the Manhattan House of Detention never would have occurred if the guards had inspected the prison bars every night as they were supposed to.
The four major United States auto makers reacted here today with dismay at the decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to relax the 1975 autoemission standards of the Clean Air Act.

This is likely to be as good as anything in a technical sense, and has a psychological advantage: if you lead partner's suit unsuccessfully, he will be less irritated than he would be if you led something else unsuccessfully.
Two former White House aides and a man they are said to have hired for a campaign of espionage and sabotage against the Democrats last year appeared before the Watergate grand jury today.

The decision today by William D. Ruckelshaus, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, to grant United States automakers a year's extension in meeting Federal emission standards drew mixed reaction from environmental groups and politicians.
Duane Bobick, Olympic heavyweight boxer, made his professional debut tonight flooring Tommy Burns of Canada four times and stopping him at 2 minutes 59 seconds of the first round.

John H. Fenton, who served as Boston correspondent of The New York Times from 1947 until he retired in 1970, died this evening, apparently of a heart attack, at the Lawrence General Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Winthrop, a Boston suburb.

A proposed shield law designed to protect newsmen in Connecticut from having to disclose confidential sources died in committee this morning, the victim of an unresolved disagreement over the extent to which sources should be protected.

Swiss and British investigators flew to London today with a flight recorder that may explain why a British charter airliner crashed in a snowstorm here yesterday killing more than 100 people, mainly British mothers on an outing to Switzerland.

The realization is growing among influential members of Congress that, if it is to hold its own institutionally in the battle with the White House over the budget, it has to modernize its procedures. The failure of the House this week to override President Nixon's veto of the rural sewer and water program and the Senate failure last week to override his veto of the vocational rehabilitation bill underscore the urgency of Congressional action.
Israeli sources here and in Western Europe have reported that Libya 'has transferred some of her Mirage 5 fighterbombers to Egypt.

William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, did what he had to do in giving the automobile industry an additional year to achieve the antipollution standards laid down by law. Rather than risk widespread economic disruption, especially on the employment front, by insisting that all the standards be met for 1975 models, he chose to postpone their full impact to 1976. The statute clearly empowered him to make that decision.

Dr. Daniel Ellsberg testified today at the Pentagon papers trial that his feelings about the Vietnam war had been changed by such experiences as standing amid burning huts or watching schools built with American supplies turn to dust and "blow away" on the wind.

Citing "foreign policy reasons," President Nixon overruled the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday and approved the acquisition by Eastern Air Lines of a Puerto Rico-based airline, Caribair, that has island-hopping routes from Miami down to Trinidad.
El Diario-La Prensa, the Spanish-language daily, reached a settlement last night with four striking craft unions that have blocked the newspaper's publication since April 5.
After just one year of trying, Stanford University has raised more than one-third of its $300-million fund drive goal.
The course of the Jupiter-bound Pioneer 11 spacecraft was altered by a rocket burn today as the 570-pound payload hurtled through space at 84.000 miles an hour.
The New York Mets defeated the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 5-4, for their third straight victory of the season and the Cardinals' fourth straight loss.
The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had raised the orbit of its space workshop Salyut 2 to a height not normally accessible to manned flights.

Sixty-five per cent of Americans feel they are paying too much Federal income tax, a Gallup poll reported yesterday.

Some very well known names in American ballet were not doing their usual thing Tuesday night, and we have the New Jersey Ballet Company to thank for this opportunity to see these dancers performing outside their repertory at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

The executive board of Local 365 of the Cemetery Workers Union voted last night to strike the cypress Hills Cemetery in Brooklyn at 8 A.M. today, as state mediation officials moved to get stalled contract negotiations going again.

Representatives of the Long Island Rail Road and 12 nonoperating unions met separately yesterday with a three-man federally appointed panel in an effort to forestall another shutdown when the 90-day cooling-off period expires April 20. Frederick C. Fischer, who heads the panel, declined to report on the negotiations, but said that "everybody's trying." The talks continue today at the Hilton Inn at Kennedy International Airport.

Officials of New York, New Jersey and other East Coast states said yesterday they would intensify their efforts to prevent what they believe could be "disastrous consequences,' of offshore petroleum drilling.
Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., expects to spend "about $62-million" on construction this year, Charles H. Tenney, 2d, chairman, told about 200 stockholders at today's annual meeting here.

General and local chairmen of the 195,000-member United Transportation Union have approved the proposed railroad industry agreement, which would raise the salaries of railroad men by 4 per cent next January.

An unusually personal and vituperative attack by one State Senator upon another kept the Senate in session until late tonight over a bill creating a corporation that would permit bonds to be sold for redeveloping downtown Newburgh.

The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, parent of the country's seventh largest bank, reported yesterday that its operating earnings, before securities transaction, increased 19.8 per cent in the first quarter.

Fourteen more food establishments in New York City have been cited by the Health Department for failing a second health-code inspection. If the violations have not been corrected before a third and final inspection later this month, the establishments may be ordered closed.

At Bunraku, the National Puppet Theater of Japan, in residence through Sunday at the City Center 55th Street Theater, one is compelled to focus on the lifelike puppets, but for full appreciation one should also be aware of the other aspects of this complex, highly synchronized art.

An international financier, Edward Krock, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today in what Internal Revenue Service officials say is the "largest individual tax case in the history of the United States."
A grand jury in Queen yesterday exonerated a policeman who fatally shot a 17-year-old boy he was attempting to arrest last month.
Student activists at the university of Michigan have resurrected book-burning as a form of protest.

For two weeks we listened to the top forty. Some songs we heard a hundred times and the lyrics were still indecipherable. There was one about a night the lights went out in Georgia, and the plot was so involved and the singer's diction so bad that even after those two weeks in the room with that radio it was impossible to tell what happened that dark Georgia night.
Robert J. Suslow, 39, has been named president and chief operating officer of Ohrbach's, Inc., the 11-unit specialty-store chain in metropolitan New York and metropolitan Los Angeles.
Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, called yesterday for new manpower and economic strategies to move the city from its "present position of depression."
Because of his superstition about death, Pablo Picasso did not make out a will his lawyer and friend Armand Antebi said today.

President Nixon announced today that he would nominate John O. Marsh Jr., a former Democratic Representative from Strasburg, Va., to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Legislative Affairs.
A special state grand jury investigating corruption in the criminal justice system of New York City handed up an unknown number of sealed indictments yesterday in State

A group of leading commodity trading houses asked yesterday that the Commodity Exchange Authority hold full hearings on the regulatory agency's proposed plan to prohibit dealings in commodity options.

The flowers that bloom in the spring have long been a favorite subject of some of our greatest painters. As a general rule, however, we tend to see these flower paintings in the company of works depicting larger and more dramatic subjects.

After 10-year-old Luis Ortiz was murdered and sexually mutilated on West 106th Street last month; a wave of terror swept the West Side. Parents escorted their children everywhere to protect them from "the West Side child killer;"
Interstate Stores, Inc., New York-based operator of discount and conventional department stores will close 19 unprofitable Topps stores after Easter, Sol. W. Cantor, chairman, said yesterday.
Mrs. Helen Wiedenbeck is one of those rare breeders whose first purchases turn out to be champions.
Ferdinand Jelke 3d, a retires New York lawyer who ha lived here since 1952, died yes terday at his home. He was 7 years old.

The Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives is about to meet a severe test. Last year the House was prevented by a technicality from even having the opportunity to vote on an amendment to the highway bill which would have allowed cities to divert Highway Trust funds to the needs of local mass transit.

William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, gave automobile makers today an additional year to produce new cars meeting the 1975 standards for reducing emissions of hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide, the two major exhaust pollutants.

The first of the long-awaited and much delayed Cosmopolitan commuter cars for the New Haven branch of the Penn Central are expected to go into service Monday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation achieved record first-quarter sales but net income fell below the 1972 peak, Donald C. Burnham, chairman. reported yesterday.
The quest for at fusion candidate for Mayor was initiated by Senator Jacob K. Javits, not, as has been believed, by Alex Rose, the Liberal party leader, or by Governor Rockefeller.
James Stolcz, owner and president of WNLK and WDRN-FM radio stations in Norwalk and WBUX in Doylestown, Pa., died Tuesday at his home here.

David Rabe, the American playwright, was accused today of having written a letter attacking a Soviet version of his play "Sticks and Bones" because he lacked the courage to stand up to pressures from the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Robert F. Wagner declined yesterday to run for Mayor, declaring that he did not have the "overriding desire" needed for the post and expressing concern that he might hurt the election prospects of his son, Robert Jr., who is a candidate for councilman at large in Manhattan.

It seemed as if Gaylord Perry's spitball froze up on him but perhaps it was just a case of the Yankees finally heating up enough to win a game. Whatever the reason, the Yankees defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4-0, yesterday.
A strong rally accompanied by rising volume in the final hour of trading yesterday enabled the stock market to post its fourth consecutive advance.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will add four animated cartoon series to its Saturday children's schedule next season. Two of the cartoons will be based on "My Favorite Martian" and "I Dream of Jeannie," comedy shows that ran successfully in prime evening time.

Three Palestinian guerrilla leaders and the wife of one, all slain by Israeli commandos in a raid here Tuesday, were buried today in the Martyrs Cemetery, to which they were borne by the largest funeral procession in Beirut in three years.

Jeff Bennett won the United States Track and Field Federation decathlon today, amassing 7,855 points in the two-day event at the 46th Texas Relays. Bennett, who placed fourth in the Olympics, was most impressive with a pole vault of 16 1/4 feet.

By masterly leadership at Hanover, West German Chancellor Willy Brandt has routed the noisy leftist minority in the Social Democratic party and rededicated his Government to a policy of pragmatic reform at home and a foreign policy anchored in the Atlantic Alliance.
The two most extensive agrarian reforms in the modem history of South America are taking place in Chile and Peru with radically different approaches and results.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The British, Australian and Japanese Embassies here evacuated the wives and children of their diplomats today, partly for security reasons but mainly because of discomforts caused by a serious shortage of electricity in the city.

A civilian lawyer who aided in the Army's investigation of the My Lai 4 massacre said today that the pending retirement of Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers, who headed the inquiry, was "simply incredible."

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation signed the largest commercial agreement in the history of Soviet-American trade today--a 20-year, multibillion-dollar chemical-fertilizer barter arrangement with the Soviet Government.
Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell is accused of covering up his office's involvement in a "Ponzi scheme," one of the oldest confidence games around.

Two of the world's greatest clarinetists, Benny Goodman and Pete Fountain, began the fourth annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival that opened Tuesday with music that will rival the hot Creole foods to be served during the week.

If you listen to all the arguments and threats between the White House and the Congress these days, you might think this town was hell-bent for a constitutional crash, but that's not exactly the way it is.
When George Foreman stuck out a friendly hand, the slackness around Otis Taylor's jaw disappeared in a grin of elation. "How you doing?" asked the world heavyweight boxing champion.
Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx ca1led yesterday for 700 more Transit Authority policemen to combat what he called a "reign of terror" on the city's buses.
Australia has protested to Peking against China's nuclear tests in the atmosphere, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced today.
The Mississippi River swelled today to its highest level in 35 years, flooding miles of rich farmland and threatening many farmers with heavy crop losses.

Top-seeded Marty Riessen continued to march toward the final of the Cleveland Tennis Classic today, defeating Ross Case of Australia, 6-4, 7-5.
Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

Big-store retailing in March ran into its tightest month in more than a year following a strong February performance. But most of the sales declines may have been caused by this year's later Easter, which comes three weeks after it did in 1972.
The House Democratic leadership reversed itself today and pushed through the Rules Committee legislation that would roll back prices, rents and some interest rates.
More than 100 Soviet Jews who have been refused exit visas to Israel appealed to the United States Congress in an open letter today not to be misled by an apparent lifting of high emigration taxes. .

The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to hold a special meeting within two weeks to discuss the competency of the top management of the agency, which operates the city's 19 municipal hospitals.

Citing evidence that women are better credit risks than men, the Assembly passed without dissent today a bill prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex or marital status in extending credit or granting bank loans.
A Federal judge has ruled that a basic computer patent held by the Sperry Rand Corporation is invalid and that Honeywell, Inc., need not pay royalties for it, a spokesman for Sperry confirmed today.
The Pittsburgh Pirates paid attention to neither the freezing weather in Three Rivers Stadium last night nor the talented pitching of Chicago's Ferguson Jenkins.
Gen. Alexander M. Haig, Jr., just back from a special mission to Southeast Asia, reported to President Nixon this afternoon on the military situation in Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam.

Kathy Whitworth and Jane Blalock, the favorites, got caught in water hazard confusion and Mrs. Murle Lindstrom Breer shot 68 for a one-stroke first-round lead today in the $154,000 Colgate-Dinah Shore golf tournament.

Thomas J. Mackell of Queens is the first District Attorney ever indicted in New York City, according to legal historians. But he is hardly the first prosecutor in the five boroughs to get in trouble with the law.

First-quarter earnings reports yesterday were led by PPG Industries, Inc., with a 28 per cent rise in profits; the American Can Company, whose net was up 91.5 percent; Time Inc., whose profit rose 25 per cent, and CPC International, Inc., whose earnings were up 9.9 per cent. The earnings all set records.
The Chemical New York Corporation, the fifth big New York City banking concern to report its first-quarter results, was the first to show a decline in earnings.
Farmers put on a display of beef and an array of speakers here today in a counterattack against boycotters and backers of a bill in Congress to roll back prices.

The chief mate of a cargo vessel that got through a Communist ambush on the South Vietnamese side of the border and sailed up the Mekong River to Phnom Penh accuses the South Vietnamese armed forces of failing to provide promised protection.

H. Chandlee Turner Jr., chairman of the executive committee of the Turner Construction Company, died today in Greenwich Hospital from the effects of a stroke he suffered April 3. He was 70 years old and lived here.

Jay E. Crane, a former director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died last evening at his home here. He was 81 years old. Mr. Crane retired in 1957 after 22 years with the concern, which last Nov. 1 changed its name to the Exxon Corporation.
The Pentagon, two months after the first American prisoners of war began coming home, said today that it had no evidence that there were any more Prisoners still alive in all of Indochina.

Experts of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today that a series of bad harvests in many parts of the world--caused mainly by severe droughts-and other unfavorable factors had resulted in acute food shortages.

District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens was arrested yesterday after his indictment on charges of blocking the prosecution of a $4-million get-rich-quick scheme in which members of his staff had invested money.
The Securities and Exchange Commission withdrew today a proposed rule that would have prevented a payment of solicitation fees in stock tender and exchange offers
I had some ambiguous feelings about adopting a Bangladesh child," David McCormick said, "because it would make us the toast of the bleeding heart liberal circuit."
