Three-quarters of the Beatles, defunct since 1970, were out in Los Angeles recently, and the question many people in the recording industry asked was: Will the four of them soon be playing and singing together again?
The principal exhibitor here of the film "Deep Throat" was fined $100,000 by Criminal Court Judge Joel T. Tyler on charges of promoting obscenity.
The Soviet Union marked Astronautics Day today by sending up the 553d satellite in its Cosmos series, apparently an electronic monitoring craft.

Twelve years ago President Kennedy dispatched a trusted military aide to Southeast Asia to assess a rapidly deteriorating military and political situation there. The recommendations brought back by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor led to fateful steps into the quagmire from which this country has recently emerged, sadder but not necessarily wiser.

MANILA--The United States and the Philippines are now approaching the final phase of renegotiating an American base agreement here designed to assure U.S. support of mobile forces in the western Pacific after withdrawal from Indochina and Okinawa's reversion to Japan. A joint working group from both nations has completed about 90 per cent of a proposed draft.

Wil liam B. Colsey 3d, reputedly a key figure under investigation by the state and the Federal Government in financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign, testified be fore a state grand jury here today.

The State Division of Consumer Affairs, which has been criticized in the past for having expensive tastes, shaved $2,69 off the price of its recommended dinners in its list of seven "best buy" menus issued today.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the present tax laws bestowed a Government "welfare payment" averaging $720,448 a year on each of the nation's 3,000 families with incomes of more than $1-million.

One of the hotel guests kept asking about the weather forecast because, he said, he wanted to go swimming. Another went to the seashore every night "to fish." Another two were "perfect English gentlemen."
The situation at Wounded Knee reached a new impasse today, one week after a general peace agreement to end the siege and occupation was signed, and there was no solution in sight.

City College honored its own last night, bringing together 44 alumni who had gone on to glory in things as various as the Broadway stage, the New York City Housing Authority and the literary marketplace.

A $300,000 cutback in Federal aid has prompted the Highland Falls Board of Education to consider closing schools two months early next school year, the board president, Ronald Cornwall said yesterday.

The Assembly today rejected an attempt to introduce state controls over a broad range of mental health counselors and therapists after opponents argued that the bill was a "power grab" that would have allowed psychologists with degrees to monopolize the field.
For the first time in its 90-year history, the National Funeral Directors Association of the United States is running a national institutional advertising campaign.
After four consecutive sessions of advances, prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market finished mixed yesterday in slower trading.

Bony fish, however sweet to the taste, are discouraging table fare, but there are ways of surmounting the problem. Some species in this category that come to mind immediately are the common chain pickerel, the shads, the alewife, the sucker and the bonefish.
Two Representatives introduced legislation today to outlaw military discharge numbers that they said placed homosexuals and alcoholics, for example, in the same category.
The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it had taken initial steps to reactivate a potline at its Listerhill, Ala., aluminum reduction plant.

Despite calls by national boycott leaders for meatless Tuesdays and Thursdays, there was little indication here yesterday of the sort of intense shopper resistance to meat that characterized the widespread consumer rebellion last week.
Federal judge rejected today a request by Senate investigators to keep secret further pretrial testimony by James W. McCord Jr., one of those convicted in the Watergate conspiracy.

12-A group of residents on Shippan Point, a sedate residential section here jutting into Long Island Sound, are protesting to City Hall over a tree-cutting program ordered to make way for a sewer project.

Arthur H. Bremer, the man who shot and crippled Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, is an odd example of what Hannah Arendt described as "the banality of evil." Except for that single act, Bremer would seem to be only banal.

With the election of a respected Senator, Fahri Koruturk, as President by the Grand National Assembly, Turkey seems to have surmounted one of its worst crises since the founding of the republic. At a time of tension and instability in the eastern Mediterranean, their allies share with the Turks a great sense of relief at the breaking of a dangerous month-long deadlock between political leaders and the armed forces.
President Nixon nominated William E. Kriegsman of Bethesda, Md., today as a commissioner on the Atomic Eenrgy Commission, replacing James R. Schlesinger, who is now director of Central Intelligence.
With strong persuasion from Chancellor Willy Brandt, his Social Democratic party tonight rejected a number of resolutions critical of the United States or opposed to American policy.

Many a small investor believes that he ordinarily gets taken to the cleaners when he buys or sells a listed stock. He blames the specialist, the man on the floor of the exchange who is charged with making a market in the stock in question.

W. Harold Essex, president of the Triangle Broadcasting Corporation here and a past president of the National Association of Broadcasters, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.
Supporters of pupil busing charged today that a constitutional amendment to prohibit busing would result in resegregation of the schools.
Total business inventories continued to rise strongly in February, though the increase was less than the big jump in January, the Commerce Department reported today. .
Cesar Chavez, saying, "We're fighting for our lives," pledged yesterday to strike and boycott grape growers it they refused to renew their contracts with the United Farm Workers union.

Nolan Ryan, who has an "unhittable" reputation when his fastball is under control, says he has learned to keep his composure under pressure and he is showing it in his first two starts for the California Angels.

Talks between Czechoslovakia and West Germany designed to arrange for the opening of diplomatic relations between the two countries resumed today, with both governments indicating optimism after a 10 month deadlock.

Five New Jersey peace activists, all in their 20's, were released yesterday on $7,500 bond each in York, Pa., for a May 7 hearing on charges of conspiracy and malicious mischief to railroads. The three men and two women, part of an antiwar group calling itself the East Coast Conspiracy to Save Lives, were indicted on charges of tampering with rail lines in York last Dec. 18.
Tomorrow will be Kitty Lucerno's last day of employment at the Equity Funding Corporation of America at 1900 Avenue of the Stars in Century City here.

A new, $16,000 video system is helping to cut down crime at Jersey City State College, the first of New Jersey's eight state colleges to install such a system.

Donald F. Cawley, chief of patrol, was named Police Commissioner yesterday to succeed Patrick V. Murphy, and he immediately vowed to wage war on street crime, "continue the efforts to elevate the professionalism of the department" and "root out any cancers of corruption that exist."

Andre Bing, former general manager of The International Herald Tribune and a hero of the French resistance during World War II, died today in a hospital here. He was 62 years old and lived in La Varenne.
With the Government of Saudi Arabia owning 25 percent of the Arabian-American Oil Company since Jan. 1, it now has three representatives on the board of the petroleum corporation.

Three of President Nixon's senior energy advisers, including Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz, flew to the Bahamas today for an off-the-record conference at an exclusive club with 80 top executives from oil, natural gas, mining and electric power companies.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is prepared to make concessions to critics of proposed new rules controlling Federal funding of such social services as day care for children and aid to the elderly and mentally disturbed.
TURIN, Italy-Thirty-seven years after the fire that destroyed it, on Feb. 8, 1936, Turin's Teatro Regio reopened this week.

If Fur Elise, who is coupled with Bootsie Barrett in tomorrow night's featured $25,000 Jones Beach pacing series final at Roosevelt Raceway, finishes in a dead heat for first place, she will earn a place in the record books that may never be matched.
The former secretary general of the Chinese Communist party, Teng Hsiao-ping, purged in the Cultural Revolution after being heavily criticized, has been rehabilitated and named a Deputy Premier.
The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that a disciplinary panel had found Leon F Diodoardo, an Amex member, guilty of certain acts detrimental to the exchange.
The Navy plans a construction and conversion program covering 271 ships that will cost $50-billion in the next 10 years, according to data collected by defense experts.

Senators examining President Nixon's use of executive privilege were told today that they needed no new laws and no further hearings, only the "gumption" to assert their "superior power" under the Constitution.

Henry Kearns, chairman of the United States Export - Import Bank, today forecast that the United States would realize a surplus in its trade balance around July or August. He said at a news conference following completion of a 12-nation, six-and-a-half-week tour that "we can solve our balance-of-trade problems and ultimately our balance-of-payments problems if we use the tools that are at hand."
Traffic Cop held off a spirited bid by Whitey II at the close to take the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday by a head.

Ministers of the Saigon Government and the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government met today for the sixth time to try to agree on an agenda for their political talks. But again they failed to make any progress. .

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday brought disciplinary charges of fraud against Raymond L, Dirks, the security analyst who gave his clients advance warning of the financial problems of the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America.
Evonne Goolagong of Australia advanced to the semifinals today of the $20,000 Miami Beach tennis tournament with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Isabel Fernandez of Colombia.

Billy Whitman, the manager, had seen me work on the sandlots in Philadelphia and conceived the peculiar notion that I had a future. It was opening day, around April 18 or 20.
Governor Rockefeller today proposed a significantly modified version of his stringent proposals for dealing with traffickers in dangerous drugs.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, urged yesterday a return to a Phase 1 economic controls "freeze" and said he believed President Nixon would take such a step despite his abhorance of controls.

The board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to review the competency of the top management of the $800-million quasi-autonomous agency that runs the city's 19 municipal hospitals.

Should the Boston Celtics end their National Basketball Association Eastern Conference play off semifinal tonight in Atlanta, the final round of the four-of-seven-game series with the Knicks would begin Sunday afternoon at the Boston Garden.

G. Bradford Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, met with governors of the American Stock Exchange yesterday at a get-acquainted luncheon at the Amex.

Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona displays a native shrewdness in taking an olfactory approach to the Watergate affair rather than a strictly judicial one. When he says that "there's a smell to it" that recalls the aura surrounding the Harding Government, he is not trying to abuse the present Administration but to persuade President Nixon to take forceful action to dispel an atmosphere in which public trust in that Administration is threatened.

Arthur Freed, the film producer who won Academy Awards for the musicals "An American in Paris" (1951), and "Gigi" (1958), died today of a heart attack. He was 78 years old and had retired several years ago.
A reputation for making "impossible" contracts is a mixed blessing: it implies remarkable skill in card play, but a tendency to overoptimism in the bidding.
The United States Court of Appeals has upheld a Connecticut Federal judge's rulings th Stamford may not require one year of residence for welfare recipients.

Three Palestinian guerrilla leaders and the wife of one, all slain by Israeli commandos in a raid here Tuesday, were buried today in the Martyrs Cemetery, to which they were borne by the largest funeral procession in Beirut in three years.

Murray Wilson scored one goal and assisted on another during a four-goal first-period outburst tonight and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres. The victory advanced the Canadiens to the semifinals of the National Hockey League playoffs.
Mrs. Billie Jean King and Mrs. Margaret Court moved toward a confrontation with victories today at the Virginia Slims national indoor championships in Quincy, Mass.
A nonprofit community-development organization proposed today to join with private business in building a $50-million community of 8,000 people on the exclusive western shore of Lake Candlewood.
Al Hirshberg, a former Boston sportswriter and an author, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Sarasota Memorial Hospital yesterday. He was 63 years old and lived on Longboat Key.

Governor Cahill signed legislation today that will provide up to $960 a year in direct aid to poor families for each foster child they adopt.
A Suffolk County grand jury indicted a Dorchester man yesterday for the murder of Ellen Reich of Hackensack, N. J., whose body was found in an abandoned tenement last November.
A second week-long meat boycott to protest "still outrageous" prices has been scheduled for April 30-May 6, June Donavan, chairman of Fight Inflation Together, announced today.

President Nixon formally announced the nomination of William H. Sullivan, the State Department's top Southeast Asia expert, as Ambassador to the Philippines. The White House also said that Robert J. McCloskey, for many years the chief press spokesman at the State Department, had been nominated as Ambassador to Cyprus.

The Utah Stars with Willie Wise and Zelmo Beaty leading the way, pushed open a tight game in the fourth quarter tonight to defeat the Indiana Pacers, 124-107, in the first game of their American Basketball Association Western Division title playoff series.

There was confusion in antipoverty offices yesterday in the wake of a Federal judge's decision that stops President Nixon from going ahead with his plan to dismantle the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons of the Atlanta Hawks, a Southern gentleman to the core, complimented his hosts lavishly today before going home to plot their destruction.
Liberal party leaders selected Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal last night to replace Robert F. Wagner as their candidate for Mayor.

The Board of Estimate deferred action at the last moment yesterday on an unusual proposal that would grant builders extra "bulk" rights in return for cash contributions to a special fund for the improvement of parks and other public areas.
Liberal party leaders selected Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal last night to replace Robert F. Wagner as their candidate for Mayor.
Dr. Donald W. Bradeen, an authority on Greek history and head of the department of classics at the University of Cincinnati, died of a heart attack at his home here last night. His age was 54.
Vice President Agnew, the Nixon Administration's most outspoken critic of the news media, said today that media fears of threats to their freedom were "fictional."

Israeli security forces reported arresting a number of suspected Arab guerrillas in Israel and the occupied territories last night and today on the basis of documents described as having been seized Tuesday during the Israeli commando raid in Beirut.

Over the opposition of Mayor Lindsay, the City Council unanimously passed a bill yesterday that would give the city's 5,100 auxiliary policemen a $75 yearly allowance for uniforms and equipment. The men receive no salary.

Although the professional ice shows make their annual visits to New York, the performers the skating public is eager to see are the top amateurs who recently made headlines at the various international championships.
The residency requirement for voter registration in elections in Maine has been reduced to nine days by a state Supreme Court ruling.
The Writers Guild of America went on strike at 12:01 A. M. yesterday against television network live and videotaped entertainment programs, such as "soap operas" and talk shows.

In his twelve years as Mayor, Robert F. Wagner was never a ball of fire, when it came to decisions. But even by his own standard of not making up his mind until the last possible moment, Mr. Wagner outdid Hamlet in soul-searching on whether to seek a new lease on City Hall in November. Now the answer is out: No.
Bond prices bobbed up and down yesterday as the market continued to debate the prospects for tightened economic controls and whether interest rates might be included.

American farmers and ranchers produced 22.3 billion pounds of beef in 1972, an increase of 430 million pounds over 1971.

District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens was arrested yesterday after his indictment on charges of blocking the prosecution of a $4 million get-rich-quick scheme in which members of his staff had invested money.

Robert D. McFadden, a rewrite man for The New York Times, was named yesterday as the winner of the annual Byline Award of the New York Press Club for the best example of spot news writing on deadline.
British soldiers killed an Irish Republican Army gunman and captured three others in a running battle in Belfast's Lower Falls area to night, the British Army said.

Steve Kline made it two shutouts in a row for the New York Yankee pitching staff yesterday by hurling a twohitter and defeating the Cleveland Indians, 5-0, before a paying crowd of 4,532, and 6,800 youngsters from the New Jersey Safety Patrol who got in free.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation signed the largest commercial agreement in the history of Soviet-American trade today a 20-year, multibillion-dollar chemical-fertilizer barter arangement with the Soviet Government.

William B. Colsey 3d, reputedly a key figure under investigation by the state and the Federal Government in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign testified before a state grand jury here today.

A proposal to create probably the first major exhibition facility in the country dedicated exclusively to films took a giant step forward yesterday when the Board of Estimate approved a resolution to lease the "cathedral area" under the Queensboro Bridge to the City Center Cinematheque for $1 a year.
Dr. Dwight W. Chapman Jr., professor of psychology at Vassar College and chairman of the school's psychology department from 1952 to 1968, died here yesterday. His age was 67.
The Exxon Corporation announced today that it planned to eliminate about a third of the service stations the Houston-based company operates in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Wisconsin.
Homero Blancas scored a four-under-par 67 today for the first-round lead in the $150000 Monsanto open golf tournament and the new Masters champion, Tommy Aaron, withdrew after a 77.
The Senate passed today a two-year $930-million Federal highway safety authorization bill, which was more than the White House wanted but far less than had been authorized in recent years.

A chase that began after a woman was mugged on a Brooklyn street ended with the death of one suspect and the capture of two others after an exchange of gunfire. The police said they had stepped up patrols in the area Sheepshead Bay-following a rash of muggings.... .
Stanton R. Cook, president of The Chicago Tribune, has been appointed publisher and elected chief executive officer of the company, it was announced today.
In ostentatiously bulky bundles or in modest shopping bags, or briefcases candidates for public office carried their nominating petitions to the city Board of Elections yesterday.
Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's testimony in the Pentagon papers trial was suspended today because of the illness of his chief attorney, Leonard B. Boudin, and will not begin again until Monday morning.

The John Guggenheim Memorial Foundation yesterday announced fellowships amounting to $3,852,600 to 339 scholars, scientists and artists chosen from among 2,416 applicants in the foundation's 49th annual competition.

Pablo Picasso's second wife and his only legitimate son announced through Picasso's lawyer today that the artist's priceless private collection of works by other great modern painters would be given to France.

More than 100 opponents of abortion attended a meeting at the National Institutes of Health here today to ask questions about the institutes' policy on the use of aborted human fetuses for medical research.
The Japanese Government dispatched the Foreign Ministry's senior specialist on North Vietnam to Hanoi today in a major step toward establishing diplomatic relations between Tokyo and Hanoi.

A small beanball war broke out between Tom Seaver and Bob Gibson today as the New York Mets and St. Louis Cardinals passed each other in opposite directions-the Mets winning their fourth straight game, the Cardinals losing their fifth.

Federal prosecutors made an unusual move yesterday to disqualify the judge assigned to a massive stock-fraud case involving the Four Seasons Nursing Homes of America, Inc.

The Jamaica National Dance Theater Company, which presented three new pieces on its second program Wednesday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is delightful rather than slick, loose rather than rigid.

Premier Giulio Andreotti demanded and won four votes of confidence in Parliament today as he fought for the survival of his 10-month-old centrist Government.
President Nixon asked Congress today to set Federal standards for unemployment compensation and to extend coverage to 635,000 farm workers.

Grain futures prices, which closed mixed Wednesday, rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, joining an advance in soybeans and soybean meal futures. The last two rose the daily limit of 15 cents a bushel for soybeans and $5 a ton for soybean meal in the nearby contracts.

Yugoslavia disclosed to day that three emigres captured last summer during gun battles after they had infiltrated from Austria had been tried on coun terrevolutionary and other charges and put to death by firing squad.
The stock market consolidated its gains yesterday in moderately active trading and closed with its first decline in five sessions.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today it has struck oil on the second well it 'has drilled in jungle terrain under contract with Petro-Peru. Production of the well in the Peruvian northeast was estimated at 3,931 barrels a day.

Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx called yesterday for 700 more Transit Authority policemen to combat what he called a "reign of terror" on the city's buses.

Charles Courboin, organist and music director of St. Patrick's Cathedral from 1943 to 1970, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old. A native of Antwerp, Belgium, Mr. Courboin studied at the Brussels Conservatory and played at the Antwerp Cathedral before coming to the United States in 1904.

Mike Byers's goal after 3 minutes 47 seconds of overtime gave the New England Whalers a 5-4 victory over the Ottawa Nationals tonight. The Whalers clinched the four-of-sevengame World Hockey Association quarterfinal series, 4-1.

Machines of Internal Revenue Service justice are cranking at battle speed now, spitting out skewed income-tax returns by the hundreds of thousands, delivering them down a brutally efficient track of keypunch operators and mailroom clerks and into the hands of I.R.S. agents for audit.

Two drivers of "gypsy" cabs attempted to rescue a damsel in distress yesterday morning. The damsel turned out to be a female impersonator, and the cab drivers suffered superficial gunshot wounds for their trouble. The police said the impersonator had been dragged out of a Bronx social club at 1551 Southern Boulevard where the piercing shrieks brought the cabbies on the run.
The women's hat industry is climbing out of the depths of a 15-year recession and business this year is expected to be the best since the midnineteen-sixties.

Marlu Pride, who returned to the races last week after a layoff of. 14 months, failed again in his comeback campaign tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, finishing fourth in the field of six as the 1-2 favorite in a $17,500 trot handicap.

NEW DELHI--The Pallor Stadium, the only open ground in the capital of Sikkim, is where the King and his nobles played. polo, During the last 10 days It has been a camping ground for thousands of demonstrators. The feudal order in the Himalayan ShangriLa of 200,000 people was shattered.

One of the more gripping, bitter books about the cold war is THE MUSHROOM CAVE by Robert Rosenblum (Doubleday, $4.95). It is an espionage novel. It also is a merciless comment on present-day morality.

The Society for Animal Rights, Inc., called last week for a nationwide boycott of Chanel No. 5 perfume on the ground that the civet cat musk oil used as one ingredient is obtained from animals allegedly treated cruelly.
John Lionberger Davis, art collector and philanthropist, died yesterday at the Medical Center at Princeton. He was 94 years old and lived here at 41 Independence Drive.

Will Henry conducts his excursions into Americana from the inside looking out. Whether it is a horse-soldier's lot on San Juan Hill or the end game of the horseback Indian, his recreations of old adventures carry a rare essence of immediacy.

Confronted once more with persistent violence in the Middle East, the United Nations is in danger of being railroaded into another one-sided action that can only exacerbate tensions threatening the peace of the area and the world.

CAN chemical pest control in home gardens be safe for the user and safe for the environment? There is legislation trying to make it so. On October 21, 1972, the Federal Environmental Pesticide Control Act was signed into law, to be administered by the Environmental Protection Agency, set up in 1970.
A visitor to Grover Cleveland High School these days might encounter a medium conducting a seance or an instructor teaching a class in his specialty, horror literature.

From a purely chronological standpoint it will be threes days early, but that will seem of little consequence today when the Yankees toss a gigantic birthday party to mark the opening of the Yankee Stadium 50 years ago this week. It will signify the start of a golden anniversary year that the planners would love to see end with the flourish of a World Series.

Leaders of the Liberal party formally substituted Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal for Robert F. Wagner as their candidate for Mayor yesterday, but their actions will be challenged in the courts as "illegal and invalid."
The Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, who became pastor emeritus of the West End Presbyterian Church of New York in 1967, died today here, where he had recently made his home. His age was 82.

FOR Americans, especially younger ones whose entire lives were cut off from all contact with main land China, the gradually opening door to that country reveals mysteries of all sorts. A prenatal clinic that has been operating at Rikers Island for nearly five months now has drawn praise from hundreds of inmates who say they now receive immediate medical attention during pregnancy. The clinic also provides counseling and assists women Inmates in the placement of their babies.

The fall of America is not Ginsberg's real subject in this new book, in spite of his title. He has two subjects: the state of America and the state of his life, the first now almost eclipsing, on the pages, the second. Balked by the roadblock of middle age, Ginsberg marks time around it, baffled, like other poets, by the era when poetry thins out, everything is already known, and everything has stoppd happening.

Early last June, shortly before Hurricane Agnes inundated much of the East Coast and usurped the nation's interest in natural disasters, prodigious rains and thunderstorms in the moody Black Hills of southwestern South Dakota sent a massive flood out of the mountains and through the middle of Rapid City, the second largest town in the state and, by an eagle's route, less than 65 miles from the geographical heart of the country.

Major conservative churches in the United States appear to be experiencing the same slowdown in numerical growth that has been evident for some time among their liberal counterparts, according to figures released yesterday by the National Council of Churches.

The Bronx Zoo is playing marriage broker with its monkey-eating eagle these days, but it is not making any bets on results. What it is trying to do is, to mate its bird at the Philadelphia Zoo with a monkeyeating eagle that has been laying unfertilized eggs.

WASHINGTON--The House of Representatives is considering a bill to roll back prices to their level of March 16, 1973. This is obviously a step in the right direction. Since consumer prices have probably risen about .5 per cent since March 16, this action would at one stroke make everyone .5 per cent better off than he is.

NEWARK-To step inside the Newark Museum these days is to be drawn back into the mystical, mountainous and medieval Asiastic theocracy that was early 20th-century Tibet. The museum has mounted a multi-media exhibition, "Tibet: A Lost World," that sets forth some 1,000 objects from its outstanding, 1,500-object collection of Tibetan art and artifacts. The exhibition, which will continue through September, relates these objects to the rituals and routines of Tibetan daily life.

President Nixon has now underscored the importance of his designation of 1973 as "the Year of Europe" by confirming his plans to visit several European countries this fall. His trip will include return calls on at least four leaders of European governments allied with the United States who will have been White House guests earlier in the year.
A group of more than 50 American financial and business executives just finishing a twoweek tour of Southeast Asia have expressed optimism on the potential for investment in the region.
James Nicolson and his wife Katie stood on the porch of their two-story frame house surrounded by a neat lawn and cyclone fence and looked across to a row of houses wrecked by vandals and fires.

A special committee of the Nixon Administration that has been working for nearly two years on a long-range Government policy for cable television is expected to recommend soon that cable-system operators be prohibited eventually from producing their own programs.

The Rubicon in the path of all serious politicians--whether to stop renting dinner jackets for the chicken banquet circuit-was crossed last month by a freshman Assemblyman, Edward H. Lehner, when he bought his first formal outfit for $130 and took his mother to the Governor's annual legislative ball.
A $78.7-million Federal grant which would provide not for expansion of New York City's neighborhood development program, but for its "winding down," was requested by city officials yesterday.

Holy Week, the last seven lays in Lent that commemorate the final events in the life of Christ before His Resurrection, began yesterday in Ronan Catholic and Protestant churches with the traditional prayers, meditations and music of Palm Sunday.

Gail Goodrich scored on a breakaway with 28 seconds left to give Los Angeles the lead for the first time since midway in the second quarter tonight and the Lakers beat the Chicago Bulls, 95-92. The victory gave Los Angeles the opening Western series in the National Basketball Association, four games to three.

Miss Leila Muriel Joseph, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Joseph, was married here this afternoon to Paul M. Elkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Elkin of Larchmont. Cantor William Wolff. performed the ceremony at the Joseph home.

MADRID-A woman here has spent about $50 in car fare to see "Last Tango in Paris." The woman had to travel more than 250 miles by train to Biarritz in France. Neither the expense nor the time involved discouraged her or thousands of other Spaniards.
Judge Leonard E. Ruisi of the Family Court died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 245-20 Grand Central Parkway, Bellerose, Queens. He was 69 years old.

State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that a pilot center in the reorganization of the Department of Social Services was paying ineligible clients, had misused manpower and had been laggard in its investigations of reports of child abuse and neglect.
The Newark Boys Chorus is full of the noblest purpose, both sociologically and artistically. Ideally, it could become our leading ensemble of its type.

MOSCOW-In the economic outlook of the Soviet Union there is one fundamental factor that gets relatively little attention in the West. That is the demographic trend: a drastic reduction in prospective new recruits for the labor force.

They hung the championship banners from the roof, they placed wreaths n the monuments, they sang happy birthday, they cut the golden anniversary cake and filled Yankee Stadium with nostalgia of Yankees of the past.

The New York University Choral Arts Society celebrated a century of group singing at the school with a concert on Sunday afternoon at Town Hall. (The New York University Glee Club was operating in 1873.) The major effort was Honegger's "King David," conducted by E. Jon de Revere in a conscientiously genteel oratorio style that did not achieve much intensity or dramatic power.

Ben R. Womer, a steel worker who lives in Dundalk, Md., earned $11,000 last year and has just received a tax refund of $190. "We gave it to Sears, Roebuck," he said toward a new clothes washer and dryer.
South Vietnamese troops have pushed across the Cambodian border for the first time since a Vietnam cease-fire went into effect two and a half months ago, according to reports from the field.

The Bergen Mall Ice Arena, a long-awaited and much-needed facility in this area, is expected to be open by Sunday. The arena, formerly a Food Fair supermarket, will bring to reality the dream and initiative of four young men, the largess of an understanding landlord and the faith of a bank.

The Central Westchester Humane Society today said it would have to kill 50 dogs, both purebred and mongrel, unless they were adopted by Easter. The Greenburgh Town Board gave the humane society until next Sunday to place the dogs because neighbors near the kennel had complained about their loud barking, a society

The Winnipeg Jets scored four goals in a fourminute spurt early in the second period en route to a 8-5 victory tonight over the Minnesota Fighting Saints and won their World Hockey Association quarterfinal series, four games to one.

The sentencing of a well-known white Rhodesian journalist to two years at hard labor has provoked a fresh outcry, especially in Britain, against the white minority Government in Salisbury. Even Tory members of Parliament who have previously defended Prime Minister Ian Smith were infuriated by the harsh punishment decreed for Peter Niesewand after six weeks in solitary confinement and a secret trial on an unknown charge.

The Administration's strange reversion to do-nothingism on the inflation front is forcing Congress into actions that will complicate the intricate task of managing economic controls. The need for swift Federal moves to hold prices in check is incontestable. The economy is in a state of exuberant boom. Auto sales, a prime index of consumer aDDetite for heavy goods, are running ahead of last year's

only Paul Robeson's famous bass-baritone voice was present (on tape) yesterday at Carnegie Hall. Its owner, in impaired health, had stayed at home in Philadelphia. But despite his absence, a crowd nearly filled the hall,
Three of the 15 patients who received the first Americandeveloped nuclear - powered heart pacemakers last week were released from Beth Israel Hospital today.

There were contented purrs coming from Doyle Dane Bernbach Friday when the staff received a memo from on high that the agency had been assigned the Purina Cat Chow business by RalstonPurina. The memo said the
Communist China swept the singles titles today at the world table tennis championships. Hsi En-ting took the men's crown with a 21-18,

Cooperative housing is a good thing for the city, because older buildings are generally better maintained as co-ops than as rentals. But too often since the end of World War II, conversion to cooperative status has been forced upon unwilling rental tenants because a minority-35 per cent-have favored it. For the majority the alternative has been buy or get out.

South Vietnamese troops have pushed across the Cambodian border for the first time since a Vietnam cease-fire went into effect two and a half months ago, according to reports from the field. Fighting was reported yesterday at two points along the border and hundreds of refugees were said to have fled from Cambodia into South Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 8.]

In a wild, whirling third period that displayed Stanley Cup hockey at its best for a national TV audience, the Chicago Black. Hawks preserved a 5-4 victory over the New York Rangers today and squared their semifinal playoff series at one game each.

Oh, dear! There really are so very many little things to like and laugh at in Don DeLillo's third and latest novel, "Great Jones Street." Browsing through it once more, I can see all the jelly beans fairly leaping off the pages; so if you'll be patient a moment, I'll try to convince you (and myself) that this novel is alive and a worthy successor

Homero Blancas blew a four-stroke lead, then rallied and limped home the winner with a 75 today in the final round of the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament. Blancas had bogeys on two of his last three holes but even that was good enough to hold off Frank Beard in the fight for the $30,000 first prize.

Under the minimum tax added to the law in 1969 to insure that all wealthy persons paid some Federal income tax, 24,000 of them are paying at a rate averaging 4.13 per cent, or about what a $6,000-a-year worker pays.

Premier Glulio Andreott, who is due to arrive in Washington tomorrow for talks with President nixon, says that Italy and the United States are linked by "a friendship of peoples that no event can Jeonardize."

Miss Lisbeth Lynn Levenson, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Levine, was married here this noon to Heywood Henry Adler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Adler of White Plains. Rabbis Morris Kertzer and H. Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Temple. They were assisted by Cantor Edward Graham.

Knowledgeable Western diplomats here say that they believe that the heavy United States bombing campaign in Cambodia is being carried out on the basis of inadequate intelligence data and often with imprecise control, causing high civilian casualties.

Despite a 30-minute overtime session in the game between the Greek-Americans and Hellenic for the German-American Soccer League playoffs yesterday, the Battle of the Greeks ended in a 1-1 tie. The teams will meet again Wednesday night at Metropolitan Oval.

Rhodesia has obtrained three Boeing 707 airliners despite United Nations sanctions, and no one will say where the jets came from. The chairman of Air Rhodesia, Frank Buch, said today that the arrival of the aircraft last night was "a great moralebooster for Rhodesians" but would say no more.

There was a telephone call in the locker room for Harry Parker after the New York Mets right-hander won his first major league game as a starter, 2-1, from Philadelphia today, but it wasn't from President Nixon.

Cook Industries, Inc., a concern involved last Augus in the multimillion dollar grail sale to the Soviet Union, an nounced this weekend an an most five-fold jump in profit for the first nine months o fiscal 1973. Net after-tax earn

High property tax rates in the slums -- higher than in better neighborhoods in many casesare discouraging rehabilitation that would otherwise be a profitable investment, according to a study by independent experts.

They're calling the longer hemlines, the ones that stop anywhere from below the knees to above the ankles, the "young" lengths in Paris. The hems that stop at the knees or just above are called the "mature" look.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today it had won contracts from growers previously signed with the United Farm Workers Union led by Cesar Chavez.

In only 80 minutes Stan Smith defeated Rod Laver, 6-2, 6-4, 6-1, to win the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Group A tournament today. The tall American earned the $10,000 first prize, but perhaps more satisfying for him, he now holds a 3-2 edge over the Australian in their matches this year.

Ship's Company, a brown gelding owned by Dani McGrath of Essex, Conn., won his second championship of the year at the Bennett College horse show today where he was best of the regular working hunters.

Despite a finding by his panel that special city narcotics courts were failing, Paul J. Curran, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, said yesterday that the federally financed courts should continue and that their efforts should be "beefed up." On April 8 the commission

The head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that Congress would be less inclined to relax auto emission standards now that the auto makers have a one-year extension of the stiff 1975 requirements.

In nine months without a normal cabinet, the Netherlands appears farther than ever from solving the longest - lasting political crisis faced here. But the experienced adminstrative bureaucracy keeps Governmental machinery turning as if nothing had happened, the heavily industrialized economy keeps producing and polluting, and a poll this month discloses that 35 per cent of the population thinks the crisis has long been settled.
President Nixon said today that he planned to make "a grand tour" of Europe-the first foreign trip of his second termthis fall.

Regional medical programs all over the country are winding up their affairs, on orders from the Nixon Administration, in spite of the fact that the Senate has passed a bill to keep them alive and the House is considering an almost identical measure.

Frederick J. Balmer, president of the Balmer Cadillac Corporation, car dealers at 8904 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, and a founder and vice president of the Dealers Leasing Corporation, died Saturday in New York Hospital, after an operation.
"James Paul McCartney," an 8 to 9 o'clock special on the American Broadcasting Company network this evening, gets off to a smashing start and comes to an effectively low-keyed end.
First the Americans concentrated on Vietnamization. Then they turned to civilianization. Now they are trying a little feminization.
Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. has found a 1928 law that he said empowers his Government Operations Committee to obtain in writing virtually any information it wants from the Nixon Administration.
David Pearson won his third 500-mile stock car race in a row today, weaving his red-and-white Mercury through a maze of broken cars to capture the 17th Rebel 500 at Darlington International Raceway.

The Libyan copilot of an airliner downed by Israeli jets Feb. 21 in the Sinai Peninsula said today that the plane's captain heard the warning shots fired by the interceptors and planned to land, "but at the last moment he changed his mind" and tried to escape back to Egypt.
If a group of top experts were asked to name the best six players in North America in ranked order, there would be considerable disagreement about the top spot.
The leaders of the giant country-music industry met here and upstate over the weekend to plot the capitulation of the Northeast to the sound that has swept most of the rest of the country.

The official death toll in the earthquake here rose to 16 today and rescue workers said they believed it might eventually reach 50. Four more bodies were recovered overnight from the ruins of homes in Tilaran, near the border with Nicaragua. Tilaran,

The New Jersey Office of Cable Television, which was created last Dec. 15 and charged with responsibility for regulating and supervising cable TV in the state's 567 municipalities, is not yet ready for business.
Despite technical flaws in promotion and presentation, professional track and field appears to have survived its first few hurdles in the race for recognition and respectability.

Highly volatile elements could combine to produce bond-market explosions this week. The raw materials are these: Data to be released on consumer prices for March that are virtually certain to be depressing, a Congressional decision before adjournment for Easter on tightening economic

The room at 2 St. Mark's Place, which was known until 1968 as the Five Spot, was a basic stomping ground for Charles Mingus, the eminent jazz bassist, until it abandoned its jazz policy in 1967. Recently reopened as the Two Saints, it has now retrieved Mr. Mingus.

When last Thursday a correspondent tried to reach a rather important government official he was told, "It's out of the question." "He is preparing to leave Mexico City for Holy Week and he is not seeing anyone today or tomorrow," his secretary said. "In fact, I think he has left already."
The White House has mobilized the Government's extensive public relations machinery to rally support for the Administration's budget cuts.

Robert B. McKay said yesterday that his main goal during a probable nine months in office as chairman of the city's Board of Correction would be to "depopulate" the city's jails as much as possible and to try to make them "less degrading, less dehumanizing and less brutal than in the past."

American and Canadian jurists who came to Athens more than a week ago to seek information about the arrest and detention of six young lawyers left here today saying, in a statement, "We regret that the Greek Government has rejected an opportunity extended in good faith to sttae its position."

Ken Rosewall, the so-called old man on the World Championship Tennis Group B tour, vanquished Roger Taylor of Britain, 6-3, 6-4, in the final of the $50,000 Cleveland tennis tournament today. It was the Australian's second tournament triumph in two weeks. The match lasted 1 hour 3 minutes, and Rosewall's backhand passing shots were the big factors. Rosewall is the only

Regional medical programs all over the country are winding up their affairs, on orders from the Nixon Administration, in spite of the fact that the Senate has passed a bill to keep them alive and the House is considering an almost identical measure.

The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to start next month on the rule-making procedures for a composite quotation system for stocks. This would mark the first implementation of the S.E.C.'s March 29 white paper on a central market system.

Holy Week, the last sever days in Lent that commemorate the final events in the life of Christ before His Resurrec tion, began yesterday in Ro man Catholic and Protestan churches with the tradition prayers, meditations and music of Palm Sunday.

The Defense Department has reopened a controversy within the Administration by proposing to the White House that the foreign military aid program be consolidated within the overall defense budget

Peronists today con. solidated their gains made in the March 11 general election by electing senators and governors in 12 of Argentina's 15 provinces, according to official returns that are almost completed.

Klaus Dibiasi of Italy, an Olympic gold medalist, took the 10-meter platform title today and 18-year-old Christine Lock of Fort Worth, Tex., won the three-meter springboard event in the swimming Hall of Fame diving championships.

The Carnegie Corporation announced yesterday that it had awarded three grants totaling $377,733 to support projects for spreading information about faculty unionization and collective bargaining in American colleges and universities, United Press International reported.

The Public Education Association has released a citywide survey indicating that only one out of five candidates in the May 1 school boards elections feel that the schools in their districts are performing "as well as can be expected."

Five young men believed returning from a dance in La Junta, Colo., were killed today when their car struck the rear of a two-and-a-halfton truck. The victims were identified as Alan J. Lopez, 27 years old, of Thornton, Colo., the driver of the car; Barney R. Ferri Jr., 18, also of Thornton;
State and city laws prohibiting discrimination because of race, religion, national origin and sex apply equally to New Yorkers and non-New Yorkers, the Appellate Division ruled last week.

Peter M. Flanigan, a top Presidential adviser, predicted yesterday that the Administration's trade bill would be enacted by the House of Representatives by September in time for the start of forthcoming world trade negotiations.

Fifteen former officers of the Krueger Manufacturing Company have filed suit against the Lear Siegler Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., alleging fraud and deception in the California company's purchase of Kreuger three years ago.

Advanced plans for a new Broadway version of the long-running mystery thriller, "Sleuth," with one or two women in the hitherto allmale cast, wait chiefly upon the possible acceptance of the lead by Joan Crawford.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ABORTION Denied a rehearing to antiabortion forces in New York and Connecticut who were seeking to overturn the Court's Januarydecision that prohibited state interference with termination of pregnancy in all but the last 10 weeks. Last September, Frank Shorter became the first American in 64 years to win an Olympic gold medal in the marathon. Yesterday, Jon Anderson ended four years of foreign rule with a convincing victory in the Boston Marathon.

BARTHOLOMEW FAIR, a play by Ben Jonson. Directed by Robert Mandel; setting by William G. Mickley Jr.; costumes by Pullellen Weiss; lighting by Jack Carr; composer, Robert Dennis; choreographer, Virginia Freeman; music director, Cash Clay; production stage manager, Steven Rlstow. Presented by
A twin-engine sixseater charter plane apparently fell apart early this morning and crashed here in an area of small homes, killing all six persons aboard.
Miss Elizabeth Flood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Flood, was married last Saturday to John Fell Stevenson, youngest son of the late Adlai E. Stevenson, United States Representative
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denied today the Government's request to halt courtordered desegregation proceedings against school districts in 17 states.
A top aide of the Interstate Commerce Commission told Congress today that the Nixon Administration's plan for resolving the Northeastern railroad crisis was little more than a "naive hope."

The clubs that have played some of the more memorable Stanley Cup games-the Rangers and Chicago Black Hawks -bring their semifinal playoff series to Madison Square Garden tonight for Game 3 of this Four-of-seven-game affair. The series is tied, 1-1.
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether use of a New York Stock Exchange special trust fund to soften the financial collapse of a major stock broker violated bankruptcy law.

Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the 21-member New York City Board of Higher Education, which is now entirely filled by mayoral appointees, be cut to 10 appointees with the Governor assuming the power to name half the members.

A key hormone produced by the thymus gland is directly related to the process of aging, University of Texas scientists reported today.

Norman C. Bowersox, a member of the law firm of what Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside Wolff, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 870 United Nations journal Plaza. He was 67 years old.

Tagging is one of the most effective ways to learn something of the growth rate, numbers and migratory habits of fish. A variety of tags, ranging from simple loops of legendbearing plastic tubing inserted through a fish's dorsal area and knotted, to more sophisticated stainless steel darts are used.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that seasonal workers from Mexico, estimated by the United Farm Workers Union to total between 100,000 and 400,000, must obtain visas before entering the United States.

Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, and the five Republican county leaders won a partial victory yesterday in a suit to have the newly established Councilmanic districts declared in violation of the State and. Federal Constitutions.
A joint Senate and House study committee gave unanimous approval today to a plan for a drastic revision of the Congressional budget process.

Pfizer, Inc., realized a 20 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 12 per cent, both setting records for the period, Edmund T. Pratt, chairman, told 400 shareholders yesterday at the concern's annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

George K. Myers, director of finance and relationships for the Boy Scouts of America national office in North Brunswick, N.J., and Manhattan Scout Executive from 1948 to 1954, died Thursday of a heart attack in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Matawan and Mendham, N. J.
Charlie Moir, the head basketball coach at Roanoke College, announced his resignation today to take a similar position with Tulane University.

State-licensed masseurs and masseuses, up in arms over a city law scheduled to go into effect tomorrow, a law actually aimed at massage parlors, have filed suit in State Supreme Court to prevent the law's being applied to them.

Student leaders from five major universities circulated a secretly printed note today accusing the military-run Government of responding to legitimate student activities with "slander, threats, arrests and even death."

Two leaders of the American Indian Movement pleaded not guilty today to Federal indictments, including charges that they wounded a United States marshal and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in the 48-day-old occupation of Wounded Knee.

A fournation truce investigating team unanimously has agreed to ask the Vietcong to let survivors of the crash of a peacekeeping helicopter visit the wreckage to determine whether it was moved, Canadian sources said today.

The Justice Department today accused the National Broiler Association of fixing prices. A civil antitrust suit filed in Atlanta charges that the members of the association and others entered into a combination and conspiracy to fix prices of broiler chickens at artificially high prices.
An agreement for the purchase of $800-million of American grain and soybeans by Taiwan over the next three years was signed here yesterday. Purchase of $560-million of other products is in prospect.
Rodrigo Valdes, the World Boxing Association's thirdranked middleweight, stopped Kim Booker at 2 minutes 12 seconds of the fifth round before a crowd of 2,562 in the Felt Forum last night.
Peter J. Brennan, the former New York labor leader who is now Secretary of Labor, occasionally carries a pistol, an aide confirmed today.

For onion fanciers who have been viewing with alarm for some time the sharp escalation in onion prices, matters have now reached a crisis. There are none to be had, even for a great deal of ready money.
The Senate investigating committee on the Watergate case, is studying rules under which witnesses, including White House aides, would testify at public hearings beginning about May 15.

Callagy Hall, New York City's oft-criticized shelter for adolescent girls, and Manida, the city's turn-of-the-century girls' jail, will be closed "within the year," Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.
Glen Hatcher, who has kept his Atlanta area gasoline stations open around the clock for nearly 20 years, went out last week to buy some locks for the doors.

State-licensed masseurs and masseuses, up in arms over a city law scheduled to go into effect tomorrow, a law actually aimed at massage parlors, have filed suit in State Supreme Court to prevent the law's being applied to them.

Amerigo Lassie of the Live Oak Plantation won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and the first thing the assistant trainer, Pat Kelly, said to the filly's rider in the winner's circle was, "I'm sure glad she runs with her neck out."
The number of possible champions of the National Basketball Association for 1973 is down to four, and each team has ample reason to consider its own chances excellent.

Conrad K. Osterman, who was acting director of the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce at his retirement in 1958, died Sunday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived at 44 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly, N. J.
Mrs. Marie Bradley Manly, widow of Basil Manly, economist, author and former chairman of the Federal Power Commission, died yesterday at her home here. She was 91 years old.

An arson attack on the home of a neoFascist party activist here today resulted in the death of two of his sons. Burning gasoline was poured into the small top-floor apartment of Mario Mattei in the Primavalle District on Rome's western outskirts.

The House rejected today legislation sponsored by the Democratic leadership that would have placed ceilings on prices, rents and interest rates. The House then gave President Nixon the economic controls legislation that he wanted. It approved a bill that would continue for another year without restriction his authority to regulate wages and prices.
Two policemen have been suspended as a result of a departmental investigation into whether a man fell or was thrown to his death from a Bronx roof last September.

Mrs. Martha Mitchell said today that a White House denial that her husband, former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, conferred with President Nixon at the White House Saturday was a "God-blessed lie."
City and Federal officials announced yesterday the indictment of 86 reputed drug dealers and said 65 of them had already been arrested--61 in the metropolitan area and four in Detroit.
Tuesday, April 17-A South Vietnamese military official said yesterday that Government troops "might" have crossed the border into Cambodia Sunday as newsmen on the scene reported.

Among the 1,300 Americans still missing in Indochina, there are five who were not there to shoot anyone, drop bombs or napalm on anyone or help in any other way to carry on the U.S. military intervention.

A judge ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to stop using telephone records to trace the identity of Jack Anderson's sources. United States District Court Judge John J. Sirica issued the temporary injunction after a hearing in which an F.B.I.

President Nixon came to the defense today of his Secretary of Labor, Peter J. Brennan, who has been under heavy attack from organized labor for supporting the Administration's new minimum wage legislation.

Pentagon officials told Congressmen from New York and New Jersey today that St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens would be closed by June 30, 1974, and that Lakehurst Naval Air Station in New Jersey would lose 632 jobs by the same date.
The tempo of negotiations in the Long Island Rail Road contract dispute quickened yesterday as the end of a 90day cooling-off period
- Striking teachers and the Hawaii Department of Education announced today that they had agreed to settle their three-week dispute by arbitration.
The Food and Drug Administration ordered today that prescription drugs for oral dosage be packaged in containers most children cannot open.
Esthetically shaped and tasteful gymnastics in wittily appealing vignettes is the most obvious quality of the Pilobolus Dance Theater.

Runoff elections in Argentina yesterday consolidated the March 11 electoral victory of the Peronist coalition headed by Dr. Hector J. Campora. Dr. Campora's Justicialist Liberation Front, a five-party alliance dominated by the Peronist party, emerged with 43 of the 69 Senate seats and 20 of the 22 provincial governorships.
Sales of personal holdings of stock in the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America by two more company officers just before trading was halted, came to light yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller's modified drug program is in some respects worse than the one he originally unveiled some weeks ago. While he has dropped hashish from the list of dangerous drugs for which life-term penalties might be imposed-certainly a welcome change-Mr. Rockefeller at the same time proposes to expand the application of mandatory criminal sentences.
Hyman J. Fliegel, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old and lived at 141 East 21st Street. Brooklyn.
Barnet Nover, a leading editor and syndicated columnist based in Washington, died yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 74 years old and had lived in Washington

What happens when students in a college dormitory are suddenly forced to cook for themselves? "Disaster," says Mildred Steinberg, program coordinator of Lenny Bruce College at the State University at Stony Brook.

Unknown saboteurs tried to blow up the Arabian-American Oil Company's pipeline today, Government sources in southern Lebanon reported. Explosive charges went off under the pipeline four miles from the Zahrani terminal, which is five miles south of Saida, the informants added.

The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that it had entered into a $110.8-million lease covering all of the equipment at the company's new 120,000-ton-a-year primary aluminum-reduction plant at Sebree, Ky. United States Leasing International, Inc., of San Francisco negotiated equity for the transaction, and the First Boston Corporation placed the debt.
Yields on United States Treasury bills were virtually the same as last week's in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.
John E. Foley, director of the Internal Revenue Service in the Buffalo district, died last night in Buffalo General Hospital. He was 56 years old.
Josef Grossman, an information officer for the United States Information Agency in Accra, Ghana, died Friday apparently of a heart attack, while visiting friends in Bethesda, Md. He was 49 years old.
New York and New Jersey are telling the Federal Government it will be too costly for them to meet clean-air standards by 1975.
Pablo Picasso was buried this afternoon in the park of his 16thcentury castle at Vauvenargues, near Aix-en-Provence.

Several hundred Mexican-American followers of Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, picketed several grape ranches in the lower Coachella Valley today after their union lost field work contracts to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Playing it cool while one leader after another wilted in 77degree heat, Jon Anderson moved up strongly in the late stages today and became the first American since 1968 to win the Boston Marathon.

Forrest Allen, a retired investigative reporter for The Cleveland Press and other Scripps-Howard newspapers, died yesterday in Melbourne while on a roundthe-world tour with his wife, Elizabeth. He was 70 years old and lived in Boulder, Colo.
The Finance Ministry reported today that Japan had registered a record monthly deficit of $1.1-billion in the nation's balance of international payments in March.

Sean MacStiofain, the one-time chief of staff of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, was released from the Curragh Military Prison this morning and told newsmen at the gates, "I remain an unrepentant republican separatist."

Pentagon officials told Congressmen from New York and New Jersey today that St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens would be closed by June 30, 1974, and that Lakehurst Naval Air Station in New Jersey would lose 632 jobs by the same date.
The Republican mayoral ticket was revamped yesterday with the designation of two Lindsay administration officials as candidates for Council President and Controller.

An immediate halt to all new hospital construction here, both public and private, was recommended yesterday by a state commission that has spent a year and a half examining the inner workings of the Lindsay administration.
The C.B.S. Evening News was nominated today for three Emmy awards in the news and documentary categories for its coverage of the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama last May 15.

Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the 21-member New York City Board of Higher Education, which is now entirely filled by mayoral appointees, be cut to 10 appointees with the Governor assuming the power to name half the members.

Johnny wilson, dismissed last Friday as coach of the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, fired repeated volleys of criticism at the team's frent office duringa news conference today.

The New Haven Division of the Penn Central unveiled the first of a modern fleet of commuter cars yesterday in a special run from Stamford, Conn., to Grand Central Terminal. The train was new but, to New Haven veterans, its performance was familiar: it was 12 minutes late.

The country's colleges and universities, faced with a deepening financial crisis two years ago, have achieved a "fragile stability" in the tug-of-war between rapidly rising costs and more slowly growing incomes, according to a new report by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education.

Jews began the week-long observance of Passover at sundown yesterday, marking the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage. In Jewish households, families sat down to the traditional Seder at which the Haggadah was read, telling the story of the exodus of the Israelites. On the table

A $1-billion Federal District Court trial between the Tulsa-based Telex Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation began today with Telex lawyers asking the court to make the computer-accessories market competitive again.
The Maryland State Police arrested the Baltimore Oriole manager, Earl Weaver, today on charges of drunken driving, malicious destruction of property and failure to drive within a single lane.

The Chrysler Corporation today reported record sales and earnings for the first quarter of 1973, but it said the profit would have been higher if the company could have raised prices further to balance costs.

Lost in a limbo in the Equity Funding scandal stand holders of nearly $23-million of 5 1/4 per cent convertible debentures sold in Europe, $38.5-million of 5 1/2 per cent convertibles sold in this nation, and $22-million of 9 1/2 per cent debentures with no conversion privilege.
Cliff Richey Roy Barth and Brian Gottfried of the United States won their opening-round matches in the World Championship Tennis Group A tour today. Earlier
Tagging is one of the most effective ways to learn something of the growth rate, numbers and migratory habits of fish.

The Witco Chemical Corporation has completed its plan to purchase 200,000 shares of its common stock in the open market and through block purchases. The shares will be used for convertible securities and stock option programs. The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 20 7/8 up 1/8.

The Union Jack went up today on Unter Den Linden to mark the opening of the British Embassy there 35 years after the closing of the last British embassy here at the start of World War II.
President Nixon announced plans today to sell, over a period of several years, about $6-billion of the $6.7-billion worth of "critical" materials in the Government's stockpile.
New York and New Jersey are telling the Federal Government it will be too costly for them to meet clean-air standards by 1975.

Miss Patricia Angly, an editorial assistant with Cleveland, a magazine, was married here this morning to Peter G. Dearing, a law student at Case Western Reserve University. The civil ceremony was performed in the Municipal Court.

Sam Snead, hailed "as the greatest player in the history of golf," waited until the ovation given him today at the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association ceremony ceased, and said, "I'm surprised and happy."

The echoes of President Nixon's pronouncement that this is "the year of Europe" are ringing here, but with a hollow and sometimes sardonic tone. No one contends that EuropeanAmerican relations are as good as they should or could be.

More than a score of Wall Street's small organizations of security analysts known as splinter groups - often criticized for their closed meetings -have decided to permit press attendance.

President Nixon announced plans today to sell, over a period of several years, about $6-billion of the $6.7-billion worth of "critical" materials in the Government's stockpile. Of the total planned sales of $6- billion, about $4.1 - billion will need approval by Congress.
The Defense Department informed members of Congress today of plans to close or change the size of 274 military bases as part of an economy move estimated eventually to save $400-million annually.

The clubs that have played some of the more memorable Stanley Cup games-the Rangers and Chicago Black Hawks -bring their semifinal playoff series to Madison Square Garden tonight for Game 3 of this four-of-seven-game affair. The series is tied, 1-1.

SMITH There is no physical shortage of energy resources in either the United States or the world for the foreseeable future and yet Americans may spend the rest of this decade coping with brownouts and blackouts and perhaps even rationing of gasoline, heating oil and natural gas.

Premier Giulio Andreotti of Italy arrived here today for an overnight stay before beginning two days of conferences with President Nixon in Washington. A welcoming party of about 30 headed by William R. Codus, the United States assistant chief of protocol, welcomed Mr. Andreotti and his Foreign Minister,

Steve Francks of Archbishop Molloy posted the second best javelin throw in New York State history yesterday on the first day of the Brooklyn Diocese Catholic High School relay carnival at St. John's University in Queens.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie opened a counterattack today against the auto industry's effort to win a reduction in the auto emission standards set by the 1970 clean air act.
"It would be nice if I could say I was sitting in my office here and the telephone rang and I heard a voice say, 'Hi, I'm Nelson Rockefeller,'" remarked Peter Preiser.

United States military spokesmen said today that a special American unit assigned to search for more than 1,300 American servicemen missing in Indochina would begin its task as soon as diplomatic permission was received from the countries involved.
A twin-engine six-seater charter plane apparently fell apart early this morning and crashed here in an area of small homes, killing all six persons aboard.
Johnny Wilson, dismissed last Friday as coach of the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, fired repeated volleys of criticism at the team's front office during a news conference today.

The Administration told a Congressional subcommittee today that the daily bombing raids over Cambodia had permitted the survival of the Lon Nol Government but had failed so far to persuade the Communuistbacked insurgents to start negotiations for a cease-fire.
City and Federal officials announced yesterday the indictment of 86 reputed drug dealers and said 65 of them had already been arrested-61 in the metropolitan area and four in Detroit.

Playing it cool while one leader after another wilted in 77degree heat, Jon Anderson moved up strongly in the late stages today and became the first American since 1968 to win the Boston Marathon. An applauding, sympathetic crowd of perhaps one million saw him do it.

Open Market Committee voted at its Jan. 16 meeting to seek bank reserve and money market conditions that would support slower growth in the monetary aggregates than occurred in the second half of last year.

The Yankees bolstered their right-handed hitting yesterday by purchasing Jim Ray Hart from the San Francisco Giants for an undisclosed amount of cash. Hart, a 31year-old third baseman and outfielder who has been prone to injury since coming up the Giants in 1964, will be used mainly as a designated hitter.

A bullet shattered a window early today at the home of a New Zealand diplomat. The shot was apparently fired by terrorists who believed that the building was still oc-, cupied by the Jordanian Ambassador.
Premier Golda Meir said in an interview published here today that Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had never said a good word about Israel.

Add to your list of hitherto unknown bel canto operas "Caterina Cornaro" by Gaetano Donizetti. It was composed in 1843, was a failure at its premiere the following year and had a long, long rest before turning up in Italy last year in Naples. On that occasion the Turkish soprano Leyla Gencer sang the title role.
