New York State asked the Supreme Court today to sustain its controversial 1972 law aimed at providing financial assistance for hard-pressed parochial schools through state aid for maintenance costs and tuition and tax benefits for parents.
Mrs. Phyllis Winterbottom MacDonald and .Edwin R. Masback Jr., both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon by Judge Jacob Zuckerman of the Family Court in his chambers.

Here in southern California there is no way to escape the so-called "environmental issues" and their human costs. Air pollution is something you see and breathe--and cause when you take to the freeways. The energy crisis is in plain view out in the Santa Barbara Channel. Offshore oil drilling is an issue in the city election, as it may become in New York politics with the discovery of oil deposits off Long Island.

There have always been gamblers of the chessboard, hunch players who prefer to operate beyond the limits of foreseeable logic. When the genial Frank Marshall, United States champion from 1909 to 1936, got off a brilliant knight sacrifice in a game with H. Wolf, Nuremberg, 1906, he scribbled the symbol for "questionable" (!?) next to his move on his scoresheet.

Marian Bender, a flashy filly who has been nominated for the May 19 running of the $150,000-added Preakness Stakes, chalked up her seventh straight victory in eight career starts today. She defeated five other Maryland-bred 3-year-old fillies at Pimlico. Pete's Lass was second, Softly was third.
Mayor Les Anderson of Eugene, Ore., lost his political cool today when he heard his son, Jon, won the Boston Marathon.

Callagy Hall, New York City's oft-criticized shelter for adolescent girls, and Manida, the city's turn-of-the-century girls' jail, will be closed "within the year," Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.
The arrests of 65 suspected narcotics dealers were announced yesterday by city and Federal officials, who said they were among the most important drug arrests in the city's history.

New York's Environmental Protection Administrator, Herbert Elish, called upon the Port Authority yesterday to reverse its announced intention to "nearly double" the price of tickets at the authority's Park and Ride facility in North Bergen.
American bombers, for only the second time since the ceasefire in Laos, today struck North Vietnamese positions in that country, Pentagon officials said.

President Nixon has made three useful suggestions for improving the Federal-state unemployment insurance system. Congress ought not only to approve all three but also to add at least two more reforms in the interest of making the system stronger still.
When Ralph Lauren presented his Polo collection for men, he was wearing a pinstriped black suit, a white shirt and a black tie. How long has it been since designers dressed that way?
Chief Inspector Michael J. Codd, head of all the uniformed and detective forces of the Police Department, announced his retirement yesterday, his 57th birthday.
Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc., consistently one of the more profitable firms in Wall Street, reported its first quarterly loss yesterday since its incorporation in December, 1971.

The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday a first-quarter net loss-on a fully accrued basis-of $55.2-million. This represented a decrease of 15.2 per cent from the $65.2-million net loss reported for the comparable period of 1972.

The BankAmerica Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation, holding companies that own three of the country's largest banks, reported higher first-quarter earnings yesterday.
The Board of Supervisors today authorized an additional $5.525-million to complete the Dynamic Care Building at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.

Believe me, President. Nixon, prices just aren't going to stop rising without some firm, nononsense action from you. And may I respectfully suggest that you act quickly and start a Phase 4 right at the heart of the matter-prices of food at the farm level.

"The buyers are saying the prices are too high and the sellers are saying they're too low. So what else is new?" said Mike Weinblatt, vice president for sales of the National Broadcasting Company television network.

State education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist refused today to order the New York City Board of Education to furnish lists of names and addresses of parents of students in the city schools to candidates in the forthcoming elections for community school board members.

In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Barbara Joy Dillon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reed Aldridge Dillon of Indianapolis, became the bride of Peter Roe Greenfield.

KATHRYN BOULEYN, soprano, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and 53d Street, 12 Noon. TRINITY CHURCH CHOIR, Trinlty Church, Broadway at Wall Street, 12:45. CATHERINE AKS and LUCY SHELTON, sopranos, Federal Hall National Memorial, corner Wall and Broad Street, 5:45.

Two Bronx policemen were suspended for refusing complete cooperation with a Police Department inquiry into charges that a man was thrown to his death by two policemen from a Bronx roof last September.
Heavy thunderstorms dumped more water today on already flooded sections of Mississippi and caused new flash flooding in other parts of the state.

Many a Soviet conversation with visiting Americans these days opens with a discreet private question: "What can you tell us about who 'our ambassador' will be?" American businessmen are asked by their counterparts.

"The Chinese Government asked me to come and bring a delegation of regular American women to meet regular Chinese women," said Shirley MacLaine, the actress. "They asked for some peasants and working-class women.
The drive to put a legalized gambling referendum before the voters in November died in a Senate Republican caucus here today without a public fight.

For more than five weeks now, a massive manhunt has been conducted by the police throughout the Upper West Side-in fact, throughout the world-for the man responsible for the brutal murder and sexual mutilation of 10year-old Luis Ortiz, whose body was found in a tenement basement on West 106th Street.

Two Palestinian editors of an East Jerusalem Arabic weekly were arrested by the Israeli police today on charges of evading censorship and inciting revolution among the residents of the West Bank of the Jordan River.

The House of Lords ruled today that a Formosan convicted of attempting to assassinate Gen. Chiang Kai-shek's son in New York three years ago must be extradited to the United States.
A special Senate committee today made public a 1967 Food and Drug Administration report showing that a "very high" rate of cavities occurs among children who eat presweetened cereals.

Those of us who were brought up with absolute faith in the absolute superiority of American mechanical skills cannot help feeling embarrassed about Detroit's performance in this matter of exhaust pollution standards.

In the wake of the suspension of superfecta betting at New York race tracks and OTB shops, George M. Levy, president of Roosevelt Raceway, has asked that all drivers at his track take a lie-detector test.

Industrial production recorded another sizable gain in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The board's index of industrial production rose seventenths of a per cent during the month. The rise brought the
The Supreme Court let stand today a decision barring public school officials from discharging a teacher who refuses to recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag with pupils in her homeroom.
Led by Dan Issei's 34 points, the Kentucky Colonels defeated the Carolina Cougars, 108-94, tonight to take a 2-1 edge in their American Basketball Association Eastern Division playoffs.

The State Assembly gave final legislative approval by an overwhelming margin today to a tough campaign disclosure bill that provides criminal penalties for state or local candidates who "willfully" violate its terms.

Federal Judge George Rosling, who had served on the bench for the Eastern District of New York since 1961, died yesterday in the Downstate Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 1600 East 26th Street in Brooklyn.
A He was Picasso painting valued at $207,500 was stolen from a private collection here today. It was the second robbery in the last few days of a canvas by the late painter.

Battered by conflicting scenarios of doomsday, threatened with cutoffs of electricity at any moment, warned of the possibility of localized gasoline rationing this summer, the American consumer has ample reason to demand Federal Government leadership in charting a way out of this country's energy crisis.
Tony Perez, Dave Concepcion and Johnny Bench hit home runs tonight to lead the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-6 victory over the Padres.
Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had accepted "with deep regret" the long-reported resignation of his Commissioner of Correction, Russell G. Oswald, effective May 1.

Contracts totaling $7.8-million for the race track and football stadium at the Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex were announced today at a meeting of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.
A tough environmentall measure that would give the state the power to ban heavy industry from much of New Jersey's remaining undeveloped coastline was approved overwhelmingly in the Assembly today.

The final stages of the Grand National Championship in Westchester and New Jersey were completed during the weekend. The winners were David Mason and Ron Rubin of Maplewood, N. J.; Louis Levy of Fort Lee, N. J., and Neil Silverman of East Orange, N. J. They will compete with the Greater New York Bridge Association winners, to be decided next weekend, and the New England champions, to determine the zonal champions.
In a heated and at times unruly debate, Egypt's Foreign Minister called upon the Security Council today to prevent the United States from giving economic assistance and military supplies to Israel.
The Supreme Court declined today to halt imports of Rhodesian chrome by the United States despite the United Nations embargo on trade with Rhodesia.

When George Medich passed up the second half of his third year of medical school to go to spring training with the Yankees last month, he wanted to find out whether or not he could win a major league job.

President Nixon's announcement that he planned to cut the nation's stockpiled matrials by some $6-billion worth of commodities out of a total of $6.7-billion sent metals futures tumbling on the commodities markets yesterday.

A controversial book ditied "Sex in the Confessional," based on secret tape recordings of 632 false confessions to Roman Catholic priests, has been ordered seized throughout Italy on grounds of obscenity.
A 28-year-old former Transit Authority patrolman was sentenced to 15 years in prison yesterday on a manslaughter conviction stemming from a gun slaying in Greenwich Village in August, 1968.

A woman was shot with her own .22 caliber pistol yesterday as she allegedly tried to hold up a Lexington Avenue clothes store. The police said the woman, Lenora Brown of 191-01 122d Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, had made several purchases in Mangol's, 736 Lexington Avenue near 58th Street, and had then pulled a pistol at the cash register. Stewardesses and Stewards of Eastern Airlines agreed tonight to postpone a strike deadline until 6 P.M. tomorrow while negotiations continued for a new contract, a national mediator announced.

Guillermo Vilas defeated South Africa's Deon Joubert, 6-2, 6-1, 6-1 today to enable Argentina to clinch the Davis Cup South American Zone semifinal series. The victory gave Argentina a 3-1 lead in the three-of-five match series assuring its advance to the final against Chile.
Willie Horton wrecked Boston strategy by smashing a three-run homer today, powering the Detroit Tigers to a 9-7 victory over the Red Sox before a Patriot's Day crowd of 29,006.

A little-noticed item in President Nixon's proposed budget suggests that the supersonic transport plane still has a champion or two in the White House. The sum of $5.8 million is included to cover further studies of the plane's possible effect on the stratosphere. The persistence of the SST's promoters within the Government is remarkable on at least three counts.

The Skylab space station was moved to its launching pad today to be prepared for launching on May 14.
The credit markets, operating with one eye on Washington and the possibility of tightened economic controls, traded cautiously yesterday and generated no discernible trend in interest rates.
The Justice Department accused United and Delta Air Lines and five labor unions today of discrimination against black and women employes and job applicants.

Harold N., on April 16, 1973, beloved husband of Lillian, son of Stella Aronsohn, loving father of L. Jack Aronsohn, Patricia Garson, Robert Grimes and Jay Lesselbaum, brother of Ben Aronsohn Sr., Leo J. Aronsohn, Tea Phillips, and Helen Elsenbach, dear grandfather and great-grandfather. Funeral Wednesday, 10 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment private. in lieu of flowers gifts to your favorite charity will be appreciated.
The Syrian Army opened fire and used tanks against antiGovernment Moslem demonstrators yesterday during celebrations of the birthday of Mohammed, according to travelers arriving from Syria.
Don't be surprised if the fun-minded Morris' Bar softball team of the New Jersey Industrial League opens its season by serving an order to show cause to the seven other clubs in the Class A division.

Amer.), 36 day European Cruise; sails 11 P.M. from W. 571h St. RED JACKET (American Export), Halfa May ), Naples 4 and Genoa 7; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

The head of the United Mine Workers, whose members dig most of the nation's coal, assailed the Nixon Administration today for what he called its deference to the "instincts for profit" of private industry in shaping national energy policy.

Five Roman Catholic priests said today that they were withholding 20 per cent of the money due on their Federal income tax returns to protest the continuing United States war effort in Southeast Asia.

Prices for one-third of America's natural gas can be increased by the Federal Power Commission to stimulate further exploration, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled here today.
The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced plans yesterday to enter the field of total personal financial counseling by the proposed purchase of the AIMS Group, Inc.

Grapal Street looks like a perfectly ordinary suburban street. Curving in a now sharp, now gentle Sshape for the length of about one long city block, it is lined with small neat houses and immaculate little lawns, treeshaded, flower-bright and filled with the homey sound of children playing.

A drive to raise $3-million over a threeyear period for the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra was announced today.

Legislation extending President Nixon's authority to regulate wages and prices ran into unexpected difficulty in Congress today, raising considerable doubt whether a bill could be enacted by the April 30 deadline.

The office of the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, disclosed yesterday that it had started investigating whether a gasoline shortage existed in the state and if major companies were using alleged shortages "as a tool" to force small, independent retailers out of business.
The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that income from its mortgage portfolio rose to $45million in the first quarter from $27.9-million a year earlier.

Ben Feliciano, taking advantage of an injury to the leading jockey, Vincent Bracciale Jr., improved his position as the runner-up in the riding competition at Pimlico with four winners today. He now has 31 victories.

Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, charged today that growers in California were engaged in a "conspiracy" with teamsters officials, involving large illegal cash payments, to crush his union.

The F.B.I. told us that violent crimes in the nation rose again last year and that forcible rape took the biggest jump of all, a whopping 11 per cent. It is not exactly unrelated that at the age of 38 I have solemnly embarked on a dedicated program of self-defense instruction.
Tomorrow will be "Women's Night" at Roosevelt Raceway and one of the better trotters in the $14,075 New York Sire Stakes fourth race one-mile feature will be Sheer Move, a mare.
The Department of Labor is about to issue regulations limiting workers' exposure to more than a dozen industrial chemicals suspected of causing cancer.

Promising their electorate nothing more than "mindless perversion," four Princeton University students were given solid chances today for victory tomorrow in several races in the election for Undergraduate Assembly officers.

Following, excerpted from news conference transcripts, are previous statements by President Nixon on the Watergate case - including statements denying any involvement by White House staff members that Ronald L. Ziegler, the President's press secretary, said today were now "inoperative":
Trans World Airlines reported yesterday a consolidated net loss for the first quarter this year of $14.8-million. A $22.9million net loss had been reported for the same period of last year.

Although he has repeatedly denied it, Representative Mario Biaggi, a leading candidate for Mayor, refused to answer at least 30 questions when he appeared before a Federal grand jury more than a year ago, according to authoritative sources.
Government-appointed commission recommended today wide spread reforms to diminish the impact of medical malpractice suits on health care.

Emanuel Balaban, former orchestra conductor and a member of the faculty of the Juilliard School of Music, died yesterday of cancer at St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 235 West 76th Street.
Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson' defended today a nationwide reduction of military bases as a "necessary and timely" economy measure in the wake of the Vietnam war.

Mrs. Isabel Mathews Mason, the last descendant of the Van Cortlandt family of New York to occupy the 283-year-old Van Cortlandt Manor House at Croton-on-Hudson, N. Y., died Sunday at the Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing, Queens. She was 93 years old.
The idea of group improvisation is a seductive one for some musicians, but for this listener the interest often seems to be inversely proportional to the number of performers involved.
As a public issue, the Watergate affair began with a brazen but inept burglary exactly 10 months ago today. It came to embrace a highly complex range of covert and questionable political activity.

Scientists at the Baylor College of Medicine say they have captured animals' memories in a test tube. Working with rat brains, they have found that the memory of the sound of an electric bell is a chemical thing-an eight-segment chain of six specific amino acids, basic chemicals of life.

Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan announced yesterday that he had asked Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark "to agree to the removal" of three top officials in Newark's Public Employment Program and to the return of more than $1million of Federal job funds. That the Labor Department said had been misused.
Bond prices staged a broad decline yesterday, apparently reflecting disappointment over efforts to tighten economic controls and in the higher prime rate posted late in the day by three major banks.

Tom Heinsohn of the Boston Celtics was named yesterday as the National Basketball Association coach of the year for the 1972-73 season. "This is the first coaching trophy I've ever won," said the 38-year-old Heinsohn after the announcement by the N.B.A. commissioner, Walter Kennedy.
The National zoo is spending $550,000 this fiscal year on its two newly acquired Chinese pandas-and $4-million for the zoo's 1,800 other inhabitants.

A lawyer for a West Long Branch company building the controversial $6.4-million Kawaida Towers high-rise apartment today requested an indefinite suspension of work on the project pending the outcome of suits filed by white opponents of the building in state and Federal courts.

Using the slogan "Broadway will live," Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the "one-shot" crackdowns on pornography and prostitution in the Times Square area would be followed at once by and accelerated and sustained offensive.
Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States From 1941 to 1945, died yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old.

The Chicago Black Hawks' wondrous little Stan Mikita, perhaps the finest "small" center in recent hockey history, was in the right place when it mattered last night and his final-period goal lifted the visitors to a 2-1 victory over the Rangers.
Mrs. Eloise Jones recalls that 23 years ago, when she asked to be transferred from her job at an Army base in Brooklyn to St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens, she was told she was being foolish.

The leader of a migrant camp in Homestead, Fla., was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Miami today on charges of holding 13 workers in peonage and involuntary servitude, the Justice Department said.
Mrs. Cardiss Collins won the Democratic primary race in the Seventh Congressional District today. The victory almost assures that she will succeed her late husband in the House seat.

The Consumers Distributing Company, a joint venture of the May Department Stores Company of St. Louis and the Consumers Distributing Company of Toronto, announced today plans to open 50 catalogue showroom stores in the New York and San Francisco areas this year.

Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, charged today that growers in California were engaged in a "conspiracy" with teamsters officials, involving large illegal cash payments, to crush his union.

President Nixon's announcement today that White House aides would be allowed to testify before the Senate committee investigating the Watergate affair was greeted with general approval on Capitol Hill.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest brokerage house, yesterday announced a drop of more than 50 per cent in its first-quarter earnings to $10,824,000 from the year-earlier $23,250,000. Earnings per share dropped to 34 cents from 72 cents.

Declaring that it had "no alternative but to obey" the order of a Federal Judge, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare sent letters to 184 elementary and high school districts in 16 states today in an effort to end alleged school segregation.

Many players of moderate ability are firmly convinced that while the experts may be ahead in such matters as counting the hand or executing a squeeze they can bid as well as anyone. For those who wish to demonstrate their ability in this area, or simply to obtain some partnership practice, the world bidding contest organized by the International Bridge Academy will afford an opportunity on May 9.

Simon, "almost anything he does in his second four years in office will almost seem anticlimactical.

The three American jet airliners that Rhodesia has recently managed to purchase are only the latest proof that international economic sanctions against this breakaway British colony cannot block the flow of goods for which Rhodesia can pay.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market posted losses for the third consecutive day yesterday as trading continued light.

Edward J. Barrett, a long-time Democratic politician, was sentenced today in United States District Court here to three years in prison and was fined $15,000 for accepting bribes and kickbacks.
John Hope, chief exploration geologist of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, producers of copper, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown. He was 56 years old and had lived here.

United States B-52 bombers struck at what were identified as North Vietnamese forces in Laos today for the second consecutive day in response to what Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson this morning called "a flagrant violation" of the Laotian ceasefire by Hanol.

President Nixon's announcement today that White House aides would be allowed to testify before the Senate committee investigating the Watergate affair was greeted with general approval on Capitol Hill.
O. Pendleton Thomas, chairman and chief executive officer of the B. F. Goodrich Company, told the annual meeting here yesterday that sales and earnings in the first quarter set records.

Hatteras Income Securities, a bond fund advised by the North Carolina National Bank, made of a public offering yesterday of 2.75 million shares of capital stock through a six-manager syndicate of underwriting firms headed by Salomon Brothers. The stock was priced at $20 a share.

Henry S. Reeder, a senior partner in the law firm of Whitman Ransom, 522 Fifth Avenue, died at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center on Monday after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street and in Quogue, L.I.
Victor F. Aldridge, a former major league baseball pitcher, died today at St. Anthony Hospital here. He was 79 years old.

Pablo Picasso's three illegitimate children, Claude Ruiz-Picasso, his sister Paloma, and Maya Widmaier, have filed suit to be decleared his legal offspring, their lawyer Gaston Bouthoul, said in Antibes yesterday.
School lunch officials warned the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs today that vending machines that dispense "junk food" threatened to undermine the national school lunch program.

Three earth scientists have concluded after extensive study that "earthquake prediction, an old and elusive goal of seismologists and astrologers alike, appears to be on the verge of practical reality."
Egypt's press today hailed Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chairman of the United States Senate's Foreign Relations Committee, as a courageous voice of truth on the Middle East.

A National Transportation Safety Board investigator said yesterday that the plane crash that killed six persons in Brick Township, N. J., resulted from excessive stress placed on the aircraft by its pilot. Noting eyewitness reports of aerial acrobatics before the crash, the investigator said that the pilot had forced the plane beyond its capabilities.
Seven members of a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee tried in vain today to reach a consensus on a news men's privilege bill.

Greece's military dictatorship has received a stern rebuke and an admonition to return the country to democratic rule from an unexpected but significant source. Four retired generals who have held highest positions in the Greek armed forces have warned Premier Papadopoulos that his regime "is no longer permissible," and called on him to "create immediately" the conditions for a return to "free democratic institutions."
Stan Smith, the Wimbledon champion, was beaten by a fellow American, Charlie Pasarell, 6-2, 6-2, today in the first round of the World Championship Tennis tour's $57,000 tournament.

To the Editor: The annual controversy over the decline in reading scores for the New York City schools is really not all that mystifying. It is, as a matter of fact, the outcome of demographic changes.

The National Institutes of Health have, in effect, declared a ban on research involving live aborted human fetuses in this country.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had begun proceedings to remove District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens from office.

The First National City Corporation reported yesterday that its consolidated operating earnings in the first quarter jumped 25 per cent in a broadly based increase resulting about equally from operations overseas and in the United States.

Kentucky Derby nominee Hearts of Lettuce, owned by Tom Gentry of Lexington and William R. Eagan, was sold today for an undisclosed price. The purchaser was identified as Peter Tattersall, a Louisiana horseman.
After having survived a halfdozen productions of "Peter and the Wolf," one realizes that the music and the narrator are paramount, with cute costunning following behind.
The Toronto Maple Leafs, who finished a dismal sixth in the National Hockey League's East Division this season, failing to make the playoffs, announced today the resignation of Coach John McLellan.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir -- The Nehru family of Kashmiri Brahmins has already furnished India with two prime ministers and it is no accident that the second, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, should have adopted as her special hero Joan of Arc, about whom the first, Jawaharlal Nehru, wrote when he was a political prisoner of the British.

Sid Abel, a hockey Hall of Famer as a player who later gained extensive experience as a club executive, was named general manager today of the Kansas City team that will begin play in the National Hockey League in 1974.

Harry M. Jones, who made, in 1913, the first air parcel post flight from Boston to New York in 52 days - died Sunday in Tulsa, Okla., where he had been living since his retirement as an inspector for the Civil Aeronautics Administration. He was 82 years old.
Tin Song, the small daily newspaper that has often reflected the thinking of President Nguyen Van Thieu's Government, ceased publication today.
The 26 groundskeepers at Three Rivers Stadium went on strike today to back their demands for higher wages, a union spokesman said.

Elwood R. Quesada, former head of the Federal Aviation Agency and now a Washington realtor, was named by President Nixon today to be chairman of the board of directors of the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation.

Elton H. Rule, president of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., yesterday urged broadcasters not to allow any Presidential Administration to "bully" them into putting on bland news and entertainment programs in exchange for "license security."

Two former members of the staff of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens were indicted yesterday on charges of having failed to report on their Federal tax returns income of about $352,000 they made from an illegal get-rich-quick scheme.

Former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. was pictured today as a fugitive from a Federal grand jury that wanted to question him about his fund-raising activities for Governor Cahill's 1969 gubernatorial campaign.
After months of being at loggerheads over spending issues, Congress and the White House reached agreement today on major legislation that President Nixon had earlier threatened to .veto.
The Nixon Administration has decided not to appeal a court ruling that halted dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity, in the current fiscal year, The Washington Post said tonight.

Like Tom Seaver the day before, Jon Matlack allowed the Chicago Cubs only one run yesterday at Shea Stadium. But like Seaver, he saw the run defeat the New York Mets, 1-0, as the Mets' springtime slumber at home plate continued.

George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., accused the Teamsters today of a "vicious" and "disgraceful" campaign to wipe out the United Farm Workers Union and pledged an all-out battle by his federation to help "this small, struggling union."

The President did it his way. He did not stand in front of the cameras, bruised and embittered, apologizing about Watergate, saying he was misled by his subordinates or otherwise pushing an alibi. He neither submitted to cross-examination nor requested television time for a long explanation.

Form held up in the first round of the Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis championships last night. The boys' 18 and 16 divisions went into action, with the girls scheduled to start play today at Tennis 59, York Avenue and 59th Street.
With "The Orphan," which opened last night at the Anspacher Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater complex, David Rabe brings his "Vietnam trilogy" to completion.
Max Nomad, an anti-Czarist author, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical' Center. He was 92 years old and lived at 664 West 161st Street.

Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin ended an 18-month-old freeze on SovietBritish relations today by warmly receiving Peter Walker, the British Trade Minister, and sending a message of good wishes through him to Prime Minister Heath.

Burlington Northern, Inc., the country's longest railroad system, asked shareholders yesterday to authorize at the company's annual meeting May 10 a new class of preferred stock and to increase the authorized number of common shares to 25 million from 17.5 million.
The Vatican made a public overture today for a "dialogue" with Peking on the basis of Roman Catholic recognition that the thoughts of Chairman Mao Tsetung also reflected Christian values.
Long before President Nixon's energy message yesterday, energy had become a pressing political issue of national and international scope, a matter of concern and debate of "crisis" magnitude.

Form held up in the first round of the Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis championships last night. The boys' 18 and 16 divisions went into action, with the girls scheduled to start play today at Tennis 59, York Avenue and 59th Street.
The Knicks really rubbed it into the Celtics last night. Got even for what happened up in Boston on Sunday. Except they didn't. To hear them tll it.
The Public Broadcasting Service said today that it would provide live television coverage of the Senate hearings on the Watergate case.
Cambodia's chief of state, President Lon Nol, and two leading nonCommunist opposition figures appeared to be moving rapidly today toward collective leadership of this wartorn country.
Higher earnings were announced yesterday by the American Electric Power Company and the Commonwealth Edison Company, two of the nation's largest electric utilities, for the quarter ended March 31.
Sharply higher first-quarter earnings continued to be reported yesterday in the flurry of financial statements from companies all across the country in all kinds of businesses.

Following are excerpts from the President's energy message sent to Congress today: At home and abroad, America is in a time of transition. Old problems are yielding to new initiatives, but in their place new problems are arising which once again challenge our ingenuity and require vigorous action.

Ten Hackensack high School students were treated for cuts, scrapes, bruises and similar injuries at Morrisania Hospital after a bus carrying them home from the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., colided with another bus yesterday in their convoy on the Cross Brnox Expressway near Weeks Avenue.

Many breeders take as much pride in winning a specialty as an all-breed show. This school goes even a step further. It insists the specialty is more of a test and a victory helps to prove a breeding program is on the right trail.

The United States has been in a state of national emergency since 1933. This is not a flippant statement, but a matter of law discovered-to the astonishment of members of Congress as well as many in the executive and judiciary branches-by a special Senate committee investigating the powers of the Presidency.
As befitting her light, rather fragile soprano, Joy Kim offered a correspondingly light, rather fragile program of art songs in Tully Hall Tuesday night.

The University of Oklahoma forfeited eight of last season's 11 football victories, including a 14-0 Sugar Bowl triumph over Penn State, after it was disclosed yesterday that the high-school academic ktranscript of Kerry Jackson, a freshman quarterback, had been altered. The games forfeited were those in which Jackson played.

Dr. Max Jacobson, whose hearings before the New York State Board for Medicine began yesterday, has been charged, among other things, with giving himself depressant and stimulant drugs for nonmedical purposes and with failing to oversee the use of such drugs by his patients and employes.

One of the paradoxes of tournament bridge is that a team is not really a teamit consist of two pairs, or three pairs. This can be avoided by a requirement that partnerships should rotate, so that each player must play with each of his teammates in turn.
An attempt by the Northern States Power Company to prevent a consumer spokesman from being elected to the utility's board was debated for four and a half hours today in Minneapolis Federal Court.

The secret police campaign against the Chronicle of Current Events, the main underground dissident journal here, has reportedly drawn a confession of involvement from Irina Yakir, a member of a prominent dissident family.

The Long Island Rail Road and 12 nonoperating unions reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday and averted the possible resumption of a strike that could have come one minute after midnight tomorrow.
The Department of Consumer Affairs has issued a new booklet, "Do's and Dont's for Senior Consumers," giving tips on how to save money shopping.

The Renault auto works were half paralyzed today by intensified work stoppages reflecting continued social tensions five weeks after the Gaullist election victory and nearly five years after the student-worker revolt of May and June, 1968.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. declared here today that the Senate committee investigating the Watergate conspiracy would be the final judge on whether a White House aide could refuse to answer any of the committee's questions.
As badly as the Boston Celtics whipped the New York Knicks in Boston last Sunday, so did the Knicks thoroughly Crush the Celtics at Madison Square Garden last night, by a 129-96 score.

Raising questions about potential health hazards to humans, the Food and Drug Administration today gave pharmaceutical companies two years to prove the safety of antibacterial drugs used in animal feeds.

The internal Revenue Service says that late-filing taxpayers will have to wait at least six to seven weeks before any refund checks duo them are mailed.
A tornado touched down near here late today, injuring at least 14 persons, the authorities said. The twister overturned a number of mobile homes, toppled power lines and uprooted trees.

President Nixon's striking statement about the Watergate case yesterday was in keeping with his reliance on bold action in the face of crists. By taking the counteroffensive his associates in the White house believe, he hopes to show that he sinned not but was sinned against, to portray himself as the prosecutor and not the protector of those to be prosecuted.
The Right Rev. Dr. Albert Rhett Stuart, who retired last year as Episcopal Bishop of Georgia, died in a hospital here today. He was 67 years old and lived at 611 East Bay Street.

Acting Interior Secretary John C. Whitaker told Congress today that the Administration was willing to accept almost any bill that would clear the way for immediate construction of the transAlaska oil pipeline.

Under pressure from its Players Association and a multimillion-dollar antitrust suit, the National Hockey League yesterday repudiated the secret merger talks held recently between some N.H.L. and World Hockey Association owners.
Hayden, Stone Inc., a large brokerage and investment-bank ing firm, said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire H. Hentz Co., Inc.

Bobby Seale, the Black Panther leader, showed surprising strength at the polls yesterday and qualified for a runoff election in his bid to become Mayor of Oakland.

Carl Stokes, former Cleveland Mayor turned television newsman, will lose his co-anchorman on WNBC-TV here. He will remain as an anchorman on the National Broadcasting Company's local 6 P.M. news show, and Paul Udell, his partner, will become an N.B.C. correspondent and may be assigned to Vietnam.

The Carolina Cougars, breezing along on a 32-point performance by Billy Cunningham, overwhelmed the Kentucky Colonels, 102-91, tonight and tied the American Basketball Association Eastern Division final playoff series, 2-2.
Public television plans to provide complete "gavel-to-gavel" coverage of forthcoming Senate hearings into the Watergate bugging allegation, it was announced here yesterday.

Representative Mario Biaggi, a front-running candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, has repeatedly asserted that he answered every question put to him in a recent grand jury investigation of immigration matters. The grand jury's term has ended with no indictments, but reports have persisted that, while under interrogation before the panel, Mr. Biaggi invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination to refuse answers to as many as thirty questions about his personal finances.

A warrant was issued today for the arrest of Edward Krock, a multimillionaire and former officer of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, in New York City, after he failed to appear in Federal District Court here to be arraigned on charges of violating the Federal income tax law.

President Nixon and Premier Giulio Andreotti of Italy completed two days of talks today on East-West relations and ways to overcome problems between Western Europe and the United States. They also discussed the Middle East crisis-heightened recently by Arab terrorist attacks against Israeli diplomats and Israel's military strikes into Lebanon-and voiced hope that the earliest possible progress could be made toward a settlement.

President Nixon, arguing that he was making progress in getting the Soviet Union to relax its controversial exit tax for emigrants, sought to prevail upon a group of Senators today not to impose restrictions on future Soviet trade.

The city's Commissioner of Air Resources, Fred C. Hart, has reversed his earlier stand about New York City's ability and need to meet clean-air standards by 1975. He said yesterday that he agreed with Governor Rockefeller that the city needed more time to clean up.

A record $5,360.20 big triple payoff was registered tonight at Roosevelt Raceway when the 10-9-1 combination in the feature race was posted on the board. The previous high was $4,900 on Sept. 11, 1971.

Howard B. Levy, six years ago were so vague as to be unconstitutional.

Heads of governments of seven South Pacific nations meeting in this picturesque tropical capital drew up a stiff protest today against tests of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, especially those by France over South Pacific waters.

The National Association for theAdvancementof Colored People proposed plans in Federal court today to bus 57,563 Memphis public school children next fall. The move came one day after a school was closed by racial violence over busing.

DETROIT, April 18 (Reuters)--The Chrysler Corporation said today that if Congress accepted suggestions that it relax nitrogen oxide pollution standards for cars, the prospects for the gas turbine engine would increase.

Mayor Richard J. Daley's Cook County Democratic organization demonstrated last night - that it could still get out enough voters in a special primary election, even in a predominantly black district, to sweep a candidate to victory.

International Because of Washington's irritation over Poland's performance on the Vietnam ceasefire commission, the State Department yesterday told Warsaw to postpone plans by Deputy Premier Jan Mitrega to visit the United States.

One of the F.B.I.'s 10 mostwanted men was killed yesterday and his two alleged accomplices were captured after the attempted holdup of a Harlem bank in which 32 customers and 10 employes were held hostage for nearly two hours.

International Because of Washington's irritation over Poland's performance on the Vietnam ceasefire commission, the State Department yesterday told Warsaw to postpone plans by Deputy Premier Jan Mitrega to visit the United States.

Daniel Ellsberg completed his testimony in the Pentagon papers trial today, telling the jury that the documents contained 1,000 pages depicting American war crimes and illegal actions -- not by the troops in Vietnam, but by high Government officials.

Goodman Pollak carried 27 raw eggs to the Passover seder her mother-in-law held this week. The eggs were not a contribution to the menu; they were ornately decorated "place cards" that Mrs. Pollak's class made at Westhill High School here.
After months of being at loggerheads over spending issues, Congress and the White House reached agreement today on major legislation that President Nixon had earlier threatened to veto.

The members of the Security Council, consulting behind closed doors, tried today to formulate a resolution on the Lebanese complaint that resuited from last week's Israeli commando raid in Beirut and its suburbs.

Fighting in South Vietnam remained at a relatively low level today, with the military command here reporting a rise in Communist violations of the cease-fire from yesterday, but no significant attacks.

This year, New Yorkers again will be treated to the city's annual ridTimes-Square-of-undesirables summer festival. If history is any guide, this clean-up will eliminate only the most visible allurements of vice-thestreetwalker--for a few months at best.

The manager of Representative Mario Biaggi's mayoral campaign urged him yesterday to request the release of his testimony before a Federal grand jury and thus support Mr. Biaggi's assertion that had not invoked the Fifth Amendment.

A 23-year-old nurse at Trenton State Prison has received plaudits from inmates for rushing to the aid of a prisoner who suffered an epileptic seizure in a cell block last week. Phyllis Ann Salvatore, described by one inmate as "a modern Joan of Arc, a dear lady in white," had to break prison regulations to aid the prisoner.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18--The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit declared today that two key provisions of the Uniform Code of Military Justice that led to the court-martial conviction of an antiwar Army physician, Capt. Howard B. Levy, six...
Bill Shoemaker, enjoying his finest day since recovering from a broken hand, rode four winners-including three in a row-at Hollywood Park today.
Bond prices continued to erode yesterday, pushing interest rates higher, as the market adjusted to what seemed waning hopes of immediate action to tighten economic controls.

The Consolidated Edison Company is expected to receive authority today from the Atomic Energy Commission to start operating its $200-million Indian Point No. 2 nuclear power plant on a limited capacity.
After fairly optimistic economic news in recent weeks, the British Government found itself in gloom today over the prospect of serious balance-of-payments problems.

The secretary general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party proposed today that a top-level meeting of the leaders of Japan, the United States, Britain, France and West Germany be called to resolve the continuing monetary issue.

Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has disqualified himself from further involvement in the Watergate investigation, sources close to the case said today, amid persistent reports that three or more of his present and former colleagues in the Nixon Administration would be indicted.

An Albany County grand jury said today that two Assemblymen acted in a "boisterous and obscene manner during the administration of free heart tests by a 20-year-old female technician at the Albany Medical Center last Feb. 27.

Blue Cross of New York has announced that it will disoontinue payment for open-heart surgery at five hospitals in Brooklyn and Nassau County whose programs have not been approved by the State Department of Health.

One of the F.B.I.'s 10 mostwanted men was killed yesterday and his two alleged accomplices were captured after the attempted holdup of a Harlem bank in which 32 customers and 10 employes were held hostage for nearly two hours.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter finished slightly lower yesterday in slow trading. Brokers attributed the indifferent performance to the rise in the prime rate by several major banks on Tuesday and continued investor concern over the growing inflationary trend.

The Office of Revenue Sharing asked 38,000 local and state governments today to tell how they are spending their revenue -sharing funds. It mailed out report forms to the various jurisdictions and said they must be returned by June 20.

" Sisters, sisters, there were never such devoted sisters," or so the song goes. But in their case, it isn't just a song, insist Marisa and Berry Berenson, the current Big Two sisters in the frenetic New York society-fashionshow business crowd. It's true.

The National Basketball Association owners, after nine hours of wrestling with the john Brisker-Philadelphia 76ersSeattle Supersonics triangle, came up with an intricate solution last night.

George Miller, a 31-year-old mathematics teacher at Park Junior High here, has added a new dimension to New Jersey track and field in the last 18 months. His junior distance running program, run in cooperation with the Union County Park Commission, provides almost weekly competition for the 12 to 15-year-old set during the present school year. And it has probably uncovered some future stars.
Jim Colbert, who says his concept of golf differs from other professionals, scored a six-under-par 66 to lead the $200,000 Tournament of Champions by one stroke today.

Yet another country music concert, the commercial Nashville kind, and yet another cable from Mayor Lindsay read from the stage at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday. It seems nobody can sit down at a pedal steel guitar these days without getting congratulations from Gracie Mansion.

Federal officials and the State of New Hampshire have taken the first step toward what is designed to be the nation's first major experiment involving children in private and parochial schools in the "voucher system" of education.
An 83-year-old man with the appearance of a vagrant was picked up on a park bench in Greenwich Village last night for public drunkenness and disorderly conduct, the police reported.

A 13-year-old boy was killed in crossfire tonight after a British Army patrol was ambushed. Gunmen who had attacked the patrol in the Roman Catholic Ardoyne district of Belfast poured their fire into a military observation post.
JAZZ POP UPS However it turns out, it promises to be different-the jazz show coming up at 8 tonight in Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 32d Street, (564-4400).

The stock market turned in a solid advance yesterday on rising volume ahead of the Good Friday holiday in Wall Street. The Dow-Jones industrial average was higher throughout the session and closed up 4.89 points at 963.20.

Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., added a third-seeded player to his list of victims in the $50,000 South African tennis tournament today by beating Bob Lutz, 6-1, 5-7, 7-6, in the quarterfinals.

Common Cause and the Democratic National Committee said today they would not settle their civil suits against the Republicans, holding them instead as a weapon for investigating the Republican party's finances and the Watergate break-in.

Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., added a third-seeded player to his list of victims in the $50,000 South African tennis tounrament today by beating Bob Lutz, 6-1, 5-7, 7-6, in the quarterfinals.

Redemptions of mutual fund shares topped sales by only $12-million in March, compared with $203.8-million in February, the Investment Company Institute, the national association of the industry, said today.
Several ousted residents of Wounded Knee, angered by the Government's hesitancy to evict insurgents from the village, have threatened to take up arms themselves.
The Connecticut Senate voted narrowly today to restore the death penalty for six types of crime, including the sale of hard drugs by a nonaddicted person to another who dies because of them.
Miklos Laszlo, Hungarian playwright whose plays were made into successful Hollywood films, died yesterday of emphysema at his home, 31-74 29th Street, in Astoria, Queens. He was 69 years old.

Members of the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association went on strike tonight against Ozark Air Lines. The walkout, effective at 8 P.M. Eastern standard time, was called after contract negotiations collapsed.
Governor Rockefeller, citing disastrous and costly effects of several recent strikes here, suggested yesterday that voluntary arbitration was a better way to resolve deadlocks in negotiations.

President Nixon sent to Congress today a proposal for a $2.3-billion-a-year program for locally controlled urban development, designed to replace a number of similar programs administered by the Federal Government.

Officials of the Office of Economic Opportunity have begun a detailed review of all programs funded by the agency after an unannounced decision not to appeal a court ruling last week that declared "illegal" previous efforts to dismantle the operation.

The House of Representatives voted today to bar 90 per cent Federal funding for approaches to the proposed Rye-Oyster Bay bridge unless the bridge project is approved by the legislatures of both New York and Connecticut.
Purists may gripe and broadcasters may groan, but entertainers will help broadcast most of the National Broadcasting Company's 13 televised baseball games this season.

Angry residents of Greenwich Village disrupted a meeting of their community board last night, forcing it to adjourn before voting on the issue of the evening-whether to retain a "dog run" on a local vacant lot or replace it with a basketball court.

For today, Good Friday, the following is a list of services that are or are not affected: Stock Exchanges--Closed. Parking--Alternate side-of-the-street rules suspended. Public and Parochial Schools--Closed.

Two teen-agers were hospitalized yesterday after being wounded in separate subway shooting incidents. One was a 14-year-old boy shot by transit policemen after he was alleged to have held up a change agent in a Bronx elevated station.

The United States announced today the suspension of all mine-clearing operations along the coast of North Vietnam and the recall of the chief American official in the Paris negotiations on possible reconstruction aid to the North.
South Africa's attempt to project a favorable international image through a recent two-week sports spectacular was a failure; a prominent black American sports official said yesterday.
Nebraska has reinstated the death penalty for the crimes of premeditated murder, killing in the course of rape, arson, robbery, kidnapping, hijacking and burglary.

A missing piece of tape for a dust cover forced at least a 24-hour postponement tonight in the launching of Canada's second national communications satellite. The launching of Anik 2 was stopped seven minutes before the scheduled 6:30 P.M.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has told friends that he was aware of proposals to bug the Democratic opposition, and that he participated in three meetings at which these proposals were discussed. But he insists that he rejected the scheme on each occasion.

Even after the courts and the Senate have passed judgment in the Watergate case, we will still not know what happened here unless we understand the mood and assumptions of the Administration in which these bizarre events occurred.

By most measures, the Aluminum Company of America achieved a record first quarter, John D. Harper, chairman and chief executive officer, told 335 stockholders at the annual meeting here today. Only earnings, which topped the comparable 1972 period, failed to reach a new high.

The railroad industry said today that it planned to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a 5 percent freight-rate increase. The 402 lines said in a petition to be filed tomorrow that no increase in net operating income was expected to result from the proposal because "the expected revenue yield is far short of the increased costs already experienced."

Federico Chavez, 22-year- old nephew of the United Farm Workers Union leader, Cesar Chavez, was among 135 persons arrested today in connection with further alleged illegal picketing at the Coachella Valley's largest grape vineyard.

Michigan State's first football season under the inspired direction of Duffy Daugherty began with a defeat by Iowa, which came from behind in the closing minutes to make It 14-10. The next game, against Wisconsin, was scoreless until the last few seconds of the first half. Then a Wisconsin play was piled up on the sideline, where the bandsmen were assembling for their half-time didoes. s.

About 130 uniformed welfare guards walked off the job and picketed the offices of the Human Resources Administration yesterday, demanding the right to carry guns, after a guard was shot outside a juvenile home in Brooklyn.

Tree of Knowledge performed to the satisfaction of his trainer, Sid Watters Jr., in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The Pin Oak Stable's colt, flashing steady speed, took the 6 1/2-furlong sprint by 1 1/2-lengths from Edgar Zantker's Sell, who had three-quarters of a length over Dawn Flight.

In the Niles Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon Miss Joan Gale Aller, a financial analyst with Management Planning, Inc., was married to Charles Richard Smith, an independent insurance broker.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today in his annual foreign policy report that the United States would press in coming months to persuade the Israelis and Arab states to begin "a genuine negotiating process."

The curtain was 15 minutes late last night for the musical "Irene," but the audience, which had been growing restless, responded with a standing ovation for the late guest, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, the President's widow.

Six players tied for the first-round lead in the Tallahassee open golf championship today with four-under-par 68's. Rocky Thompson, Terry Wilcox, Dave Eichelberger, Mike Wynn, Dick Crawford, and Gary Groh were the leaders over Killearn County Club's 7,124-yard layout.

It was thirty years ago yesterday that the German troops in Warsaw launched their attack against the city's ghetto. The plan was for a three-day operation which would end with all the Warsaw Jews dead or on their way to extermination camps. But the Jews surprised their Nazi murderers by refusing to go quietly to their destruction. They fought back with the desperation of people deprived of everything but their humanity.
The Atchafalaya river swept into the Gulf of Mexico at Morgan City today, several feet higher than downtown streets and held back only by a concrete wall topped with a plywood and mud barricade.

New quarterly records in sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Weyerhaeuser Company, a major producer of forest products.
A fifth cadet at the United States Military Academy at West Point has been found guilty of violating the honor code in an investigation of cheating being carried out by the cadet honor committee.
F. Edward Biertuempfel, who was Mayor here since 1939, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 78 years old and had been in poor health for several years.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

Having traded Sunday punches in such awesome but bewildering manner, the New York Knicks and Boston Celtics will resume their National Basketball Association playoff series tomorrow night at 8:10, with the eventual outcome no easier to predict than before the series began.
A fare increase next year for Long Island Rail Road riders seemed virtually certain yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's tentative agreement between the railroad and its 12 non-operating unions.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has told friends that he was aware of proposals to bug the Democratic opposition, and that he participated in three meetings at which these proposals were discussed. But he insists that he rejected the scheme on each occasion.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has confirmed for the first time, in conversations with friends, that he discussed bugging the Democratic opposition with other Nixon Administration aides. But he has said that he told them not to go through with it. .

The police in Atlantic City say they have smashed a mail-order prostitution ring in which conventioneers were invited to join a "swingers' club." Five women accused of being members of the ring were arrested at a hotel, and the alleged ringleader was arrested in his car shortly after dropping off the women at the hotel. He was identified as Louis Giannini, 54 years old. .
The British and French submitted a resolution to the Security Council today that condemned Israeli attacks against Lebanon, but did not condemn the Arab terrorist attacks that touched them off.

United States bombers rain death on Cambodia, South Vietnamese troops sally across the Cambodian border, American bombers strike intermittently in Laos--it has all the aspect of the rerun of a bad movie. And yet, thus far the American public seems largely unconcerned about this repetition of the sordid history of United States escalation in Indochina.

Things may change later on this baseball season, but for the nonce the Detroit Tigers own the Boston Red Sox. Yesterday in Fenway Park the Tigers crushed Boston, 11-7, on a 16-hit barrage and swept the four-game series.
A near-riot at Carnegie Hall last night threatened to break up the concert of zarzuela music given by Montserrat Caballe, the Spanish soprano, and her husband Bernabe Marti, the tenor.

Governor Rockefeller's staff was reported yesterday to have begun preparation of charges that will be given to District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens in connection with the Governor's previously announced decision to initiate removal proceedings against Mr. Mackell.

John S. Marshall pleaded guilty today in the Jan. 30 robbery-shooting of Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, the Justice Department said. Mr. Marshall, 21 years old, arrested with two others on March 13,
Suddenly quieting a raucous Madison Square Garden crowd by scoring two late goals, the Chicago Black Hawks again stunned the Rangers last night with a 3-1 decision.

Soybean and soybean-meal futures in the near months rose sharply again yesterday, with soybean meal advancing the limit of $5 a ton and soybean futures up 11 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean oil futures prices increased 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

Two thousand people gathered at Dag Hammarskold Plaza yesterday to hear tributes to the Jews who lived and died in the Warsaw ghetto 30 years ago. The observance commemorated the uprising in the ghetto against the Nazi occupiers on April 19, 1943.

The refusal by the House of Representatives to allow a mere 10 per cent of the $7 billion available annually in Highway Trust funds to be spent on urban mass transit is a heavy blow to urban survival. The combined power of the highway lobby of truckers and construction interests and of the anti-urban rural forces succeeded in denying some relief to cities poisoned by exhaust fumes and immobilized by collapsing transportation systems.
Dr. Hans Kelsen, a legal scholar and an authority on international law and jurisprudence, died today of cardiac arrest. He was 91 years old.

William D. Eberle, the President's special representative for trade negotiations, expressed optimism yesterday for progress on both reducing the United States's deficit this year and attaining "a balanced and equitable" world trading system.

The House of Representatives voted today to bar 90 per cent Federal funding for approaches to the proposed Rye-Oyster Bay bridge unless the bridge project is approved by the legislatures of both New York and Connecticut.

The Indiana Pacers survived a 34-point effort by Utah's Willie Wise and defeated the Stars, 104-102, tonight in the fifth game of their American Basketball Association West Division playoff final.
Efficiently but without any effervescence, the Montreal Canadiens recorded a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight for a 2-1 advantage in their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff.

Military planners expect that the strategic interests of the United States and global strategy in general will pivot on the Persian Gulf late in this decade as a result of competition for the area's oil.

Two prominent Republican leaders with close ties to the Cahill administration were indicted today on bribery charges involving an alleged conspiracy to have $6-million in state funds controlled by former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. illegally deposited in a local bank.
A plainclothesman shot and seriously wounded a narcotic suspect in Greenwich Village last night when the suspect threatened the patrolman with a gun, the police reported.
A widow and her four young children were killed today when their small foreign car plunged into a dry river bed west of. here, the Arizona Highway Patrol said.

It's been three months now since Jerry Riccio broke the siege of John and Al's sporting goods store by leading eight people in a daring escape from the four gunmen who had kept them hostage for two days.
New Jersey's Insurance Department today ordered a 10 per cent reduction in the rates paid by 1.3 million subscribers to the state's Blue Shield plan.

A City Council committee has scheduled a closed meeting for next Friday to vote on a long-delayed and controversial bill that would outlaw discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations.

Common Cause and the Democratic National Committee said today they would not settle their civil suits against the Republicans, holding them instead as a weapon for investigating the Republican party's finances and the Watergate break-in.
A team of jolly Chinese giants amazed a Paris basketball crowd last night by playing Florence Nightingale to their flustered opponents.
"The Waltons," a low-keyed series about a family in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia during the Depression, took top honors in the nominations for the 25th Television Academy Awards today.
Porfirio Salinas, a favorite artist of President Lyndon B. Johnson, died last evening of a liver ailment. He was 62 years old. He leaves his wife, Maria, and a daughter.
The White House abandoned today all show of support for the embattled Presidential counsel, John W. Dean 3d, who has been accused of complicity in the Watergate case.

In the Niles Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon Miss Joan Gale Aller, a financial analyst with Management Planning, Inc., was married to Charles Richard Smith, an independent insurance broker.
Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. rested their defense today in the Pentagon papers trial, and the Government immediately started its rebuttal case.

Unconfirmed reports were circulating in Wall Street late yesterday that two major brokerage houses-duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., and Walston Co., Inc.-were exploring the possibilities of some form of combination.

Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Mrs. Lee B. Goodwin as acting chairman of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, replacing Charles J. Urstadt, who had held the position since Jan. 16, 1969.
Representative Mario Biaggi's press secretary said yesterday that a Federal grand jury had questioned Mr. Biaggi not about his personal finances but about "the finances of the Beame 1965 campaign."

The Tanzanian government appealed today to Tanzanians not to throw stones at drivers in the East African safari motor 'rally, which started today in Nairobi, Kenya. The government also asked citizens not to mislead the drivers about the Safari route.

Robert C. Durham, president of Durham, Reid Durham, financial consultants, died Tuesday of acute gastritis at his home, 1009 Park Avenue. He was 58 years old.
Edwin C. Wood, an organizer and a former manager of the Wood Regan Instrument Company of Nutley, N. J., died yesterday. He was 83 years old and lived in Whiting.

The sands of Jones Beach and nearly two miles of the best recreational beaches in the New York region are in imminent danger of destruction, the head of the Army Corps of Engineers for the New York region said yesterday, necessitating a program that it is hoped will rebuild the areas this summer.

Normally when a child comes to see his mother at the state prison for women here, they have to sit in a stuffy visiting room, separated from each other by a wide table. When the time comes to say good-by, they are limited to a "short embrace."

The American Basketball Association played follow the leader yesterday as, for the second time, it postponed its college draft following similar action by the National Basketball Association.

Royal and Regal scored a narrow victory over Cari County in the seven-furlong Forerunner Purse at Keeneland today. Tuning up for the Kentucky Derby on May 5, Royal and Regal ran head and head with Carl County the entire race and won by a nose.

William J. Kennedy, president of Pressmen's Union No. 2, said yesterday that non-economic issues had been resolved in contract negotiations with The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times.

A proposal for a Bergen County Athletic Commission to monitor league alignments and act as a coordinating agency for minor sports, officiating, and other interscholastic activities is finding broad-based support among school and athletic administrators throughout the county. .

ADAMS-Albion H., 89 years of age, died Friday, April 13, at the Lincoln Lutheran Home, Racine, Wisc. His survivors Include many friends. Mr. Adams was a retired executive secretary of tile Oratorio Society of New York and had also served as Manager of the Chautauqua Opera Co. Services were held at St. Johns Episcopal Chapel-DeKoven Foundation, Racine.

Charles Rutenberg, president of the U.S. Home Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chairman. Last week, Robert Winnerman sold his entire holdings of 394,000 common shares of the company and resigned as chairman.

Five years ago, a New Yorker could scarcely utter the words "community control" in public without touching off an argument. But now community control-or decentralization, as legislators refer to it-is a legitimate if still controversial part of the city's education system.

William Murphy, a 58-year-old international vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association and a powerful New Jersey waterfront figwas in critical condition today after being shot in what a police official called "a rub-out attempt."

James Louis Robertson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and a member for 21 years, disclosed yesterday that he would resign by the end of this month. The senior member of the board with a term expiring in 1978, Mr. Robertson will leave at the age of 65 after 46 years of Government service.

President Tito and Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, meeting at this resort island in the Adriatic, agreed today to settle the 28-year-old problem of indemnification for World War II damage to Yugoslavia by adopting a program of long-term economic cooperation.
Highly favorable first-quarter profit results continued yesterday to pour from the company headquarters of a widely diversified group of industries around the nation.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market made slight advances yesterday to break their four-session losing streak. Brokers attributed the upswing mostly to technical factors including some bargain hunting. The securities markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday.

About 130 uniformed welfare guards walked off the job and picketed the offices of the Human Resources Administration yesterday, demanding the right to carry guns, after a guard was shot outside a juvenile home in Brooklyn.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has uncovered a massive counterfeit securities operation that is connected to the Equity Funding Corporation of America fraud case, according to informed sources close to the investigation.

The man whom former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has retained as counsel, William G. Hundley, has 22 years of experience in criminal law, the first 15 as a hard-nosed Justice Department prosecutor and the last seven as an effective Washington defense lawyer.

The nation's output continued to rise at the abnormal rate of about 8 per cent in the first quarter of this year and the rate of inflation doubled from from that of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Raymond F. Waters, assistant picture assignment editor of the Daily News in New York, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 21 Mary knoll Road. He was 60 years old.
Mrs. Gertrude Kingsbacher Sunstein, for many years an educator and civic worker, died at St. Mary's Hospital today. She was 85 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.
The British and French submitted a resolution to the Security Council today that condemned Israeli attacks against Lebanon, but did not condemn the Arab terrorist attacks that touched them off.

Pepsi-Cola was officially signed on today as the first American consumer product for sale in the Soviet Union. But how much Pepsi Ivan Ivanov gets will depend on how much Soviet vodka John Jones consumes.

Ricky Meyer, Mike Grant and Peter Fleming, top metropolitan players, won second-round matches in the 18's division at the Tennis 59 courts. In an upset Sheila Mclnerny of Rome, N.Y., seeded third in the girls' 16's.
The United States Merchant Marine Academy won the varsity and the junior varsity eight-oared races yesterday in the Easter Regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Orchard Beach Lagoon.

David Storey's five published novels and five produced plays-his first novel was "This Sporting Life," and his latest play, "The Changing Room," is now having a successful run on Broadway-have made him, at 39, one of England's most highly regarded young writers.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has confirmed for the first time, in conversations with friends, that he discussed bugging the Democratic opposition with other Nixon Administration aides. But he has said that he told them not to go through with it. .

To the surprise of virtually no one, Bob McAdoo of the Buffalo Braves was named the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year yesterday. He will receive $500 and a trophy from Walter Kennedy, the commissioner, who announced the result of the voting.

Former Gov. Otto Kerner was sentenced today to serve three years in Federal prison and pay a fine of $50,000.
