Dr. J. William Hinton, a heart specialist and former director of surgery at Post Graduate Hospital, died Wednesday at his home, 1520 York Avenue. His age was 78.

The head of the gravediggers' union said yesterday that he had disregarded a subpoena that called for his appearance before a state board of inquiry that was investigating the dispute between his union and owners of 47 cemeteries in the metropolitan area.
Food prices in the metropolitan area continued their precipitous climb in March, contributing to the biggest monthly increase in the Consumer Price Index in 21 years--I per cent seasonally adjusted.

A 5.5 per cent increase in the pay rates of city employes who are not covered by collective bargaining contracts was announced yesterday by Harry I. Bronstein, chairman of the City Civil Service Commission. .

The Securities and Exchange Commission directed registered companies today to Include in registration and reporting forms information showing any material effects of compliance with environmental-protection laws on their expenditures, earnings and competitive position.

The Security Council agreed today to have the Secretary General submit a comprehensive report on the Middle East situation. But it ran into a series of complicated snags in its efforts to avert a United States veto for a resolution that would have condemned the Israeli commando raid into Lebanon without equally condemning Palestinian terrorist attacks.

Cued in by sprouting Long Island buds, the "Ice Follies" company is back a year later, swarming all over the rink of the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum. The huge arena's first tenants will perform through April 29, and more power to them. Why? Simply because they've got what it takes on ice, and they sock it over so warmly.

Two rubber-suited frogmen swam through the murky waters of Brooklyn's Erie Basin yesterday and retrived some 28 pounds of heroin and cocaine lowered by accomplices from the deck of a Chilean freighter.

Essex International, Inc., reported yesterday that in the first quarter of this year it had record net earnings of $10.9-million, equal to 60 cents a share, an increase of 20 per cent from $8.9-million, or 50 cents a share, in the 1972 period.

Josephine Schain, a former lecturer on international affairs and long a leader in women's rights and peace activities, died Wednesday in the Peabody Home, 1000 Pelham Parkway South, the Bronx. She was 88 years old.
Perhaps for the first time since he charged onto the Ranger scene 10 years ago, there was a plaintive quality to Coach Emile Francis yesterday as he said:
The Rev. Gerard Rooney, director of the department of education of the Diocese of Worcester, died today at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old.

Gov. Mike O'Callaghan signed today a measure making Nevada the first state to allow acupuncture to be practiced without supervision by licensed United States physicians. The new law to permit such practice of the ancient Chinese healing art had been opposed by Nevada medical groups.
Representative Herman Badillo condemned yesterday as "a naked power grab" Governor Rockefeller's proposal to give the Governor authority to appoint half of the Board of Higher Education.

Dr. Derrick T. Vail, an eye specialist and former president of the American Academy of Ophthalmology, died Wednesday in London, where he had gone for a medical meeting. He was 74 years old and lived here.

TEHERAN-Shah Mohammed Riza is convinced he has managed to impose on Iran a revolution from the top, by imperial decree, and that as a result this country has left the category of developing lands and will be at a "European" level in a decade.

Despite a two-hit pitching perfonnance by Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees bowed to Milwaukec, 2-0, tonight in a tight pitching duel in which no New York player reached third and no Brewer got on base until the sixth inning.
Led by another big jump in food prices, the Consumer Price Index rose last month by the largest amount for a month since the Korean War inflation of 1951, the Labor Department reported today.

A syndicate has agreed to buy the New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association for about $1.5-million, and the man who arranged the marriage said yesterday: "Money is no object. We want to fill Madison Square Garden and erase the stench of what happened last year."
Led by another big jump in food prices, the Consumer Price Index rose last month by the largest amount for a month since the Korean War inflation of 1951, the Labor Department reported today.
Food prices in the metropolitan area continued their precipitous climb in March, contributing to the biggest monthly increase in the Consumer Price Index in 21 years -1 per cent seasonally adjusted.

Common Cause, the citizens lobbying group, accused Representative James R. Grover Jr., Republican of Long Island, of contributing to the defeat yesterday of his own amendment that would have allowed cities to use highway trust funds for urban mass transit.
Herbert Stein, the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, asserted here yesterday that there was no need to return to a freeze on prices.

In an interoffice memorandum earlier this year, Howard Phillips, acting director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, set forth his intention to dismantle the agency before Congress had a chance to stop him. Congress has not yet acted on this irregular and irresponsible assertion of power, but a court has.
Peter Lazarus Paniloo, a 35-year-old Eskimo who grew up in a drafty sod house covered with snow, sat in his warm modern kitchen the other day, sipping tea and playing with his infant son.

A compelling new reason has arisen for Representative Mario Biaggi to clear up definitively the issue of fact on whether he did or did not refuse to answer questions about his personal finances in a recent grand jury investigation of immigration matters, and whether he did or did not at that time invoke his constitutional right to protection against self-incrimination under the Fifth Amendment.

An Air Force Phantom jet was reported missing in Cambodia by the United States Pacific command today. The command said that the plane had been participating in raids in Cambodia Wednesday when it disappeared.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 20--Official American sources here said today that since the Vietnam cease - fire three months ago, there has been no documented evidence that Vietnamese Communist troops are serving in combat roles in Cambodia.
The Queen Elizabeth 2 steamed into Israeli waters early today, her worries over possible Arab guerrilla attacks eclipsed by last-minute rabbinical criticism of her docking on the Jewish sabbath.
Dr. Henri Rolin, international jurist, died of a heart ailment in Paris today. His age was 81. Dr. Rolin, born in Ghent, became a Belgian Senator in 1932. He left the Senate in 1968.

PARIS, April 20--The European Common Market, which consumes more than 10 percent of the energy produced in the world and itself produces only 5 per cent, is in the throes of defining policies that would assure its supplies.

The Ayer School Committee has closed its schools to 2,300 pupils who reside at Fort Devens near here in an effort to force the Nixon Administration to release more impact-aid funds to school districts near Federal installations.

John W. Dean 3d, the White House Counsel, supervised cash payments of more than $175,000 in Republican campaign funds to the seven Watergate defendants and their lawyers after the bugging of the Democratic headquarters in June, 1972, sources close to the case reported today.

Thirty-five members of the Loyola Christian Life Community and their families reverently, but informally, marked the 14 solemn Stations of the Cross here today on a grassy hillside under a cloudless Good Friday sky.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges this week issued their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by major shareowners, directors and officers of their listed companies.

As it has for the last two months, the brownstone at 331 West 84th Street came to life at 4 A.M. Amparo Vasquez, who has spent most of her 62 years getting up early to pick lettuce and onions in the California fields, was the first one to rise.

New orders for durable goods increased $900-million, or 2.2 per cent, during March in what economists said was a good, but not a spectacular, increase. The increase in new orders was primarily because of an increase of $730-million in primary-metals investors, especially steel, Commerce Department economists said today.

The Federal Reserve Board approved today an increase in the discount rate from 5 1/2 per cent to 5 3/4 per cent. The increase was approved initially for seven of the 12 Federal Reserve Banks, to take effect Monday. The five other banks, judging by past experience, will shortly follow.

The European Economic Community's new trade agreement with Norway is distinctly less generous than the agreements that the bloc negotiated last year with Sweden and other members of the European Free Trade Association.

Public officials concerned with the community-school-board elections expressed varying degrees of alarm yesterday over the possibility that the elections--now scheduled for May 1--might have to be postponed.

The members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have formed a cartel whose take last year was about $16 billion. A conservative estimate for 1980 is $80 billion, $30 billion from this country alone; about $360 billion cumulative in nine years.

There women and a soldier were shot and wounded today when a British Army patrol came under fire in Belfast. They were hit when at least one gunman fired three times as the troops patrolled in the Roman Catholic district of New Lodge, an army spokesman said.

A long time after swapping Manhattan for the legendary $24 worth of trinkets, American Indians are making a new hit as local traders thanks to a boom in the popularity of their jewelry and other handmade items.
Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

The Soviet Union has shipped about 40 MIG jet fighters to Syria since January, Pentagon sources report. About 30 of the planes are said to be MIG-21'S, rated as first-class fighters.
Manhattan, the only metropolitan school ever to win a national collegiate track and field title, will try to put the competitive pieces into place again today at the 19th annual Queens-Iona Relays.
The South Vietnamese Navy has apprehended a Thai fishing boat carrying from two to three tons of narcotics, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

Volume Merchandise, Inc., announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its drug division to the Adams Drug Company, Inc., of Pawtucket, R. I. New Jersey, the only state of the 50 without a VHF television station, will have its own four-station UHF network in six weeks. With the expected spread of CATV franchises throughout the state, the network could well become a viable alternative to the commercial New York and Philadelphia TV outlets.

The indictment of two Republican fund raisers on bribery charges yesterday by a state grand jury came nearly three years after complaints were first made to law-enforcement officials, according to sources close to the case.
The concluding stages of the new Grand National Championship, as far as New York is concerned, will be played this weekend at the New York Hilton.
The freshness of the dozens of eggs that will be cooked and colored this Easter week can now be determined by a new gadget from Switzerland.

In his most slashing attack in the mayoral campaign so far, Controller Abraham D. Beame questioned Representative Mario Biaggi's "fitness to be Mayor" yesterday as Mr. Biaggi remained out of public view.

The Union Carbide Corporation will receive a patent next week for a solid-waste disposal process that it regards as an environmental breakthrough.

George Mackay of Pascack Hills High School, the state's premier middle-distance runner, recently ran a 1:52 half-mile shortly after signing a letter of intent with Rice University that completed negotiations for a four-year athletic grant-in-aid scholarship.

Among the victims of inflation may be the teen-age baby-sitter who has been nudged out of the market in some areas by economy-minded baby-sitting cooperatives. These have been started by parents anxious to save money.

Talks between the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers have been extended past tonight's midnight contract deadline to next Tuesday. The old contract will be extended while talks continue, both sides said today.

Pathet Lao rebels have blown up a bridge and cut the road from Vientiane to the southern town of Paksane on the Mekong River, a military spokesman said today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted raids against alleged underworld figures in Buffalo, Rochester and Scranton, Pa., late Friday night, resulting in charges against 18 men for interference with interstate commerce, obstruction of justice, gambling and transporting stolen property.
By applying "good basic management concepts" to the judicial process, the city's Criminal Courts are saving more than $6.7-million a year, according to a study made public yesterday.
Harvard and Radcliffe Colleges mailed acceptance today to 2,098 of 10,742 applicants to next fall's freshman class.

Daniel Ellsberg, on the 71st day of his trial, last Monday got to tell the jury why he had disclosed the Pentagon papers. The reason, he said, was "to give Congress the confidence to act" to end the Vietnam war.
Two bombs exploded here early today. One slightly damaged Parliament House, and the other planted in an electricity transformer, black out part of the Australian capital.

Two Soviet warships sailed the length of the Mediterranean last week carrying a large contingent of Moroccan motorized and armored troops to be deployed against Israel on the Syrian front, the newspaper Le Monde reported today.

Among the photographs accompanying Marion K. Sanders's biography of Dorothy Thompson is a picture of a commanding yet curiously unsure lady in black velvet who is waiting for the signal to begin a radio broadcast; next to her is an oleaginous character wielding a baton.
Architect Richard Moger completed this two-bedroom vacation house in Southampton, L. I., just a year ago. It cost $35,000. And he paid another $4,000 for grading, site work and utility hookups.

PRO: By Christine E. Samurovich, housing consultant to the West Side Tenants Union, and a leader in a successful effort to defeat a cooperative conversion in her West End Avenue building. Under present law, a rental building may be converted into a cooperative when only 35 per cent of the tenants agree to purchase their apartments.

Mr. and Mrs. Lonnie Fox Kent of Houston and Baytown announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Armmia Kent, to Henry Lewis Meltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Meltzer of Great Neck, L. I., and Santiago, Chile, at an engagement party yesterday at the Goose Creek Country Club.

Clyde Lee is not a flashy player. His name is the one people usually skip over in the Golden State Warrior box scores. He doesn't score a lot of points. The things he does are often noticed only by knowledgeable basketball people. For seven National Basketball Association seasons, he has earned his keep grabbing rebounds, playing defense, boxing out and setting picks.

MANY experienced gardeners consider corn to be the most worthwhile vegetable to grow in the home garden. The yield is not often great, but no other homegrown vegetable tastes so much better than its supermarket counterpart.
Nine Chinese students plan to leave Peking next week to study English at Carleton University in Ottawa. They will be the first students sent to Canada by China under a new exchange program.
Some 28 Massachusetts communities, contending that they are not prepared to open kindergartens by next September, have asked the state Department of Education to extend that deadline.

HE hill of Swayambhunath rises about 300 feet near the western rim of the valley of Katmandu in Nepal. It overlooks the city of Katmandu with its tiered pagodas, decaying palaces and colorful medieval bazaars. The hill's base is encircled by rice fields, salad-green, salted with egrets. From the top of the hill can be seen two giant Himalayan snowpeaks; Everest is a hundred miles uprange on the border with Tibet.

The world auto racing champion, Emerson Fittlpaldi of Brazil, takes a break from the Grand Prix scene here Monday in a "second division" Formula Two race that has attracted drivers from a dozen nations.

The difference between a Boston Red Sox pennant and Dick O'Connell's scalp may be 40 pounds of Bob Veale. The 37-year-old Veale, former ace of the Pittsburgh Pirates' pitching staff, is on the comeback trail as a reliever for the Red Sox and he credits his new lease on life, shedding some 40 pounds of excess weight that had eventually sent him packing to the minor leagues in Charleston, W. Va.
